filed all reports required to be filed by Section&nbsp;13 or

preceding 12&nbsp;months (or for such shorter period that the
registrant was required to file such reports), and (2)&nbsp;has

90&nbsp;days.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Yes&nbsp;<FONT face="wingdings">&#254;</FONT>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No&nbsp;<FONT face="wingdings">&#111;

pursuant to Item&nbsp;405 of

not contained herein, and will not be contained, to the best of
registrant&#146;s knowledge, in definitive proxy or information
statements incorporated by reference in Part&nbsp;III of this
Form&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">10-K</FONT> or any
amendment to this
Form&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">10-K.&nbsp;</FONT>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="wingdings">&#111;
</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Indicate by check mark whether the registrant is a large
accelerated filer, an accelerated filer or a non-accelerated
filer. See definition of &#147;accelerated filer and large
accelerated filer&#148; in
Rule&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">12b-2</FONT> of the
Exchange Act.
</DIV>

    <DIV style="margin-left: 10px; text-indent: -10px">

    Transactions</A></DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
This combined Annual Report on
Form&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">10-K</FONT> is filed
by US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc. (&#147;US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#148;) and its direct and indirect wholly owned
subsidiaries US&nbsp;Airways, Inc. (&#147;US&nbsp;Airways&#148;)
and America West Airlines, Inc. (&#147;AWA&#148;). AWA is a
wholly owned subsidiary of America West Holdings Corporation
(&#147;America West Holdings&#148;), which is a wholly owned
subsidiary of US&nbsp;Airways Group. References in this
Form&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">10-K</FONT> to
&#147;we,&#148; &#147;us,&#148; &#147;our&#148; and the
&#147;Company&#148; refer to US&nbsp;Airways Group and its
consolidated subsidiaries.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Note Concerning Forward-Looking Statements</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain of the statements contained in this report should be
considered &#147;forward-looking statements&#148; within the
meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
These forward-looking statements may be identified by words such
as &#147;may,&#148; &#147;will,&#148; &#147;expect,&#148;
&#147;intend,&#148; &#147;anticipate,&#148; &#147;believe,&#148;
&#147;estimate,&#148; &#147;plan,&#148; &#147;project,&#148;
&#147;could,&#148; &#147;should,&#148; and &#147;continue&#148;
and similar terms used in connection with statements regarding
the Company&#146;s outlook, expected fuel costs, the revenue
environment, and the Company&#146;s expected financial
performance. These statements include, but are not limited to,
statements about the benefits of the business combination
transaction involving America West Holdings and US&nbsp;Airways
Group, including future financial and operating results, the
Company&#146;s plans, objectives, expectations and intentions
and other statements that are not historical facts. These
statements are based upon the current beliefs and expectations
of management and are subject to significant risks and
uncertainties that could cause the Company&#146;s actual results
and financial position to differ materially from these
statements. These risks and uncertainties include, but are not
limited to, those described below under Item&nbsp;1A. &#147;Risk
Factors&#148; and the following:

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<A name='101'></A>
</DIV>

<!-- link1 "PART I" -->

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>PART&nbsp;I</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<A name='102'></A>
</DIV>

<!-- link1 "Item 1. Business" -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>Item&nbsp;1.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Business</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Overview</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group, a Delaware corporation, is a holding
company formed in 1982 and whose origins trace back to the
formation of All American Aviation in 1939. US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s principal executive offices are located at
111&nbsp;West Rio Salado Parkway, Tempe, Arizona 85281.
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s telephone number is
(480)&nbsp;693-0800, and its internet address is
<I>www.usairways.com.</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;12, 2004, US&nbsp;Airways Group and its
domestic subsidiaries US&nbsp;Airways, Piedmont Airlines, Inc.
(&#147;Piedmont&#148;), PSA Airlines, Inc. (&#147;PSA&#148;) and
Material Services Company, Inc., which at the time accounted for
substantially all of the operations of US&nbsp;Airways Group,
filed voluntary petitions for relief under Chapter&nbsp;11 of
the United States Bankruptcy Code (the &#147;Bankruptcy
Code&#148;) in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the
Eastern District of Virginia, Alexandria Division (the
&#147;Bankruptcy Court&#148;). On May&nbsp;19, 2005,
US&nbsp;Airways Group signed a merger agreement with America
West Holdings, pursuant to which America West Holdings agreed to
merge with a wholly owned subsidiary of US&nbsp;Airways Group.
Following the merger, America West Holdings continued as a
wholly owned subsidiary of US&nbsp;Airways Group.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The plan of reorganization of US&nbsp;Airways Group and its
domestic subsidiaries was confirmed by the Bankruptcy Court on
September&nbsp;16, 2005, and the plan of reorganization and the
merger became effective on September&nbsp;27, 2005. Critical to
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s emergence from bankruptcy and the
merger with America West Holdings was additional financing and
liquidity to fund operations. The financing and liquidity was
provided through a combination of new equity investments, new
and restructured debt instruments and agreements with
significant stakeholders. See &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion
and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
Operations&#148; for a full description of the equity and debt
instruments.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s primary business activity prior to
the merger was the operation of a major network air carrier
through its ownership of the common stock of US&nbsp;Airways,
Piedmont, PSA, Material Services Company and Airways Assurance
Limited. US&nbsp;Airways, along with a network of
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s regional airline subsidiaries,
affiliated carriers and its MidAtlantic division flying as
US&nbsp;Airways Express, was a hub-and-spoke carrier with a
substantial presence in the eastern United States and with
service to Canada, the Caribbean, Latin America and Europe.
US&nbsp;Airways had approximately 42&nbsp;million passengers
boarding its planes in 2005 and, prior to the merger, was the
seventh largest U.S.&nbsp;air carrier based on available seat
miles (&#147;ASMs&#148;) and revenue passenger miles
(&#147;RPMs&#148;). As of December&nbsp;31, 2005,
US&nbsp;Airways operated 232 jet aircraft and 18 regional jet
aircraft. During 2005, US&nbsp;Airways provided regularly
scheduled service or seasonal service at 91 airports in the
continental United States, Canada, the Caribbean, Latin America
and Europe. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, the US&nbsp;Airways
Express network served 130 airports in the United States, Canada
and the Bahamas, including approximately 39 airports also served
by US&nbsp;Airways. During 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Express air
carriers had approximately 18.7&nbsp;million passengers boarding
their planes, including 1.9&nbsp;million passengers on
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; MidAtlantic division. For the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, passenger revenues
accounted for approximately 90%, 90% and 91%, respectively, of
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; operating revenues. Cargo revenues and
other sources accounted for 10%, 10% and 9% of
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; operating revenues in 2005, 2004 and 2003,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
America West Holdings, a Delaware corporation formed in 1996, is
a holding company that owns all of the stock of AWA, a Delaware
corporation formed in 1981. AWA accounted for most of America
West Holdings&#146; revenues and expenses prior to the merger in
September 2005. Prior to the merger and based on 2005 ASMs and
RPMs, AWA was the eighth largest passenger airline and the
second largest low-cost carrier in the United States. AWA was
the largest low-cost carrier operating a hub-and-spoke network
before the merger, with hubs in Phoenix, Arizona and Las Vegas,
Nevada. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, AWA operated a fleet of
141 aircraft and served 64 destinations in North America,
including eight in Mexico, two in Hawaii, four in Canada and one
in Costa Rica. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, AWA
had approximately 22&nbsp;million passengers boarding its planes
and generated mainline revenues of
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">1

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
approximately $2.5&nbsp;billion. Passenger revenues accounted
for approximately 93% of AWA&#146;s operating revenues in each
of the three years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003.
Cargo revenues and other sources accounted for 7% of AWA&#146;s
operating revenues in 2005, 2004 and 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Following the merger, US&nbsp;Airways Group began moving toward
operating under the single brand name of
&#147;US&nbsp;Airways&#148; through its two principal
subsidiaries: US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. US&nbsp;Airways Group
expects to integrate the two principal subsidiaries into one
operation over the first 24&nbsp;months following the merger. As
a result of the merger, US&nbsp;Airways Group, through its two
principal operating subsidiaries, operates the fifth largest
airline in the United States as measured by domestic RPMs and
ASMs. For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003,
passenger revenues accounted for approximately 92%, 93% and 93%,
respectively, of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s operating
revenues. Cargo revenues and other sources accounted for 8%, 7%
and 7% of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s operating revenues in
2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively. The Company has primary hubs
in Charlotte, Philadelphia and Phoenix and secondary hubs/focus
cities in Pittsburgh, Las Vegas, New York, Washington,&nbsp;D.C.
and Boston. The Company is a low-cost carrier offering scheduled
passenger service on approximately 3,700 flights daily to
233&nbsp;cities in the U.S., Canada, the Caribbean, Latin
America and Europe, making it the only low-cost carrier with a
significant international route presence. The Company is also
the only low-cost carrier with an established East Coast route
network, including the US&nbsp;Airways Shuttle service, with
substantial presence at capacity constrained airports including
New York&#146;s LaGuardia Airport (&#147;LaGuardia&#148;) and
the Washington,&nbsp;D.C. area&#146;s Ronald Reagan Washington
National Airport (&#147;Reagan National&#148;). Starting in
December 2005, we expanded our route network to include Hawaii.
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s two
principal subsidiaries operate 373 mainline jets and are
supported by its regional airline subsidiaries and affiliates
operating as US&nbsp;Airways Express, which operate
approximately 255 regional jets, of which 80 have 70 or more
seats, and approximately 107 turboprops.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s results are seasonal. Operating results are
typically highest in the second and third quarters due to
greater demand for air and leisure travel during the summer
months and US&nbsp;Airways&#146; and AWA&#146;s combination of
business traffic and North-South leisure traffic in the eastern
and western United States during those periods.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Material Services Company and Airways Assurance Limited operate
in support of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s airline subsidiaries
in areas such as the procurement of aviation fuel and insurance.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
You may read and copy any materials US&nbsp;Airways Group, AWA
or US&nbsp;Airways files with the Securities and Exchange
Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;) at the SEC&#146;s Public Reference
Room at 100 F Street, NE, Washington, DC 20549. You may obtain
information on the operation of the Public Reference Room by
calling the SEC at
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">1-800-SEC-0330.</FONT> A copy
of this Annual Report on
Form&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">10-K,</FONT> as well
as other Annual Reports on
Form&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">10-K,</FONT>
Quarterly Reports on
Form&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">10-Q,</FONT> Current
Reports on
Form&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">8-K</FONT> and
amendments to those reports are accessible free of charge at
<I>www.usairways.com </I>and at the SEC&#146;s website at
<I>www.sec.gov </I>as soon as reasonably possible after the
report is filed with or furnished to the SEC.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Airline Industry</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In 2005, passenger travel finally regained the levels seen
before the terrorist attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001. Despite
strong passenger demand, and significant efforts by carriers to
contain costs, the industry remained largely mired with excess
capacity, high fuel prices, fierce competition, and high costs.
No carriers were immune to these pressures with the traditional
low cost carriers posting virtually no operating profits and in
many cases, outright losses. Two traditional legacy
carriers&nbsp;&#151; Delta Air Lines and Northwest
Airlines&nbsp;&#151; were forced into bankruptcy despite having
earlier achieved significant cost reductions from their
employees. Strong competition and the large spike in fuel costs
in light of the damage caused by the Gulf Coast hurricanes have
particularly impacted smaller carriers, and led to Independence
Air&#146;s complete shut down in January 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
A number of structural changes in the industry are taking shape.
While all carriers are focusing on lowering costs and increasing
revenues, traditional legacy carriers and some newer carriers
are reducing domestic capacity and redeploying aircraft in
international markets. A significant number of new
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">2

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
international services has been started and/or announced by
U.S.&nbsp;carriers. New international capacity is being added in
transoceanic markets, as well as to points in Latin America and
the Caribbean.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Regional jets continue to play a large and growing role within
the U.S.&nbsp;airline industry. The more recent trend, however,
is toward larger 70- and 90-plus seat regional jets rather than
the 50-seat and smaller jets that had dominated the marketplace
in prior years. As carriers use the bankruptcy laws to
restructure and reduce their mainline fleets, replacement
aircraft frequently are larger regional aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Fares remained at or near historically low levels, although the
rising cost of fuel did lead to increased fares toward the
latter part of 2005. Whether demand can remain at historically
high levels in the face of rising fares is unclear, but as
domestic capacity continues to rationalize through fleet
reductions and the redeployment of aircraft to international
markets, the likelihood of further fare restructurings such as
Delta Air Lines&#146; Simplifare program, a pricing scheme
introduced in January 2005 that generally lowered fares
significantly and reduced restrictions on discount fares, seems
to be diminishing.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Finally, the differences between low-cost carriers and
traditional legacy carriers is blurring. Traditional carriers
are restructuring with lower cost structures, greater labor
flexibility, and new and innovative products and thinking much
like low-cost carriers, while still maintaining vast route
networks, alliances, and generous frequent flyer benefits.
Low-cost carriers are adding amenities to their offerings,
including
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">state-of</FONT>-the-art
inflight entertainment, co-branded credit cards, international
service and more generous frequent flyer programs that were
traditionally the exclusive province of the legacy carriers.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Airline Operations</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Prior to the merger, AWA operated its route system through a
hub-and-spoke network centered in its Phoenix and Las Vegas
hubs. US&nbsp;Airways&#146; major connecting hubs prior to the
merger were at airports in Charlotte and Philadelphia.
US&nbsp;Airways also had substantial operations at Logan
International Airport (&#147;Logan Airport&#148;), LaGuardia,
Pittsburgh International Airport, and Reagan National. Following
the merger, the combined company has primary hubs in Charlotte,
Philadelphia and Phoenix and secondary hubs/focus cities in
Pittsburgh, Las Vegas, New York, Washington,&nbsp;D.C. and
Boston. In 2005, both AWA and US&nbsp;Airways made significant
strides in right-sizing their respective fleets for the overall
benefit of the combined airline. Despite the return of 55
aircraft in 2005, both carriers were able to increase service in
certain markets. In 2005, AWA launched Phoenix-Honolulu and
Phoenix-Maui service with extended over-water equipped Boeing
757 Aircraft. Additional Hawaii service is planned from Phoenix
and Las Vegas in 2006. AWA also started new service from Phoenix
to Oklahoma City. The largest service expansion by AWA was from
Las Vegas, where service to seven new markets was started in
2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways added new seasonal transatlantic service to
Barcelona and Venice in May 2005, and revamped its Philadelphia
hub operations to improve connectivity. US&nbsp;Airways also
added 15 70-seat regional jets to its operation. After the
merger, the combined airline began redeploying certain regional
jet capacity from the western United States to Charlotte to take
advantage of market opportunities. For 2006, further fleet
efficiencies are being realized and implemented. In February
2006, US&nbsp;Airways announced new service from Philadelphia to
Stockholm, Sweden, Milan, Italy and Lisbon, Portugal. These
services were made possible by the acquisition of additional
Boeing 757 aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Express Operations</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>US&nbsp;Airways Express Network</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain air carriers have code share arrangements with
US&nbsp;Airways to operate under the trade name
&#147;US&nbsp;Airways Express.&#148; Typically, under a code
share arrangement, one air carrier places its designator code
and sells tickets on the flights of another air carrier, which
is referred to generically as its code share partner.
US&nbsp;Airways Express carriers are an integral component of
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s operating network. US&nbsp;Airways
relies heavily on feeder traffic from its US&nbsp;Airways
Express partners, who carry passengers from low-density markets
that are uneconomical for US&nbsp;Airways to serve with large
jets to US&nbsp;Airways&#146; hubs. As of December 2005, the
US&nbsp;Airways Express network served 130 airports in the
continental
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">3

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
United States, Canada and the Bahamas, including 39 airports
also served by US&nbsp;Airways. During 2005, US&nbsp;Airways
Express air carriers enplaned approximately 18.7&nbsp;million
passengers, approximately 53% of whom connected to
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s flights. Of these 18.7&nbsp;million
passengers, approximately 7.6&nbsp;million were enplaned by
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned regional airlines,
approximately 1.9&nbsp;million were enplaned by
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; MidAtlantic division, approximately
8.0&nbsp;million were enplaned by third-party carriers operating
under capacity purchase agreements and approximately
1.2&nbsp;million were enplaned by carriers operating under
prorate agreements, as described below. In addition,
US&nbsp;Airways Express operators offer complementary service in
existing US&nbsp;Airways markets by operating flights during
off-peak periods between US&nbsp;Airways flights.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The US&nbsp;Airways Express code share arrangements are either
in the form of capacity purchase or prorate agreements. The
capacity purchase agreements provide that all revenues,
including passenger, mail and freight revenues, go to
US&nbsp;Airways. In return, US&nbsp;Airways agrees to pay
predetermined fees to these airlines for operating an agreed
upon number of aircraft, without regard to the number of
passengers on board. In addition, these agreements provide that
certain variable costs, such as fuel and airport landing fees,
will be reimbursed 100% by US&nbsp;Airways. US&nbsp;Airways
controls marketing, scheduling, ticketing, pricing and seat
inventories. Under the prorate agreements, the prorate carriers
pay certain service fees to US&nbsp;Airways and receive a
prorated share of ticket revenue paid for connecting customers.
US&nbsp;Airways is responsible for pricing and marketing of
connecting services to and from the prorate carrier. The prorate
carrier is responsible for pricing and marketing the local,
point to point markets, and is responsible for all costs
incurred operating the aircraft. All US&nbsp;Airways Express
carriers use US&nbsp;Airways&#146; reservation systems, and have
logos, service marks, aircraft paint schemes and uniforms
similar to those of US&nbsp;Airways.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The following table sets forth US&nbsp;Airways Express code
share agreements and the number and type of aircraft operated
under those agreements at December&nbsp;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

    turboprops under a prorate agreement and 13 regional jets under
    a capacity purchase agreement. In September 2005, Trans States
    began operating under a prorate agreement and operated eight
    regional jets as US&nbsp;Airways Express as of December&nbsp;31,
    2005.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In April 2004, MidAtlantic, US&nbsp;Airways&#146; regional jet
division, began operating as part of the US&nbsp;Airways Express
network. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, MidAtlantic operated 18
Embraer ERJ-170 regional jets with 72&nbsp;seats. MidAtlantic
served approximately 1.9&nbsp;million passengers in 2005. On
June&nbsp;23, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways exercised its option under
its agreement with Republic and Wexford Capital LLC to sell
certain assets used by MidAtlantic, including the regional jets,
a flight simulator and certain commuter slots at Reagan National
and LaGuardia. Under the terms of the agreement, Republic
purchased ten regional jets owned by US&nbsp;Airways and leased
the ten purchased aircraft back to US&nbsp;Airways subject to
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">4
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
their future transfer to Republic. Republic also assumed the
leases of 15 additional regional jets. Republic entered into a
regional jet service agreement that continues the operation of
the aircraft as a US&nbsp;Airways Express carrier under a
ten-year capacity purchase agreement. In addition to the
aircraft, Republic purchased commuter slots at Reagan National
and LaGuardia and leases the slots back to US&nbsp;Airways.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>America West Express</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA has a regional airline code share agreement with Mesa. Mesa,
operating regional jets and large turboprop aircraft as America
West Express, provides regional feeder service to and from
Phoenix and Las Vegas to destinations in the western United
States, Canada and northern Mexico. AWA collects the revenue and
income generated from the services provided by Mesa and, in
return, (1)&nbsp;reimburses Mesa for actual non-controllable
costs and costs and expenses incurred at stations maintained and
operated by Mesa, (2)&nbsp;pays Mesa for actual controllable
non-maintenance costs, subject to a cap, and controllable
maintenance costs at fixed rates, and (3)&nbsp;shares with Mesa
a percentage of the revenue allocated to the flight segments
flown by Mesa. Through this arrangement with Mesa, AWA offered
America West Express service to an additional 30 destinations as
of December&nbsp;31, 2005. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, the
America West Express fleet included 62 aircraft comprised of 38
86-seat CRJ 900s, 18 50-seat CRJ 200s and six 37-seat Dash 8
turboprop aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Marketing and Alliance Agreements with Other Airlines</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA and US&nbsp;Airways maintain alliance agreements with each
other and with several leading domestic and international
carriers to give customers a greater choice of destinations.
Airline alliance agreements provide an array of benefits that
vary by partner. By code sharing, each airline is able to offer
additional destinations to its customers under its flight
designator code without materially increasing operating expenses
and capital expenditures. Frequent flyer arrangements provide
members with extended networks for earning and redeeming miles
on partner carriers. The Company&#146;s club members also have
access to certain partner carriers&#146; airport lounges.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>AWA</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA has a variety of code share agreements with different
carriers. Among international carriers, AWA has code share
relations with ALIA/ Royal Jordanian, British Airways, EVA
Airways and Virgin Atlantic Airways. The code shares primarily
funnel international traffic onto AWA&#146;s domestic flights.
The agreement with British Airways terminated last year, and a
complete end of AWA&#146;s relationship with British Airways is
scheduled for 2006. AWA also has a code share agreement to feed
Northwest Airlines flights to Asia with Phoenix and Las Vegas
passengers. This relationship also is scheduled to end in 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Domestically, AWA code shares with Hawaiian Airlines on
intra-Hawaii flights and with Big Sky Airlines to smaller
markets in Idaho, Montana, and Washington.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA and US&nbsp;Airways entered into a broad systemwide code
share agreement that started soon after the merger. This
agreement permits passengers to travel throughout the combined
route networks of both carriers. The code share is fully
implemented except in a few international markets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>US&nbsp;Airways</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways has entered into a number of bilateral and
multilateral alliances with other airlines. In May 2004,
US&nbsp;Airways joined the Star Alliance, the world&#146;s
largest airline alliance, with 16 member airlines serving
approximately 790 destinations in 138 countries. Membership in
the Star Alliance further enhances the value of
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; domestic and international route network
by allowing customers wide access to the global marketplace.
Expanded benefits for customers include network expansion
through code share service, Dividend Miles benefits, airport
lounge access, convenient single-ticket pricing, one-stop
check-in and coordinated baggage handling. US&nbsp;Airways also
has bilateral marketing/code sharing agreements with Lufthansa,
Spanair, bmi and other Star Alliance carriers, as well as
several smaller regional carriers in the Caribbean that operate
collectively as the &#147;GoCaribbean&#148; network.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">5

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In addition, US&nbsp;Airways has comprehensive marketing
agreements with United Airlines, a member of the Star Alliance,
which began in July 2002. United, as well as its parent company,
UAL Corporation, and certain of its affiliates, filed for
protection under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the Bankruptcy Code on
December&nbsp;9, 2002 and emerged on February&nbsp;1, 2006.
United assumed these marketing agreements in its bankruptcy
proceedings. On March&nbsp;3, 2006, US&nbsp;Airways filed a
motion with the Bankruptcy Court to assume its agreements with
United; however, the Company is continuing to negotiate with
United concerning revisions to the existing agreements. In the
event the Company is unable to reach agreement with United, the
Company&#146;s codeshare relationship with United and membership
in Star Alliance could be terminated.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Competition in the Airline Industry</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Most of the markets in which the Company operates are highly
competitive. Price competition occurs on a market-by-market
basis through price discounts, changes in pricing structures,
fare matching, target promotions and frequent flyer initiatives.
Airlines typically use discount fares and other promotions to
stimulate traffic during normally slack travel periods to
generate cash flow and to maximize revenue per ASM. Discount and
promotional fares are often non-refundable and may be subject to
various restrictions such as minimum stay requirements, advance
ticketing, limited seating and change fees. The Company has
often elected to match discount or promotional fares initiated
by other air carriers in certain markets in order to compete in
those markets. Most airlines will quickly match price reductions
in a particular market. The Company&#146;s ability to compete on
the basis of price is limited by its fixed costs and depends on
its ability to maintain its operating costs.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company also competes on the basis of scheduling (frequency
and flight times), availability of nonstop flights, on-time
performance, type of equipment, cabin configuration, amenities
provided to passengers, frequent flyer programs, the automation
of travel agent reservation systems, on-board products, markets
served and other services. The Company competes with both major
full service airlines and low-cost airlines throughout its
network of hubs and focus cities.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company believes the growth of low-fare low-cost competition
will continue. Recent years have seen the entrance and growth of
low-fare low-cost competitors in many of the markets in which
the Company operates. These competitors include Southwest
Airlines Co., which has steadily increased East Coast
operations, AirTran Airways, Inc. and JetBlue Airways. Some of
these low cost carriers have lower operating cost structures
than the Company.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In addition, with its significant activity in the eastern United
States, US&nbsp;Airways&#146; average trip distance, or stage
length, is shorter than those of other major airlines. This
makes US&nbsp;Airways more susceptible than other major airlines
to competition from surface transportation such as automobiles
and trains.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Industry Regulation and Airport Access</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s airline subsidiaries operate under
certificates of public convenience and necessity or certificates
of commuter authority, both of which are issued by the
Department of Transportation (the &#147;DOT&#148;). These
certificates may be altered, amended, modified or suspended by
the DOT if the public convenience and necessity so require, or
may be revoked for failure to comply with the terms and
conditions of the certificates. US&nbsp;Airways and AWA
currently operate under separate certificates, and are in the
process of obtaining DOT approval to combine the certificates.
Approval is expected within two years of the effective date of
the merger.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Airlines are also regulated by the U.S.&nbsp;Federal Aviation
Administration (the &#147;FAA&#148;), primarily in the areas of
flight operations, maintenance, ground facilities and other
operational and safety areas. Pursuant to these regulations, the
Company&#146;s airline subsidiaries have FAA-approved
maintenance programs for each type of aircraft they operate. The
programs provide for the ongoing maintenance of such aircraft,
ranging from periodic routine inspections to major overhauls.
From time to time, the FAA issues airworthiness directives and
other regulations affecting the Company&#146;s airline
subsidiaries or one or more of the aircraft types they operate.
In recent years, for example, the FAA has issued or proposed
mandates
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">6

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
relating to, among other things, enhanced ground proximity
warning systems, fuselage pressure bulkhead reinforcement,
fuselage lap joint inspection rework, increased inspections and
maintenance procedures to be conducted on certain aircraft,
increased cockpit security, fuel tank flammability reductions
and domestic reduced vertical separation. Regulations of this
sort tend to enhance safety and increase operating costs.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The DOT allows local airport authorities to implement procedures
designed to abate special noise problems, provided such
procedures do not unreasonably interfere with interstate or
foreign commerce or the national transportation system. Certain
locales, including Boston, Washington,&nbsp;D.C., Chicago,
San&nbsp;Diego and San&nbsp;Francisco, among others, have
established airport restrictions to limit noise, including
restrictions on aircraft types to be used and limits on the
number of hourly or daily operations or the time of these
operations. In some instances these restrictions have caused
curtailments in services or increases in operating costs, and
these restrictions could limit the ability of the Company&#146;s
airline subsidiaries to expand their operations at the affected
airports. Authorities at other airports may consider adopting
similar noise regulations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The airline industry is also subject to increasingly stringent
federal, state and local laws aimed at protecting the
environment. Future regulatory developments and actions could
affect operations and increase operating costs for the airline
industry, including the Company&#146;s airline subsidiaries.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s airline subsidiaries are obligated to collect
a federal excise tax, commonly referred to as the &#147;ticket
tax,&#148; on domestic and international air transportation. The
Company&#146;s airline subsidiaries collect the ticket tax,
along with certain other U.S. and foreign taxes and user fees on
air transportation, and pass along the collected amounts to the
appropriate governmental agencies. Although these taxes are not
operating expenses of the Company, they represent an additional
cost to our customers.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Aviation and Transportation Security Act (the &#147;Aviation
Security Act&#148;) was enacted in November 2001. Under the
Aviation Security Act, substantially all aspects of civil
aviation security screening were federalized, and a new
Transportation Security Administration (the &#147;TSA&#148;)
under the DOT was created. TSA was then transferred to the
Department of Homeland Security pursuant to the Homeland
Security Act of 2002. The Aviation Security Act, among other
matters, mandates improved flight deck security; carriage at no
charge of federal air marshals; enhanced security screening of
passengers, baggage, cargo, mail, employees and vendors;
enhanced security training; fingerprint-based background checks
of all employees and vendor employees with access to secure
areas of airports pursuant to regulations issued in connection
with the Aviation Security Act; and the provision of passenger
data to U.S.&nbsp;Customs and Border Protection.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Funding for TSA is provided by a combination of air-carrier
fees, passenger fees, and taxpayer monies. The air-carrier fee,
or Aviation Security Infrastructure Fee (&#147;ASIF&#148;) has
an annual cap equivalent to the amount that an individual air
carrier paid in calendar year 2000 for the screening of
passengers and property. TSA may lift this cap at any time and
set a new higher fee for air carriers. In addition, TSA has
recently assessed additional ASIF liability on 43 air carriers,
including AWA, US&nbsp;Airways, Piedmont, PSA and non-owned
affiliates for whom AWA and US&nbsp;Airways pay ASIF. The
passenger fee, which is collected by air carriers from their
passengers, is currently set at $2.50&nbsp;per flight segment
but not more than $10.00&nbsp;per round trip. A proposal is
currently before Congress to increase the fee to $5.00&nbsp;per
flight segment but not more than $10.00&nbsp;per round trip.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In 2005, the Company incurred expenses of $16&nbsp;million for
the ASIF, including amounts related to regional carriers.
US&nbsp;Airways incurred expenses of $28&nbsp;million including
amounts paid by US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned
regional subsidiaries. Of this amount $21&nbsp;million was for
the period prior to the merger. AWA incurred expenses of
$9&nbsp;million including amounts related to regional carriers.
TSA has also issued bills for an additional $9&nbsp;million per
year for US&nbsp;Airways, $4&nbsp;million per year for AWA and
$2&nbsp;million for US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s other wholly
owned subsidiaries retroactive to January&nbsp;1, 2005. The
Company&#146;s expenses will further increase for amounts
assessed to non-owned regional affiliates who can pass through
their increased ASIF to US&nbsp;Airways. Implementation of the
requirements of the Aviation Security Act have resulted and will
continue to result in increased costs for the Company and its
passengers and has and will likely continue to result in service
disruptions and delays. As a result of
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">7

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
competitive pressure, AWA, US&nbsp;Airways and other airlines
may be unable to recover all of these additional security costs
from passengers through increased fares. In addition, we cannot
forecast what new security and safety requirements may be
imposed in the future or the costs or financial impact of
complying with any such requirements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Most major U.S.&nbsp;airports impose passenger facility charges.
The ability of airlines to contest increases in these charges is
restricted by federal legislation, DOT regulations and judicial
decisions. With certain exceptions, air carriers pass these
charges on to passengers. However, our ability to pass-through
security fees and passenger facility charges to our customers is
subject to various factors, including market conditions and
competitive factors.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
At John F. Kennedy International Airport (&#147;Kennedy&#148;),
LaGuardia and Reagan National, which are designated &#147;High
Density Airports&#148; by the FAA, there are restrictions that
limit the number of departure and arrival slots available to air
carriers during peak hours. In April 2000, legislation was
enacted that will eliminate slot restrictions in 2007 at
LaGuardia and Kennedy. Among other things, the legislation
encouraged the development of air service to smaller communities
from slot-controlled airports. During the interim period while
slot restrictions remained in effect at LaGuardia, airlines
could apply for slot exemptions to serve smaller communities
using aircraft with a maximum seating capacity of less than 71.
As a result of this legislation, airlines increased service from
LaGuardia, and this led to excessive flight delays. In response
to these delays, the FAA implemented a slot lottery system in
December 2000 limiting the number of new flights at LaGuardia.
As a result, several airlines were required to reduce the number
of flights added at LaGuardia. The resulting allocation of slots
from the slot lottery system was initially scheduled to expire
on September&nbsp;15, 2001, but was subsequently extended
through 2006. As a result of the 2007 slot elimination, the FAA
has indicated an intent to rethink its approach to regulating
operations at LaGuardia. Several proposals, including auctions,
congestion pricing and other market-based solutions, are being
considered along with more traditional regulatory approaches.
The Company expects a rule-making on this issue in spring 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the future, takeoff and landing time restrictions and other
restrictions on the use of various airports and their facilities
may result in further curtailment of services by, and increased
operating costs for, individual airlines, including the
Company&#146;s airline subsidiaries, particularly in light of
the increase in the number of airlines operating at these
airports. In general, FAA rules relating to allocated slots at
High Density Airports contain provisions requiring the
relinquishment of slots for non-use and permit carriers, under
certain circumstances, to sell, lease or trade their slots to
other carriers. All slots must be used on at least 80% of the
dates during each two-month reporting period. Failure to satisfy
the use rate will result in loss of the slot and reversion of
the slot to the FAA for reassignment through a lottery
arrangement. US&nbsp;Airways and AWA exceed the minimum use rate.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
There is a federal prohibition on flights exceeding
1,250&nbsp;miles operating to or from Reagan National. This
prohibition, which is referred to as the &#147;perimeter
rule,&#148; historically prevented the Company from flying
nonstop between Reagan National and its principal hubs or
secondary hubs/focus cities of Phoenix and Las Vegas. In 2000,
Congress passed legislation that authorized the DOT to grant
exceptions to the
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">1,250-mile</FONT> perimeter
rule for up to 12 slots per day. Subsequent legislation in 2004
entitled the Vision 100&nbsp;&#151; Century of Aviation
Reauthorization Act (&#147;Vision 100&#148;), among other
things, authorized the DOT to grant 12 additional slots exempted
from the perimeter rule. AWA received exemptions permitting
three roundtrips between Reagan National and Phoenix and one
roundtrip between Reagan National and Las Vegas.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Where the FAA has seen congestion and delay increases, it has
generally stepped in and worked with the carriers to freeze
operations at current or somewhat reduced levels. Specifically,
incumbent carriers, including US&nbsp;Airways and AWA, are not
permitted to increase operations at Chicago O&#146;Hare
International Airport (&#147;Chicago O&#146;Hare&#148;) as a
result of an agreement reached between the FAA and these
airlines in August 2004. The industry is waiting for a final
decision on restrictions at Chicago O&#146;Hare, which is
expected in spring 2006.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">8

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The availability of international routes to domestic air
carriers is regulated by agreements between the U.S. and foreign
governments. Changes in U.S.&nbsp;or foreign government aviation
policy could result in the alteration or termination of these
agreements and affect the Company&#146;s international
operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The DOT has proposed far-reaching changes to the regulations
that define what constitutes a U.S.&nbsp;airline. The proposed
rule, expected to be finalized in spring 2006, significantly
increases the amount of foreign influence/control permitted in
the management of U.S.&nbsp;carriers than currently is allowed.
These changes could result in new competition and/or new
airlines starting service. Additionally, the United States and
the European Union have agreed on a significant liberalization
of transatlantic air service rights. If implemented,
US&nbsp;Airways could face new competition on many of its
transatlantic routes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Employees and Labor Relations</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s businesses are labor intensive. In 2005,
wages, salaries and benefits represented 20% for US&nbsp;Airways
Group, 21% of AWA&#146;s operating expenses and 19% of
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; operating expenses. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company employed approximately
36,600 active full time equivalent employees. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2005, AWA employed approximately 12,100 active
full time equivalent employees including approximately 1,900
pilots, 2,500 flight attendants, 2,600 passenger service
personnel, 1,800 fleet service personnel, 800 maintenance
personnel and 2,500 in administrative and various other job
categories. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways
employed approximately 20,100 active full time equivalent
employees including approximately 2,700 pilots, 4,600 flight
attendants, 3,800 passenger service personnel, 4,200 fleet
service personnel, 2,600 maintenance personnel and 2,200 in
administrative and various other job categories. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s remaining
subsidiaries employed approximately 4,400&nbsp;active full time
equivalent employees including approximately 900&nbsp;pilots,
500&nbsp;flight attendants, 1,500&nbsp;customer service
personnel, 400&nbsp;maintenance personnel and 1,100&nbsp;in
administrative and various other job categories.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
A large majority of the employees of the major airlines in the
United States are represented by labor unions. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2005, approximately 80% of the Company&#146;s
active employees were represented by various labor unions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The status of AWA&#146;s and US&nbsp;Airways&#146; labor
agreements with its major domestic employee groups is as follows:
</DIV>

<TR>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left: 10px; text-indent: -10px">
    International Brotherhood of Teamsters (&#147;IBT&#148;)</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>

    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(1)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Approximate number of active full time equivalent employees
    covered by the contract as of December&nbsp;31, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(2)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    In contract negotiations. On September&nbsp;21, 2005, AFA filed
    for mediation with the National Mediation Board
    (&#147;NMB&#148;). On December&nbsp;15, 2005, the NMB recessed
    the negotiations indefinitely.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(3)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    In contract negotiations.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(4)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    In contract negotiations. On January&nbsp;19, 2006, TWU filed
    for mediation with the NMB.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(5)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    On February&nbsp;17, 2006, TWU served notice that it is invoking
    a contract provision that allows it to re-open negotiations only
    on the issues of wage rates and hours of service as a result of
    changes to AWA&#146;s loan formerly guaranteed by the ATSB.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(6)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    On December&nbsp;5, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA reached an
    Interim Transition Agreement with the Association, an alliance
    created by the IBT, who formerly represented passenger service
    employees at AWA, and the Communication Workers of America
    (&#147;CWA&#148;), who formerly represented passenger service
    employees at US&nbsp;Airways. Pursuant to the Interim Transition
    Agreement, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA voluntarily recognized the
    Association as the collective bargaining representative of the
    AWA and US&nbsp;Airways passenger service employees. The parties
    agreed that AWA passenger service employees would transition to
    the US&nbsp;Airways-CWA collective bargaining agreement and thus
    AWA&#146;s separate contract negotiations with IBT were
    terminated.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Since the merger, the Company has been in the process of
integrating the labor unions of its two principal airline
subsidiaries. On September&nbsp;23, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways and
AWA reached a Transition Agreement with ALPA governing many
merger-related aspects of the parties&#146; relationship until
there is a single collective bargaining agreement covering all
pilots. US&nbsp;Airways and AWA currently are negotiating the
single collective bargaining agreement with ALPA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On December&nbsp;5, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA reached an
Interim Transition Agreement with the Association as described
above in note (5). US&nbsp;Airways and AWA currently are
negotiating rules to transition the AWA passenger service
employees to the US&nbsp;Airways-CWA collective bargaining
agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On January&nbsp;18, 2006, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA reached a
transition agreement with AFA governing many merger-related
aspects of the parties&#146; relationship until there is a
single collective bargaining agreement covering all flight
attendants. US&nbsp;Airways and AWA currently are negotiating
the single collective bargaining agreement with AFA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On January&nbsp;30, 2006, the NMB issued a finding that
US&nbsp;Airways and AWA are a single transportation system for
representation purposes for mechanics and related employees,
fleet service personnel and maintenance training specialists.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Although there are few remaining employee groups who could
engage in organization efforts, we cannot predict the outcome of
any future efforts to organize those remaining employees or the
terms of any future labor agreements or the effect, if any, on
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; or AWA&#146;s operations or financial
performance. For more discussion, see Item&nbsp;1A &#147;Risk
Factors&nbsp;&#151; Risk Factors Relating to the Company and
Industry Related Risks&nbsp;&#151; <I>Union disputes, employee
strikes and other labor-related disruptions may adversely affect
our operations.</I>&#148;
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">10
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Aviation Fuel</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Aviation fuel has historically been the Company&#146;s second
largest expense, but in 2005, aviation fuel was the largest
expense. The average cost of a gallon of aviation fuel increased
33% from 2004 to 2005. Because the operations of the airlines
are dependent upon aviation fuel, increases in aviation fuel
costs could materially and adversely affect liquidity, results
of operations and financial condition.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The following table shows aircraft fuel consumption and costs
for US&nbsp;Airways mainline 2003 through 2005 (gallons and
aircraft fuel expense in millions):
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>

</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(1)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Includes fuel taxes and the impact of fuel hedges.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In addition, US&nbsp;Airways incurs fuel expense related to its
US&nbsp;Airways Express operations. For the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004, and 2003, total fuel expense for
MidAtlantic, US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned
subsidiaries and affiliate carriers was $504&nbsp;million,
$285&nbsp;million, and $170&nbsp;million respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

for AWA mainline for 2003 through 2005 (gallons and aircraft
fuel expense in millions):

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(1)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Includes fuel taxes and the impact of fuel hedges.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In addition, AWA incurs fuel expense for its regional airline
alliance with Mesa. For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005,
2004 and 2003, total fuel expense for the Mesa alliance was
$182&nbsp;million, $102&nbsp;million and $61&nbsp;million,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Prices and availability of all petroleum products are subject to
political, economic and market factors that are generally
outside of the Company&#146;s control. Accordingly, the price
and availability of aviation fuel, as well as other petroleum
products can be unpredictable. Prices may be affected by many
factors, including:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    the impact of global political instability on crude production;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    unexpected changes to the availability of petroleum products due
    to disruptions in distribution systems or refineries, as
    evidenced in the third quarter of 2005 when Hurricane Katrina
    and Hurricane Rita caused widespread disruption to oil
    production, refinery operations and pipeline capacity along
    certain portions of the U.S.&nbsp;Gulf Coast. As a result of
    these disruptions, the price of jet fuel increased significantly
    and the availability of jet fuel supplies was diminished;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    unpredicted increases to oil demand due to weather or the pace
    of economic growth;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    inventory levels of crude, refined products and natural
    gas;&nbsp;and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    other factors, such as the relative fluctuation between the
    U.S.&nbsp;dollar and other major currencies and influence of
    speculative positions on the futures exchanges.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">11

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
To reduce the exposure to changes in fuel prices, AWA has
periodically entered into certain fixed price swaps, collar
structures and other similar derivative contracts.
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; recent financial position and credit
rating have negatively affected its ability to enter into these
kinds of arrangements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Insurance</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group and its subsidiaries maintain insurance of
the types and in amounts deemed adequate to protect themselves
and their property. Principal coverage includes:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    liability for injury to members of the public, including
    passengers;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    damage to property of US&nbsp;Airways Group, its subsidiaries
    and others;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    loss of or damage to flight equipment, whether on the ground or
    in flight;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    fire and extended coverage;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    directors and officers;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    travel agents&#146; errors and omissions;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    advertiser&#146;s and media liability;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    fiduciary;&nbsp;and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    workers&#146; compensation and employer&#146;s liability.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Since September&nbsp;11, 2001, US&nbsp;Airways Group and other
airlines have been unable to obtain coverage for liability to
persons other than employees and passengers for claims resulting
from acts of terrorism, war or similar events, which is called
war risk coverage, at reasonable rates from the commercial
insurance market. US&nbsp;Airways and AWA therefore purchased
their war risk coverage through a special program administered
by the FAA, as have most other U.S.&nbsp;airlines. The Emergency
Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act extended this insurance
protection until August 2005. The program was subsequently
extended, with the same conditions and premiums, until
August&nbsp;31, 2006. Under Vision 100, the President may
continue the insurance program until March&nbsp;30, 2008. If the
federal insurance program terminates, we would likely face a
material increase in the cost of war risk coverage, and because
of competitive pressures in the industry, our ability to pass
this additional cost to passengers may be limited.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Frequent Traveler Program</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
All major United States airlines offer frequent flyer programs
to encourage travel on their respective airlines and customer
loyalty. Prior to the merger, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA operated
separate frequent flyer programs, known as &#147;Dividend
Miles&#148; and &#147;FlightFund,&#148; respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>FlightFund</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA&#146;s FlightFund program allows members to earn mileage
credit by flying AWA and America West Express, by flying on
certain partner airlines and by using the services of a wide
variety of other program participants such as hotels, rental car
agencies and other specialty services. AWA also sells mileage
credits to credit card companies, telephone companies, hotels,
car rental agencies and others that participate in the
FlightFund program.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Through the FlightFund program, accumulated mileage credits can
be redeemed for free travel on AWA, America West Express and
certain partner airlines and for first class upgrades on AWA.
Use of mileage credits is subject to industry standard
restrictions including availability and blackout dates. AWA must
purchase space on other airlines to accommodate FlightFund
redemption travel on those airlines. AWA reserves the right to
terminate the FlightFund program or portions of the program at
any time. Program rules, partners, special offers, blackout
dates, awards and requisite mileage levels for awards are
subject to change.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">12

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Dividend Miles</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; Dividend Miles frequent flyer program
