<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B><I>Substantial sales of our common stock after the merger
could cause our stock price to fall.</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Upon completion of all of the merger related equity
transactions, we had approximately 77.1&nbsp;million shares of
common stock outstanding, and as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, we
had approximately 81.7&nbsp;million shares of common stock
outstanding. Each of the new equity investors entered into a
stockholders
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">24

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
agreement that prohibits the equity investors&#146; sale of our
common stock prior to the date that is six months after
September&nbsp;27, 2005, or March&nbsp;27, 2006. The
stockholders agreements generally provide that the equity
investors will not sell, assign, transfer or pledge our common
stock or any securities exercisable for or convertible into our
common stock owned by them, subject to limited exceptions.
Approximately 44.0&nbsp;million shares, or 54% of the
outstanding shares of our common stock, owned by the equity
investors will be eligible for resale after the expiration of
the <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">lock-up</FONT> period. In
addition, under the terms of the PBGC settlement under
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s plan of reorganization, the
approximately 4.9&nbsp;million shares of common stock issued to
the PBGC could not be sold, assigned, transferred or pledged
prior to the end of five months after September&nbsp;27, 2005.
This restriction expired on February&nbsp;27, 2006. Sales of any
of these shares into the market after the expiration of the
respective <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">lock-up</FONT>
periods could cause the market price of our common stock to drop
significantly, even if our business is doing well.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B><I>Conversion of our convertible notes will dilute the
ownership interest of existing stockholders and could adversely
affect the market price of our common stock.</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The conversion of some or all of our outstanding convertible
notes, including US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s 7%&nbsp;Senior
Convertible Notes due 2020 or America West Holdings&#146;
7.5%&nbsp;Convertible Senior Notes due 2009, will dilute the
ownership interests of existing shareholders. Beginning
January&nbsp;18, 2005, the 7.5%&nbsp;notes became convertible
into shares of our common stock, at the option of the holder.
Any sales in the public market of the common stock issuable upon
such conversion could adversely affect prevailing market prices
of our common stock. In addition, the existence of the notes may
encourage short selling by market participants because the
conversion of the notes could depress the price of our common
stock.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B><I>A small number of stockholders beneficially own a
substantial amount of our common stock.</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
A significant portion of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s common
stock is beneficially owned by a relatively small number of
equity investors. As a result, until these stockholders sell a
substantial portion of their shares, they will have a greater
percentage vote in matters that may be presented for a vote to
stockholders than most other stockholders. This may make it more
difficult for other stockholders to influence votes on matters
that may come before stockholders of US&nbsp;Airways Group.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B><I>Certain provisions of the amended and restated certificate
of incorporation and amended and restated bylaws of
US&nbsp;Airways Group will make it difficult for stockholders to
change the composition of our board of directors and may
discourage takeover attempts that some of our stockholders might
consider beneficial.</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain provisions of the amended and restated certificate of
incorporation and amended and restated bylaws of US&nbsp;Airways
Group may have the effect of delaying or preventing changes in
control if our board of directors determines that such changes
in control are not in the best interests of US&nbsp;Airways
Group and its stockholders. These provisions include, among
other things, the following:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">25

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
These provisions are not intended to prevent a takeover, but are
intended to protect and maximize the value of US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s stockholders&#146; interests. While these
provisions have the effect of encouraging persons seeking to
acquire control of our company to negotiate with our board of
directors, they could enable our board of directors to prevent a
transaction that some, or a majority, of our stockholders might
believe to be in their best interests and, in that case, may
prevent or discourage attempts to remove and replace incumbent
directors. In addition, US&nbsp;Airways Group is subject to the
provisions of Section&nbsp;203 of the Delaware General
Corporation Law, which prohibits business combinations with
interested stockholders. Interested stockholders do not include
stockholders, such as our new equity investors, whose
acquisition of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s securities is
approved by the board of directors prior to the investment under
Section&nbsp;203.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B><I>Our charter documents include provisions limiting voting
and ownership by foreign owners.</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Our amended and restated certificate of incorporation provides
that shares of capital stock may not be voted by or at the
direction of persons who are not citizens of the United States
if the number of such shares would exceed 24.9% of the voting
stock of our company. In addition, any attempt to transfer
equity securities to a
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">non-U.S.&nbsp;</FONT>person in
excess of 49.9% of our outstanding equity securities will be
void and of no effect.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<A name='104'></A>
</DIV>

<!-- link1 "Item 1B. Unresolved Staff Comments" -->

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

</DIV>

<!-- link1 "Item 2. Properties" -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>Item&nbsp;2.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Properties</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group Flight Equipment</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the merger, US&nbsp;Airways Group negotiated
reductions to its existing fleet so that the fleet of the
combined company better matches aircraft size with consumer
demand. As a result of the integration of US&nbsp;Airways and
AWA, US&nbsp;Airways Group is expected to operate a mainline
fleet of approximately 354 aircraft at the end of 2006
(supported by approximately 240 regional jets and approximately
103 turboprops that provide passenger feed into the mainline
system), down from a total of 411 mainline aircraft operated by
the airlines prior to the merger. During 2006, US&nbsp;Airways
Group projects removing 22 aircraft and adding five aircraft to
the mainline fleet. During February and March 2006,
US&nbsp;Airways Group removed two Boeing
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT> aircraft from
the fleet. In February 2006, US&nbsp;Airways Group took delivery
of two A319 aircraft previously ordered by AWA. Airbus has also
agreed to reschedule 30 narrow-body A320-family aircraft
deliveries from the 2006 to 2010 period to the 2009 to 2010
period, which represented the combined commitment of AWA and
US&nbsp;Airways prior to the merger. To modernize its
international product and improve the efficiency of its
international network, the merged company will begin accepting
deliveries of A350 aircraft in 2011.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group had the
following jet and regional jet aircraft:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B><U>AWA</U></B>
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

    <TD width="48%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 8pt;">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(1)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    All owned aircraft are pledged as collateral for various secured
    financing agreements.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(2)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The terms of the leases expire between 2006 and 2023.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
wholly owned regional airline subsidiaries operated the
following turboprop and regional jet aircraft:
</DIV>

    <TD>(1)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As discussed in Item&nbsp;1. &#147;Business&nbsp;&#151;
US&nbsp;Airways Express Network&#148; above, AWA and
US&nbsp;Airways have code share agreements with certain regional
jet affiliate operators. Collectively, these affiliate operators
flew 255 regional jet aircraft and 107 turboprop aircraft as
part of America West Express and US&nbsp;Airways Express as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group maintains inventories of spare engines,
spare parts, accessories and other maintenance supplies
sufficient to meet its operating requirements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The following table illustrates US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
committed orders, scheduled lease expirations, and lessor call
and put options as of December&nbsp;31, 2005.
</DIV>

</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>AWA Flight Equipment</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In August 2004, AWA amended its aircraft purchase contract with
AVSA S.A.R.L., an affiliate of Airbus Industrie, to acquire 22
Airbus A320 family aircraft (thirteen A320s and nine A319s), all
powered by V2500 engines from International Aero Engines. Of the
22 aircraft, 18 will be purchased directly from the manufacturer
and four have been leased under noncancelable leases from
various lessors on aircraft delivered in 2005. In the context of
this incremental order, AWA also secured extensive flexibility
from Airbus with respect to its existing A318 order, allowing
AWA to better react to market conditions by enabling it to amend
its 15 A318 delivery positions to A319s and A320s, if it so
desires, or to take no additional aircraft under certain
conditions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, in connection with the merger, AWA
amended its A320 family aircraft purchase contract with AVSA
S.A.R.L., to reschedule 11 aircraft deliveries from 2006 and
2007 to 2009. All other terms remained unchanged.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In 2005, AWA returned two
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200,</FONT> two
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT> and four A320
aircraft. AWA renewed the leases on four
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300s</FONT> for four
years, one A320 for three years and one 757 for one year. AWA
took delivery of seven A320s, five of which were through the
Airbus agreement. Three of these seven aircraft have new lease
terms of five years; the other four have leases of twelve years.
AWA also took deliveries of four A319 aircraft per the same
Airbus agreement of which one has a lease term of five years and
the other three have twelve-year leases. In 2006, AWA is
expected to take deliveries of two more A319 aircraft and return
eight 737-300s, two A320s and one 757. As of December&nbsp;31,
2005, 48 aircraft have lease expirations prior to the end of
2008.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA is a participant in the Civil Reserve Air Fleet, a voluntary
program administered by the U.S.&nbsp;Air Force Air Mobility
Command. The General Services Administration of the
U.S.&nbsp;Government requires that airlines participate in Civil
Reserve Air Fleet, if activated, in order to receive
U.S.&nbsp;Government business. AWA&#146;s present commitment to
the Civil Reserve Air Fleet is to provide up to eight aircraft.
Upon activation, AWA may also be obligated to provide up to 15%
of the total fleet, up to a maximum of 19 aircraft, in support
of military missions. AWA is reimbursed at compensatory rates
when aircraft are activated under Civil Reserve Air Fleet. AWA
is reimbursed during peacetime proportionally to its commitment.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Flight Equipment</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Prior to the merger, US&nbsp;Airways Group had 19 A320-family
aircraft on firm order with Airbus scheduled for delivery in the
years 2008 through 2010. US&nbsp;Airways Group also had ten
A330-200 aircraft on firm order with Airbus scheduled for
delivery in the years 2008 and 2009. In connection with the
merger, on May&nbsp;18, 2005, Airbus, US&nbsp;Airways Group,
US&nbsp;Airways and AWA executed a Memorandum of Understanding
that, in addition to providing for a $250&nbsp;million line of
credit from Airbus upon the satisfaction of various conditions
precedent (including the completion of the merger and the
emergence of US&nbsp;Airways from bankruptcy), provides for the
rescheduling of US&nbsp;Airways&#146; A320-family and A330-200
delivery commitments, and an order for 20 A350 aircraft, for
which Airbus has agreed to provide backstop financing for a
substantial number of aircraft, subject to certain terms and
conditions. Under the Airbus Memorandum of Understanding,
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; A320-family aircraft will be rescheduled
for delivery in 2009 and 2010, with US&nbsp;Airways&#146;
A330-200 aircraft orders rescheduled for delivery in 2009 and
2010. The
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">28

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
new A350 aircraft deliveries are currently scheduled to occur
during the period 2011 through 2013. The Airbus MOU also
modifies the cancellation rights on US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
orders for the ten A330-200 aircraft provided that
US&nbsp;Airways Group has met certain predelivery payment
obligations under the A350 order. On September&nbsp;27, 2005,
upon emergence from bankruptcy and effective with the merger,
US&nbsp;Airways Group, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA executed an A350
Purchase Agreement with AVSA S.A.R.L. and executed amendments to
its existing Airbus purchase agreements to support and finalize
the transactions called for in the Airbus MOU.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Pursuant to the regional jet leasing term sheet of the GE Master
Memorandum of Understanding approved by the Bankruptcy Court on
December&nbsp;17, 2004, General Electric Capital Corporation
(&#147;GECC&#148;) or its affiliates agreed to provide lease
financing for up to 31 regional jet aircraft, consisting of
70-to <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">100-seat</FONT> regional
jet aircraft manufactured by Bombardier and/or Embraer in a mix
and subject to other terms to be agreed mutually by GECC and
US&nbsp;Airways. As provided for in the Master Memorandum of
Understanding, GECC entered into short-term leases for six
Bombardier <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">CRJ-700s</FONT>
with US&nbsp;Airways in the first quarter of 2005, which were
converted, pursuant to the Merger Memorandum of Understanding,
into long term leases. These long term leases were deemed
post-petition agreements during the Chapter&nbsp;11 cases,
subject to a limitation on administrative expense status to rent
payable through October&nbsp;31, 2005 (or a later date agreed to
by the parties) and return condition obligations. The Merger
Memorandum of Understanding eliminated any further obligation on
GE to provide regional jet financing directly to US&nbsp;Airways
Group, but GE agreed to provide single investor or operating
leases to airlines that are not owned by US&nbsp;Airways Group
but that would operate the aircraft as part of the US Airway
Express network provided that those airlines meet financial
tests and are otherwise acceptable to GE. The aircraft available
for lease by these other airlines are ten
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">EMB-170/190/195</FONT>
aircraft to be delivered between 2007 and 2008, on a schedule
and terms to be agreed on by the parties and subject to
manufacturer support. GE also provided single investor or
operating lease financing to Republic for three EMB-170 aircraft
that had been committed to be delivered to the Debtors, subject
to manufacturer support and other terms and conditions
acceptable to GE. Finally, to facilitate a transaction agreed to
between US&nbsp;Airways Group and Republic, GE consented to the
assignment to Republic of up to 15 EMB-170 leases, subject to
manufacturer support and other conditions acceptable to GE.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In December 2004, pre-merger US&nbsp;Airways Group reached
aircraft leasing and financing agreements with Embraer and
Bombardier. These agreements were approved by the Bankruptcy
Court in January 2005. Pursuant to the agreement reached with
Embraer, US&nbsp;Airways purchased and took delivery of three
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">EMB-170</FONT> aircraft in
January 2005 and endeavored to purchase and take delivery of
three additional
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">EMB-170</FONT> aircraft by
March&nbsp;31, 2005. US&nbsp;Airways did not take delivery of
the additional aircraft in March 2005. As a result, damages at
the rate of $162,795&nbsp;per month per aircraft accrued from
April&nbsp;1, 2005 until the delivery of the aircraft.
US&nbsp;Airways Group secured GE&#146;s agreement to provide
financing for those three additional aircraft under the Merger
Memorandum of Understanding, as discussed above. Under the terms
of the Merger Memorandum of Understanding, US&nbsp;Airways Group
assigned the delivery of the three remaining aircraft deliveries
to Republic with leases to be provided by GECC. US&nbsp;Airways
Group agreed with Embraer to extend the deadline for delivery of
these aircraft, but incurred an additional penalty equal to one
month of damages per aircraft in connection with this extension.
On February&nbsp;16, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court approved the
settlement and assumption term sheet executed by US&nbsp;Airways
Group and Embraer on February&nbsp;9, 2006. US&nbsp;Airways has
agreed to place an initial firm order for 25 EMB-190 aircraft
during the period 2006 through 2008 for which Embraer has agreed
to provide backstop financing. An additional firm order for 32
EMB-190 aircraft, subject to reconfirmation by US&nbsp;Airways,
may be delivered subsequently.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under its agreement with Bombardier, US&nbsp;Airways Group
acquired three new
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">CRJ-700</FONT> aircraft in
January 2005. The purchase was financed through the application
of $28&nbsp;million of existing purchase deposits held by
Bombardier, $2&nbsp;million in cash and a financed lease
facility with DVB&nbsp;Bank&nbsp;AG. Additionally,
$7&nbsp;million of purchase deposits held by Bombardier were
used to satisfy existing defaults, cure payments and liquidated
damages. While US&nbsp;Airways Group continued to operate under
the protection of Chapter&nbsp;11 in compliance with the
Bankruptcy Code and until a decision is reached to
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">29

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
assume or reject the Bombardier regional jet purchase agreement,
no obligations arise on the part of US&nbsp;Airways Group or
Bombardier with respect to the purchase and delivery of any
aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During 2005, the pre-merger US&nbsp;Airways returned 50 aircraft
from its fleet: twenty-nine
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300s,</FONT> five
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-400,</FONT> twelve A319s
and four A320s in 2005. Ten more
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT> aircraft are
expected to be returned in 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group owned or
leased the following aircraft that were not considered part of
its operating fleet presented in the tables above. These
aircraft were either parked at storage facilities or, as shown
in the far right column, leased or subleased to third parties or
related parties.
</DIV>

<CENTER>

    De Havilland Dash 8</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="top" nowrap>15.6</TD>

    <TD align="right" valign="top" nowrap>1</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD align="left" valign="top">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="top" nowrap>&#151;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways is a participant in the Civil Reserve Air Fleet.
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; commitment under Civil Reserve Air Fleet,
upon activation, is to provide up to its entire widebody fleet
of ten <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">767-200ER</FONT>
aircraft and nine
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A330-300</FONT> aircraft in
support of military missions. US&nbsp;Airways is reimbursed at
compensatory rates when aircraft are activated under Civil
Reserve Air Fleet. US&nbsp;Airways is reimbursed during
peacetime proportionally to its commitment.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; 767-200ER aircraft are committed to the
Aeromed Program of the Civil Reserve Air Fleet. Under this
program, the aircraft are converted to flying hospitals for
transportation of injured troops. US&nbsp;Airways, Delta Air
Lines and United Airlines are participants in the Aeromed
Program. Participation in this program provides increased
U.S.&nbsp;government revenues for US&nbsp;Airways. Since the
Civil Reserve Air Fleet activation of 2003, US&nbsp;Airways has
not provided &#147;voluntary&#148; lift to Air Mobility Command,
due to operational limitations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Ground Facilities</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company leases the majority of its ground facilities,
including:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

</TR>

<TR valign="top">

</TR>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In addition, America West Holdings and AWA have leased an
aggregate of approximately 207,000&nbsp;square feet of data
center, office and warehouse space in Tempe and Phoenix.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Space for ticket counters, gates and back offices has been
obtained at each of the other airports operated by AWA and
US&nbsp;Airways, either by lease from the airport operator or by
sublease or handling agreement from another airline.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Terminal Construction Projects</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group uses public airports for its flight
operations under lease arrangements with the government entities
that own or control these airports. Airport authorities
frequently require airlines to execute long-term leases to
assist in obtaining financing for terminal and facility
construction. Any future requirements for new or improved
airport facilities and passenger terminals at airports in which
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s airline subsidiaries operate could
result in additional occupancy costs and long-term commitments.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">31

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<A name='106'></A>
</DIV>

<!-- link1 "Item 3. Legal Proceedings" -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>Item&nbsp;3.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Legal Proceedings</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;12, 2004, US&nbsp;Airways Group and its
domestic subsidiaries (the &#147;Debtors&#148;) filed voluntary
petitions for relief under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the Bankruptcy
Code in the United States bankruptcy court for the Eastern
District of Virginia, Alexandria Division (the &#147;Bankruptcy
Court&#148;) (Case
Nos.&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">04-13819-SSM</FONT>
through <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">03-13823</FONT>-SSM)
(the &#147;2004 Bankruptcy&#148;). On September&nbsp;16, 2005,
the Bankruptcy Court issued an order confirming the plan of
reorganization submitted by the Debtors and on
September&nbsp;27, 2005, the Debtors emerged from the 2004
Bankruptcy. The court&#146;s order confirming the plan included
a provision called the plan injunction, which forever bars other
parties from pursuing most claims against the Debtors that arose
prior to September&nbsp;27, 2005 in any forum other than the
Bankruptcy Court. The great majority of these claims are
pre-petition claims that, if paid out at all, will be paid out
in common stock of the post-bankruptcy US&nbsp;Airways Group at
a fraction of the actual claim amount.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On February&nbsp;26, 2004, a company called I.A.P. Intermodal,
LLC filed suit against US&nbsp;Airways Group and its wholly
owned airline subsidiaries in the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Texas alleging that the
defendants&#146; computer scheduling system infringes upon three
patents held by plaintiffs, all of which patents are entitled,
&#147;Method to Schedule a Vehicle in Real-Time to Transport
Freight and Passengers.&#148; Plaintiff seeks various injunctive
relief as well as costs, fees and treble damages.
US&nbsp;Airways Group and its subsidiaries were formally served
with the complaint on June&nbsp;21, 2004. US&nbsp;Airways Group
is unable to ascertain at this time the likelihood or potential
scale of liability. On the same date, the same plaintiff filed
what US&nbsp;Airways Group believes to be substantially similar
cases against nine other major airlines, including British
Airways, Northwest Airlines Corporation, Korean Airlines Co.,
Ltd., Deutsche Lufthansa AG, Air France, Air Canada, Singapore
Airlines Ltd., Delta Air Lines and Continental Airlines, Inc.,
and had filed a suit against AMR Group, Inc., the parent company
of American Airlines, along with its airline subsidiaries, in
December 2003. This action has been stayed as to US&nbsp;Airways
Group and its wholly owned subsidiaries as a result of the 2004
Bankruptcy. In the meantime, several foreign airline defendants
were dismissed from the case for reasons unique to their status
as foreign operators, and the remaining defendants in September
2005 obtained a ruling that there had been no infringement of
any of I.A.P.&#146;s patents. In October 2005, I.A.P. entered
into consent judgments with several defendants but has since
filed a notice of appeal against Continental Airlines and the
AMR Group defendants. I.A.P. did not file any claims against
US&nbsp;Airways Group or any of its subsidiaries in the 2004
Bankruptcy.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey filed a proof of
claim against US&nbsp;Airways in the bankruptcy case filed on
August&nbsp;11, 2002 (the &#147;2002 Bankruptcy&#148;). The
claim was in the amount of $8.5&nbsp;million and it alleged
environmental contamination and building deficiencies at
LaGuardia. US&nbsp;Airways&#146; liability and defenses to this
liability were unaffected by the 2002 Bankruptcy. In connection
with the 2004 Bankruptcy, the Port Authority filed a proof of
claim in the amount of approximately $24&nbsp;million again
alleging environmental contamination and building deficiencies
at LaGuardia, of which approximately $2&nbsp;million is related
to alleged environmental contamination.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On January&nbsp;7, 2003, the Internal Revenue Service
(&#147;IRS&#148;) issued a notice of proposed adjustment to
US&nbsp;Airways Group proposing to disallow $573&nbsp;million of
capital losses that US&nbsp;Airways Group sustained in the tax
year 1999 on the sale of stock of USLM Corporation (the
&#147;USLM matter&#148;). On February&nbsp;5, 2003, the IRS
filed a proof of claim with the Bankruptcy Court in connection
with the 2002 Bankruptcy asserting the following claims against
US&nbsp;Airways with respect to the USLM matter:
(1)&nbsp;secured claims for U.S.&nbsp;federal income tax and
interest of $1&nbsp;million; (2)&nbsp;unsecured priority claims
for U.S.&nbsp;federal income tax of $68&nbsp;million and
interest of $14&nbsp;million; and (3)&nbsp;an unsecured general
claim for penalties of $25&nbsp;million. On May&nbsp;8, 2003,
US&nbsp;Airways Group reached a tentative agreement with the IRS
on the amount of U.S.&nbsp;federal income taxes, interest and
penalties due subject to final approval from the Joint Committee
on Taxation. By letter dated September&nbsp;11, 2003,
US&nbsp;Airways Group was notified that the Joint Committee on
Taxation had accepted the tentative agreement with the IRS,
including a settlement of all federal income taxes through the
end of 2002. Due to the 2004 Bankruptcy filing, which suspended
payment of prepetition liabilities, final payment terms under
the agreement have not been submitted to the Bankruptcy Court
for approval. The IRS has submitted a proof of claim relating to
the USLM matter in
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">32

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
the 2004 Bankruptcy in the amount of approximately
$31&nbsp;million, and on August&nbsp;2, 2005 the IRS filed a
motion for relief from the automatic stay seeking to setoff
against approximately $4&nbsp;million of tax refunds due to the
Debtors. On October&nbsp;20, 2005, the IRS filed an amended
proof of claim reducing its claim in the USLM matter to
$11&nbsp;million. On November&nbsp;3, 2005, the IRS filed an
amended motion continuing to seek relief for the $4&nbsp;million
setoff. A hearing was set for December&nbsp;15, 2005 on this
matter, but was continued to March&nbsp;16, 2006 for a status
hearing. The Debtors are in the process of analyzing the
IRS&#146;s amended motion.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Williard, Inc. and the joint venture of Williard, Inc. and Len
Parker Associates, was awarded construction contracts with
US&nbsp;Airways for work to be performed at the Philadelphia
International Airport. On May&nbsp;29, 2002, US&nbsp;Airways
terminated the largest contracts between the parties. Williard,
Inc. and the joint venture sued US&nbsp;Airways in Pennsylvania
state court for over $14&nbsp;million in damages representing
termination costs and lost profits, along with other alleged
contractual damage claims. Subsequently, Limbach Company, LLC
purchased the claims of Williard, Inc. After a trial, the
Bankruptcy Court in the 2002 Bankruptcy, on June&nbsp;7, 2004,
determined the value of the Limbach Company and the joint
venture claims to be approximately $2.5&nbsp;million. Limbach
Company and the joint venture are challenging on appeal various
rulings of the Bankruptcy Court, including the amount of the
claim and its status as an unsecured claim. US&nbsp;Airways has
also filed an appeal regarding the denial of its right to offset
the claims with asserted backcharges.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Limbach Company and the joint venture have filed an action in
state court against the City of Philadelphia and the
Philadelphia Authority for Industrial Development, as well as
US&nbsp;Airways, but did not assert any claims against
US&nbsp;Airways in that action. In the lawsuit against the City
of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority for Industrial
Development, Limbach Company and the joint venture are seeking
the same sums as in their earlier lawsuit and proofs of claim
against US&nbsp;Airways, but this time under the equitable
theories of third-party beneficiary, quantum meruit and
constructive trust. On a pre-answer motion to dismiss, the court
in the Philadelphia action dismissed US&nbsp;Airways from the
lawsuit and dismissed the third-party beneficiary claims against
the City of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority for
Industrial Development.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On May&nbsp;21, 2004, the City of Philadelphia and the
Philadelphia Authority for Industrial Development filed a Motion
for Summary Judgment seeking dismissal of the remaining claims
for constructive trust and quantum meruit. On October&nbsp;18,
2004, the City of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority
for Industrial Development also filed an alternative Motion for
Partial Summary Judgment that the damages claimed by Limbach
Company and the joint venture, if any, are capped at the amount
determined by the Bankruptcy Court on the prior trial of its
claims. On June&nbsp;29, 2005, the court granted the Motion for
Summary Judgment and dismissed the alternative Motion for
Partial Summary Judgment as moot. Limbach Company and the joint
venture have appealed the dismissal of these claims, as well as
the prior dismissal of its third party beneficiary claim, but
have not appealed the dismissal of US&nbsp;Airways from the
lawsuit.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Should the Philadelphia court&#146;s rulings be reversed on
appeal and Limbach Company and/or the joint venture subsequently
recover in the Philadelphia action against the City of
Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority for Industrial
Development, that award would be paid by them at 100 cents on
the dollar. Although US&nbsp;Airways&#146; agreements with the
City of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority for
Industrial Development related to the airport development have
neither been assumed nor rejected as part of the 2004
Bankruptcy, if assumed, US&nbsp;Airways may have an obligation,
under those agreements, to indemnify the City of Philadelphia
and the Philadelphia Authority for Industrial Development, at
full value, for any recovery against them by Limbach Company
and/or the joint venture. Proceedings in the Bankruptcy Court
related to the claims in the 2002 Bankruptcy remain stayed by
the 2004 Bankruptcy filing.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group and US&nbsp;Airways have been named as
defendants in two lawsuits filed in federal district court for
the Eastern District of Michigan in May 1999. Delta Air Lines is
also named as a defendant in both actions, while Northwest
Airlines and the Airlines Reporting Corporation were sued
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">33

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
separately in a third action. The complaints were filed on
behalf of a class of airline passengers who originated or
terminated their trips at the defendant carriers&#146;
respective hubs. These passengers allege that they paid
excessive fares due to the respective airlines&#146; enforcement
of ticketing rules that prohibit the use of a connecting segment
coupon that is part of a through-fare ticket where the passenger
does not fly or intend to fly the entire ticketed itinerary.
Plaintiffs allege monopolization and restraint of trade in
violation of federal antitrust laws. They seek recovery of
treble damages from all named defendants in the amount of
$390&nbsp;million and an injunction prohibiting future
enforcement of the rules at issue. On May&nbsp;16, 2002, the
court denied the defendant airlines&#146; Motion for Summary
Judgment and granted the plaintiffs&#146; Motion for
Class&nbsp;Certification in each of the cases. On May&nbsp;31,
2002, US&nbsp;Airways Group and US&nbsp;Airways filed a petition
with the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
seeking a discretionary review of the certification order. On
November&nbsp;21, 2002, the petition for permission to appeal
the class certification decision was denied. On December&nbsp;4,
2002, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines filed a rehearing
petition seeking en banc review of the initial Sixth Circuit
denial. On February&nbsp;24, 2003, Northwest Airlines&#146; and
Delta Air Lines&#146; petition for rehearing en banc was denied.
Notwithstanding the district court&#146;s denial of summary
judgment and the petition, US&nbsp;Airways Group and
US&nbsp;Airways believe the claims are without merit and intend
to pursue a vigorous defense. The action was stayed as to
US&nbsp;Airways during the 2002 Bankruptcy and again during the
2004 Bankruptcy. On April&nbsp;29, 2005, Northwest Airlines and
Delta Air Lines filed a renewed motion for summary judgment on
all counts. That motion was denied. Delta Air Lines and
Northwest Airlines filed two additional motions: one seeking
decertification of the class and the other seeking dismissal of
all class members who received ticket refunds. While those
motions were pending, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines
filed for bankruptcy. The federal district court has now
deactivated the case because of the bankruptcy filings. However,
in January 2006, plaintiffs filed a motion for relief from the
stay imposed by the Northwest Airlines bankruptcy filing to
pursue litigation against that defendant only. On
December&nbsp;1, 2005, plaintiffs withdrew the claims filed
against US&nbsp;Airways in the 2002 and 2004 Bankruptcies, thus
effectively cutting off their right to obtain any relief against
US&nbsp;Airways for damages that might have accrued prior to
September&nbsp;27, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;29, 2000, US&nbsp;Airways intervened in a
proceeding that was originally brought on January&nbsp;26, 1998
by the Pennsylvania Department of Environment Protection against
Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, and the Allegheny County
Aviation Administration alleging that a variety of airfield and
aircraft de-icing activities at Pittsburgh International Airport
violated the requirements of (a)&nbsp;a 1994 Consent Order and
Adjudication issued to Allegheny County and air carrier tenants
at the Pittsburgh International Airport, (b)&nbsp;the Pittsburgh
International Airport&#146;s National Pollutant Discharge
Elimination System Permit, and (c)&nbsp;the Pennsylvania Clean
Streams Law. The action was brought before the Pennsylvania
Environmental Hearing Board. During March 2001, the
Environmental Hearing Board approved Allegheny County&#146;s
Motion to Withdraw the Appeal without Prejudice, thereby
terminating the appeal. However, during the course of settlement
discussions leading to the termination of the appeal, the
Pennsylvania Department of Environment Protection advised
Allegheny County and US&nbsp;Airways that the Department of
Environment Protection will require additional measures to be
taken to control de-icing materials at the Pittsburgh
International Airport, and will assess a civil penalty against
Allegheny County and US&nbsp;Airways for the alleged violations
described above. The Allegheny County Aviation Administration,
US&nbsp;Airways and the Pennsylvania Department of Environment
Protection have continued to work together with the goal of
fashioning an ultimate resolution to the de-icing issues.
US&nbsp;Airways Group does not believe that the settlement of
this matter will have a material adverse effect on its financial
condition, results of operations or liquidity.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;7, 2005, 240 pilots employed by the MidAtlantic
division of US&nbsp;Airways filed a complaint in the federal
district court for the Eastern District of New York against
ALPA, US&nbsp;Airways, US&nbsp;Airways Group, Republic Airways
Holdings, Inc., Wexford Capital LLC and AWA, alleging that
defendants conspired to deceive plaintiffs into believing that
MidAtlantic was a separate entity from US&nbsp;Airways in order
to deprive them of the benefits they are due as US&nbsp;Airways
pilots pursuant to the US&nbsp;Airways collective bargaining
agreement. Plaintiffs&#146; claims against the airline
defendants include breach of collective bargaining agreement,
violation of the Railway Labor Act and racketeering under the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">34

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act
(&#147;RICO&#148;). Plaintiffs&#146; complaint requests
$2&nbsp;billion in damages from the airline defendants and
injunctive relief.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On February&nbsp;8, 2006, 103 flight attendants employed by the
MidAtlantic division of US&nbsp;Airways filed a complaint
against AFA, AFA&#146;s international president Pat Friend and
US&nbsp;Airways, alleging that defendants conspired to deceive
plaintiffs into believing that MidAtlantic was a separate entity
from US&nbsp;Airways in order to deprive them of the benefits
they are due as US&nbsp;Airways flight attendants pursuant to
the US&nbsp;Airways collective bargaining agreement.
Plaintiffs&#146; claims against US&nbsp;Airways include breach
of collective bargaining agreement, violation of the Railway
Labor Act and racketeering under RICO. Plaintiffs&#146;
complaint requests $400&nbsp;million in damages from
US&nbsp;Airways and injunctive relief. Because the complaint has
not yet been served on US&nbsp;Airways, no action is due on its
part at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;12, 2005, Bank of America, N.A., which is the
issuing bank of the US&nbsp;Airways frequent flier program
credit card and also acts as the processing bank for most
airline ticket purchases paid for with credit cards, filed suit
in the Delaware Chancery Court in New Castle County, against
US&nbsp;Airways, US&nbsp;Airways Group and AWA, alleging that
US&nbsp;Airways breached its frequent flier credit card contract
with Bank of America by entering into a similar, competing
agreement with Juniper and allowing Juniper to issue a
US&nbsp;Airways frequent flier credit card. Bank of America also
alleges that US&nbsp;Airways Group and AWA induced these
breaches. Bank of America seeks an order requiring
US&nbsp;Airways to market the Bank of America card and prohibit
Juniper from issuing a US&nbsp;Airways credit card, as well as
unspecified damages. On October&nbsp;27, 2005, Juniper, which
was not originally a party to the lawsuit, sought and later
received court permission to intervene as a defendant in the
case and has made counterclaims against Bank of America. Juniper
seeks an order declaring the validity of its new agreement to
issue a US&nbsp;Airways frequent flier credit card. On
November&nbsp;3, 2005, Bank of America filed a motion for
partial summary judgment on the breach of contract claim against
US&nbsp;Airways. After a series of procedural steps, Bank of
America&#146;s motion, along with a cross-motion for summary
judgment filed by Juniper, was heard in the Bankruptcy Court,
where the case is now pending as an adversary proceeding. On
January&nbsp;30, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court ruled that Bank of
America is equitably estopped from pursuing its claims that
US&nbsp;Airways breached its agreement with Bank of America by
negotiating and entering into the agreement with Juniper. Bank
of America is seeking appeal of that ruling while it continues
to pursue its claim that US&nbsp;Airways failed to fulfill
contractual marketing obligations to Bank of America. The
resolution of the final two claims that Bank of America made in
the lawsuit, which are (i)&nbsp;that AWA tortiously interfered
with the contractual relationship between US&nbsp;Airways and
Bank of America (ii)&nbsp;that US&nbsp;Airways Group and AWA
tortiously interfered with Bank of America&#146;s right to
future economic benefit under its agreement with
US&nbsp;Airways, are dependent on the outcome of the pending
appeal. Bank of America will pursue those two claims only if its
appeal of the January&nbsp;30, 2006 order is successful.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company is unable to estimate at this time the amount of
loss or probable losses, if any, that might result from an
adverse resolution of the proceedings discussed above, and
currently is unable to predict whether the outcome of these
proceedings will have a material adverse effect on its results
of operations or financial condition. The Company intends,
however, to vigorously pursue all available defenses and claims
in these matters.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<A name='107'></A>
</DIV>

</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
No matters were submitted to a vote of security holders during
the fourth quarter of 2005.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">35

<!-- link1 "PART II" -->

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>PART&nbsp;II</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<A name='109'></A>
</DIV>

<!-- link1 "Item 5. Market for US Airways Group&#146;s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities" -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>Item&nbsp;5.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Market for US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s Common Equity,
    Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity
    Securities</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Stock Exchange Listing</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Beginning on September&nbsp;27, 2005, the effective date of the
merger, our common stock began trading on the NYSE under the
symbol &#147;LCC.&#148; As of March&nbsp;1, 2006, the closing
price of our common stock on the NYSE was $32.80. As of
March&nbsp;1, 2006, there were 2,930 holders of record of the
common stock.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Prior to the 2004 Bankruptcy, pre-merger US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s then outstanding Class&nbsp;A common stock was
traded on the NASDAQ National Market under the symbol
&#147;UAIR,&#148; beginning on October&nbsp;21, 2003. Prior to
listing on the NASDAQ National Market, the Class&nbsp;A Common
Stock had limited trading activity on the
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Over-the</FONT>-Counter
Bulletin&nbsp;Board and in the Pink Sheets, which provide
trading for the
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">over-the</FONT>-counter
securities markets.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;13, 2004, US&nbsp;Airways Group received
written notice from the NASDAQ Stock Market that its
Class&nbsp;A common stock would be delisted in accordance with
Marketplace Rules&nbsp;4300 and 4450(f), effective with the
opening of business on September&nbsp;22, 2004. NASDAQ indicated
in its letter that the delisting determination followed its
review of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s press release announcing
that it had filed for bankruptcy protection. As a result of this
notification, a fifth character &#147;Q&#148; was added to the
trading symbol, changing it from &#147;UAIR&#148; to
&#147;UAIRQ&#148; at the opening of business on
September&nbsp;15, 2004. Shares were traded on the NASDAQ
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">over-the</FONT>-counter market
under the symbol as changed above until the Class&nbsp;A common
stock was cancelled upon the effectiveness of the plan of
reorganization on September&nbsp;27, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Market Prices of Common Stock</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The following table sets forth, for the periods indicated, the
high and low sale prices of our common stock on the NYSE and the
previously outstanding Class&nbsp;A common stock on the NASDAQ
National Market and
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">over-the</FONT>-counter market:
</DIV>

    </TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>0.58</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(1)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    As described above, the Class&nbsp;A common stock of pre-merger
    US&nbsp;Airways Group was cancelled upon the effectiveness of
    the plan of reorganization on September&nbsp;27, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group, organized under the laws of the State of
Delaware, is subject to Sections&nbsp;160 and 170 of the
Delaware General Corporation Law, which govern the payment of
dividends on or the repurchase or redemption of its capital
stock. US&nbsp;Airways Group is restricted from engaging in any
of these activities unless it maintains a capital surplus.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Pre-merger US&nbsp;Airways Group has not declared or paid cash
or other dividends on its common stock since 1990 and America
West Holdings has never declared or paid in cash or other
dividends on its
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">36

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
common stock. The Company currently does not intend to do so.
Under the provisions of certain debt agreements, including our
secured loans, our ability to pay dividends on or repurchase our
common stock is restricted. Any future determination to pay cash
dividends will be at the discretion of our board of directors,
subject to applicable limitations under Delaware law, and will
depend upon our results of operations, financial condition,
contractual restrictions and other factors deemed relevant by
our board of directors. See &#147;Liquidity and Capital
Resources&#148; in Item&nbsp;7, &#147;Management&#146;s
Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
Operation,&#148; below for more information, including
information related to dividend restrictions associated with our
secured loans.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Foreign Ownership Restrictions</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under current federal law,
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">non-U.S.&nbsp;</FONT>citizens
cannot own or control more than 25% of the outstanding voting
securities of a domestic air carrier. We believe that we were in
compliance with this statute during the time period covered by
this report.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Recent Sales of Unregistered Securities</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Completion of the merger between US&nbsp;Airways Group and
America West Holdings on September&nbsp;27, 2005 constituted a
&#147;change of control&#148; under AWA&#146;s Senior
Exchangeable Notes due 2023 and required AWA to make an offer to
holders to purchase those notes within 30 business days after
the effective time of the merger at a purchase price of
$343.61&nbsp;per $1,000 principal amount at maturity. Under the
terms of the notes and the related Guarantee and Exchange
Agreement, dated as of July&nbsp;30, 2003, between America West
Holdings and U.S.&nbsp;Bank National Association, as Trustee, as
supplemented by the Guarantee and Exchange Agreement Supplement
No.&nbsp;1 among America West Holdings, US&nbsp;Airways Group
and the Trustee, dated as of September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA&#146;s
obligation to purchase the notes was satisfied at
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s election by delivery of shares of
US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock having a &#147;fair market
value&#148; of not less than $343.61&nbsp;per $1,000 principal
amount at maturity. For this purpose, &#147;fair market
value&#148; means 95% of the market price of US&nbsp;Airways
Group common stock calculated as the average closing prices over
the five business days ending on and including the third
business day before the purchase date.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;24, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group issued a total
of 4,156,411&nbsp;shares of its common stock in exchange for
approximately $250&nbsp;million in principal amount at maturity
of AWA&#146;s Senior Exchangeable Notes due 2023, which notes
were fully and unconditionally guaranteed by US&nbsp;Airways
Group. The shares were exchanged at a rate of 16.6&nbsp;shares
of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock per $1,000 principal
amount at maturity, in full satisfaction of the purchase price
of the notes. The amount of notes exchanged represented
approximately 99% of the outstanding principal amount, and
approximately $2&nbsp;million in principal amount at maturity of
the notes remained outstanding after the exchange. On
November&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group issued a total of
38,864&nbsp;shares of its common stock to repurchase the
remaining outstanding principal amount of the notes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The issuance of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock to the
holders of the notes was made pursuant to the exemption from
registration under Section&nbsp;3(a)(9) of the Securities Act of
1933, as amended.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">37

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(1)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    On October&nbsp;1, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group entered into an
    agreement with the ATSB to purchase all of its outstanding
    warrants for an aggregate purchase price of approximately
    $116&nbsp;million. The transaction represents the repurchase of
    all of the replacement warrants issued to the ATSB in connection
    with the merger with America West Holdings. US&nbsp;Airways
    Group repurchased 7,735,770 warrants to purchase shares of
    common stock that had an exercise price of $7.27&nbsp;per share.
    The average price paid per share is calculated by dividing the
    total cash paid for the warrants by the number of warrants
    purchased.</TD>
</TR>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Selected Consolidated Financial Data of US&nbsp;Airways
Group</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The selected consolidated financial data presented below under
the captions &#147;Consolidated Statements of Operations
Data&#148; and &#147;Consolidated Balance Sheet Data&#148; as of
and for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004, 2003, 2002
and 2001 are derived from the audited consolidated financial
statements of US&nbsp;Airways Group. The selected consolidated
financial data should be read in conjunction with the
consolidated financial statements for the respective periods,
the related notes and the related reports of US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s independent registered public accounting firms.

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform
    with the 2005 presentation. These reclassifications include
    reclassing: fuel hedging activities from nonoperating to
    operating expenses, fuel-related tax expenses from other
    expenses to aircraft fuel and related taxes expense and the sale
    of frequent flier miles and related marketing services to
    affinity partners from other operating expense to mainline
    passenger and other revenue. The portion of the affinity partner
    revenue related to passenger ticket sales is classified as
    mainline passenger revenue and the marketing portion of the
    affinity partner revenue is classified as other revenue.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The Company reclassified amounts related to settled fuel hedge
    transactions and
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to</FONT>-market
    adjustments on open hedge instruments from nonoperating income
    (expense) to operating. The amounts for the years ended
    December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 reduced operating expenses
    by $75&nbsp;million, $24&nbsp;million and $11, respectively. For
    the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, the amounts
    increased operating expenses by $1&nbsp;million and
    $7&nbsp;million, respectively.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The sale of frequent flier miles and related marketing services
    to affinity partners were reclassed from operating expenses to
    operating revenues. The amounts for the years ended
    December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004, 2003, 2002 and 2001 were
    $20&nbsp;million, $38&nbsp;million, $32&nbsp;million,
    $29&nbsp;million and $24&nbsp;million.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    AWA Express expenses were reclassed from operating revenues to
    operating expenses. See also Part&nbsp;II, Item&nbsp;8A,
    Note&nbsp;5 &#147;Change in Method of Reporting for America West
    Express Results and Other Reclassifications.&#148;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">

    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The 2005 results include $121&nbsp;million of special charges,
    including $13&nbsp;million of merger related transition
    expenses, a $27&nbsp;million loss on the sale and leaseback of
    six <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT> aircraft
    and two 757&nbsp;aircraft, $7&nbsp;million of power by the hour
    program penalties associated with the return of certain leased
    aircraft and a $50&nbsp;million charge related to an amended
    Airbus purchase agreement, along with the write off of
    $7&nbsp;million in capitalized interest. The Airbus
    restructuring fee was paid by means of set-off against existing
    equipment purchase deposits held by Airbus.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    AWA&#146;s 2004 results include a $16&nbsp;million net credit
    associated with the termination of the rate per engine hour
    agreement with General Electric Engine Services for overhaul
    maintenance services on V2500-A1 engines. This credit was
    partially offset by $2&nbsp;million of net charges related to
    the return of certain Boeing 737-200 aircraft, which includes
    termination payments of $2&nbsp;million, the write-down of
    leasehold improvements and deferred rent of $3&nbsp;million,
    offset by the net reversal of maintenance reserves of
    $3&nbsp;million related to the returned aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    resulting from the elimination of AWA&#146;s hub operations in
    Columbus, Ohio ($11&nbsp;million), the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">reduction-in</FONT>-force of
    certain management, professional and administrative employees
    ($2&nbsp;million) and the impairment of certain owned</TD>
</TR>

    related to the impairment of reorganization value in excess of
    amounts allocable to identifiable assets (&#147;ERV&#148;) and

    a <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">reduction-in</FONT>-force in

    <TD valign="top">
    (b)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Nonoperating income (expense) in the 2005 period includes an
    $8&nbsp;million charge related to the write-off of the
    unamortized value of the ATSB warrants upon their repurchase in
    October 2005 and an aggregate $2&nbsp;million write-off of debt
    issue costs associated with the exchange of the
    7.25%&nbsp;Senior Exchangeable Notes due 2023 and retirement of
    a portion of the loan formerly guaranteed by the ATSB. In the
    fourth quarter 2005 period, US&nbsp;Airways recorded
    $4&nbsp;million of derivative gain attributable to stock options
    in Sabre, and warrants in a number of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">e-commerce</FONT> companies.</TD>

    disposition of property and equipment due principally to the
    sale of one Boeing 737-200 aircraft and a $1&nbsp;million charge
    for the write-off of debt issue costs in connection with the
    refinancing of the term loan.</TD>

    $81&nbsp;million recognized as nonoperating income under the
    Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act and
    $9&nbsp;million and $108&nbsp;million recognized in 2002 and
    2001, respectively, as nonoperating income under the Air
    Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act.</TD>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD valign="top">
    (c)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The 2005 period includes a $202&nbsp;million adjustment which
    represents the cumulative effect on retained earnings of the
    adoption of the direct expense method for accounting for major
    scheduled airframe, engine and certain component overhaul costs
    as of January&nbsp;1, 2005. (See Part&nbsp;II, Item&nbsp;8A,
    Note&nbsp;4 &#147;Change in Accounting Policy for Maintenance
    Costs&#148;).</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The 2002 period includes a $208&nbsp;million adjustment which
    represents the cumulative effect on retained earnings of the
    adoption of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;142, &#147;Goodwill and other
    Intangible Assets&#148; which was issued by the FASB in June
    2001. SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;142 primarily addresses the accounting
    for goodwill and intangible assets subsequent to their
    acquisition. Under SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;142, ERV is reported as
    goodwill and accounted for in the same manner as goodwill.
    SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;142 was effective for fiscal years beginning
    after December&nbsp;15, 2001.</TD>
</TR>

    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>(2,630</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" nowrap>)</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">

    Position&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">90-7,</FONT>

    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    A $392&nbsp;million impairment charge as a result of an
    impairment analysis conducted on the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">B737-300,</FONT>
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">B737-400,</FONT>
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">B757-200</FONT> and
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">B767-200</FONT> aircraft

    accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards
    No.&nbsp;144, &#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of
    Long-Lived Assets,&#148; the carrying values were reduced to
    fair market value.</TD>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

    <TD width="3%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
