    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The results for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 include:</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    An aircraft impairment and related charge of $787&nbsp;million.
    During August 2001, US&nbsp;Airways conducted an impairment
    analysis in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting
    Standards No.&nbsp;121 &#147;Accounting for the Impairment of
    Long-Lived Assets and for Long-Lived Assets to Be Disposed
    Of&#148; (&#147;SFAS&nbsp;121&#148;) on its 36 F-100 aircraft,
    16 MD-80 aircraft and 39&nbsp;B737-200 aircraft as a result of
    changes to the fleet plan as well as indications of possible
    material changes to the market values of these aircraft. The
    analysis revealed that estimated undiscounted future cash flows
    generated by these aircraft were less than their carrying
    values. In accordance with SFAS&nbsp;121, the carrying values
    were reduced to fair market value. This analysis resulted in a
    pretax charge of $403&nbsp;million. In the aftermath of
    September&nbsp;11, 2001, US&nbsp;Airways elected to accelerate
    the retirement of the aforementioned aircraft. All B737-200
    aircraft retirements were accelerated to the end of 2001 while
    the F-100s and MD-80s were scheduled to be retired by April
    2002. Based on this, US&nbsp;Airways conducted another
    impairment analysis which revealed that these aircraft were
    impaired. This culminated in an additional pretax charge of
    $173&nbsp;million largely reflecting the further diminution in
    value of used aircraft arising from the events of
    September&nbsp;11, 2001. Management estimated fair market value
    using third-party appraisals, published sources and recent sales
    and leasing transactions. As a result of the events of
    September&nbsp;11, 2001, US&nbsp;Airways reviewed other
    aircraft-related assets which resulted in a pretax charge of
    $15&nbsp;million as certain aircraft assets had carrying values
    in excess of their fair value less costs to sell. Management
    estimated fair value based on recent sales and leasing
    transactions. US&nbsp;Airways also recognized a pretax charge of
    $26&nbsp;million in connection with the write-down to lower of
    cost or market of surplus parts for the F-100, B737-200 and
    MD-80 fleets. Management estimated market value based on recent
    sales activity related to these parts. During the first quarter
    of 2002, US&nbsp;Airways entered into agreements to sell 97
    surplus aircraft and related spare engines and parts, including
    substantially all its DC-9, MD-80 and B737-200 aircraft. In
    connection with these agreements, US&nbsp;Airways reduced the
    carrying values of these assets resulting in a $148&nbsp;million
    charge during the fourth quarter of 2001, including a
    $138&nbsp;million impairment charge and a charge of
    $10&nbsp;million to write down the related spare parts.
    Additionally, US&nbsp;Airways recognized a pretax impairment
    charge of $22&nbsp;million in connection with the planned
    retirement of five B737-200 aircraft due to a third-party&#146;s
    early return of certain leased B737-200 aircraft, and early
    retirement of certain other B737-200s during the first quarter
    of 2001.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">42

    <TD width="94%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    An $83&nbsp;million charge for employee severance and benefits.
    In September 2001, US&nbsp;Airways announced that in connection
    with its reduced flight schedule it would terminate or furlough
    approximately 11,000 employees across all employee groups.
    Approximately 10,200 of the affected employees were terminated
    or furloughed on or prior to January&nbsp;1, 2002. Substantially
    all the remaining affected employees were terminated or
    furloughed by May 2002. US&nbsp;Airways&#146; headcount
    reduction was largely accomplished through involuntary
    terminations/furloughs. In connection with this headcount
    reduction, US&nbsp;Airways offered a voluntary leave program to
    certain employee groups. Voluntary leave program participants
    generally received extended benefits (e.g. medical, dental, life
    insurance) but did not receive any furlough pay benefit. The
    nine months ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and the year ended
    December&nbsp;31, 2002 include $1&nbsp;million and
    $3&nbsp;million, respectively, in reductions to severance pay
    and benefit accruals related to the involuntary termination or
    furlough of certain employees.</TD>
</TR>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<A name='111'></A>
</DIV>

<!-- link1 "Item 7. Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations" -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>Item&nbsp;7.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial
    Condition and Results of Operations</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Background</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group is a holding company whose primary
business activity, prior to the merger, was the operation of a
major network air carrier through its ownership of the common
stock of US&nbsp;Airways, Piedmont, PSA, Material Services
Company and Airways Assurance Limited. US&nbsp;Airways, along
with a network of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s regional airline
subsidiaries and affiliated carriers flying as US&nbsp;Airways
Express, was a hub-and-spoke carrier with a substantial presence
in the Eastern United States and with service to Canada, the
Caribbean, Latin America and Europe. US&nbsp;Airways had
approximately 42&nbsp;million passengers boarding its planes in
2005 and, prior to the merger, was the seventh largest
U.S.&nbsp;air carrier based on ASMs and RPMs. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways operated 232 jet
aircraft and 18&nbsp;regional jet aircraft. During 2005,
US&nbsp;Airways provided regularly scheduled service or seasonal
service at 91 airports in the continental United States, Canada,
the Caribbean, Latin America and Europe. As of December&nbsp;31,
2005, the US&nbsp;Airways Express network served 130 airports in
the United States, Canada and the Bahamas, including
approximately 39 airports also served by US&nbsp;Airways. During
2005, US&nbsp;Airways Express air carriers had approximately
18.7&nbsp;million passengers boarding their planes, including
1.9&nbsp;million passengers on US&nbsp;Airways&#146; MidAtlantic
division. In 2005, US&nbsp;Airways and US&nbsp;Airways Express
generated passenger revenues of $6.48&nbsp;billion.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
America West Holdings is a holding company whose primary
business activity was the operation of a low-cost air carrier
through its ownership of AWA. AWA accounted for most of America
West Holdings&#146; revenues and expenses prior to the merger in
September 2005. Prior to the merger and based on 2005
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">43

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
operating revenues and ASMs and RPMs, AWA was the eighth largest
passenger airline and the second largest low-cost carrier in the
United States. AWA was the largest low-cost carrier operating a
hub-and-spoke network before the merger, with hubs in both
Phoenix, Arizona and Las Vegas, Nevada. As of December&nbsp;31,
2005, AWA operated a fleet of 141 aircraft and served 64
destinations in North America, including eight in Mexico, two in
Hawaii, four in Canada and one in Costa Rica. In 2005, AWA had
approximately 22&nbsp;million passengers boarding its planes and
generated mainline passenger revenues of approximately
$2.52&nbsp;billion.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;12, 2004, US&nbsp;Airways Group and its
domestic subsidiaries, US&nbsp;Airways, Piedmont, PSA and
Material Services Company, which at the time accounted for
substantially all of the operations of US&nbsp;Airways Group,
filed voluntary petitions for relief under Chapter&nbsp;11 of
the Bankruptcy Code in the United States Bankruptcy Court for
the Eastern District of Virginia, Alexandria Division. On
May&nbsp;19, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group signed a merger
agreement with America West Holdings pursuant to which America
West Holdings merged with a wholly owned subsidiary of
US&nbsp;Airways Group. The merger agreement was amended by a
letter agreement on July&nbsp;7, 2005. The merger became
effective upon US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s emergence from
bankruptcy on September&nbsp;27, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Following the merger, US&nbsp;Airways Group began moving toward
operating under the single brand name of
&#147;US&nbsp;Airways&#148; through its two principal
subsidiaries: US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. US&nbsp;Airways Group
expects to integrate the two principal subsidiaries into one
operation over the first 24&nbsp;months following the merger. As
a result of the merger, US&nbsp;Airways Group, through its two
principal operating subsidiaries, operates the fifth largest
airline in the United States as measured by domestic RPMs and
ASMs. The Company has primary hubs in Charlotte, Philadelphia
and Phoenix and secondary hubs/focus cities in Pittsburgh, Las
Vegas, New York, Washington,&nbsp;D.C. and Boston. The Company
is a low-cost carrier offering scheduled passenger service on
approximately 3,700 flights daily to 233&nbsp;cities in the
U.S., Canada, the Caribbean, Latin America and Europe, making it
the only low-cost carrier with a significant international route
presence. Starting in December 2005, we expanded our route
network to include Hawaii. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005,
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s two principal subsidiaries operate
373 mainline jets and are supported by its regional airline
subsidiaries and affiliates operating as US&nbsp;Airways
Express, which operate approximately 255 regional jets, of which
80 have 70 or more seats, and approximately 107&nbsp;turboprops.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The merger has been accounted for as a reverse acquisition using
the purchase method of accounting. As a result, although the
merger was structured such that America West Holdings became a
wholly owned subsidiary of US&nbsp;Airways Group, America West
Holdings was treated as the acquiring company for accounting
purposes due to the following factors: (1)&nbsp;America West
Holdings&#146; stockholders received the largest share of
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s common stock in the merger in
comparison to unsecured creditors of US&nbsp;Airways Group;
(2)&nbsp;America West Holdings received a larger number of
designees to the board of directors; and (3)&nbsp;America West
Holdings&#146; Chairman and Chief Executive Officer prior to the
merger became the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the
combined company. As a result of the reverse acquisition, the
2005 consolidated statement of operations for the new
US&nbsp;Airways Group presented in this report includes the
results of America West Holdings for the 269&nbsp;days through
September&nbsp;27, 2005 and consolidated results of
US&nbsp;Airways Group for the 96&nbsp;days from
September&nbsp;27, 2006 through December&nbsp;31, 2005. The
results of operations for fiscal years 2004 and 2003 are those
of America West Holdings.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Emergence and Merger Transactions</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>The New Equity Investments</I>&nbsp;&#151; On
September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group received new
equity investments of $565&nbsp;million in the aggregate from
ACE Aviation Holdings Inc. (&#147;ACE&#148;); Par Investment
Partners, L.P. (&#147;Par&#148;); Peninsula Investment Partners,
L.P. (&#147;Peninsula&#148;); a group of investors under the
management of Wellington Management Company, LLP
(&#147;Wellington&#148;); Tudor Proprietary Trading, L.L.C. and
certain investors advised by Tudor Investment Corp.
(collectively referred to as &#147;Tudor&#148;); and Eastshore
Aviation, LLC (&#147;Eastshore&#148;). In connection with the
equity investments, each of the equity investors received an
option to purchase additional shares at $15.00&nbsp;per share.
Par purchased the options granted to ACE and Eastshore, and each
option holder exercised the first two-thirds of its option on
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">44

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
September&nbsp;28, 2005, for aggregate proceeds to
US&nbsp;Airways Group of approximately $75&nbsp;million. On
October&nbsp;13, 2005, each of the equity investors exercised
the remaining portion of its option for aggregate proceeds to
US&nbsp;Airways Group of approximately $38&nbsp;million.
Proceeds from these new equity investments, including the option
exercises, totaled approximately $678&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Public Stock Offering</I>&nbsp;&#151; On September&nbsp;30,
2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group completed a public offering of
common stock in which it issued 9,775,000&nbsp;shares of its
common stock at a price of $19.30&nbsp;per share. The Company
received net proceeds of $180&nbsp;million from the offering.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>GE Merger MOU</I>&nbsp;&#151; US&nbsp;Airways Group and
America West Holdings reached a comprehensive agreement with
GECC and its affiliates as described in the Master Merger
Memorandum of Understanding (the &#147;GE Merger MOU&#148;). The
key aspects of the GE Merger MOU are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Continued use by US&nbsp;Airways Group of certain leased Airbus,
    Boeing and regional jet aircraft, the modification of monthly
    lease rates, and the return to GECC of certain other leased
    Airbus and Boeing aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    GECC provided a bridge facility of approximately
    $56&nbsp;million for use by US&nbsp;Airways Group during the
    pendency of the Chapter&nbsp;11 proceedings. US&nbsp;Airways
    paid an affiliate of GE $125&nbsp;million in cash on
    September&nbsp;30, 2005 in exchange for retirement of the bridge
    facility, forgiveness and release of US&nbsp;Airways from
    certain prepetition obligations, deferral of certain payment
    obligations and amendments to maintenance agreements. The
    payment was funded through the issuance of 7%&nbsp;Senior
    Convertible Notes due 2020 on September&nbsp;30, 2005, as
    discussed in more detail below.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    In June 2005, GECC purchased and immediately leased back to
    US&nbsp;Airways Group: (a)&nbsp;the assets securing the credit
    facility obtained from GE in 2001 and the liquidity facility
    obtained from GE in 2003 in connection with US&nbsp;Airways
    Group&#146;s emergence from the first bankruptcy, and other GE
    obligations, consisting of 11 Airbus aircraft and 28 spare
    engines and engine stands; and (b)&nbsp;ten regional jet
    aircraft previously debt-financed by GECC. The proceeds from the
    sale leaseback transaction of approximately $633&nbsp;million
    were used to pay down balances due to GE by US&nbsp;Airways
    Group under the 2003 GE liquidity facility in full, the GECC
    mortgage-debt financed CRJ aircraft in full, and a portion of
    the 2001 GE credit facility. The 2001 GE credit facility was
    amended to allow certain additional borrowings up to
    $28&nbsp;million.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Airbus MOU</I>&nbsp;&#151; In connection with the merger, a
Memorandum of Understanding was executed between AVSA S.A.R.L.,
an affiliate of Airbus S.A.S. (&#147;Airbus&#148;),
US&nbsp;Airways Group, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. The key aspects
of the Airbus Memorandum of Understanding are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

    <TD width="96%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA entered into
    two loan agreements with Airbus Financial Services, as Initial
    Lender and Loan&nbsp;Agent, Wells Fargo Bank Northwest, National
    Association, as Collateral Agent, and US&nbsp;Airways Group, as
    guarantor, with commitments in initial aggregate amounts of up
    to $161&nbsp;million and up to $89&nbsp;million. The Airbus
    loans bear interest at a rate of LIBOR plus a margin, subject to
    adjustment. In each of the separate financial statements of
    US&nbsp;Airways and AWA, the Airbus loan has also been presented
    as a liability, as each entity is jointly and severally liable
    for this obligation.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Airbus rescheduled US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s A320-family and
    A330-200 delivery commitments and has agreed to provide backstop
    financing for a substantial number of aircraft, subject to
    certain terms and conditions, on an order of 20 A350 aircraft.
    US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s A320-family aircraft are now
    scheduled for delivery in 2009 and 2010. US&nbsp;Airways
    Group&#146;s A330-200 aircraft are scheduled for delivery in
    2009 and 2010 and A350 aircraft deliveries are currently
    scheduled to occur beginning in 2011. The Airbus Memorandum of
    Understanding also eliminates cancellation penalties on
    US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s orders for the ten A330-200
    aircraft, provided that US&nbsp;Airways Group has met certain
    predelivery payment obligations under the A350 order. In
    connection with the restructuring of aircraft firm orders,
    US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West Holdings were required to
    pay an aggregate non-refundable restructuring fee which was paid
    by means of set- off against existing equipment purchase
    deposits of US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West Holdings held
    by</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

    <TD align="left">
    Airbus. US&nbsp;Airways recorded its restructuring fee of
    $39&nbsp;million as a reorganization item in the third quarter
    of 2005. The America West Holdings restructuring fee of
    $50&nbsp;million was recorded as a special charge in the

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Restructuring of the ATSB
Loan&nbsp;Guarantees</I>&nbsp;&#151; US&nbsp;Airways Group and
America West Holdings each had loans outstanding guaranteed
under the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act
by the ATSB. In connection with the September&nbsp;12, 2004
Chapter&nbsp;11 filing, the ATSB and the lenders under the
US&nbsp;Airways ATSB loan agreed to authorize US&nbsp;Airways
Group to continue to use cash collateral securing the
US&nbsp;Airways ATSB loan on an interim basis, which we refer to
as the cash collateral agreement. US&nbsp;Airways reached
agreements with the ATSB concerning interim extensions to the
cash collateral agreement, the last of which was extended to the
earlier of the effective date of the plan of reorganization or
October&nbsp;25, 2005. The cash collateral agreement and
subsequent extensions each required US&nbsp;Airways Group, among
other conditions, to maintain a weekly minimum unrestricted cash
balance which decreased periodically during the term of the
extension.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On July&nbsp;22, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West
Holdings announced that the ATSB approved the proposed merger.
Under the negotiated new loan terms, the US&nbsp;Airways loan is
guaranteed by US&nbsp;Airways Group (including all domestic
subsidiaries, with certain limited exceptions) and is secured by
substantially all of the present and future assets of
US&nbsp;Airways Group not otherwise encumbered, other than
certain specified assets, including assets which are subject to
other financing agreements. The AWA loan is also guaranteed by
US&nbsp;Airways Group (including all domestic subsidiaries, with
certain limited exceptions) and is secured by a second lien in
the same collateral. The loans continue to have separate
repayment schedules and interest rates; however, the loans are
subject to similar repayments and mandatory amortization in the
event of additional debt issuances, with certain limited
exceptions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;19, 2005, $777&nbsp;million of the loans, of
which $752&nbsp;million was guaranteed by the ATSB, was sold by
the lenders by order of the ATSB to 13 fixed income investors.
The sale of the debt removed the ATSB guaranty, and the ATSB no
longer has an interest in any of the Company&#146;s debt. The
total outstanding balance of the loans as of December&nbsp;31,
2005 was $801&nbsp;million, of which $551&nbsp;million is
outstanding under the US&nbsp;Airways loan and $250&nbsp;million
is outstanding under the AWA loan. Terms associated with these
loans remain unchanged, with the AWA loan terminating in 2008
and the US&nbsp;Airways loan terminating in 2010.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The US&nbsp;Airways loan bears interest as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    90% of the US&nbsp;Airways loan (Tranche&nbsp;A), which was the
    portion of the loan previously guaranteed by the ATSB, was
    originally funded through a participating lender&#146;s
    commercial paper conduit program and bears interest at a rate
    equal to the conduit provider&#146;s weighted average cost
    related to the issuance of certain commercial paper notes and
    other short term borrowings plus 0.30%, provided that portions
    of Tranche&nbsp;A that were held by the ATSB or are held by an
    assignee and are no longer subject to such commercial paper
    conduit program bear interest at LIBOR plus 40&nbsp;basis
    points, and portions of Tranche&nbsp;A that are under certain
    circumstances assigned free of the ATSB guarantee bear interest
    at LIBOR plus 6.0%;&nbsp;and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    10% of the US&nbsp;Airways loan (Tranche&nbsp;B) bears interest
    at the greater of the Tranche&nbsp;A interest rate plus 6.0% and
    LIBOR plus 6.0% from a prior rate of LIBOR plus 4.0%.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The US&nbsp;Airways loan also reschedules amortization payments
for US&nbsp;Airways with semi-annual payments beginning on
March&nbsp;31, 2007, and continuing through September&nbsp;30,
2010.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways was required to pay down the principal of its
loan with the first $125&nbsp;million of net proceeds from
specified asset sales identified in connection with its
Chapter&nbsp;11 proceedings, whether completed before or after
emergence from bankruptcy. US&nbsp;Airways then retains the next
$83&nbsp;million of net proceeds from specified asset sales, and
must prepay the principal of loan with 60% of net proceeds in
excess of an aggregate of $208&nbsp;million from specified asset
sales. Any such asset sales proceeds up to $275&nbsp;million are
to be applied in order of maturity, and any such asset sales
proceeds in excess of
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">46

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
$275&nbsp;million are to be applied pro rata across all
maturities in accordance with the loan&#146;s early amortization
provisions. US&nbsp;Airways made prepayments totaling
$156&nbsp;million in connection with these specified asset sales
completed during 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain third party counter-guarantors have fully and
unconditionally guaranteed the payment of an aggregate amount of
$11&nbsp;million of the remaining principal amount of the AWA
loan, plus accrued and unpaid interest thereon, as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005. The AWA loan previously bore interest at
a rate of LIBOR plus 40&nbsp;basis points, with a guarantee fee
equal to 8.0% per annum with annual increases of 5&nbsp;basis
points. As a result of the sale of the AWA loan, the
non-guaranteed portion of the loan is no longer subject to the
annual guarantee fee, but instead bears interest at a rate per
annum equal to LIBOR plus 840&nbsp;basis points, increasing by
5&nbsp;basis points on January 18 of each year, beginning
January&nbsp;18, 2006, through the end of the loan term, payable
on a quarterly basis. The amortization payments under the AWA
loan become due in seven installments of $42&nbsp;million on
each March&nbsp;31 and September&nbsp;30, commencing on
September&nbsp;30, 2005 and ending on September&nbsp;30, 2008.
The AWA loan also requires a premium, in certain instances, for
voluntary prepayments. AWA made a voluntary prepayment of
$9&nbsp;million dollars in principal amount on
September&nbsp;27, 2005, after the closing of the AWA loan,
prepaying in full the portion of the loan subject to one of the
counter-guarantees, which prepayment has been applied pro rata
against each scheduled amortization payment.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The terms of both amended and restated loans require
US&nbsp;Airways Group to meet certain financial covenants,
including minimum cash requirements and required minimum ratios
of earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization
and aircraft rent to fixed charges, starting with the quarter
ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the
Company is in compliance with these covenants.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>New Convertible Notes</I>&nbsp;&#151; On September&nbsp;30,
2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group issued $144&nbsp;million aggregate
principal amount of 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes due 2020
for proceeds, net of expenses, of approximately
$139&nbsp;million. The 7%&nbsp;notes are US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s senior unsecured obligations and rank equally in
right of payment to its other senior unsecured and
unsubordinated indebtedness and are effectively subordinated to
its secured indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets
securing such indebtedness. The 7%&nbsp;notes are fully and
unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally and on a
senior unsecured basis, by US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s two
major operating subsidiaries, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. The
guarantees are the guarantors&#146; unsecured obligations and
rank equally in right of payment to the other senior unsecured
and unsubordinated indebtedness of the guarantors and are
effectively subordinated to the guarantors&#146; secured
indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets securing such
indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Restructuring of Affinity Credit Card Partner
Agreement</I>&nbsp;&#151; In connection with the merger, AWA,
US&nbsp;Airways Group and Juniper Bank, a subsidiary of Barclays
PLC, entered into an agreement on August&nbsp;8, 2005 amending
AWA&#146;s co-branded credit card agreement with Juniper, dated
January&nbsp;25, 2005. Pursuant to the amended credit card
agreement, Juniper agreed to offer and market an airline mileage
award credit card program to the general public to participate
in US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s Dividend Miles program through
the use of a co-branded credit card.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s credit card program is currently
administered by Bank of America, N.A. (USA). On
December&nbsp;28, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways issued a notice of
termination under its agreement with Bank of America and that
notice will become effective on December&nbsp;28, 2007. Pending
termination of the Bank of America agreement, both Juniper and
Bank of America will run separate credit card programs for
US&nbsp;Airways Group. The amended credit card agreement is the
subject of pending litigation filed by Bank of America against
US&nbsp;Airways Group, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. (See also
Part&nbsp;I, Item&nbsp;3, &#147;Legal Proceedings.&#148;)
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The amended credit card agreement took effect at the effective
time of the merger. The credit card services provided by Juniper
under the amended credit card agreement began in January 2006,
and will continue until the expiration date, which is the later
of December&nbsp;31, 2012 or seven years from the date on which
Juniper commences marketing to the general public.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">47

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the amended credit card agreement, Juniper will pay to
US&nbsp;Airways Group fees for each mile awarded to each credit
card account administered by Juniper, subject to certain
exceptions. Juniper also agreed to pay a one-time bonus payment
of $130&nbsp;million, following the effectiveness of the merger,
subject to certain conditions. The bonus payment was made to AWA
on October&nbsp;3, 2005. Juniper will pay an annual bonus of
$5&nbsp;million to US&nbsp;Airways Group, subject to certain
exceptions, for each year after Juniper becomes the exclusive
issuer of the co-branded credit card. If Juniper is not granted
exclusivity to offer a co-branded credit card after the dual
branding period with Bank of America, US&nbsp;Airways Group must
repay the $130&nbsp;million bonus amount and repurchase unused
pre-paid miles with interest, plus $50&nbsp;million in
liquidated damages.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;3, 2005 Juniper pre-paid for miles from
US&nbsp;Airways Group totaling $325&nbsp;million, subject to the
same conditions as apply to the $130&nbsp;million bonus payment.
To the extent that these miles are not used by Juniper as
allowed under the co-branded credit card program in certain
circumstances, US&nbsp;Airways Group will repurchase these miles
in 12 equal quarterly installments beginning on the fifth year
prior to the expiration date of the co-branded credit card
agreement with Juniper, until paid in full. US&nbsp;Airways
Group makes monthly interest payments at LIBOR plus 4.75% to
Juniper, beginning on November&nbsp;1, 2005, based on the amount
of pre-purchased miles that have not been used by Juniper in
connection with the co-branded credit card program and have not
been repurchased by US&nbsp;Airways Group. US&nbsp;Airways Group
will be required to repurchase pre-purchased miles under certain
reductions in the collateral held under the credit card
processing agreement with JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. Accordingly,
the prepayment has been recorded as additional indebtedness in
the consolidated financial statements of AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Juniper requires US&nbsp;Airways Group to maintain an average
quarterly balance of cash, cash equivalents and short-term
investments of at least $1&nbsp;billion for the entirety of the
agreement. Further, the agreement requires US&nbsp;Airways Group
to maintain certain financial ratios beginning January&nbsp;1,
2006. Juniper may, at its option, terminate the amended credit
card agreement, make payments to US&nbsp;Airways Group under the
amended credit card agreement in the form of pre-purchased miles
rather than cash, or require US&nbsp;Airways Group to repurchase
the pre-purchased miles before the fifth year prior to the
expiration date in the event that US&nbsp;Airways Group breaches
its obligations under the amended credit card agreement, or upon
the occurrence of certain events.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Restructuring of Credit Card Processing
Agreement</I>&nbsp;&#151; In connection with the merger, AWA,
JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A.,
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">successor-in</FONT>-interest
to JPMorgan Chase Bank, and Chase Merchant Services, L.L.C.
(collectively, &#147;Chase&#148;), entered into the First
Amendment to the Merchant Services Bankcard Agreement on
August&nbsp;8, 2005. Pursuant to the amended card processing
agreement, Chase will perform authorization, processing and
settlement services for sales on Visa and Mastercard for AWA and
US&nbsp;Airways following the merger. The original card
processing agreement is guaranteed by America West Holdings, and
US&nbsp;Airways Group executed a guaranty of the amended card
processing agreement on the effective date of the merger.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; credit card processing is currently
administered by Bank of America and these processing services
are expected to be transferred to Chase on or before
April&nbsp;25, 2006. US&nbsp;Airways will become a party to the
amended card processing agreement at the time that Chase begins
processing for US&nbsp;Airways.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The amended card processing agreement took effect at the
effective time of the merger and continues until the expiration
of the initial term, which is three years from the effective
date. Upon expiration of the initial term, the amended card
processing agreement will automatically renew for successive
one-year periods pursuant to the terms of the agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the amended card processing agreement, AWA will pay to
Chase fees in connection with card processing services such as
sales authorization, settlement services and customer service.
AWA and US&nbsp;Airways are also required to maintain a reserve
account to secure Chase&#146;s exposure to outstanding air
traffic liability.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">48
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s Emergence from
Bankruptcy</I>&nbsp;&#151; As discussed above under Part&nbsp;I,
Item&nbsp;1 &#147;Business&nbsp;&#151; Pre-merger
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s Second Chapter&nbsp;11 Bankruptcy
Proceedings,&#148; in accordance with the Bankruptcy Code, the
plan of reorganization classified claims into classes according
to their relative seniority and other criteria and provides for
the treatment for each class of claims. Pursuant to the
bankruptcy process, the Debtors&#146; claims agent received
approximately 4,800 timely filed proofs of claims as of the
general bar date totaling approximately $26.4&nbsp;billion in
the aggregate, and approximately 380 proofs of claims timely
filed by governmental entities totaling approximately
$13.4&nbsp;billion in the aggregate. As of December&nbsp;31,
2005, there are $19.6&nbsp;billion of unresolved claims. The
ultimate resolution of certain of the claims asserted against
the Debtors in the Chapter&nbsp;11 cases will be subject to
negotiations, elections and Bankruptcy Court procedures. The
amount of stock ultimately distributed to any particular general
unsecured creditor under the plan of reorganization will depend
on a number of variables, including the value of any claims
filed by that creditor, the aggregate value of all general
unsecured claims and the value of shares of common stock of
US&nbsp;Airways Group in the marketplace at the time of
distribution. The effects of these distributions were reflected
in US&nbsp;Airways&#146; financial statements upon emergence and
will not have any further impact on the results of operations.
The unsecured creditors eligible to receive stock distributions
are expected, in the aggregate, to recover between approximately
3.1% and 17.4% of the value of their claim.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>PBGC Claim</I>&nbsp;&#151; On November&nbsp;12, 2004,
US&nbsp;Airways filed a motion requesting a determination from
the Bankruptcy Court that US&nbsp;Airways satisfied the
financial requirements under section&nbsp;4041(c)(2)(B)(ii)(IV)
of ERISA for a &#147;distress termination&#148; of three
retirement plans and approval of each such plan&#146;s
termination. These plans had aggregate benefit obligations of
$2.71&nbsp;billion and aggregate plan assets of only
$1.76&nbsp;billion as of the plans&#146; termination dates in
January 2005. On January&nbsp;6, 2005, the Bankruptcy Court
entered an order (i)&nbsp;finding that the financial
requirements for a distress termination of the plans had been
met and (ii)&nbsp;approving termination of the plans. The plans
were terminated in January 2005 by agreement between the PBGC
and US&nbsp;Airways, and effective February&nbsp;1, 2005, the
PBGC was appointed trustee for each of the three plans. As a
result of these terminations, the PBGC filed claims against the
Debtors for the unfunded portion of each of the plans. Under the
plan of reorganization, the PBGC received, as treatment for its
claims: (i)&nbsp;cash in the amount of $13,500,000; (ii)&nbsp;an
unsecured promissory note in the principal amount of $10,000,000
issued by US&nbsp;Airways and guaranteed by US&nbsp;Airways
Group, bearing interest at a rate of 6.00%&nbsp;per annum
payable annually in arrears, with the promissory note to be
payable in a single installment on the seventh anniversary of
the effective date of the plan of reorganization; and
(iii)&nbsp;70%, or 4,873,485&nbsp;shares, of common stock of
US&nbsp;Airways Group issued to the unsecured creditors, net of
the shares allocated to ALPA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Agreements with ALPA</I>&nbsp;&#151; On September&nbsp;14,
2005, pre-merger US&nbsp;Airways Group, US&nbsp;Airways, America
West Holdings and AWA reached agreement with the two
ALPA-represented pilot groups at the separate airlines on a
comprehensive Transition Agreement that will govern many
merger-related aspects of the parties&#146; relationships until
there is a single collective bargaining agreement covering all
pilots. Pre-merger US&nbsp;Airways Group and US&nbsp;Airways had
entered into a separate letter of agreement that provided that
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; pilots designated by ALPA would receive
1.25&nbsp;million shares of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock
and options to purchase&nbsp;1.1&nbsp;million shares of
US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock. The 1.25&nbsp;million shares
were drawn from the 8.2&nbsp;million shares initially allocated
to unsecured creditors in the plan of reorganization. The shares
were issued to the pilots in accordance with instructions
provided by ALPA during the fourth quarter of 2005. The options
will be issued according to the following schedule: the first
tranche of 500,000 options was issued on January&nbsp;31, 2006,
a second tranche of 300,000 options will be issued on
January&nbsp;31, 2007, and the third tranche of 300,000 options
will be issued on January&nbsp;31, 2008. The options will have a
term of five years from date of issuance. The exercise price for
each tranche of options will be the average of the closing price
per share of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock as reflected on
the NYSE for the 20 business day period prior to the applicable
option issuance date. The letter of agreement also includes
provisions restricting transfer of the options and governing
anti-dilution. In connection with the negotiation of the
Transition Agreement and the letter of agreement,
US&nbsp;Airways also agreed with ALPA to eliminate an existing
1% pay reduction that would have otherwise applied to all pilots
as a result of a lump sum payment due to pilots recalled from
furlough and further agreed to pay
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">49

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
$500,000 to resolve an outstanding grievance over pay credits
for pilots assigned by US&nbsp;Airways to travel to and from
certain duty assignments.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
While a significant amount of the Debtors&#146; liabilities were
extinguished as a result of the discharge granted upon
confirmation of the plan of reorganization, not all of the
Debtors&#146; liabilities were subject to discharge. The types
of obligations that the Debtors remain responsible for include
those relating to their secured financings, aircraft financings,
certain environmental liabilities, the continuing obligations
arising under contracts and leases assumed by the Debtors and
certain grievances with our labor unions, as well as allowed
administrative claims. Allowed administrative claims consist
primarily of the costs and expenses of administration of the
Chapter&nbsp;11 cases, including the costs of operating the
Debtors&#146; businesses since filing for bankruptcy. The
Debtors received a large number of timely filed administrative
claims, as well as additional claims that were late filed
without permission of the Bankruptcy Court. Included in these
claims, however, are claims for amounts arising in the ordinary
course that have either already been paid, or that are included
in the Debtors&#146; business plan and are expected to be paid
in the ordinary course. Also included are claims that are
duplicative, claims for which the Debtors believe there is no
legal merit for a claim of any status, and claims that the
Debtors believe may be valid as unsecured claims but are not
entitled to administrative claims status. Accordingly, the
Debtors believe that only a very small portion of the claims
filed in response to the bar dates for non-ordinary course
administrative expense claims will actually be allowed in
amounts exceeding the ordinary course expenditures already
contained in the Debtors&#146; business plan. However, there can
be no assurances that the aggregate amount of the claims
ultimately allowed will not be material. To the extent any of
these claims are allowed, they will generally be satisfied in
full.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>2005 Overview</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Merger and Related Synergies</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We believe that US&nbsp;Airways Group has one of the most
competitive cost structures in the airline industry due to cost
cutting measures initiated by both companies over the last three
years. US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s restructuring activities in
its Chapter&nbsp;11 bankruptcy proceedings specifically targeted
cost reductions in four main areas. First, it achieved important
reductions in labor, pension and benefit costs resulting in
ratified collective bargaining agreements, representing over
$2&nbsp;billion of annual cost savings. Second, it put
restructuring initiatives in place to reduce overhead including
reducing management payroll, and re-vamped its schedule to
improve aircraft utilization. Third, it renegotiated various
contractual obligations resulting in lower costs, including
those related to aircraft, real estate and suppliers, and
lowered catering costs. Lastly, US&nbsp;Airways Group
rationalized its fleet through the elimination of older, less
efficient aircraft, the introduction of large regional jet
aircraft with low trip costs to better match capacity with
demand, and the reduction of the number of mainline aircraft
types it operates in order to lower maintenance, inventory and
pilot training costs.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Separately, America West Holdings has also been able to greatly
reduce its operating expenses as a percentage of revenues since
2002. America West Holdings instituted programs to reduce
management payroll, clerical payroll, travel agency based
commissions, incentive programs and override commissions. It
reduced capital expenditures and discretionary expenses, and
lowered catering costs. Other initiatives include increasing
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">point-to</FONT>-point flying
at minimal additional costs using aircraft that would otherwise
be parked at a gate, which increases daily utilization of
aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In addition to cost saving initiatives already undertaken at the
individual companies, we believe the combination of America West
Holdings and US&nbsp;Airways Group may result in significant
annual revenue and cost synergies of approximately
$600&nbsp;million that would have been unachievable without the
merger. These synergies derive from three principal sources.
US&nbsp;Airways Group has reduced its existing fleet so that the
fleet of the combined company suits the expected network.
US&nbsp;Airways Group will be able to schedule the combined
fleet to better match aircraft size with consumer demand. By
scheduling the reduced fleet more efficiently and with the
addition of our new, low-fare service to Hawaii in December
2005, we expect to create approximately $175&nbsp;million in
annual operating synergies. We also expect to
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">50

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
realize annual cost synergies of approximately $250&nbsp;million
by reducing administrative overhead, consolidating our
information technology systems and combining facilities. Cost
synergies are currently tracking ahead of targets as overhead
reductions are substantially in place, our facilities are
largely consolidated, systems integration is progressing and we
are exceeding our original estimates in areas such as insurance
and vendor contract negotiations. Lastly, by becoming one
nationwide, low-cost carrier with a global reach that provides
more choice for consumers and an improved ability to connect, we
expect to realize approximately $175&nbsp;million in additional
annual revenue. While we are optimistic about our programs thus
far, we cannot assure you that we will be able to achieve these
revenue, operating and cost synergies or that they can be
achieved in a timely manner.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group and its subsidiaries currently employ
approximately 36,600 people on a full time equivalent basis. Of
this total, US&nbsp;Airways currently employs approximately
20,100 people while AWA currently employs approximately 12,100
people. After seniority lists have been integrated for each of
the combined airline&#146;s unionized labor groups, we
anticipate that a single labor contract will be applied to each
of those groups.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the merger, US&nbsp;Airways Group negotiated
planned reductions to its existing fleet so that the fleet of
the combined company better matches aircraft size with consumer
demand. As a result of the integration of US&nbsp;Airways and
AWA, US&nbsp;Airways Group is expected to operate a mainline
fleet of approximately 354 aircraft at the end of 2006
(supported by approximately 240 regional jets and approximately
103 turboprops that provide passenger feed into the mainline
system), down from a total of 411 mainline aircraft operated by
the airline prior to the merger. During 2006, US&nbsp;Airways
Group projects removing 22 aircraft and adding five aircraft to
the mainline fleet. In February 2006, US&nbsp;Airways Group took
delivery of two A319&nbsp;aircraft previously ordered by AWA.
Airbus has also agreed to reschedule 30&nbsp;narrow-body
A320-family aircraft deliveries from the 2006 to 2010 period to
the 2009 to 2010 period, which represented the combined
commitment of AWA and US&nbsp;Airways prior to the merger. To
modernize its international product and improve the efficiency
of its international network, the Company will begin accepting
deliveries of A350 aircraft in 2011.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We believe the merger created one of the industry&#146;s most
financially stable airlines with approximately $1.7&nbsp;billion
in new liquidity coming from investments, the offering of
US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock, new cash infusions from
commercial partners, asset sales and the release of currently
restricted cash.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group unrestricted
and restricted cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments
totaled $2.38&nbsp;billion, of which $1.58&nbsp;billion was
unrestricted.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Cost Control</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We remain committed to maintaining a low cost structure, which
we believe is necessary to compete effectively in the airline
industry. Low cost carriers, some of which have cost structures
lower than ours, continue to enter and grow in the markets in
which we operate. In addition, the traditional legacy carriers,
which have competitive advantages including vast route networks,
alliances and generous frequent flyer programs, remain focused
on lowering their respective costs. This includes using the
bankruptcy process to restructure with lower cost structures. In
light of this environment, we continue to focus on minimizing
unnecessary capital expenditures and prudent spending for
discretionary expenses.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">52
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In 2005, AWA&#146;s mainline cost per available seat mile
(&#147;CASM&#148;) was 9.28 cents, which included a
$222&nbsp;million year-over-year increase in fuel expense, as
the average cost per gallon of fuel increased 37.4% in 2005 to
$1.80. US&nbsp;Airways&#146; mainline CASM was 10.80 cents in
2005, which included a $495&nbsp;million year-over-year increase
in fuel expense as the average cost per gallon of fuel increased
58.0% in 2005 to $1.77, while mainline fuel consumption
decreased 4.8% for the same period. In the fourth quarter of
2005, the first full quarter following the effective date of the
merger, AWA&#146;s and US&nbsp;Airways&#146; mainline CASM was
11.20 cents on a combined basis, which included a
$147&nbsp;million quarter-over-quarter increase in fuel expense
as the average cost per gallon of fuel increased 49.9% in the
fourth quarter of 2005 to $2.08. We believe our combined
mainline CASM will remain competitive with the low cost carriers
and among the lowest of the traditional legacy carriers,
particularly as the benefits of our cost synergies are realized.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Revenue Pricing Environment</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The revenue environment improved dramatically during 2005 as
AWA&#146;s mainline passenger revenue per available seat mile
(&#147;PRASM&#148;) increased 13.1% to 8.27 cents from 7.31
cents in 2004. The increase in US&nbsp;Airways&#146; mainline
PRASM was more modest (1.2%), increasing to 9.44 cents in 2005
from 9.33&nbsp;cents in 2004. In the fourth quarter 2005, the
first full quarter following the effectiveness of the merger,
AWA&#146;s and US&nbsp;Airways&#146; mainline PRASM increased to
9.32 cents in the 2005 period from 7.23&nbsp;cents in the 2004
period on a combined basis. The improvement in mainline PRASM
during 2005 was driven by: (1)&nbsp;a reduction in industry
capacity growth, which led to pricing power and yielded growth
for the entire industry; (2)&nbsp;strong leisure demand; and
(3)&nbsp;in the fourth quarter, realization of some of the
synergy benefits from the merger, including the implementation
of a code share agreement between AWA and US&nbsp;Airways that
helped each airline sell more tickets, an improved and combined
frequent flyer program and a rationalized route network that
eliminated capacity on our weakest routes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Customer Service</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We are committed to building a successful combined airline by
taking care of our customers. We believe that our focus on
excellent customer service in every aspect of our operations
including personnel, flight equipment, inflight and ancillary
amenities, on-time performance, flight completion ratios and
baggage handling, will strengthen customer loyalty and affect
new customers. Combined DOT measures as reported by AWA and
US&nbsp;Airways for the years 2005, 2004 and 2003 and for the
fourth quarter of 2005 were as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In January 2006, the combined AWA and US&nbsp;Airways mainline
on-time performance as reported to the DOT was 81.1%, which
placed second among the major U.S.&nbsp;carriers. Customer
complaints for the month of January 2006 (1.28&nbsp;per 100,000
passengers) placed fifth among the major U.S.&nbsp;carriers. The
number of mishandled bags (8.45&nbsp;per 1000 passengers) in
January 2006, while tenth among the major U.S.&nbsp;carriers,
was improved versus the month of December 2005.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">53

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s Results of Operations</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
For 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s operating revenues were
$5.1&nbsp;billion, operating loss was $217&nbsp;million and loss
per common share before cumulative effect of a change in
accounting principle was $10.65 on a loss of $335&nbsp;million.
In 2005, America West Holdings retroactively changed its
accounting policy for certain maintenance costs from the
deferral method to the direct expense method as if that change
occurred January&nbsp;1, 2005. This resulted in a
$202&nbsp;million loss from the cumulative effect of a change in
accounting principle, or $6.41&nbsp;per common share. See
note&nbsp;4, &#147;Change in Accounting Principle for
Maintenance Costs,&#148; to the consolidated financial
statements in Item&nbsp;8A of this report. For 2004, operating
revenues were $2.7&nbsp;billion, operating loss was
$20&nbsp;million and loss per common share was $5.99 on a net
loss of $89&nbsp;million. For 2003, US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
operating revenues were $2.6&nbsp;billion, operating income was
$33&nbsp;million and diluted earnings per common share was $3.07
on net income of $57&nbsp;million. As noted above, the
2005&nbsp;statement of operations presented includes the results
of America West Holdings for the 269&nbsp;days through
September&nbsp;27, 2005, the effective date of the merger, and
the consolidated results of US&nbsp;Airways Group and its
subsidiaries, including US&nbsp;Airways, America West Holdings
and AWA, for the 96&nbsp;days from September&nbsp;27, 2005 to
December&nbsp;31, 2005. The table below shows the consolidated
results of the 96&nbsp;days of US&nbsp;Airways Group and the
operating results of America West Holdings for the 269&nbsp;days
ended September&nbsp;27, 2005 (in millions):
</DIV>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
For 2004 and 2003, the consolidated statements of operations for
US&nbsp;Airways Group reflect only the results of America West
Holdings.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 2005 results included $75&nbsp;million of net gains
associated with AWA&#146;s fuel hedging transactions. This
includes $71&nbsp;million of net realized gains on settled hedge
transactions and $4&nbsp;million of unrealized gains resulting
from the application of
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to</FONT>-market
accounting for changes in the fair value of fuel hedging
instruments. AWA is required to use
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to</FONT>-market
accounting as its fuel hedging instruments do not meet the
requirements for hedge accounting as established by Statement of
Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;133, &#147;Accounting
for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities.&#148; If
these instruments had qualified for hedge accounting treatment,
any unrealized gains or losses, including the $4&nbsp;million
discussed above, would be deferred in other comprehensive
income, a subset of stockholders&#146; equity, until the jet
fuel is purchased and the underlying fuel hedging instrument is
settled. Given the market volatility of jet fuel, the fair value
of these fuel hedging instruments is expected to change until
settled.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 2005 results include $121&nbsp;million of special charges
including $28&nbsp;million of merger related transition
expenses, a $27&nbsp;million loss on the sale and leaseback of
six 737-300 aircraft and two 757 aircraft, $7&nbsp;million of
power by the hour program penalties associated with the return
of certain leased aircraft and a $50&nbsp;million charge related
to the amended Airbus purchase agreement, along with
$7&nbsp;million in capitalized interest. The restructuring fee
was paid by means of set-off against existing equipment purchase
deposits held by Airbus. The 2005 results also included
nonoperating expenses of $8&nbsp;million related to the
write-off of the unamortized value of the ATSB warrants upon
their repurchase in October 2005 and an aggregate
$2&nbsp;million write-off of debt issue costs associated with
the exchange of the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">54

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
7.25%&nbsp;Senior Exchangeable Notes due 2023 and retirement of
a portion of the loan formerly guaranteed by the ATSB.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group did not record an income tax benefit for
the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 as it
currently expects to continue to record a full valuation
allowance on any future tax benefits until it has achieved
several consecutive quarters of profitable results coupled with
an expectation of continued profitability.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 2004 results include a $16&nbsp;million net credit
associated with the termination of the rate per engine hour
agreement with General Electric Engine Services for overhaul
maintenance services on V2500-A1 engines. This credit was
partially offset by $2&nbsp;million of net charges related to
the return of certain Boeing 737-200 aircraft which includes
termination payments of $2&nbsp;million, the write-down of
leasehold improvements and deferred rent of $3&nbsp;million,
offset by the net reversal of maintenance reserves of
$3&nbsp;million related to the returned aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 2004 results also include a $24&nbsp;million net gain on
derivative instruments associated with AWA&#146;s fuel hedging
program. This amount includes $26&nbsp;million of realized gains
on settled hedge transactions and $2&nbsp;million of unrealized
losses resulting from
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to</FONT>-market
accounting for changes in the fair value of AWA&#146;s fuel
hedging instruments. A $6&nbsp;million charge arising from the
resolution of pending litigation, a $5&nbsp;million loss on the
sale and leaseback of two new Airbus aircraft and a
$1&nbsp;million charge for the write-off of debt issue costs in
connection with the refinancing of the term loan were also
recognized in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 2003 results include a nonoperating gain of $81&nbsp;million
related to the federal government assistance received under the
Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act and an
$11&nbsp;million net gain on derivative instruments associated
with AWA&#146;s fuel hedging program. This amount includes
$10&nbsp;million of realized gains on settled hedge transactions
and $1&nbsp;million of unrealized gains resulting from
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to</FONT>-market
accounting for changes in the fair value of AWA&#146;s fuel
hedging instruments. The 2003 results also include a
$10&nbsp;million nonoperating gain on sale of America West
Holdings&#146; investment in Hotwire.com, a $3&nbsp;million
nonoperating gain on sale of America West Holdings&#146;
investment in National Leisure Group (see note&nbsp;13,
&#147;Nonoperating income (expenses)&nbsp;&#151; other,
net&#148; in US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s notes to consolidated
financial statements), an operating gain of $4&nbsp;million
related to the purchase and subsequent exchange of an A320
airframe and a $3&nbsp;million operating gain related to the
settlement of disputed billings under AWA&#146;s frequent flyer
program. These gains were offset in part by $20&nbsp;million of
charges related to the execution of a new labor agreement with
ALPA, net charges of $14&nbsp;million resulting from the
elimination of AWA&#146;s hub operations in Columbus, Ohio
($11&nbsp;million), the
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">reduction-in</FONT>-force of
certain management, professional and administrative employees
($2&nbsp;million) and the impairment of certain owned Boeing
737-200 aircraft that have been grounded ($3&nbsp;million),
offset by a $1&nbsp;million reduction due to a revision of the
estimated costs related to the early termination of certain
aircraft leases and a $1&nbsp;million reduction related to the
revision of estimated costs associated with the sale and
leaseback of certain aircraft. See note&nbsp;7, &#147;Special
charges (credits), net&#148; in US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
notes to consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>AWA&#146;s Results of Operations</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The following discussion provides an analysis of AWA&#146;s
results of operations and reasons for material changes therein
for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">55
