<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA realized operating losses of $120&nbsp;million and
$16&nbsp;million in 2005 and 2004, respectively, as compared to
$37&nbsp;million of operating income in 2003. Loss before income
taxes and cumulative effect of change in accounting principle
was $195&nbsp;million and $85&nbsp;million in 2005 and 2004,
respectively, as compared to income before income taxes and
cumulative effect of change in accounting principle of
$61&nbsp;million in 2003. In 2005, AWA changed its accounting
policy for certain maintenance costs from the deferral method to
the direct expense method as if that change occurred
January&nbsp;1, 2005. This resulted in a $202&nbsp;million loss
from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle.
See note&nbsp;3, &#147;Change in Accounting Principle for
Maintenance Costs,&#148; to the consolidated financial
statements in Item&nbsp;8B of this report.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">56

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA&#146;s 2005 results included $75&nbsp;million of net gains
associated with its fuel hedging transactions. This includes
$71&nbsp;million of net realized gains on settled hedge
transactions and $4&nbsp;million of unrealized gains resulting
from the application of
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to</FONT>-market
accounting for changes in the fair value of fuel hedging
instruments.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 2005 results include $106&nbsp;million of special charges,
including $13&nbsp;million of merger related transition
expenses, a $27&nbsp;million loss on the sale and leaseback of
six 737-300 aircraft and two 757 aircraft, $7&nbsp;million of
power by the hour program penalties associated with the return
of certain leased aircraft and a $50&nbsp;million charge related
to an amended Airbus purchase agreement, along with
$7&nbsp;million in capitalized interest. The Airbus
restructuring fee was paid by means of set-off against existing
equipment purchase deposits held by Airbus. The 2005 results
also included nonoperating expenses of $8&nbsp;million related
to the write-off of the unamortized value of the ATSB warrants
upon their repurchase in October 2005 and an aggregate
$2&nbsp;million write-off of debt issuance costs associated with
the exchange of the 7.25%&nbsp;Senior Exchangeable Notes due
2023 and retirement of a portion of the loan formerly guaranteed
by the ATSB.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA&#146;s 2004 results include a $16&nbsp;million net credit
associated with the termination of the rate per engine hour
agreement with General Electric Engine Services for overhaul
maintenance services on V2500-A1 engines. This credit was
partially offset by $2&nbsp;million of net charges related to
the return of certain Boeing 737-200 aircraft, which includes
termination payments of $2&nbsp;million, the write-down of
leasehold improvements and deferred rent of $3&nbsp;million,
offset by the net reversal of maintenance reserves of
$3&nbsp;million related to the returned aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 2004 results also include a $24&nbsp;million net gain on
derivative instruments associated with AWA&#146;s fuel hedging
program. This amount includes $26&nbsp;million of realized gains
on settled hedge transactions and $2&nbsp;million of unrealized
losses resulting from
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to</FONT>-market
accounting for changes in the fair value of AWA&#146;s fuel
hedging instruments. A $6&nbsp;million charge arising from the
resolution of pending litigation, a $5&nbsp;million loss on the
sale and leaseback of two new Airbus aircraft and a
$1&nbsp;million charge for the write-off of debt issuance costs
in connection with the refinancing of the term loan were also
recognized in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA&#146;s 2003 results include a gain of $81&nbsp;million
related to the federal government assistance received under the
Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act and an
$11&nbsp;million net gain on derivative instruments associated
with its fuel hedging program. This amount includes
$10&nbsp;million of realized gains on settled hedge transactions
and $1&nbsp;million of unrealized gains resulting from
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to</FONT>-market
accounting for changes in the fair value of AWA&#146;s fuel
hedging instruments. The 2003 results also include a
$10&nbsp;million nonoperating gain on the sale of AWA&#146;s
investment in Hotwire.com (see note&nbsp;14, &#147;Nonoperating
Income (Expenses)&nbsp;&#151; Other, Net&#148; to the
consolidated financial statements in Item&nbsp;8B of this
report), an operating gain of $4&nbsp;million related to the
purchase and subsequent exchange of an A320 airframe and a
$3&nbsp;million operating gain related to the settlement of
disputed billings under AWA&#146;s frequent flyer program. These
gains were offset in part by $20&nbsp;million of charges related
to the execution of a new labor agreement with ALPA and net
charges of $14&nbsp;million that resulted from the elimination
of AWA&#146;s hub operations in Columbus, Ohio
($11&nbsp;million), the
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">reduction-in</FONT>-force of
certain management, professional and administrative employees
($2&nbsp;million) and the impairment of certain owned Boeing
737-200 aircraft that have been grounded ($3&nbsp;million),
offset by a $1&nbsp;million reduction due to a revision of the
estimated costs related to the early termination of certain
aircraft leases and a $1&nbsp;million reduction related to the
revision of estimated costs associated with the sale and
leaseback of certain aircraft. See note&nbsp;5, &#147;Special
Charges&#148; to the consolidated financial statements in
Item&nbsp;8B of this report.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">57

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff">
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left: 10px; text-indent: -10px">
    Revenue passenger miles (in millions)(a)</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Revenue passenger mile (&#147;RPM&#148;)&nbsp;&#151; A basic
    measure of sales volume. It is one passenger flown one mile.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Available seat mile (&#147;ASM&#148;)&nbsp;&#151; A basic
    measure of production. It is one seat flown one statute mile.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Load factor&nbsp;&#151; The percentage of available seats that
    are filled with revenue passengers.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Yield&nbsp;&#151; A measure of airline revenue derived by
    dividing passenger revenue by revenue passenger miles and
    expressed in cents per mile.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Passenger revenue per available seat mile
    (&#147;RASM&#148;)&nbsp;&#151; Total passenger revenues divided
    by total available seat miles.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Total revenue per available seat mile&nbsp;&#151; Total
    operating revenues divided by total available seat miles.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (g)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Passenger enplanements&nbsp;&#151; The number of passengers on
    board an aircraft including local, connecting and through
    passengers.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (h)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Average daily aircraft utilization&nbsp;&#151; The average
    number of block hours per day for all aircraft in service.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (i)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Block hours&nbsp;&#151; The hours measured from the moment an
    aircraft first moves under its own power, including taxi time,
    for the purposes of flight until the aircraft is docked at the
    next point of landing and its power is shut down.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (j)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Average stage length&nbsp;&#151; The average of the distances
    flown on each segment of every route.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (k)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Average passenger journey&nbsp;&#151; The average one-way trip
    measured in statute miles for one passenger origination.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">58

for AWA for the applicable years:

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD><TD></TD>

    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD><TD></TD>

    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD><TD></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD><TD></TD>
</TR>

</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>2005 Compared With 2004</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Total operating revenues for 2005 were $3.25&nbsp;billion, an
increase of $507&nbsp;million from 2004. Passenger revenues were
$2.52&nbsp;billion in 2005 compared to $2.20&nbsp;billion in
2004. RPM&#146;s increased 4.0% as mainline capacity, as
measured by ASM&#146;s, increased 1.2%, resulting in a 2.1 point
increase in load factor to 79.5%. This increase in load factor
was achieved with higher passenger yield, which increased 10.1%
to 10.39 cents. As a result, mainline RASM during 2005 increased
13.1% to 8.27 cents from 7.31 cents in 2004, despite a 2.3%
decrease in average stage length.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Express passenger revenues were $512&nbsp;million for 2005, an
increase of $159&nbsp;million from 2004 due to increased flying
by Mesa under its alliance agreement with AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Cargo revenues for 2005 increased $5&nbsp;million, or 17.9%, to
$33&nbsp;million due to higher mail volumes. Other revenues
increased 15.3% from $163&nbsp;million in 2004 to
$188&nbsp;million in 2005 due principally to net revenues
associated with the sale of tour packages by the America West
Vacations division and an increase in ticket change and service
fees.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Total operating expenses were $3.37&nbsp;billion in 2005, an
increase of $611&nbsp;million or 22.1% compared to 2004.
Mainline operating expenses were $2.83&nbsp;billion in 2005, an
increase of $440&nbsp;million from 2004, while ASMs increased
1.2%. Mainline CASM increased 17.0% to 9.28 cents in 2005 from
7.92 cents in 2004. The 2005 period includes $106&nbsp;million
of net special charges, which comprises 0.35 cents of mainline
CASM, as compared to $16&nbsp;million of net special credits in
2004. The increase in CASM during 2005 was due principally to a
37.9% increase in the average fuel price per gallon, offset by
the $75&nbsp;million net gain associated with the fuel hedging
transactions discussed above.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Significant changes in the components of operating expense per
ASM are explained as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft fuel and related tax expense per ASM increased 36.0%
    due primarily to a 37.4% increase in the average price per
    gallon of fuel to $1.80 in 2005 from $1.31 in 2004.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Salaries and related costs per ASM increased 5.8% primarily due
    to a $23&nbsp;million increase in benefit related expenses,
    including $13&nbsp;million in defined contribution plan payments
    that our pilots became eligible for beginning on January&nbsp;1,
    2005, a $5&nbsp;million increase related to self-funded
    disability requirements and higher medical insurance costs of
    $4&nbsp;million. A $9&nbsp;million accrual for employee
    performance bonuses also contributed to the increase.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">59

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft rent expense per ASM increased 6.3% due principally to
    aircraft mix, as previously owned and leased
    Boeing&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT>
    aircraft were retired or returned to aircraft lessors and
    replaced with leased Airbus A320 and A319 aircraft at higher
    monthly lease rates.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft maintenance materials and repair expense per ASM
    increased 24.5% due principally to the change in AWA&#146;s
    accounting policy for certain maintenance costs in 2005
    discussed above. See note&nbsp;3, &#147;Change in Accounting
    Principle for Maintenance Costs,&#148; to the consolidated
    financial statements in Item&nbsp;8B of this report.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Other rent and landing fees per ASM increased 3.8% mainly due to
    higher landing fees ($4&nbsp;million) and airport rents
    ($4&nbsp;million).</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Selling expenses per ASM increased 4.2% due to higher credit
    card fee expenses of $8&nbsp;million and advertising expenses of
    $2&nbsp;million.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Depreciation and amortization expense per ASM decreased 3.6% due
    principally to decreases in amortization expense related to
    computer hardware and software ($3&nbsp;million) and rotable and
    repairable spare parts ($3&nbsp;million) as a result of the 2005
    change in accounting policy for certain maintenance costs
    discussed above.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Other operating expenses per ASM increased 2.3% in 2005.
    Increases in property taxes ($3&nbsp;million), ground handling
    services ($2&nbsp;million), airport guard services
    ($2&nbsp;million) and crew per diem ($2&nbsp;million) during
    2005 were offset in part by lower legal fees ($6&nbsp;million).
    The 2005 period included an $8&nbsp;million aggregate loss
    associated with two aircraft sale-leaseback transactions and a
    $5&nbsp;million accrual for a retroactive billing by the TSA for
    passenger security fees. The 2004 period included a
    $6&nbsp;million charge resulting from the settlement of pending
    litigation and a $5&nbsp;million loss on the sale and leaseback
    of two new aircraft. A $4&nbsp;million gain resulting from the
    settlement of a claim in bankruptcy for amounts earned under an
    executory contract, a $2&nbsp;million gain resulting from the
    settlement of a lawsuit related to certain computer hardware and
    software that had previously been written off, a $2&nbsp;million
    reduction in bad debt expense due to a recovery of a previously
    reserved debt and a $1&nbsp;million volume incentive earned due
    to certain affinity card sales levels meeting certain contract
    thresholds in 2004 also contributed to the year-over-year
    increase.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Express expenses increased 45.7% in 2005 to $545&nbsp;million
from $374&nbsp;million in 2004. Aircraft operating expense for
2005 was $211&nbsp;million, which accounted for $56&nbsp;million
of the year-over-year increase in Express operating expenses.
Aircraft fuel expense was $182&nbsp;million in 2005, which
accounted for $80&nbsp;million of the year-over-year increase.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA had net nonoperating expenses of $75&nbsp;million in 2005 as
compared to $69&nbsp;million in 2004. Interest income increased
$11&nbsp;million to $25&nbsp;million in 2005 due to higher
average cash balances and higher average rates of return on
investments. Interest expense increased $8&nbsp;million or 9.3%
to $94&nbsp;million primarily due to higher average outstanding
debt, due in part to the merger and higher interest rates.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 2005 period included nonoperating expenses of
$8&nbsp;million related to the write-off of the unamortized
value of the ATSB warrants upon their repurchase in October 2005
and an aggregate $2&nbsp;million write-off of debt issuance
costs associated with the exchange of the 7.25%&nbsp;Senior
Exchangeable Notes due 2023 and retirement of a portion of the
loan formerly guaranteed by the ATSB. The 2004 period included a
$1&nbsp;million gain on the disposition of property and
equipment due principally to the sale of two Boeing
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT> aircraft and a
$1&nbsp;million charge for the write-off of debt issuance costs
in connection with the refinancing of the term loan.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>2004 Compared with 2003</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Total operating revenues for 2004 were $2.75&nbsp;billion, an
increase of $176&nbsp;million from 2003. Passenger revenues were
$2.20&nbsp;billion in 2004 compared to $2.12&nbsp;billion in
2003. RPM&#146;s increased 9.6% as capacity as measured by
ASM&#146;s increased 8.1%, resulting in a 1.0 point increase in
load factor to 77.4%. RASM
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">60

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
during 2004 decreased 3.8% to 7.31 cents from 7.60 cents in
2003, despite a 4.7% increase in average stage length, while
yields decreased 5.1% to 9.44 cents.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Express passenger revenues were $353&nbsp;million for 2004, an
increase of $85&nbsp;million from 2003 due to increased flying
by Mesa under its alliance agreement with AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Total operating expenses were $2.76&nbsp;billion in 2004, an
increase of $229&nbsp;million or 9.0% compared to 2003. Mainline
operating expenses were $2.39&nbsp;billion in 2004, an increase
of $142&nbsp;million from 2003, while ASMs increased 8.1%.
Mainline CASM decreased 1.7% to 7.92 cents in 2004 from 8.07
cents in 2003, despite a 36.5% increase in the average fuel
price per gallon. The 2004 period includes $16&nbsp;million of
net special credits, which reduced 2004 mainline CASM by 0.05
cents, as compared to $14&nbsp;million of net special charges in
2003, which increased mainline CASM by 0.06 cents. Significant
changes in the components of operating expense per ASM are
explained as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft fuel and related tax expense per ASM increased 35.0%
    due primarily to a 36.5% increase in the average price per
    gallon of fuel to $1.31 in 2004 from $0.96 in 2003.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Salaries and related costs per ASM decreased 7.9% due to
    increased productivity. ASMs increased 8.1% in 2004, while
    average full-time equivalent employees decreased 2.2% year-over
    year. This increase in productivity was offset in part by a
    $27&nbsp;million increase in pilot payroll expense, principally
    as a result of the new labor agreement with ALPA that was
    effective December&nbsp;30, 2003.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft rent expense per ASM decreased 5.4% due to the 7.9%
    increase in aircraft utilization.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft maintenance materials and repair expense per ASM
    decreased 14.8% due to decreases in capitalized maintenance
    amortization expense ($23&nbsp;million) and aircraft maintenance
    expense ($4&nbsp;million). The decrease in capitalized
    maintenance amortization expense was driven by changes in the
    estimated useful life of certain engines, effective
    January&nbsp;1, 2004, as a result of changes in aircraft
    utilization ($9&nbsp;million) and certain aircraft engine
    overhaul costs, effective April&nbsp;1, 2003, driven by a new
    maintenance agreement that guarantees minimum cycles on engine
    overhauls ($2&nbsp;million). These decreases were partially
    offset by increases in airframe maintenance ($6&nbsp;million)
    and engine overhaul ($4&nbsp;million) expenses.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Other rents and landing fees expense per ASM remained flat year
    over year as increases in airport rents ($7&nbsp;million) and
    landing fees ($6&nbsp;million) were offset by the 8.1% increase
    in ASMs.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Selling expenses per ASM decreased 9.2% due to reductions in
    various travel agency incentive programs and override
    commissions ($9&nbsp;million) and decreases in advertising
    expenses ($1&nbsp;million), which were offset in part by higher
    credit card expenses ($4&nbsp;million), and reservation system
    booking fees ($4&nbsp;million).</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Depreciation and amortization expense per ASM decreased 24.8%
    due to lower computer hardware and software amortization
    ($6&nbsp;million) as a result of AWA&#146;s cash conservation
    program, which reduced capital expenditures, and lower
    amortization on aircraft leasehold improvements
    ($2&nbsp;million). The change in the estimated useful life
    resulting from changes in aircraft utilization discussed above
    contributed to the decrease in depreciation for improvements on
    AWA&#146;s owned aircraft ($3&nbsp;million) and rotable and
    repairable spare parts ($2&nbsp;million).</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Other operating expenses per ASM decreased 2.5% in 2004.
    Decreases in catering costs ($6&nbsp;million), bad debt expense
    ($3&nbsp;million) and traffic liability insurance
    ($2&nbsp;million) were offset by increases in passenger traffic
    related expenses ($4&nbsp;million), legal fees
    ($4&nbsp;million), airport guard services ($2&nbsp;million) and
    ground handling expenses ($2&nbsp;million). The 2004 period
    included a $6&nbsp;million charge resulting from the settlement
    of pending litigation and a $5&nbsp;million loss on the sale and
    leaseback of two new aircraft. A $4&nbsp;million gain resulting
    from the settlement of a claim in bankruptcy for amounts earned
    under an executory contract, a $2&nbsp;million gain resulting
    from the settlement of a lawsuit related to certain computer
    hardware and software that had previously been written off, a
    $2&nbsp;million reduction in bad debt expense due to a recovery
    of a previously reserved</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">61

    debt and a $1&nbsp;million volume incentive earned due to

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Express expenses increased 30.3% in 2004 to $374&nbsp;million
from $287&nbsp;million in 2003. Aircraft operating expense for
2004 was $155&nbsp;million, which accounted for $24&nbsp;million
of the year-over-year increase in Express operating expenses.
Aircraft fuel expense was $102&nbsp;million in 2004, which
accounted for an additional $41&nbsp;million of the
year-over-year increase.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA had net nonoperating expense of $69&nbsp;million in 2004
compared to net nonoperating income of $24&nbsp;million in 2003.
The 2003 period benefited from $81&nbsp;million of federal
government assistance received under the Emergency Wartime
Supplemental Appropriations Act to provide certain
aviation-related assistance. (See note&nbsp;14,
&#147;Nonoperating Income (Expenses)&nbsp;&#151; Other,
Net&#148; to the consolidated financial statements in
Item&nbsp;8B of this report.) Interest income and interest
expense were relatively flat year-over-year.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 2004 period included a $1&nbsp;million gain on the
disposition of property and equipment due principally to the
sale of two Boeing 737-200 aircraft and a $1&nbsp;million charge
for the write-off of debt issuance costs in connection with the
refinancing of the term loan. The 2003 period included a
$10&nbsp;million gain related to the sale of an investment in
Hotwire.com. (See note&nbsp;14, &#147;Nonoperating Income
(Expenses)&nbsp;&#151; Other, Net&#148; to the consolidated
financial statements in Item&nbsp;8B of this report)
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways&#146; Results of Operations</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with emergence from the first bankruptcy in March
2003 and the second bankruptcy in September 2005,
US&nbsp;Airways adopted fresh-start reporting in accordance with
AICPA Statement of
Position&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">90-7,</FONT>
&#147;Financial Reporting by Entities in Reorganization Under
the Bankruptcy Code.&#148; As a result of the application of
fresh-start reporting, the financial statements prior to
March&nbsp;31, 2003 are not comparable with the financial
statements for the period April&nbsp;1, 2003 to
September&nbsp;30, 2005, nor is either period comparable to
periods after September&nbsp;30, 2005. However, for purposes of
discussion of the results of operations, full year 2005 has been
compared to 2004 and 2004 has been compared to full year 2003,
as presented in the table below. While the effective date of the
plan of reorganization and the merger was September&nbsp;27,
2005, the results of operations for US&nbsp;Airways during the
four day period from September&nbsp;27 through
September&nbsp;30, 2005 are not material to the financial
statement presentation. References to &#147;Successor
Company&#148; refer to US&nbsp;Airways on or after
September&nbsp;30, 2005, after giving effect to the application
of fresh start reporting for the second bankruptcy. References
to &#147;Predecessor Company&#148; refer to US&nbsp;Airways
prior to September&nbsp;30, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>US AIRWAYS, INC.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>

    <TD valign="top">
    (a)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The full year 2005 includes the combined results for the three
    months ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 (Successor Company) and the
    nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005 (Predecessor Company).</TD>

    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD valign="top">
    (b)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The full year 2003 includes the combined results for the nine
    months ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and the three months ended
    March&nbsp;31, 2003. US&nbsp;Airways emerged from the first
    bankruptcy effective March&nbsp;31, 2003.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
For the full year 2005, US&nbsp;Airways&#146; operating revenues
were $7.21&nbsp;billion, operating loss was $213&nbsp;million
and the net income was $160&nbsp;million. Operating revenues in
2004 were $7.07&nbsp;billion, operating loss was
$348&nbsp;million and the net loss was $578&nbsp;million.
Operating revenues for full year 2003 were $6.76&nbsp;billion,
operating loss was $244&nbsp;million and net income was
$1.45&nbsp;billion. US&nbsp;Airways&#146; results from
operations and the net income (loss) in 2005, 2004 and 2003 were
significantly impacted by the first and second bankruptcy
proceedings and the 2005 operating results also reflect the
impact of the merger with America West Holdings.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">63

</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>2005 Compared With 2004</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Total operating revenues for 2005 were $7.21&nbsp;billion, as
compared to $7.07&nbsp;billion in 2004, an increase of 2.0%.
Passenger revenue in the early part of 2005 was negatively
impacted by US&nbsp;Airways&#146; bankruptcy proceedings.
Mainline passenger revenues declined $108&nbsp;million, or 2.2%,
as compared to 2004 due to a 2.7% decrease in RPMs that reduced
revenue by $134&nbsp;million, partially offset by an increase in
rate, or yield, which increased revenue by $26&nbsp;million.
ASMs decreased in 2005 by 3.2%, resulting in an increase in load
factor from 75.1% to 75.5% and a PRASM increase of 1.2% from
9.33 cents to 9.44 cents.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Express passenger revenues were $1.62&nbsp;billion in 2005, an
increase of $241&nbsp;million, or 17.5%, from 2004 due to an
increase in RPMs, which increased revenue by $408&nbsp;million,
partially offset by a decrease in yield, which reduced revenue
by $167&nbsp;million. US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned
subsidiaries and US&nbsp;Airways&#146; MidAtlantic division,
which began service in April 2004, increased RPMs by 66.4% as
compared to 2004, and RPMs flown by affiliate carriers increased
4.0%. The yield for US&nbsp;Airways Express operations decreased
9.4% as compared to 2004 due to longer stage length and the
deployment of regional jets into mainline markets.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Cargo revenues decreased $37&nbsp;million in 2005 primarily due
to lower volume. Other revenues increased 7.3% in 2005 primarily
due to revenue generated through airline partner travel after
US&nbsp;Airways joined the Star Alliance in May 2004 and an
increase in marketing revenue related to miles sold to credit
card and other partners.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Total operating expenses for full year 2005 were
$7.43&nbsp;billion, an increase of $4&nbsp;million, or 0.1%,
compared to 2004. Mainline operating expenses were
$5.56&nbsp;billion for full year 2005, a decrease of
$285&nbsp;million as compared to 2004. Mainline cost per
available seat mile (mainline CASM) decreased 1.7% to 10.80
cents in 2005 from 10.99 cents in 2004. The 2005 results include
special charges of $15&nbsp;million, which comprised 0.03 cents
of mainline CASM for the period. The decrease in CASM was due to
cost reductions achieved as a result of the bankruptcy
proceedings, primarily related to salaries and related costs,
partially offset by increases in aircraft fuel and related taxes.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">64

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" nowrap>)</TD>
</TR>

    <TD align="left" valign="top">

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Significant changes in the components of mainline CASM are
explained as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft fuel and related tax expense per ASM increased 55.4%
    primarily due to a 58.0% increase in the average price per
    gallon of fuel from $1.12 in 2004 to $1.77 in 2005, partially
    offset by a 4.8% decrease in consumption.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Salaries and related costs per ASM decreased 33.2% primarily due
    to lower wage and benefits rates as a result of the cost-savings
    agreements achieved with each of the collective bargaining
    groups, including the termination of defined benefit pension
    plans and the curtailment of postretirement benefits, as well as
    lower headcount as compared to the same period in 2004.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft rent expense per ASM increased 1.3% reflecting a shift
    in the mix of leased to owned aircraft in 2005 as compared to
    2004.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft maintenance per ASM increased 16.1% reflecting the
    shift to outside vendors to perform scheduled maintenance,
    partially offsetting the decrease in salaries and related costs
    described above.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Other rent and landing fees per ASM decreased 4.1% primarily due
    to space rent reductions negotiated during the bankruptcy
    proceedings.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Selling expenses per ASM decreased 7.4% primarily due to
    reduction in travel agent commissions and the termination of
    certain marketing contracts and reductions in advertising
    programs as a result of the bankruptcy.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    US&nbsp;Airways recorded $15&nbsp;million of special charges in
    the fourth quarter of 2005 related to transition and integration
    costs associated with the merger. See note&nbsp;4 to
    US&nbsp;Airways&#146; financial statements included in
    Item&nbsp;8C of this report.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Depreciation and amortization decreased 9.8%&nbsp;per ASM as a
    result of fewer owned aircraft in the operating fleet and lower
    book values on the continuing fleet as a result of fresh-start
    reporting.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Other operating expenses increased primarily as a result of
    increases to expenses associated with the redemption of Dividend
    Miles on partner airlines and future travel on US&nbsp;Airways
    as well as increases in costs associated with outsourced
    aircraft cleaning services. These increases were partially
    offset by decreases in insurance expense, outsourced technology
    services and schedule-related costs including passenger food
    expenses.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Express expenses are comprised of expenses associated with
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; MidAtlantic division, US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s wholly owned regional airlines and affiliate
regional airlines operating as US&nbsp;Airways Express. Express
expenses increased 18.4% to $1.86&nbsp;billion in 2005 as
compared to 2004, reflecting a
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">65

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
14.8% increase in purchased ASMs, and increased flying by
MidAtlantic in 2005 and as a result of higher fuel prices that
are paid by US&nbsp;Airways for US&nbsp;Airways Express
operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways had net nonoperating income of $371&nbsp;million
in 2005 compared to nonoperating expense of $237&nbsp;million in
2004. The change in nonoperating income (expense) is primarily a
result of the reorganization items representing amounts incurred
as a direct result of the Chapter&nbsp;11 proceedings. See the
description below for additional information on the components
of reorganization items. Interest income increased
$14&nbsp;million in 2005 as compared to 2004 due to higher cash
balances, principally in the fourth quarter of 2005, and higher
average interest rates on cash, cash equivalents and short-term
investments. Interest expenses increased $51&nbsp;million as a
result of increased interest expense on the loan formerly
guaranteed by the ATSB, including penalty interest incurred as a
result of the bankruptcy proceedings and interest associated
with new regional jets. Other, net expense in 2005 was
$4&nbsp;million, as compared to a gain of $19&nbsp;million in
2004, due to foreign exchange losses in 2005 and unfavorable
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to</FONT>-market
adjustments on certain stock options held by US&nbsp;Airways as
compared to 2004. Other, net in 2004 also includes
$13&nbsp;million related to a business interruption insurance
recovery and a $2&nbsp;million gain on the sale of four aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>2004 Compared With 2003</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Total operating revenues for 2004 were $7.07&nbsp;billion, as
compared to $6.76&nbsp;billion in 2003, an increase of 4.6%.
Mainline passenger revenues increased $26&nbsp;million, or 0.5%,
as compared to 2003 due to a 5.8% increase in RPMs that
increased revenue by $284&nbsp;million, partially offset by an
decrease in yield, which reduced revenue by $258&nbsp;million.
ASMs increased in 2004 by 3.2%, resulting in an increase in load
factor from 73.3% to 75.1% but a decrease in PRASM of 2.6% to
9.33 cents from 9.58 cents in 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Express passenger revenues were $1.38&nbsp;billion in 2004, an
increase of $171&nbsp;million, or 14.2%, from 2003 due to an
increase in RPMs, which increased revenue by $454&nbsp;million,
partially offset by a decrease in yield, which decreased revenue
by $283&nbsp;million. US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned
subsidiaries and US&nbsp;Airways&#146; MidAtlantic division
increased RPMs by 61.8% as compared to 2004 and RPMs flown by
affiliate carriers increased 24.6%. Yield on US&nbsp;Airways
Express decreased 17.0%.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Cargo revenues were flat in 2004 as compared to 2003. Other
revenues increased 23.8% from 2003 to 2004 as a result of an
increase in service fee revenue from the wholly owned airline
subsidiaries of US&nbsp;Airways Group and affiliate carriers and
from revenue associated with certain marketing arrangements,
including revenue generated through airline partner travel after
US&nbsp;Airways joined the Star Alliance in May 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Total operating expenses for 2004 were $7.42&nbsp;billion, an
increase of $415&nbsp;million, or 5.9%, compared to full year
2003. Mainline operating expenses were $5.85&nbsp;billion for
2004, an increase of $113&nbsp;million, or 1.2%, as compared to
full year 2003 on a capacity increase, measured by ASMs, of
3.2%. Mainline CASM decreased 1.2% to 10.99 cents in 2004 from
11.12 cents in 2003. The 2003 results include special charges of
$34&nbsp;million, which comprises 0.07 cents of mainline CASM
for the period, and government compensation of
$212&nbsp;million, which reduced mainline CASM by 0.41 cents.
The decrease in CASM was due to cost reductions achieved in the
fourth quarter of 2004 as a result of the bankruptcy filing
related to salaries and related costs, partially offset by
increases in aircraft fuel and related taxes.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">66

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>(3.0</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" nowrap>)</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>10.99</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>11.12</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Significant changes in the components of mainline CASM are
explained as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft fuel and related tax expense per ASM increased 24.8%
    primarily due to a 27.3% increase in the average price per
    gallon of fuel from $0.88 in 2003 to $1.12 in 2004.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Salaries and related costs per ASM decreased 12.8% primarily due
    to lower employee pension, medical and dental and postretirement
    medical benefit expense, and an $89&nbsp;million decrease in
    stock-compensation expense related to the issuance of
    US&nbsp;Airways Group Class&nbsp;A common stock to employees
    covered by collective bargaining agreements following the
    emergence from the first bankruptcy in 2003, reduced headcount
    in 2004 as compared to 2003, and lower wage rates in the fourth
    quarter of 2004 as a result of interim or permanent relief from
    labor contracts.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft rent expense per ASM decreased 2.6% due to increases in
    mainline stage length while total aircraft rent remained flat
    from 2004 as compared to full year 2003.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft maintenance per ASM decreased 9.7% reflecting lower
    costs associated with third-party engine and airframe repair
    services and the write-off of certain surplus inventory in the
    second quarter of 2003.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Selling expenses per ASM decreased 6.8% primarily due to
    reduction in commissions, partially offset by increases in
    advertising and computer reservations fees.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    US&nbsp;Airways recorded $34&nbsp;million of special charges in
    2003 primarily related to aircraft order cancellation penalties.
    See note&nbsp;4 to US&nbsp;Airways&#146; financial statements in
    Item&nbsp;8C of this report.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Depreciation and amortization per ASM decreased 2.4% due to
    lower book values on the existing fleet as a result of
    fresh-start reporting effective March&nbsp;31, 2003 and due to
    reduced amortization associated with capitalized software,
    partially offset by the write-off of certain ground equipment
    and an indefinite lived foreign slot.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Other operating expenses per ASM decreased due to reductions in
    insurance expense and schedule-related expenses including
    passenger food expenses, partially offset by increases in the
    cost associated with the redemption of Dividend Miles for travel
    on partner airlines and future travel on US&nbsp;Airways as well
    as increases in to costs associated with passenger and baggage
    screening and navigation fees. The 2003 period also includes
    $28&nbsp;million in reductions to an accrual upon the resolution
    of previously outstanding contingencies.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Express expenses increased $303&nbsp;million, or 23.9%, in 2004
as compared to 2003. This increase reflects a 24.7% increase in
Express ASMs, including a 12.7% increase in purchased ASMs, the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">67

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
introduction of MidAtlantic service in April 2004 and higher
fuel prices that are paid by US&nbsp;Airways for US&nbsp;Airways
Express operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways had a net nonoperating loss of $237&nbsp;million
in 2004 compared to nonoperating income of $1.70&nbsp;billion in
2003. The change in nonoperating income (expense) is primarily a
result of the reorganization items representing amounts incurred
as a direct result of the Chapter&nbsp;11 proceedings related to
the first bankruptcy. See the description below for additional
information on the components of reorganizations items. Interest
income decreased $5&nbsp;million in 2004 as compared to 2003 as
a result of the reclassification of $4&nbsp;million of interest
income to reorganization item following the second bankruptcy
filing in September 2004. Interest expenses decreased
$1&nbsp;million as a result of the conversion of mortgaged
aircraft to leased aircraft and the abandonment of certain
aircraft in the first bankruptcy, offset by interest on the
US&nbsp;Airways loan formerly guaranteed by the ATSB and penalty
interest incurred as a result of the second bankruptcy filing.
Other, net in 2004 includes $13&nbsp;million related to a
business interruption insurance recovery and a $2&nbsp;million
gain on the sale of four aircraft, while the 2004 results
reflect a $30&nbsp;million gain recognized in connection with
the sale of US&nbsp;Airways&#146; investment in Hotwire, Inc.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Description of Reorganization items</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Reorganization items, net represent amounts incurred as a direct
result of US&nbsp;Airways&#146; Chapter&nbsp;11 filings and are
presented separately in the statements of operations. Such items
consist of the following (in millions):
</DIV>

</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(a)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    In January 2005, the Bankruptcy Court approved settlement
    agreements between US&nbsp;Airways and its unions and the
    court-appointed Section&nbsp;1114 Committee, representing
    retirees other than those represented by the IAM and TWU, to
    begin the significant curtailment of postretirement medical
    benefits. US&nbsp;Airways recognized a gain of $183&nbsp;million
    in connection with this curtailment in the first quarter of
    2005. Upon the emergence from bankruptcy and effectiveness of
    the plan of reorganization, an additional gain of
    $1.24&nbsp;billion was recognized as the liability associated
    with the postretirement medical benefits was reduced to fair
    market value. See also Note&nbsp;7 to US&nbsp;Airways&#146;
    financial statements included in Item&nbsp;8C of this report.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">68

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Also in January 2005, US&nbsp;Airways terminated three defined
    benefit plans related to the flight attendants, mechanics and
    certain other employees (see note&nbsp;7 to
    US&nbsp;Airways&#146; financial statements included in
    Item&nbsp;8C of this report). The PBGC was appointed trustee of
    the plans upon termination. US&nbsp;Airways recognized a
    curtailment gain of $24&nbsp;million and a $91&nbsp;million
    minimum pension liability adjustment in connection with the
    terminations in the first quarter of 2005. Upon the effective
    date of the plan of reorganization and in connection with the
    settlement with the PBGC, the remaining liabilities associated
    with these plans were written off, net of settlement amounts.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Effective March&nbsp;31, 2003, US&nbsp;Airways terminated its
    qualified and nonqualified pilot defined benefit pension plans.
    The PBGC was appointed trustee of the qualified plan effective
    with the termination. US&nbsp;Airways recognized a gain in
    connection with the termination which is partially offset by the
    estimate of the PBGC claim.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Reflects the discharge of trade accounts payable and other
    liabilities upon emergence from bankruptcy. Most of these
    obligations were only entitled to receive such distributions of
    cash and common stock as provided for under the plan of
    reorganization in each of the bankruptcies. A portion of the
    liabilities subject to compromise in the bankruptcies were
    restructured and continued, as restructured, to be liabilities
    of the Successor Company.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    As a result of US&nbsp;Airways&#146; bankruptcy filing in
    September 2004, US&nbsp;Airways was not able to secure the
    financing necessary to take on-time delivery of three scheduled
    regional jet aircraft and therefore accrued penalties of
    $3&nbsp;million until delivery of these aircraft was made to a
    US&nbsp;Airways Express affiliate in August 2005. Offsetting
    these penalties is the reversal of $33&nbsp;million in penalties
    recorded by US&nbsp;Airways in the nine months ended
    December&nbsp;31, 2003 due to its intention not to take delivery
    of certain aircraft scheduled for future delivery. In connection
    with the Airbus MOU, the accrual for these penalties were
    reversed (see also notes&nbsp;1 and 4 to US&nbsp;Airways&#146;
    financial statements included in Item&nbsp;8C of this report).</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    As the result of US&nbsp;Airways&#146; bankruptcy filing in
    September 2004, it failed to meet the conditions precedent for
    continued financing of regional jets and was not able to take
    delivery of scheduled aircraft and therefore incurred penalties
    of $7&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter of 2004.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Damage and deficiency claims are largely a result of
    US&nbsp;Airways&#146; election to either restructure, abandon or
    reject aircraft debt and leases during the bankruptcy
    proceedings. As a result of the confirmation of the plan of
    reorganization and the effectiveness of the merger, these claims
    were withdrawn and the accruals reversed.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways recorded
    $1.5&nbsp;billion of adjustments to reflect assets and
    liabilities at fair value, including an initial net write-down
    of goodwill of $1.82&nbsp;billion. Goodwill of $584&nbsp;million
    was recorded to reflect the excess of the estimated fair value
    of liabilities and equity over identifiable assets. Subsequent
    to September&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways recorded an
    additional $148&nbsp;million of goodwill to reflect adjustments
    to the fair value of certain assets and liabilities.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    As of March&nbsp;31, 2003, US&nbsp;Airways recorded
    $1.11&nbsp;billion of adjustments to reflect assets and
    liabilities at fair value (including a $1.12&nbsp;billion
    liability increase related to the revaluation of
    US&nbsp;Airways&#146; remaining defined benefit pension plans
    and postretirement benefit plans and a $333&nbsp;million
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">write-up</FONT> of gates,
    slots and routes) and the write-off of the Predecessor
    Company&#146;s equity accounts. In addition, goodwill of
    $2.41&nbsp;billion was recorded to reflect the excess of the
    estimated fair value of liabilities and equity over identifiable
    assets.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Subsequent to March&nbsp;31, 2003, US&nbsp;Airways recorded an
    additional $62&nbsp;million of adjustments to reflect assets and
    liabilities at fair value, including a $281&nbsp;million
    decrease to property and equipment, net, a $121&nbsp;million
    decrease to long-term debt, net of current maturities, a
    $13&nbsp;million increase to deferred gains and credits, net, a
    $54&nbsp;million increase to other intangibles, net, a
    $15&nbsp;million decrease to employee benefit liabilities and
    other and a $6&nbsp;million decrease to accounts payable. In
    addition, a $6&nbsp;million adjustment was made to paid-in
    capital reflecting a reallocation of US&nbsp;Airways Group
    equity as a result of additional fair value adjustments to
    assets at certain US&nbsp;Airways Group subsidiaries other than
    US&nbsp;Airways.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

    <TD width="96%"></TD>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (g)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with filing for bankruptcy on September&nbsp;12,
    2004, US&nbsp;Airways achieved cost-savings agreements with its
    principal collective bargaining groups. In connection with the
    new labor agreements, approximately 5,000 employees across
    several of US&nbsp;Airways&#146; labor groups were involuntarily
    terminated or participated in voluntary furlough and termination
    programs.</TD>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (h)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with the Airbus&nbsp;MOU, US&nbsp;Airways was
    required to pay a restructuring fee of $39&nbsp;million, which
    was paid by means of offset against existing equipment deposits
    held by Airbus. US&nbsp;Airways also received credits from
    Airbus totaling $4&nbsp;million in 2005, primarily related to
    equipment deposits. See also Note&nbsp;1 to
    US&nbsp;Airways&#146; financial statements included in
    Item&nbsp;8C of this report.</TD>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (i)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The GE Merger MOU provided for the continued use of certain
    leased Airbus, Boeing and regional jet aircraft, the
    modification of monthly lease rates and the return of certain
    other leased Airbus and Boeing aircraft. The GE Merger MOU also
    provided for the sale-leaseback of assets securing various GE
    obligations. In connection with these transactions,
    US&nbsp;Airways recorded a net loss of $5&nbsp;million.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with the first bankruptcy, US&nbsp;Airways
    restructured aircraft debt and lease agreements related to 119
    aircraft including the conversion of 52 mortgages to operating
    leases. The restructured terms generally provide for shorter
    lease periods and lower lease rates.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">

    items includes expenses related to seven aircraft that were
    legally abandoned as part of the first bankruptcy. Related
    aircraft liabilities were adjusted for each aircraft&#146;s
    expected allowed collateral value.</TD>
</TR>
