<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Liquidity and Capital Resources</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Sources and Uses of Cash</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>US&nbsp;Airways Group</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s cash,
cash equivalents, short-term investments and restricted cash
were $2.38&nbsp;billion, of which $1.58&nbsp;billion was
unrestricted. The merger of US&nbsp;Airways Group and America
West Holdings resulted in more than $1.7&nbsp;billion in new
liquidity from equity investments, a common stock offering, a
convertible debt offering, cash infusions from commercial
partners and asset-based financings. US&nbsp;Airways Group has
the ability to move funds freely between operating subsidiaries
to support operations. These transfers are recognized as
intercompany transactions. The Company believes that cash flows
from operating activities, combined with cash balances and
financing commitments, will be adequate to fund operating and
capital needs as well as to maintain compliance with its various
debt arrangements through the end of 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As discussed above in &#147;Emergence and Merger
Transactions,&#148; obtaining additional financing and liquidity
to fund operations was critical to US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
emergence from bankruptcy and merger with America West Holdings.
Several new equity investors provided an aggregate of
$565&nbsp;million of initial equity investments, and exercised
the full amount of options they held for additional equity of
$113&nbsp;million. The public stock offering completed on
September&nbsp;30, 2005 provided an additional $180&nbsp;million
in net proceeds, and the convertible notes offering completed on
September&nbsp;30, 2005 provided an additional $139&nbsp;million
in net proceeds. In addition, US&nbsp;Airways Group has received
over $700&nbsp;million of cash infusions from commercial
partners, including approximately $455&nbsp;million from an
affinity credit card partner received in October 2005 and a
$250&nbsp;million line of credit provided by Airbus, and
approximately $127&nbsp;million from asset-based financings or
sales of aircraft, net after prepayments of
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; ATSB loan.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net cash provided by operating activities was $46&nbsp;million
and $21&nbsp;million in 2005 and 2004, respectively. The 2005
period included the receipt of a $150&nbsp;million one-time
bonus payment from an affinity credit card partner and a
$120&nbsp;million release of certain restricted cash. These
increases were offset in part by the loss before cumulative
effect of change in accounting principle ($335&nbsp;million) in
2005. The 2004 period included a decrease in accounts payable
$35&nbsp;million, due to the timing of vendor payments and the
payment in February 2004 of $20&nbsp;million related to the
execution of a new pilot agreement, which
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">70

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
was accrued at December&nbsp;31, 2003. In addition, the 2004
period was impacted by a decrease in accrued compensation and
vacation benefits primarily due to the payment in March 2004 of
the Company&#146;s obligation for employee performance bonuses
and award pay ($20&nbsp;million), which was accrued at
December&nbsp;31, 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net cash provided by investing activities was $399&nbsp;million
and $16&nbsp;million in 2005 and 2004, respectively. Principal
investing activities in 2005 included the merger transaction,
which included $258&nbsp;million of net cash acquired. Other
investing activities in 2005 included net purchases of
short-term investments totaling $295&nbsp;million and purchases
of property and equipment totaling $44&nbsp;million. The Company
also received proceeds of $592&nbsp;million from flight
equipment asset sales, sale and leaseback transactions and sales
of other property and equipment. Restricted cash increased by
$112&nbsp;million in 2005 primarily due to an increase in cash
reserves required under an agreement for processing AWA&#146;s
Visa and MasterCard credit card transactions. The 2004 period
included purchases of property and equipment totaling
$219&nbsp;million, of which $139&nbsp;million was expenditures
for capitalized maintenance. The 2004 period also included net
sales of short-term investments and investments in debt
securities totaling $205&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net cash provided by (used in) financing activities was
$531&nbsp;million and ($41)&nbsp;million in 2005 and 2004,
respectively. Principal financing activities in 2005 included
the issuance of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock for
$732&nbsp;million in cash, and proceeds from the issuance of
debt totaling $655&nbsp;million, which included a
$325&nbsp;million loan from an affinity credit card partner,
$186&nbsp;million from the Airbus loans and $144&nbsp;million
from the issuance of the 7%&nbsp;senior convertible notes. The
debt repayments totaled $741&nbsp;million in 2005 and included a
$433&nbsp;million reduction in aircraft-related debt as a result
of flight equipment asset sales and sale and leaseback
transactions, the GE debt repayment of $125&nbsp;million,
approximately $125&nbsp;million in ATSB loan repayments, and the
redemption of AWA&#146;s 10.75%&nbsp;senior unsecured notes
totaling $40&nbsp;million. In 2004&nbsp;net cash used in
financing activities was $41&nbsp;million for the Company,
consisting principally of $176&nbsp;million of debt repayments,
including principal repayments of $86&nbsp;million for the
government guaranteed loan. In addition, AWA entered into a term
loan financing with GECC resulting in proceeds of
$111&nbsp;million, approximately $77&nbsp;million of which was
used to pay off the balance of the term loan with Mizuho
Corporate Bank, Ltd. and certain other lenders. The 2004 period
also includes $31&nbsp;million of proceeds from the issuance of
senior secured discount notes, secured by AWA&#146;s leasehold
interest in its Phoenix maintenance facility and flight training
center.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Capital expenditures for 2005 were $44&nbsp;million for
US&nbsp;Airways Group. This compares to $219&nbsp;million of
capital expenditures for 2004, which includes capital
expenditures for capitalized maintenance of approximately
$139&nbsp;million. The 2005 period does not include capital
expenditures for capitalized maintenance, as AWA changed its
accounting policy from the deferral method to the direct expense
method effective January&nbsp;1, 2005. See note&nbsp;4,
&#147;Change in Accounting Policy for Maintenance Costs,&#148;
in the notes to consolidated financial statements in
Item&nbsp;8A of this report.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>AWA</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
At December&nbsp;31, 2005, AWA&#146;s total cash, cash
equivalents, short-term investments, and restricted cash balance
was $1.18&nbsp;billion, of which $951&nbsp;million was
unrestricted. Net cash provided by operating activities for AWA
was $974&nbsp;million and $20&nbsp;million in 2005 and 2004,
respectively. The year-over-year increase in net cash provided
by operating activities of $954&nbsp;million was primarily due
to an increase in payable to affiliate as AWA received proceeds
on behalf of US&nbsp;Airways Group from the merger-related
financing transactions including the initial equity investments,
the public stock offering, the exercise of options by equity
investors, the issuance of 7%&nbsp;senior convertible notes and
the Airbus loans, net of cash retained by US&nbsp;Airways Group.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net cash provided by (used in) investing activities was
($283)&nbsp;million and $16&nbsp;million in 2005 and 2004,
respectively. Principal investing activities during 2005
included net purchases of short-term investments totaling
$163&nbsp;million, purchases of property and equipment totaling
$37&nbsp;million and $72&nbsp;million of net proceeds from the
sale and leaseback of certain owned aircraft. Restricted cash
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">71

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
increased by $157&nbsp;million during 2005 primarily due to an
increase in cash reserves required under an agreement for
processing AWA&#146;s Visa and MasterCard credit card
transactions. The 2004 period included purchases of property and
equipment totaling $219&nbsp;million, of which $139&nbsp;million
was expenditures for capitalized maintenance. The 2004 period
also included net sales of short-term investments and
investments in debt securities totaling $205&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In 2005, net cash used in financing activities was
$187&nbsp;million, consisting principally of $183&nbsp;million
of debt repayments. This included principal repayments of
$94&nbsp;million for the government guaranteed loan, the
redemption of 10.75%&nbsp;senior unsecured notes totaling
$40&nbsp;million and the retirement of $39&nbsp;million of
equipment notes payable as a result of the sale and leaseback
transaction discussed above. In 2004&nbsp;net cash used in
financing activities was $42&nbsp;million for AWA, consisting
principally of $176&nbsp;million of debt repayments including
principal repayments of $86&nbsp;million for the government
guaranteed loan. In addition, AWA entered into a term loan
financing with GECC resulting in proceeds of $111&nbsp;million,
approximately $77&nbsp;million of which was used to pay off the
balance of the term loan with Mizuho Corporate Bank, Ltd. and
certain other lenders. The 2004 period also includes
$31&nbsp;million of proceeds from the issuance of senior secured
discount notes, secured by AWA&#146;s leasehold interest in its
Phoenix maintenance facility and flight training center.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Capital expenditures for 2005 were $37&nbsp;million for AWA.
This compares to $219&nbsp;million of capital expenditures for
2004, which includes capital expenditures for capitalized
maintenance of approximately $139&nbsp;million. The 2005 period
does not include capital expenditures for capitalized
maintenance, as AWA changed its accounting policy from the
deferral method to the direct expense method effective
January&nbsp;1, 2005. See note&nbsp;3, &#147;Change in
Accounting Policy for Maintenance Costs,&#148; in the notes to
consolidated financial statements included in Item&nbsp;8B of
this report.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>US&nbsp;Airways</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As discussed in &#147;Results of Operations,&#148; the financial
statements prior to September&nbsp;30, 2005 are not comparable
with the financial statements for the three months ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005. However for purposes of discussion of
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; sources and uses of cash, the full year
2005 has been compared to the full year 2004 as included in the
US&nbsp;Airways statements of cash flows.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways&#146; cash, cash
equivalents, short-term investments and restricted cash were
$1.17&nbsp;billion, of which $594&nbsp;million was unrestricted.
See &#147;Emergence and Merger Transactions&#148; above for
discussion of additional financing and liquidity obtained, which
was critical to US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s emergence from
bankruptcy and merger with America West Holdings.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net cash used in operating activities was $421&nbsp;million and
$106&nbsp;million in 2005 and 2004, respectively. Cash flows
during 2005 were adversely affected by higher interest expense
and significant increases in fuel prices. Operating cash flows
for 2005 included $125&nbsp;million for reorganization items as
compared to $11&nbsp;million for reorganization items in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net cash provided by (used in) investing activities was
($28)&nbsp;million and $102&nbsp;million in 2005 and 2004,
respectively. Investing activities in 2005 included net
purchases of short-term investments totaling $132&nbsp;million
and purchases of property and equipment totaling
$141&nbsp;million. US&nbsp;Airways received proceeds of
$189&nbsp;million from flight equipment and other asset sale
transactions. Restricted cash decreased by $56&nbsp;million in
2005 primarily due to release of reserves related to tax trusts.
The 2004 period included purchases of property and equipment
totaling $198&nbsp;million and an increase in restricted cash of
$76&nbsp;million. The 2004 period also included net sales of
short-term investments totaling $358&nbsp;million and proceeds
of $18&nbsp;million from asset sales.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net cash provided by (used in) financing activities was
$177&nbsp;million and ($185)&nbsp;million in 2005 and 2004,
respectively. Principal financing activities in 2005 included
proceeds from flight equipment asset sale leaseback transactions
of $561&nbsp;million and proceeds from the issuance of debt of
$265&nbsp;million. The 2005 debt issuance proceeds included
$125&nbsp;million of
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">debtor-in</FONT>-possession
financing that converted into shares of common stock in
US&nbsp;Airways Group upon emergence from bankruptcy. Debt
repayments totaled
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">72

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
$649&nbsp;million in 2005 and included a $394&nbsp;million
reduction in aircraft-related debt as a result of the flight
equipment asset sale leaseback transactions. The 2004 period
included proceeds from the issuance of debt of $240&nbsp;million
and debt repayments of $425&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Commitments</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company had $3.12&nbsp;billion
of long-term debt (including current maturities and before
discount on debt), which consisted primarily of the items
discussed below.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>New Convertible Notes</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group received net proceeds of $139&nbsp;million
related to the 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes due 2020 that
were issued on September&nbsp;30, 2005. The 7%&nbsp;notes are
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s senior unsecured obligations, rank
equally in right of payment to its other senior unsecured and
unsubordinated indebtedness, and are effectively subordinated to
its secured indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets
securing such indebtedness. The 7%&nbsp;notes are fully and
unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally and on a
senior unsecured basis, by US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. The
guarantees are the guarantors&#146; unsecured obligations, rank
equally in right of payment to the other senior unsecured and
unsubordinated indebtedness of the guarantors and are
effectively subordinated to the guarantors&#146; secured
indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets securing such
indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 7%&nbsp;notes bear interest at the rate of 7%&nbsp;per year
payable in cash semiannually in arrears on March&nbsp;30 and
September&nbsp;30 of each year, beginning March&nbsp;30, 2006.
The 7%&nbsp;notes mature on September&nbsp;30, 2020. Holders may
convert, at any time on or prior to maturity or redemption, any
outstanding notes (or portions thereof) into shares of
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s common stock, initially at a
conversion rate of 41.4508&nbsp;shares of US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s common stock per $1,000 principal amount of
7%&nbsp;notes (equivalent to an initial conversion price of
approximately $24.12&nbsp;per share of US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s common stock). If a holder elects to convert its
7%&nbsp;notes in connection with certain specified fundamental
changes that occur prior to October&nbsp;5, 2015, the holder
will be entitled to receive additional shares of US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s common stock as a make whole premium upon
conversion. In lieu of delivery of shares of US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s common stock upon conversion of all or any portion
of the 7%&nbsp;notes, US&nbsp;Airways Group may elect to pay
holders surrendering 7%&nbsp;notes for conversion cash or a
combination of shares and cash.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Holders of the 7%&nbsp;notes may require US&nbsp;Airways Group
to purchase for cash or shares or a combination thereof, at
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s election, all or a portion of their
notes on September&nbsp;30, 2010 and September&nbsp;30, 2015 at
a purchase price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the
notes to be repurchased plus accrued and unpaid interest, if
any, to the purchase date. In addition, if US&nbsp;Airways Group
experiences a fundamental change (as defined in the indenture
governing the notes), holders may require US&nbsp;Airways Group
to purchase for cash, shares or a combination thereof, at its
election, all or a portion of their notes, subject to specified
exceptions, at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount of
the notes plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the
purchase date. Prior to October&nbsp;5, 2010, the notes will not
be redeemable at US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s option.
US&nbsp;Airways Group may redeem all or a portion of the notes
at any time on or after October&nbsp;5, 2010, at a price equal
to 100% of the principal amount of the notes plus accrued and
unpaid interest, if any, to the redemption date if the closing
price of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s common stock has exceeded
115% of the conversion price for at least 20 trading days in the
30 consecutive trading day period ending on the trading day
before the date on which US&nbsp;Airways Group mails the
redemption notice.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>GE</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Of the $139&nbsp;million net proceeds from the 7%&nbsp;notes,
$125&nbsp;million was paid in September 2005 to GE. Under
certain agreements among GE and US&nbsp;Airways Group, GE
agreed, in consideration for the early return of 51 aircraft and
six engines, the assumption of certain modified leases and the
payment of $125&nbsp;million in cash by September&nbsp;30, 2005,
to (1)&nbsp;retire an existing bridge loan facility,
(2)&nbsp;complete a
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">73

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
purchase by GE of 21 aircraft and 28 engines with a simultaneous
lease back of the equipment to US&nbsp;Airways at market rates,
(3)&nbsp;allow US&nbsp;Airways Group to draw additional amounts
under an existing credit facility, which resulted in a total
principal outstanding balance under that facility of
approximately $28&nbsp;million, (4)&nbsp;restructure lease
obligations of US&nbsp;Airways relating to 59 aircraft at market
rates, (5)&nbsp;provide financing for current and additional
aircraft, (6)&nbsp;grant concessions regarding return condition
obligations with respect to the return of aircraft and engines,
(7)&nbsp;waive penalties for the removal of engines currently
under GE engine maintenance agreements, and (8)&nbsp;reduce
outstanding balances for deferred charges under its rate per
hour engine agreements, which resulted in a remaining balance
due of $54&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Airbus Term Loans</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA entered into
two loan agreements with Airbus Financial Services
(&#147;AFS&#148;), an affiliate of Airbus, with commitments in
initial aggregate amounts of up to $161&nbsp;million and up to
$89&nbsp;million. The Airbus loans bear interest at a rate of
LIBOR plus a margin, subject to adjustment during the term of
the loans under certain conditions. In each of the separate
financial statements of US&nbsp;Airways and AWA, the Airbus loan
has also been presented as a liability, as each entity is
jointly and severally liable for this obligation. Amounts drawn
upon the Airbus loans are drawn first upon the Airbus
$161&nbsp;million loan until it has been drawn in its full
amount, in which event the remaining portion of the
$250&nbsp;million total commitment is drawn upon the Airbus
$89&nbsp;million loan.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, all of the Airbus $161&nbsp;million
loan and $14&nbsp;million of the Airbus $89&nbsp;million loan
were drawn and are available for use for general corporate
purposes. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, a total of
$186&nbsp;million was drawn under the Airbus loans. The
remaining portion of the Airbus loans is payable in multiple
draws upon the occurrence of certain conditions, including the
taking of delivery of certain aircraft, on the due dates for
certain amounts owing to AFS or its affiliates to refinance such
amounts, after payment of certain invoices for goods and
services provided by AFS or its affiliates, or upon receipt by
AFS of certain amounts payable in respect of existing aircraft
financing transactions. The full amount of the Airbus loans is
expected to be available by the end of 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The amortization payments under the Airbus $161&nbsp;million
loan will become due in equal quarterly installments of
$13&nbsp;million beginning on March&nbsp;31, 2008, with the
final installment due on December&nbsp;31, 2010. The outstanding
principal amount of Airbus $89&nbsp;million loan will be
forgiven in writing December&nbsp;31, 2010, or an earlier date,
if on that date the outstanding principal amount of, accrued
interest on, and all other amounts due under the Airbus
$161&nbsp;million loan have been paid in full and the Company
complies with the delivery schedule.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>ATSB Loans</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways and AWA each had outstanding loans that were
guaranteed by the ATSB under the Air Transportation Safety and
System Stabilization Act. In connection with the consummation of
the merger, on September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways, as
borrower, entered into an Amended and Restated Loan Agreement
with the ATSB. Also on September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA, as
borrower, entered into an Amended and Restated Loan Agreement.
The new loans amended and restated the previously outstanding
loans of both US&nbsp;Airways and AWA, each guaranteed in
substantial part by the ATSB.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;19, 2005, $777&nbsp;million of the loans, of
which $752&nbsp;million was guaranteed by the ATSB, was sold by
the lenders by order of the ATSB to 13 fixed income investors.
The sale of the debt removed the ATSB guarantee. The total
outstanding balance of the loans as of December&nbsp;31, 2005
was $801&nbsp;million, of which $551&nbsp;million is outstanding
under the US&nbsp;Airways loan and $250&nbsp;million is
outstanding under the AWA loan. Terms associated with these
loans remain unchanged, with the AWA loan terminating in 2008
and the US&nbsp;Airways loan terminating in 2010. As a result of
that sale, the ATSB no longer has an interest in any of the
Company&#146;s debt.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">74
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the Amended and Restated US&nbsp;Airways Loan Agreement,
the US&nbsp;Airways loan now bears interest as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

    <TD width="96%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    90% of the US&nbsp;Airways loan (Tranche&nbsp;A), which was the
    portion of the loan previously guaranteed by the ATSB, was
    originally funded through a participating lender&#146;s
    commercial paper conduit program and bears interest at a rate
    equal to the conduit provider&#146;s weighted average cost
    related to the issuance of certain commercial paper notes and
    other short term borrowings plus 0.30%, provided that portions
    of Tranche&nbsp;A that were held by the ATSB or are held by an
    assignee and no longer subject to such commercial paper conduit
    program bear interest at LIBOR plus 40&nbsp;basis points, and
    portions of Tranche&nbsp;A that are under certain circumstances
    assigned free of the ATSB guarantee bear interest at LIBOR plus
    6.0%;&nbsp;and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    10% of the US&nbsp;Airways loan (Tranche&nbsp;B) bears interest
    at the greater of the Tranche&nbsp;A interest rate plus 6.0% and
    LIBOR plus 6.0%.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The US&nbsp;Airways loan also has amortization payments for
US&nbsp;Airways with semi-annual payments beginning on
March&nbsp;31, 2007 and continuing through September&nbsp;30,
2010.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain third party counter-guarantors have fully and
unconditionally guaranteed the payment of an aggregate amount of
$11&nbsp;million of the remaining principal amount of the AWA
loan, plus accrued and unpaid interest thereon, as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005. The AWA loan previously bore interest at
a rate of LIBOR plus 40&nbsp;basis points, with a guarantee fee
equal to 8.0% per annum with annual increases of 5&nbsp;basis
points. As a result of the sale of the AWA loan, the
non-guaranteed portion of the loan is no longer subject to the
annual guarantee fee, but instead bears interest at a rate per
annum equal to LIBOR plus 840&nbsp;basis points, increasing by
5&nbsp;basis points on January 18 of each year beginning on
January&nbsp;18, 2006, through the end of the loan term, payable
on a quarterly basis. The amortization payments under the AWA
loan become due in seven installments of $42&nbsp;million on
each March&nbsp;31 and September&nbsp;30, commencing on
September&nbsp;30, 2005 and ending on September&nbsp;30, 2008.
The AWA loan also requires a premium, in certain instances, for
voluntary prepayments. AWA made a voluntary prepayment of
$9&nbsp;million dollars in principal amount on
September&nbsp;27, 2005, prepaying in full the portion of the
loan subject to one of the counter-guarantees. This prepayment
has been applied pro rata against each scheduled amortization
payment. The AWA loan also requires prepayments from the
proceeds of specified asset sales.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the loans, US&nbsp;Airways Group is required to maintain
consolidated unrestricted cash and cash equivalents, less:
(a)&nbsp;the amount of all outstanding advances by credit card
processors and clearing houses in excess of 20% of the air
traffic liabilities; (b)&nbsp;$250&nbsp;million presumed
necessary to fund a subsequent tax trust (to the extent not
otherwise funded by US&nbsp;Airways Group);
(c)&nbsp;$35&nbsp;million presumed necessary to post collateral
to clearinghouses (to the extent not posted); and (d)&nbsp;any
unrestricted cash or cash equivalents held in unperfected
accounts; in an amount (subject to partial reduction under
certain circumstances upon mandatory prepayments made with the
net proceeds of future borrowings and issuances of capital
stock) not less than:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways was required to pay down the principal of its
loan with the first $125&nbsp;million of net proceeds from
specified asset sales identified in connection with its
Chapter&nbsp;11 proceedings. US&nbsp;Airways
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">75

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
then retains the next $83&nbsp;million of net proceeds from
specified assets sales, and must prepay the principal of the
loan with 60% of net proceeds in excess of an aggregate of
$208&nbsp;million from specified asset sales. Any such asset
sales proceeds up to $275&nbsp;million are to be applied in
order of maturity, and any such asset sales proceeds in excess
of $275&nbsp;million are to be applied pro rata across all
maturities in accordance with the loan&#146;s early amortization
provisions. As a result, semi-annual payments are now scheduled
to begin on September&nbsp;30, 2007, instead of March&nbsp;31,
2007, as originally scheduled in the loan agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In October 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group repurchased all of the
warrants it had issued to the ATSB in exchange for warrants
previously issued by America West Holdings in connection with
the AWA loan. The Company repurchased approximately
7.7&nbsp;million warrants to purchase shares of common stock
that had an exercise price of $7.27&nbsp;per share. The total
purchase price for the warrants was $116&nbsp;million, the fair
value of such warrants on the repurchase date.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Exchange of Common Stock for AWA&#146;s 7.25&nbsp;Percent
    Senior Exchangeable Notes</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In July and August of 2003, AWA completed a private placement of
approximately $87&nbsp;million issue price of 7.25%&nbsp;Senior
Exchangeable Notes due 2023. The notes bore cash interest at a
rate of 2.49%&nbsp;per year, and were redeemable or exchangeable
under certain conditions. Completion of the merger between
US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West Holdings on
September&nbsp;27, 2005 constituted a &#147;change of
control&#148; under these notes and required AWA to make an
offer to holders to purchase those notes within 30 business days
after the effective time of the merger at a purchase price of
$343.61&nbsp;per $1,000 principal amount at maturity. Under the
terms of the notes and the related Guarantee and Exchange
Agreement, dated as of July&nbsp;30, 2003, between America West
Holdings and U.S.&nbsp;Bank National Association, as Trustee, as
supplemented by the Guarantee and Exchange Agreement Supplement
No.&nbsp;1 among America West Holdings, US&nbsp;Airways Group
and the Trustee, dated as of September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA&#146;s
obligation to purchase the notes was satisfied at
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s election by delivery of shares of
US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock having a &#147;fair market
value&#148; of not less than $343.61&nbsp;per $1,000 principal
amount at maturity. For this purpose, &#147;fair market
value&#148; means 95% of the market price of US&nbsp;Airways
Group common stock calculated as the average closing prices over
the five business days ending on and including the third
business day before the purchase date.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;24, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group issued a total
of 4,156,411&nbsp;shares of its common stock in exchange for
approximately $250&nbsp;million in principal amount at maturity
of AWA&#146;s Senior Exchangeable Notes due 2023, which notes
were fully and unconditionally guaranteed by US&nbsp;Airways
Group. The shares were exchanged at a rate of 16.6&nbsp;shares
of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock per $1,000 principal
amount at maturity, in full satisfaction of the purchase price
of the notes. The amount of notes exchanged represented
approximately 99% of the outstanding principal amount, and
approximately $2&nbsp;million in principal amount at maturity of
the notes remained outstanding after the exchange. On
November&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group issued a total of
38,864&nbsp;shares of its common stock to repurchase the
remaining outstanding principal amount of the notes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Restructuring of Affinity Credit Card Partner Agreement</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the merger, AWA, pre-merger US&nbsp;Airways
Group and Juniper Bank, a subsidiary of Barclays PLC, entered
into an amended credit card agreement on August&nbsp;8, 2005.
Pursuant to the amended credit card agreement, Juniper agreed to
offer and market an airline mileage award credit card program to
the general public to participate in US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s Dividend Miles program through the use of a
co-branded credit card.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s credit card program is currently
administered by Bank of America, N.A. (USA). On
December&nbsp;28, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways issued a notice of
termination under its agreement with Bank of America, and that
notice will become effective on December&nbsp;28, 2007. Pending
termination of the Bank of America agreement, both Juniper and
Bank of America will run separate credit card programs for
US&nbsp;Airways Group. The amended credit card agreement is the
subject of pending litigation filed by Bank
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">76

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
of America against US&nbsp;Airways Group, US&nbsp;Airways and
AWA. (See Part&nbsp;I, Item&nbsp;3, &#147;Legal
Proceedings&#148;)
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The amended credit card agreement with Juniper took effect at
the effective time of the merger and the credit card services
provided by Juniper under the amended credit card agreement
commenced in early January 2006, and will continue until the
expiration date, which is the later of December&nbsp;31, 2012 or
seven years from the date on which Juniper commences marketing
to the general public.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the amended credit card agreement, Juniper pays
US&nbsp;Airways Group fees for each mile awarded to each credit
card account administered by Juniper, subject to certain
exceptions. Juniper also agreed to pay a one-time bonus payment
of $130&nbsp;million following the effectiveness of the merger
and an annual bonus of $5&nbsp;million to US&nbsp;Airways Group,
subject to certain exceptions, for each year after Juniper
becomes the exclusive issuer of the co-branded credit card. The
one-time bonus was paid to AWA on October&nbsp;3, 2005. If
Juniper is not granted exclusivity to offer a co-branded credit
card after the dual branding period with Bank of America,
US&nbsp;Airways Group must repay this bonus payment and
repurchase unused pre-paid miles with interest, plus
$50&nbsp;million in liquidated damages.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;3, 2005 Juniper pre-paid for miles from
US&nbsp;Airways Group totaling $325&nbsp;million, subject to the
same conditions as apply to the $130&nbsp;million bonus payment
described above. To the extent that these miles are not used by
Juniper as allowed under the co-branded credit card program in
certain circumstances, US&nbsp;Airways Group will repurchase
these miles in 12 equal quarterly installments beginning on the
fifth year prior to the expiration date of the co-branded credit
card agreement with Juniper, until paid in full. US&nbsp;Airways
Group makes monthly interest payments at LIBOR plus 4.75% to
Juniper, beginning on November&nbsp;1, 2005, based on the amount
of pre-purchased miles that have not been used by Juniper in
connection with the co-branded credit card program and have not
been repurchased by US&nbsp;Airways Group. US&nbsp;Airways Group
will be required to repurchase pre-purchased miles under certain
reductions in the collateral held under the credit card
processing agreement with JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. Accordingly,
the prepayment has been recorded as additional indebtedness in
the consolidated financial statements of AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Juniper requires US&nbsp;Airways Group to maintain an average
quarterly balance of cash, cash equivalents and short term
investments of at least $1&nbsp;billion for the entirety of the
agreement. Further, the agreement requires US&nbsp;Airways Group
to maintain certain financial ratios beginning January&nbsp;1,
2006. Juniper may, at its option, terminate the amended credit
card agreement, make payments to US&nbsp;Airways Group under the
amended credit card agreement in the form of pre-purchased miles
rather than cash, or require US&nbsp;Airways Group to repurchase
the pre-purchased miles before the fifth year prior to the
expiration date in the event that US&nbsp;Airways Group breaches
its obligations under the amended credit card agreement, or upon
the occurrence of certain events.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

    <TD>
    <I>Restructuring of Credit Card Processing Agreement</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the merger, AWA, JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A.,
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">successor-in</FONT>-interest
to JPMorgan Chase Bank, and Chase Merchant Services, L.L.C.
(collectively, &#147;Chase&#148;), entered into the First
Amendment to the Merchant Services Bankcard Agreement on
August&nbsp;8, 2005. Pursuant to the amended card processing
agreement, Chase will perform authorization, processing and
settlement services for sales on Visa and Mastercard for AWA and
US&nbsp;Airways following the merger. The original card
processing agreement is guaranteed by America West Holdings, and
US&nbsp;Airways Group executed a guaranty of the amended card
processing agreement on the effective date of the merger.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; credit card processing is currently
administered by Bank of America and those processing services
are expected to be transferred to Chase on or before
April&nbsp;25, 2006. US&nbsp;Airways will become a party to the
amended card processing agreement at the time that Chase begins
processing for US&nbsp;Airways.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The amended card processing agreement took effect at the
effective time of the merger and continues until the expiration
of the initial term, which is three years from the effective
date. Upon expiration of the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">77
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
initial term, the amended card processing agreement will
automatically renew for successive one-year periods pursuant to
the terms of the agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the amended card processing agreement, AWA will pay to
Chase fees in connection with card processing services such as
sales authorization, settlement services and customer service.
AWA and US&nbsp;Airways will also be required to maintain a
reserve account to secure Chase&#146;s exposure to outstanding
air traffic liability. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005,
$543&nbsp;million in cash collateral is classified as restricted
cash on US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s consolidated balance sheet
to secure credit card sales under its various processing
agreements.
</DIV>

    <TD>
    <I>Asset Based Financings and Sales</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In addition to the sale-leaseback transactions completed in June
2005 related to the GE Merger MOU described above,
US&nbsp;Airways also executed flight equipment asset sale and
sale-leaseback transactions in the third and fourth quarters of
2005. While transactions completed prior to the merger date by
US&nbsp;Airways are not reflected in the US&nbsp;Airways Group
financial statements as a result of accounting for the merger as
a reverse acquisition, these transactions provided additional
liquidity and reductions to debt for US&nbsp;Airways Group.
US&nbsp;Airways received net proceeds of $209&nbsp;million and a
reduction in aircraft related debt of $561&nbsp;million.
Additionally during the third quarter, US&nbsp;Airways received
net proceeds of $51&nbsp;million in connection with an agreement
to sell and leaseback certain of its commuter slots at Ronald
Reagan Washington National Airport and New York LaGuardia
Airport. US&nbsp;Airways was required to use proceeds totaling
$156&nbsp;million to pay down the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
For 2005, AWA executed flight equipment asset sale and leaseback
transactions resulting in net proceeds of $23&nbsp;million and a
reduction in aircraft related debt of $38&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Airbus Purchase Commitments</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group,
US&nbsp;Airways and AWA entered into an Airbus A350 Purchase
Agreement with Airbus. This agreement provides for the delivery
of 20 A350 aircraft during the period 2011 through 2014. The
agreement contains terms and conditions with respect to aircraft
price, escalation, payment terms and pre-delivery payments,
inspection and certification, technical acceptance, excusable
and inexcusable delays, warranties and service life policy,
patent and copyright indemnity, technical data and training
aids, training, supplier product support, indemnities and
insurance, assignments and transfers, and termination events.
Airbus also agreed to provide backstop financing with respect to
a substantial number of these A350 aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group entered into
Amendment 16 to the A319/ A320/ A321 Purchase Agreement dated as
of October&nbsp;31, 1997 among US&nbsp;Airways Group and AVSA,
S.A.R.L. The amendment provides for the rescheduling of 19 firm
order A320-family aircraft for delivery during the period 2009
and 2010. The amendment also modifies other provisions of the
Purchase Agreement relating to the deletion of certain aircraft
cancellation rights and the rescheduling of aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group entered into
Amendment 10 to the A330/340 Purchase Agreement dated as of
November&nbsp;24, 1998 among US&nbsp;Airways Group and AVSA,
S.A.R.L. The amendment provides for the rescheduling of ten firm
order A330-200 aircraft for delivery during the period 2009 and
2010 and allows for cancellation in the event that
US&nbsp;Airways takes certain deliveries under the A350 Purchase
Agreement described above. Other provisions of the Purchase
Agreement which have been modified by the amendment relate to
the application of existing pre-delivery payments, adjustments
to various cancellation rights and the cancellation of the right
for additional A330 aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA entered into Amendment
No.&nbsp;9 and Amendment No.&nbsp;10 to the Airbus A320/ A319
Purchase Agreement dated as of September&nbsp;12, 1997 between
AWA and AVSA, S.A.R.L. Amendment No.&nbsp;9 provides for the
rescheduling of 11 firm order A320 family aircraft for delivery
during 2009. Amendment No.&nbsp;10 sets forth provisions for
restructuring fees and adjustments to escalation provisions and
added purchase rights for aircraft.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">78

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During the third quarter of 2005, AWA incurred a
$57&nbsp;million special charge related to the amended Airbus
purchase agreement. US&nbsp;Airways also incurred a
restructuring fee of $39&nbsp;million, which was recorded as a
reorganization item in the third quarter of 2005. The
restructuring fees were paid by means of set-off against
existing equipment purchase deposits held by Airbus.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Embraer Purchase Commitments</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On February&nbsp;16, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court approved a
settlement and assumption term sheet between the Company and
Embraer, executed by the Company on February&nbsp;9, 2006, which
amends the purchase agreement dated as of May&nbsp;9, 2003, as
amended, between the Company and Embraer and contemplates an
amended and restated financing letter with Embraer. The
Bankruptcy Court also authorized the assumption of the purchase
agreement, as amended by the term sheet, and a related
maintenance agreement, and disallowed certain proofs of claim
filed by Embraer in the bankruptcy proceedings related to these
agreements. The purchase agreement, as amended by the term
sheet, provides that Embraer will retain and apply approximately
$18&nbsp;million in non-refundable progress and deposit payments
(&#147;PDPs&#148;) previously paid by the Company. The Company
has agreed to place an initial firm order for 25 Embraer 190
aircraft and an additional firm order for 32 Embraer 190
aircraft. The outstanding PDPs will be applied to these orders
in accordance with the terms of the amended purchase agreement.
In addition, upon assumption of the amended purchase agreement,
Embraer granted the Company the right to purchase up to 50
additional Embraer&nbsp;190 aircraft in accordance with the term
sheet. The term sheet also provides that the Company will be
allowed to convert certain of the Embraer&nbsp;190 aircraft to
Embraer&nbsp;170, Embraer&nbsp;175 or Embraer 195 aircraft,
subject to availability and upon agreed notice. Embraer has
agreed to provide financing for certain of the aircraft
scheduled for delivery under the amended purchase agreement,
under the terms of the amended and restated financing letter.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Bombardier Purchase Commitments</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under its agreement with Bombardier, US&nbsp;Airways Group
acquired three new
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">CRJ-700</FONT> aircraft in
January 2005. The purchase was financed through the application
of $28&nbsp;million of existing purchase deposits held by
Bombardier, $2&nbsp;million in cash and a financed lease
facility with DVB Bank AG. Additionally, $7&nbsp;million of
purchase deposits held by Bombardier were used to satisfy
existing defaults, cure payments and liquidated damages. While
US&nbsp;Airways Group continued to operate under the protection
of Chapter&nbsp;11 in compliance with the Bankruptcy Code and
until a decision is reached to assume or reject the Bombardier
regional jet purchase agreement, no obligations arise on the
part of US&nbsp;Airways Group or Bombardier with respect to the
purchase and delivery of any aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Covenants and Credit Rating</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In addition to the minimum cash balance requirements, our
long-term debt agreements contain various negative covenants
that restrict our actions, including our ability to pay
dividends, or make other restricted payments. Finally, our
long-term debt agreements contain cross-default provisions,
which may be triggered by defaults by us under other agreements
relating to indebtedness. See <I>&#147;Risk Factors Relating to
the Company and Industry Related Risks&nbsp;&#151; Our high
level of fixed obligations limits our ability to fund general
corporate requirements and obtain additional financing, limits
our flexibility in responding to competitive developments and
increases our vulnerability to adverse economic and industry
conditions.&#148; </I>As of December&nbsp;31, 2005,
US&nbsp;Airways Group and its subsidiaries were in compliance
with the covenants in their long-term debt agreements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s credit ratings, like those of most
airlines, are relatively low, with Standard&nbsp;&#38;
Poor&#146;s (&#147;S&#38;P&#148;) assessment of the corporate
credit rating for US&nbsp;Airways Group, AWA and US&nbsp;Airways
at B- and senior unsecured debt rating at CCC for
US&nbsp;Airways Group and AWA. Fitch&#146;s ratings for both
US&nbsp;Airways Group and AWA for long-term debt and senior
unsecured debt is CCC and CC, respectively. Moody&#146;s
assessment of AWA&#146;s long-term corporate family rating and
senior unsecured debt rating is B3 and Caa2, respectively.
S&#38;P and Fitch have placed a &#147;negative&#148; outlook
designation for US&nbsp;Airways
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">79
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
Group, AWA and US&nbsp;Airways. Low credit ratings could cause
our borrowing costs to increase, which would increase our
interest expense and could affect our net income, and our credit
ratings could adversely affect our ability to obtain additional
financing. The rating agencies base their ratings on their
expectations regarding the merger, our financial performance and
operations, our cash flow and liquidity, the level of our
indebtedness and industry conditions in general. If our
financial performance or industry conditions do not improve, we
may face future downgrades, which could further negatively
impact our borrowing costs and the prices of our equity or debt
securities. In addition, any downgrade of our credit ratings may
indicate a decline in our business and in our ability to satisfy
our obligations under our indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>GECC Term Loan&nbsp;Financing</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;10, 2004, AWA entered into a term loan
financing with GECC providing for loans in an aggregate amount
of $111&nbsp;million. AWA used approximately $77&nbsp;million of
the proceeds from this financing to repay in full its term loan
with Mizuho Corporate Bank, Ltd. and certain other lenders and
to pay certain costs associated with this transaction. AWA used
the remaining proceeds for general corporate purposes. The new
term loan financing consists of two secured term loan
facilities: a $76&nbsp;million term loan facility secured
primarily by spare parts, rotables and appliances (the
&#147;Spare Parts Facility&#148;); and a $35&nbsp;million term
loan facility secured primarily by aircraft engines and parts
installed in such engines (the &#147;Engine Facility&#148;).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The facilities are cross-collateralized on a subordinated basis,
and the collateral securing the facilities also secures on a
subordinated basis certain of AWA&#146;s other existing debt and
lease obligations to GECC and its affiliates.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The loans under the Spare Parts Facility are payable in full at
maturity on September&nbsp;10, 2010. The loans under the Engine
Facility are payable in equal quarterly installments of
$1&nbsp;million beginning on March&nbsp;10, 2006 through
June&nbsp;10, 2010, with the remaining loan amount of
$12&nbsp;million payable at maturity on September&nbsp;10, 2010.
The loans under each facility may be prepaid in an amount not
less than $5&nbsp;million at any time after the
30th&nbsp;monthly anniversary of the funding date under such
facility. If AWA fails to maintain a certain ratio of rotables
to loans under the Spare Parts Facility, it may be required to
pledge additional rotables or cash as collateral, provide a
letter of credit or prepay some or all of the loans under the
Spare Parts Facility. In addition, the loans under the Engine
Facility are subject to mandatory prepayment upon the occurrence
of certain events of loss applicable to, or certain dispositions
of, aircraft engines securing the facility.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Principal amounts outstanding under the loans bear interest at a
rate per annum based on three-month LIBOR plus a margin. Both
facilities contain customary events of default, including
payment defaults, cross-defaults, breach of covenants,
bankruptcy and insolvency defaults and judgment defaults.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Senior Secured Discount Notes Due 2009</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On December&nbsp;27, 2004, AWA raised additional capital by
financing its Phoenix maintenance facility and flight training
center. The flight training center was previously unencumbered,
and the maintenance facility became unencumbered earlier in 2004
when AWA refinanced its term loan. Using its leasehold interests
in these two facilities as collateral, AWA, through a subsidiary
named FTCHP LLC, raised $31&nbsp;million through the issuance of
senior secured discount notes. The notes were issued by FTCHP at
a discount pursuant to the terms of a senior secured term loan
agreement among AWA, FTCHP, Heritage Bank, SSB, as
administrative agent, Citibank, N.A., as the initial lender, and
the other lenders from time to time party thereto. Citibank,
N.A. subsequently assigned all of its interests in the notes to
third party lenders.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA fully and unconditionally guaranteed the payment and
performance of FTCHP&#146;s obligations under the notes and the
loan agreement. The notes require aggregate principal payments
of $36&nbsp;million with principal payments of $2&nbsp;million
due on each of the first two anniversary dates and the remaining
principal amount due on the fifth anniversary date. The notes
may be prepaid in full at any time (subject to customary LIBOR
breakage costs) and in partial amounts of $2&nbsp;million on the
third and fourth
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">80

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
anniversary dates. The unpaid principal amount of the notes
bears interest based on LIBOR plus a margin subject to
adjustment based on a loan to collateral value ratio.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The loan agreement contains customary covenants applicable to
loans of this type, including obligations relating to the
preservation of the collateral and restrictions on the
activities of FTCHP. In addition, the loan agreement contains
events of default, including payment defaults, cross-defaults to
other debt of FTCHP, if any, breach of covenants, bankruptcy and
insolvency defaults and judgment defaults.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with this financing, AWA sold all of its leasehold
interests in the maintenance facility and flight training center
to FTCHP and entered into subleases for the facilities with
FTCHP at lease rates expected to approximate the interest
payments due under the notes. In addition, AWA agreed to make
future capital contributions to FTCHP in amounts sufficient to
cover principal payments and other amounts owing pursuant to the
notes and the loan agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The proceeds from this financing, together with $11&nbsp;million
from operating cash flow, were irrevocably deposited with the
trustee for AWA&#146;s
10<FONT style="font-size: 70%"><SUP>3</SUP></FONT>/<FONT style="font-size: 60%">4</FONT>%&nbsp;senior
unsecured notes due 2005, which were subsequently redeemed on
January&nbsp;26, 2005. AWA issued $75&nbsp;million principal
amount of the
10<FONT style="font-size: 70%"><SUP>3</SUP></FONT>/<FONT style="font-size: 60%">4</FONT>%&nbsp;senior
unsecured notes in August 1995, of which $40&nbsp;million
remained outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2004. Interest on the
10<FONT style="font-size: 70%"><SUP>3</SUP></FONT>/<FONT style="font-size: 60%">4</FONT>%&nbsp;senior
unsecured notes was payable semiannually in arrears on
March&nbsp;1 and September&nbsp;1 of each year.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

    <TD width="94%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>7.5%&nbsp;Convertible Senior Notes due 2009</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the closing of AWA&#146;s original ATSB loan
and the related transactions in January 2002, America West
Holdings issued $105&nbsp;million of 7.5%&nbsp;convertible
senior notes due 2009, of which approximately $112&nbsp;million
remained outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2005. The outstanding
amount includes $22&nbsp;million of interest paid through
December&nbsp;31, 2005 as a deemed loan added to the principal
of the notes. Beginning January&nbsp;18, 2005, these notes
became convertible into shares of common stock, at the option of
the holders, at an initial conversion price of $29.09&nbsp;per
share or a conversion ratio of approximately 34.376&nbsp;shares
per $1,000 principal amount of such notes, subject to standard
anti-dilution adjustments. Interest on the 7.5%&nbsp;convertible
senior notes is payable semiannually in arrears on June&nbsp;1
and December&nbsp;1 of each year. At America West Holdings&#146;
option, the first six interest payments were payable in the form
of a deemed loan added to the principal amount of these notes.
The 7.5%&nbsp;convertible senior notes mature on
January&nbsp;18, 2009 unless earlier converted or redeemed. The
payment of principal, premium and interest on the
7.5%&nbsp;convertible senior notes is fully and unconditionally
guaranteed by AWA and US&nbsp;Airways Group.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

(which are expressed as percentages of the principal amount of
the notes), if redeemed during the twelve-month period
commencing on January 18 of the years set forth below, plus, in
each case, accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the date of
redemption:
