<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<A name='113'></A>
</DIV>

<!-- link1 "Item 8A. Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data of US Airways Group, Inc." -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>Item&nbsp;8A.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data
    of US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group consummated
the transactions contemplated by its plan of reorganization,
including the merger transaction with America West Holdings. As
a result of the merger, America West Holdings became a wholly
owned subsidiary of US&nbsp;Airways Group. As described in
greater detail in Notes&nbsp;1 and&nbsp;2, while the merger was
structured such that US&nbsp;Airways Group was the legal
acquirer, the merger has been accounted for as a reverse
acquisition such that America West Holdings has been treated as
the accounting acquirer. Financial information for periods prior
to the merger include the accounts and activities of America
West Holdings. America West Holdings is the holding company that
owns all of the stock of AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Management&#146;s Annual Report on Internal Control over
Financial Reporting</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Management of US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc. is responsible for
establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over
financial reporting as defined in
Rules&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">13a-15(f)</FONT>
and <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">15d-15(f)</FONT> under the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended. US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s internal control over financial reporting is
designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the
reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of
financial statements for external purposes in accordance with
generally accepted accounting principles. US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s internal control over financial reporting includes
those policies and procedures that:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable
    detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and
    dispositions of the assets of US&nbsp;Airways Group;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as
    necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in
    accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and
    that receipts and expenditures of US&nbsp;Airways Group are
    being made only in accordance with authorizations of management
    and directors of US&nbsp;Airways Group;&nbsp;and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely
    detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of
    US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s assets that could have a material
    effect on the financial statements.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over
financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future
periods are subject to the risk that controls may become
inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree
of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Management assessed the effectiveness of US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s internal control over financial reporting as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005. In making this assessment, management
used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring
Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO)&nbsp;in Internal
Control-Integrated Framework.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Based on our assessment and those criteria, management concludes
that US&nbsp;Airways Group maintained effective internal control
over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s independent registered public
accounting firm has issued an audit report on management&#146;s
assessment of the Company&#146;s internal control over financial
reporting. That report has been included herein.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">94
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
The Board of Directors and Stockholders
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We have audited management&#146;s assessment, included in the
accompanying Management&#146;s Annual Report on Internal Control
over Financial Reporting,<I> </I>that US&nbsp;Airways Group,
Inc. (&#147;US&nbsp;Airways Group&#148; or the
&#147;Company&#148;) maintained effective internal control over
financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, based on
criteria established in <I>Internal Control&nbsp;&#151;
Integrated Framework </I>issued by the Committee of Sponsoring
Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).The
Company&#146;s management is responsible for maintaining
effective internal control over financial reporting and for its
assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over
financial reporting. Our responsibility is to express an opinion
on management&#146;s assessment and an opinion on the
effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over
financial reporting based on our audit.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the
Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those
standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control
over financial reporting was maintained in all material
respects. Our audit included obtaining an understanding of
internal control over financial reporting, evaluating
management&#146;s assessment, testing and evaluating the design
and operating effectiveness of internal control, and performing
such other procedures as we considered necessary in the
circumstances. We believe that our audit provides a reasonable
basis for our opinion.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
A company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting is a
process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the
reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of
financial statements for external purposes in accordance with
generally accepted accounting principles. A company&#146;s
internal control over financial reporting includes those
policies and procedures that (1)&nbsp;pertain to the maintenance
of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly
reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the
company; (2)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance that transactions
are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial
statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting
principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company
are being made only in accordance with authorizations of
management and directors of the company; and (3)&nbsp;provide
reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of
unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the
company&#146;s assets that could have a material effect on the
financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over
financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future
periods are subject to the risk that controls may become
inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree
of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In our opinion, management&#146;s assessment that the Company
maintained effective internal control over financial reporting
as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, is fairly stated, in all material
respects, based on criteria established in <I>Internal
Control-Integrated Framework </I>issued by COSO. Also, in our
opinion, US&nbsp;Airways Group maintained, in all material
respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as
of December&nbsp;31, 2005, based on criteria established in
<I>Internal Control-Integrated Framework </I>issued by
COSO<I>.</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the
Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the
consolidated balance sheets of US&nbsp;Airways Group and
subsidiaries as of December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, and the
related consolidated statements of operations,
stockholders&#146; equity and comprehensive income, and cash
flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005, and our report dated March&nbsp;14, 2006
expressed an unqualified opinion on those consolidated financial
statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
/s/ KPMG LLP
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
Phoenix, Arizona
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
March&nbsp;14, 2006
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">95

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
The Board of Directors and Stockholders
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of
US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc. and subsidiaries as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, and the related consolidated
statements of operations, stockholders&#146; equity and
comprehensive income, and cash flows for each of the years in
the three-year period ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. These
consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the
Company&#146;s management. Our responsibility is to express an
opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our
audits.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the
Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those
standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are
free of material misstatement. An audit includes examining, on a
test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in
the financial statements. An audit also includes assessing the
accounting principles used and significant estimates made by
management, as well as evaluating the overall financial
statement presentation. We believe that our audits provide a
reasonable basis for our opinion.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred
to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial
position of US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc. and subsidiaries as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, and the results of their
operations and their cash flows for each of the years in the
three-year period ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, in conformity
with U.S.&nbsp;generally accepted accounting principles.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As discussed in Note&nbsp;4 to the consolidated financial
statements, the Company changed its method of accounting for
major scheduled airframe, engine and certain component overhaul
costs from the deferral method to the direct expense method in
2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the
Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the
effectiveness of US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.&#146;s internal
control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2005,
based on criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated
Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of
the Treadway Commission (COSO), and our report dated
March&nbsp;14, 2006 expressed an unqualified opinion on
management&#146;s assessment of, and the effective operation of,
internal control over financial reporting.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
/s/ KPMG LLP
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
Phoenix, Arizona
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
March&nbsp;14, 2006
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">100
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>1.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Merger with America West Holdings Corporation</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;12, 2004, US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.
(&#147;US&nbsp;Airways Group&#148; or the &#147;Company&#148;)
and its domestic subsidiaries, US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.
(&#147;US&nbsp;Airways&#148;), Piedmont Airlines, Inc.,
PSA&nbsp;Airlines, Inc. and Material Services Company, Inc.
(collectively referred to as the &#147;Debtors&#148;), which
accounted for substantially all of the operations of
US&nbsp;Airways Group, filed voluntary petitions for relief
under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code in
the United States bankruptcy court for the Eastern District of
Virginia, Alexandria Division (the &#147;Bankruptcy
Court&#148;). On May&nbsp;19, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group signed
a merger agreement with America West Holdings Corporation
(&#147;America West Holdings&#148;) pursuant to which America
West Holdings merged with a wholly owned subsidiary of
US&nbsp;Airways Group upon US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
emergence from bankruptcy. The Debtors&#146; plan of
reorganization was confirmed by the bankruptcy court on
September&nbsp;16, 2005 and became effective on
September&nbsp;27, 2005, the same day that the merger with
America West Holdings became effective. As described in greater
detail in Note&nbsp;2(b), while the merger was structured such
that US&nbsp;Airways Group was the legal acquirer, the merger
has been accounted for as a reverse acquisition such that
America West Holdings was treated as the accounting acquirer.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Critical to US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s emergence from
bankruptcy and the merger with America West Holdings was
additional financing and liquidity to fund operations. The
financing and liquidity was provided through a combination of
new equity investments, new and restructured debt instruments
and agreements with significant stakeholders as described below.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>New equity investments</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; On
September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group received new
equity investments of $565&nbsp;million in the aggregate from
ACE Aviation Holdings Inc.(&#147;ACE&#148;); Par Investment
Partners, L.P. (&#147;Par&#148;); Peninsula Investment Partners,
L.P. (&#147;Peninsula&#148;); a group of investors under the
management of Wellington Management Company, LLP
(&#147;Wellington&#148;); Tudor Proprietary Trading, L.L.C. and
certain investors advised by Tudor Investment Corp.
(&#147;Tudor&#148;); and Eastshore Aviation, LLC
(&#147;Eastshore&#148;). In connection with the equity
investments, each of the equity investors received an option to
purchase additional shares at $15.00&nbsp;per share. Par
purchased the options granted to ACE and Eastshore, and each
option holder exercised the first two-thirds of its option on
September&nbsp;28, 2005, for aggregate proceeds to
US&nbsp;Airways Group of approximately $75&nbsp;million. On
October&nbsp;13, 2005, each of the equity investors exercised
the remaining portion of its option for aggregate proceeds to
US&nbsp;Airways Group of approximately $38&nbsp;million.
Proceeds from these new equity investments, including the option
exercises, totaled approximately $678&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Public stock offering</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; On
September&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group completed a
public offering of common stock in which it issued
9,775,000&nbsp;shares of its common stock at a price of
$19.30&nbsp;per share. The Company received net proceeds of
$180&nbsp;million from the offering.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>GE Merger MOU</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; US&nbsp;Airways Group
and America West Holdings reached a comprehensive agreement with
General Electric Capital Corporation (&#147;GECC&#148;), and its
affiliates as described in the Master Merger Memorandum of
Understanding (the &#147;GE Merger MOU&#148;). The key aspects
of the GE Merger MOU are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The GE Merger MOU provided for continued use by US&nbsp;Airways
    Group of certain leased Airbus, Boeing and regional jet
    aircraft, the modification of monthly lease rates, and the
    return to GECC of certain other leased Airbus and Boeing
    aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    GECC provided a bridge facility of approximately
    $56&nbsp;million for use by US&nbsp;Airways Group during the
    pendency of the Chapter&nbsp;11 proceedings. US&nbsp;Airways
    paid an affiliate of General Electric (&#147;GE&#148;)
    $125&nbsp;million in cash on September&nbsp;30, 2005 in exchange
    for retirement of the bridge facility, forgiveness and release
    of US&nbsp;Airways from certain prepetition obligations,
    deferral of certain payment obligations, and amendments to
    maintenance agreements.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">101

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    In June 2005, GECC purchased and immediately leased back to
    US&nbsp;Airways Group: (a)&nbsp;the assets securing the credit
    facility obtained from GE in 2001 (the &#147;2001 GE&nbsp;Credit
    Facility&#148;) and the liquidity facility obtained from GE in
    2003 in connection with US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s emergence
    from the first bankruptcy (the &#147;2003 GE&nbsp;Liquidity
    Facility&#148;), and other GE obligations, consisting of
    11&nbsp;Airbus aircraft and 28 spare engines and engine stands;
    and (b)&nbsp;ten regional jet aircraft previously debt financed
    by GECC. The proceeds from the sale leaseback transaction of
    approximately $633&nbsp;million were used to pay down balances
    due to GE by US&nbsp;Airways Group under the 2003
    GE&nbsp;Liquidity Facility in full, the GECC mortgage-debt
    financed CRJ aircraft in full, and a portion of the 2001 GE
    Credit Facility. The 2001 GE&nbsp;Credit Facility was amended to
    allow certain additional borrowings up to $28&nbsp;million.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Airbus MOU</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; In connection with the
merger, a Memorandum of Understanding (the &#147;Airbus
MOU&#148;) was executed between AVSA S.A.R.L., an affiliate of
Airbus S.A.S. (&#147;Airbus&#148;), US&nbsp;Airways Group,
US&nbsp;Airways and America West Airlines, Inc.
(&#147;AWA&#148;). The key aspects of the Airbus MOU are as
follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA entered into
    two loan agreements with Airbus Financial Services
    (&#147;AFS&#148;), as Initial Lender and Loan&nbsp;Agent, Wells
    Fargo Bank Northwest, National Association, as Collateral Agent,
    and US&nbsp;Airways Group, as guarantor, with commitments in
    initial aggregate amounts of up to $161&nbsp;million and up to
    $89&nbsp;million (the &#147;Airbus $161&nbsp;Million Loan&#148;
    and the &#147;Airbus $89&nbsp;Million Loan&#148; and,
    collectively, the &#147;Airbus Loans&#148;). The Airbus Loans
    bear interest at a rate of LIBOR plus a margin, subject to
    adjustment. The outstanding principal amount of the Airbus
    $89&nbsp;Million Loan will be forgiven in writing on
    December&nbsp;31, 2010, or an earlier date, if on that date the
    outstanding principal amount of, accrued interest on, and all
    other amounts due under the Airbus $161&nbsp;Million Loan have
    been paid in full.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Airbus has rescheduled US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s A320-family
    and <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A330-200</FONT> delivery
    commitments and has agreed to provide backstop financing for a
    substantial number of aircraft, subject to certain terms and
    conditions, on an order of 20 A350 aircraft. US&nbsp;Airways
    Group&#146;s A320-family aircraft are now scheduled for delivery
    in 2009 and 2010. US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s A330-200 aircraft
    are scheduled for delivery in 2009 and 2010 and A350 aircraft
    deliveries are currently scheduled to occur beginning in 2011.
    The Airbus MOU also eliminates cancellation penalties on
    US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s orders for the ten A330-200
    aircraft, provided that US&nbsp;Airways Group has met certain
    predelivery payment obligations under the A350 order. In
    connection with the restructuring of aircraft firm orders,
    US&nbsp;Airways and America West Holdings were required to pay
    an aggregate non-refundable restructuring fee which was paid by
    means of set-off against existing equipment purchase deposits of
    US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West Holdings held by Airbus.
    US&nbsp;Airways recorded its restructuring fee of
    $39&nbsp;million as a reorganization item in the third quarter
    of 2005. AWA&#146;s restructuring fee was $50&nbsp;million,
    along with $7&nbsp;million of capitalized interest, which was
    written off as a special charge upon execution of the agreement.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Restructuring of the ATSB
Loan&nbsp;Guarantees</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; US&nbsp;Airways Group
and America West Holdings each had loans outstanding guaranteed
under the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act
by the Air Transportation Stabilization Board (&#147;ATSB&#148;
and the loans, the &#147;ATSB Loans&#148;). In connection with
the September&nbsp;12, 2004 Chapter&nbsp;11 filing, the ATSB and
the lenders under the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan agreed to
authorize US&nbsp;Airways to continue to use cash collateral
securing the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan on an interim basis (the
&#147;Cash Collateral Agreement&#148;). US&nbsp;Airways reached
agreements with the ATSB concerning interim extensions to the
Cash Collateral Agreement, the last of which was extended to the
earlier of the effective date of the plan of reorganization or
October&nbsp;25, 2005. The Cash Collateral Agreement and
subsequent extensions each required US&nbsp;Airways Group, among
other conditions, to
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">102

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
maintain a weekly minimum unrestricted cash balance which
decreased periodically during the term of the extension.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On July&nbsp;22, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West
Holdings announced that the ATSB approved the proposed merger.
Under the negotiated new loan terms, the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB
Loan is guaranteed by US&nbsp;Airways Group (including all
domestic subsidiaries, with certain limited exceptions) and is
secured by substantially all of the present and future assets of
US&nbsp;Airways Group not otherwise encumbered, other than
certain specified assets, including assets which are subject to
other financing agreements. The AWA ATSB Loan is also guaranteed
by US&nbsp;Airways Group (including all domestic subsidiaries,
with certain limited exceptions) and is secured by a second lien
in the same collateral. The loans continue to have separate
repayment schedules and interest rates; however, the loans are
subject to similar repayments and mandatory amortization in the
event of additional debt issuances, with certain limited
exceptions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;19, 2005, $777&nbsp;million in the aggregate of
the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan and the AWA ATSB Loan, of which
$752&nbsp;million was guaranteed by the ATSB, was sold by the
lender by order of the ATSB to 13 fixed income investors. The
sale of the debt removed the ATSB guaranty and the ATSB has no
interest in any of the Company&#146;s debt. Terms associated
with the loans remain unchanged. As a result of the sale of the
loan, the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan is now referred to as the
US&nbsp;Airways Citibank Loan and the AWA ATSB Loan is now
referred to as the AWA Citibank Loan. The two loans had
outstanding balances of $551&nbsp;million and $250&nbsp;million,
respectively, at December&nbsp;31, 2005. See Note&nbsp;9 for
additional information related to the Citibank Loans.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>New Convertible Notes</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; On
September&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group issued
$144&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of 7%&nbsp;Senior
Convertible Notes due 2020 (the &#147;7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible
Notes&#148;) for proceeds, net of expenses, of approximately
$139&nbsp;million. The 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes are
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s senior unsecured obligations and
rank equally in right of payment to its other senior unsecured
and unsubordinated indebtedness and are effectively subordinated
to its secured indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets
securing such indebtedness. The 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes
are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally
and on a senior unsecured basis, by US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
two major operating subsidiaries, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. The
guarantees are the guarantors&#146; unsecured obligations and
rank equally in right of payment to the other senior unsecured
and unsubordinated indebtedness of the guarantors and are
effectively subordinated to the guarantors&#146; secured
indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets securing such
indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Restructuring of Affinity Credit Card Partner
Agreement</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; In connection with the merger,
AWA, US&nbsp;Airways Group and Juniper Bank, a subsidiary of
Barclays PLC (&#147;Juniper&#148;), entered into an agreement on
August&nbsp;8, 2005 amending AWA&#146;s co-branded credit card
agreement with Juniper, dated January&nbsp;25, 2005. Pursuant to
the amended credit card agreement, Juniper agreed to offer and
market an airline mileage award credit card program to the
general public to participate in US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
Dividend Miles program through the use of a co-branded credit
card.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s credit card program is currently
administered by Bank of America, N.A. (USA). On
December&nbsp;28, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways issued a notice of
termination under its agreement with Bank of America and that
notice will become effective on December&nbsp;28, 2007. Pending
termination of the Bank of America agreement, both Juniper and
Bank of America will run separate credit card programs for
US&nbsp;Airways Group. The amended credit card agreement is the
subject of pending litigation filed by Bank of America against
US&nbsp;Airways Group, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. (See also
Note&nbsp;12(d)).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The amended credit card agreement took effect at the effective
time of the merger. The credit card services provided by Juniper
under the amended credit card agreement began in January 2006,
and will
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">103
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
continue until the expiration date, which is the later of
December&nbsp;31, 2012 or seven years from the date on which
Juniper commences marketing to the general public.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the amended credit card agreement, Juniper will pay to
US&nbsp;Airways Group fees for each mile awarded to each credit
card account administered by Juniper, subject to certain
exceptions. Pursuant to the original credit card agreement,
Juniper paid to AWA a bonus of $20&nbsp;million. Juniper also
agreed to pay a one-time bonus payment of $130&nbsp;million,
following the effectiveness of the merger, subject to certain
conditions. The $130&nbsp;million bonus payment was made to AWA
on October&nbsp;3, 2005. The entire $150&nbsp;million balance
for bonus payments are included in &#147;Deferred gains and
other liabilities&#148; in the accompanying consolidated balance
sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2005. US&nbsp;Airways Group will
not recognize any revenue from the bonus payments until the dual
branding period has expired, approximately February 2008. At
that time the Company expects to begin recognizing revenue from
the bonus payments on a straight-line basis through December
2012, the expiration date of the Juniper agreement. Further, if
Juniper is not granted exclusivity to offer a co-branded credit
card after the dual branding period, US&nbsp;Airways Group must
repay the bonus payments and used pre-paid miles with interest,
plus a $50&nbsp;million penalty. Juniper will pay an annual
bonus of $5&nbsp;million to US&nbsp;Airways Group, subject to
certain exceptions, for each year after Juniper becomes the
exclusive issuer of the co-branded credit card.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;3, 2005, Juniper pre-paid for miles from
US&nbsp;Airways Group totaling $325&nbsp;million, subject to the
same conditions as apply to the $130&nbsp;million bonus payment.
To the extent that these miles are not used by Juniper as
allowed under the co-branded credit card program in certain
circumstances, US&nbsp;Airways Group will repurchase these miles
in 12 equal quarterly installments beginning on the fifth year
prior to the expiration date of the co-branded credit card
agreement with Juniper, until paid in full. US&nbsp;Airways
Group makes monthly interest payments at LIBOR plus 4.75% to
Juniper, beginning on November&nbsp;1, 2005, based on the amount
of pre-purchased miles that have not been used by Juniper in
connection with the co-branded credit card program and have not
been repurchased by US&nbsp;Airways Group. US&nbsp;Airways Group
will be required to repurchase pre-purchased miles under certain
reductions in the collateral held under the credit card
processing agreement with JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. Accordingly,
the prepayment has been recorded as additional indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Juniper requires US&nbsp;Airways Group to maintain an average
quarterly balance of cash, cash equivalents and short-term
investments of at least $1&nbsp;billion for the entirety of the
agreement. Further, the agreement requires US&nbsp;Airways Group
to maintain certain financial ratios beginning January&nbsp;1,
2006. Juniper may, at its option, terminate the amended credit
card agreement, make payments to US&nbsp;Airways Group under the
amended credit card agreement in the form of pre-purchased miles
rather than cash, or require US&nbsp;Airways Group to repurchase
the pre-purchased miles before the fifth year prior to the
expiration date of the co-branded credit card agreement with
Juniper in the event that US&nbsp;Airways Group breaches its
obligations under the amended credit card agreement, or upon the
occurrence of certain events.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Restructuring of Credit Card Processing
Agreement</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; In connection with the merger,
AWA, JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A.,
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">successor-in</FONT>-interest
to JPMorgan Chase Bank, and Chase Merchant Services, L.L.C.
(collectively, &#147;Chase&#148;), entered into the First
Amendment to the Merchant Services Bankcard Agreement on
August&nbsp;8, 2005. Pursuant to the amended card processing
agreement, Chase will perform authorization, processing and
settlement services for sales on Visa and Mastercard for AWA and
US&nbsp;Airways following the merger. The original card
processing agreement is guaranteed by America West Holdings, and
US&nbsp;Airways Group executed a guaranty of the amended card
processing agreement on the effective date of the merger.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; credit card processing is currently
administered by Bank of America, and these processing services
are expected to be transferred to Chase on or before
April&nbsp;25, 2006. US&nbsp;Airways will
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">104

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
become a party to the amended card processing agreement at the
time that Chase begins processing for US&nbsp;Airways.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The amended card processing agreement took effect at the
effective time of the merger and continues until the expiration
of the initial term, which is three years from the effective
date. Upon expiration of the initial term, the amended card
processing agreement will automatically renew for successive
one-year periods pursuant to the terms of the agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the amended card processing agreement, AWA will pay to
Chase fees in connection with card processing services such as
sales authorization, settlement services and customer service.
AWA and US&nbsp;Airways are also required to maintain a reserve
account to secure Chase&#146;s exposure to outstanding air
traffic liability
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Asset Based Financings and Sales</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; In
addition to the sale-leaseback transactions completed in June
2005 related to the GE Merger MOU described above,
US&nbsp;Airways also executed flight equipment asset sale and
sale-leaseback transactions in the third and fourth quarters of
2005. While transactions completed prior to the merger date by
US&nbsp;Airways are not reflected in the US&nbsp;Airways Group
financial statements as a result of accounting for the merger as
a reverse acquisition, these transactions provided additional
liquidity and reductions to debt for US&nbsp;Airways Group.
US&nbsp;Airways received net proceeds of $209&nbsp;million and a
reduction in aircraft related debt of $561&nbsp;million.
Additionally during the third quarter, US&nbsp;Airways received
net proceeds of $51&nbsp;million in connection with an agreement
to sell and leaseback certain of its commuter slots at Ronald
Reagan Washington National Airport and New York LaGuardia
Airport. US&nbsp;Airways was required to use proceeds totaling
$156&nbsp;million to pay down the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
For 2005, AWA executed flight equipment asset sale and leaseback
transactions resulting in net proceeds of $23&nbsp;million and a
reduction in aircraft related debt of $38&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>2.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Basis of presentation and summary of significant accounting
    policies</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Nature of operations and operating environment</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s primary business activity is the
operation of a major network air carrier through its ownership
of the common stock of US&nbsp;Airways, America West Holdings,
Piedmont Airlines, Inc. (&#147;Piedmont&#148;),
PSA&nbsp;Airlines, Inc. (&#147;PSA&#148;), Material Services
Company, Inc. (&#147;MSC&#148;) and Airways Assurance Limited,
LLC (&#147;AAL&#148;).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways and AWA are the Company&#146;s principal
operating subsidiaries. US&nbsp;Airways and America West
Airlines are both certificated air carriers engaged primarily in
the business of transporting passengers, property and mail.
US&nbsp;Airways and AWA enplaned approximately 42&nbsp;million
and 22&nbsp;million passengers, respectively, in 2005. Combined,
US&nbsp;Airways and America West Airlines are the fifth largest
U.S.&nbsp;air carrier, as ranked by domestic revenue passenger
miles (&#147;RPMs&#148;) and domestic available seat miles
(&#147;ASMs&#148;). As of December&nbsp;31, 2005,
US&nbsp;Airways operated 232 jet aircraft and 18 regional jet
aircraft and AWA operated 141 jet aircraft and 62 regional jet
aircraft. During 2005, US&nbsp;Airways provided regularly
scheduled service or seasonal service at 91&nbsp;airports in the
continental United States, Canada, Mexico, France, Germany,
Italy, Spain, Ireland, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and
the Caribbean and AWA provided regularly scheduled service at
64&nbsp;airports in North America, including eight in Mexico,
four in Canada and one in Costa Rica.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Most of the airline operations are in competitive markets.
Competitors include other air carriers along with other modes of
transportation. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways
Group employed approximately 36,600 active full time equivalent
employees. Approximately 80% of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
employees are covered by collective bargaining agreements with
various labor unions.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">105

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 24pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Basis of presentation</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The merger has been accounted for as a reverse acquisition using
the purchase method of accounting. Although the merger was
structured such that America West Holdings became a wholly owned
subsidiary of US&nbsp;Airways Group, America West Holdings has
been treated as the acquiring company for accounting purposes
under Statement of Financial Accounting Standards
(&#147;SFAS&#148;) No.&nbsp;141 &#147;Business
Combinations,&#148; due to the following factors:
(1)&nbsp;America West Holdings&#146; stockholders received the
larger share of the Company&#146;s common stock in the merger in
comparison to the unsecured creditors of US&nbsp;Airways;
(2)&nbsp;America West Holdings received a larger number of
designees to the board of directors; and (3)&nbsp;America West
Holdings&#146; Chairman and Chief Executive Officer prior to the
merger became the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the
combined company. As a result of the reverse acquisition, the
statements of operations presented include the results of
America West Holdings for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005
and consolidated results of US&nbsp;Airways Group for the period
from September&nbsp;27, 2005 through December&nbsp;31, 2005. The
financial information reflected in the financial statements for
periods prior to the merger are comprised of the accounts and
activities of America West Holdings, the holding company of AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the
accounts of US&nbsp;Airways Group and its wholly owned
subsidiaries. Principal subsidiaries include US&nbsp;Airways,
AWA, Piedmont and PSA. US&nbsp;Airways Group has the ability to
move funds freely between its operating subsidiaries to support
operations. These transfers are recognized as intercompany
transactions. All significant intercompany accounts and
transactions have been eliminated. As discussed further in
Note&nbsp;15, the financial results of US&nbsp;Airways Group and
its wholly owned subsidiaries include certain related party
transactions. The preparation of financial statements in
conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the
United States of America requires management to make estimates
and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and
liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities
at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts
of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual
results could differ from those estimates. The principal areas
of judgment relate to passenger revenue recognition, impairment
of long-lived assets and intangible assets, the frequent
traveler program and estimates of fair value for assets and
liabilities established in fresh-start reporting and purchase
accounting.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company classified revenue and expenses associated with its
wholly owned regional airline subsidiaries,
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; MidAtlantic division and affiliate
regional airlines under capacity purchase agreements as Express
revenue and Express expenses in the accompanying consolidated
statement of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform
with the 2005 presentation. In the first quarter of 2005, AWA
changed its method of reporting for its regional alliance
agreement with Mesa Airlines (&#147;Mesa&#148;) from the net
basis of presentation to the gross basis of presentation. See
also Note&nbsp;5 for additional information about the agreement
with Mesa and the reclassifications related to the change in
presentation.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Cash equivalents and short-term investments</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Cash equivalents and short-term investments consist primarily of
cash in money market securities of various banks, highly liquid
debt instruments, commercial paper and asset-backed securities
of various financial institutions and securities backed by the
U.S.&nbsp;Government. All highly liquid investments purchased
within three months of maturity are classified as cash
equivalents. All other highly liquid investments are classified
as short-term investments. Investments in auction rate
securities are classified as short-term investments on the
accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">106
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Debt securities are classified as &#147;held to maturity&#148;
in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;115, &#147;Accounting for
Certain Investments in Debt and Equity Securities&#148;
(&#147;SFAS&nbsp;115&#148;). Held to maturity investments are
carried at amortized cost, which approximates fair value.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company classifies securities other than debt underlying its
cash equivalents and short-term investments as
&#147;available-for-sale&#148; in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;115.
Cash equivalents are stated at cost, which approximates fair
value due to the highly liquid nature and short maturities of
the underlying securities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(d)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Restricted cash</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Restricted cash includes deposits in trust accounts primarily to
fund certain taxes and fees and collateralize letters of credit
and workers&#146; compensation claims, cash deposits securing
certain letters of credit and surety bonds and cash deposits
held by institutions that process credit card sales
transactions. Restricted cash is stated at cost, which
approximates fair value.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(e)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Materials and supplies, net</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Inventories of materials and supplies are valued at the lower of
cost or fair value. Costs are determined using average costing
methods. An allowance for obsolescence is provided for flight
equipment expendable and repairable parts.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(f)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Property and equipment</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Property and equipment are recorded at cost. Interest expenses
related to the acquisition of certain property and equipment are
capitalized as an additional cost of the asset or as a leasehold
improvement if the asset is leased. Interest capitalized for the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 was
$4&nbsp;million, $2&nbsp;million and $2&nbsp;million,
respectively. Property and equipment is depreciated and
amortized to residual values over the estimated useful lives or
the lease term, whichever is less, using the straight-line
method. Costs of major improvements that enhance the usefulness
of the asset are capitalized and depreciated over the estimated
useful life of the asset or the modifications, whichever is less.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The estimated useful lives for ground property and equipment
range from 3 to 12&nbsp;years for owned property and equipment
and from 18 to 30&nbsp;years for training equipment and
buildings. The estimated useful lives of owned aircraft, jet
engines, flight equipment and rotable parts range from 5 to
25&nbsp;years. Leasehold improvements relating to flight
equipment and other property on operating leases are amortized
over the life of the lease or the life of the asset, whichever
is shorter, on a straight-line basis.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company records impairment losses on long-lived assets used
in operations when events and circumstances indicate that the
assets might be impaired as defined by SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;144,
&#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived
Assets&#148; (&#147;SFAS&nbsp;144&#148;). Recoverability of
assets to be held and used is measured by a comparison of the
carrying amount of an asset to undiscounted future net cash
flows expected to be generated by the asset. If such assets are
considered to be impaired, the impairment to be recognized is
measured by the amount by which the carrying amount of the
assets exceeds the fair value of the assets. Assets to be
disposed of are reported at the lower of the carrying amount or
fair value less cost to sell.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(g)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Income taxes</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability
method. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for
the future tax consequences attributable to differences between
the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and
liabilities and their respective tax bases and operating loss
and tax
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">107

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
credit carryforwards. A valuation allowance is established, if
necessary, for the amount of any tax benefits that, based on
available evidence, are not expected to be realized.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>

    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(h)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Goodwill and other intangibles, net</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
At December&nbsp;31, 2005, goodwill represents the cost in
excess of the net amount assigned to assets acquired and
liabilities assumed by America West Holdings on
September&nbsp;27, 2005. Since that time, there have been no
events or changes that would indicate an impairment to goodwill.
The Company will perform its next annual impairment test on
October&nbsp;1, 2006. The provisions of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;142,
&#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets&#148;
(&#147;SFAS&nbsp;142&#148;) require that a two-step impairment
test be performed on goodwill. In the first step, the fair value
of the reporting unit is compared to its carrying value. If the
fair value of the reporting unit exceeds the carrying value of
the net assets of the reporting unit, goodwill is not impaired
and no further testing is required. If the carrying value of the
net assets of the reporting unit exceeds the fair value of the
reporting unit, then a second step must be performed in order to
determine the implied fair value of the goodwill and compare it
to the carrying value of the goodwill. If the carrying value of
goodwill exceeds its implied fair value, then an impairment loss
is recorded equal to the difference.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Other intangible assets consist primarily of trademark,
international route authorities and airport take-off and landing
slots and airport gates acquired in connection with the merger.
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company has $56&nbsp;million
and $30&nbsp;million of route authorities and trademarks on its
balance sheets, respectively. Route authorities and trademarks
are classified as indefinite lived assets under SFAS&nbsp;142.
Indefinite-lived assets are not amortized but instead are
reviewed for impairment annually and more frequently if events
or circumstances indicate that the asset may be impaired.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
SFAS&nbsp;142 requires that intangible assets with estimable
useful lives be amortized over their respective estimated useful
lives to their estimated residual values, and reviewed for
impairments in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;144. The following
table provides information relating to the Company&#146;s
intangible assets subject to amortization as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005 (in millions):
</DIV>

<CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
A/A=Accumulated Amortization
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The intangible assets subject to amortization generally are
amortized over 25&nbsp;years for airport take-off and landing
slots and over the term of the lease for airport gate leasehold
rights on a straight-line basis and are included in depreciation
and amortization on the statements of operations. For the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company recorded amortization
expense of $8&nbsp;million related to its intangible assets. The
Company expects to record annual amortization expense of
$29&nbsp;million in 2006, $25&nbsp;million in years 2007 through
2009 and $24&nbsp;million in 2010 related to these intangible
assets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Other assets, net consist primarily of deposits held by vendors,
unamortized debt issuance costs, long-term investments and
leasehold interests in aircraft. In connection with fresh-start
reporting for US&nbsp;Airways, aircraft operating leases were
adjusted to fair value and $101&nbsp;million of assets were
established for leasehold interests in aircraft for aircraft
leases with rental rates deemed to be below
</DIV>
