<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
market rates. These leasehold interests are amortized on a
straight-line basis as an increase to aircraft rent expense over
the applicable remaining lease periods, generally 17&nbsp;years.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(j)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Frequent traveler program</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s principal operating subsidiaries,
AWA and US&nbsp;Airways, maintain frequent travel award programs
known as &#147;FlightFund&#148; and &#147;Dividend Miles,&#148;
respectively. These programs provide a variety of awards to
program members based on accumulated mileage. The estimated cost
of providing the free travel, using the incremental cost method
as adjusted for estimated redemption rates, is recognized as a
liability and charged to operations as program members
accumulate mileage and requisite mileage award levels are
achieved. For travel awards on partner airlines, the liability
is based on the average contractual amount to be paid to the
other airline per redemption.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(k)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Derivative instruments</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company utilizes financial derivative instruments primarily
to manage its risk associated with changing jet fuel prices. The
Company utilizes heating oil-based derivative instruments to
hedge a portion of its exposure to jet fuel price increases.
These instruments primarily consist of costless collars which
hedge over 20&nbsp;percent of its 2006 total anticipated jet
fuel requirements at average crude oil equivalent prices of no
higher than $67&nbsp;per barrel as of December&nbsp;31, 2005.
The Company does not purchase or hold any derivative financial
instruments for trading purposes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
SFAS&nbsp;133, &#147;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and
Hedging Activities, as amended,&#148;
(&#147;SFAS&nbsp;133&#148;) requires that all derivatives be
marked to market (fair value) and recorded on the balance sheet.
Derivatives that are not hedges must be adjusted to fair value
through income.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways had no open fuel
hedge positions in place. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004,
AWA had open fuel hedge positions in place, which do not
currently qualify for hedge accounting under SFAS&nbsp;133.
Accordingly, the derivative hedging instruments are recorded as
an asset or liability on the balance sheet at fair value and any
changes in fair value are recorded as gains on fuel hedging
instruments, net in operating expenses in the accompanying
consolidated statements of operations in the period of change.
During 2005, 2004 and 2003, AWA recognized gains of
$75&nbsp;million, $24&nbsp;million and $11&nbsp;million,
respectively, related to hedging activities. The fair value of
AWA&#146;s financial derivative instruments at December&nbsp;31,
2005 and 2004 was a net asset of approximately $4&nbsp;million
and $0.2&nbsp;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Since AWA&#146;s financial derivative instruments are not traded
on a market exchange, the values are determined by the use of
valuation models with assumptions about commodity prices based
on those observed in the underlying markets.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways holds stock options in Sabre Holding Corporation
(&#147;Sabre&#148;) and warrants in a number of
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">e-commerce</FONT> companies as
a result of service agreements with them. On an ongoing basis,
US&nbsp;Airways adjusts its balance sheet to reflect changes in
the current fair market value of the stock options and warrants
to other non-operating income (expense) on its statements of
operations. See Note&nbsp;8 for more information on
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s derivative financial instruments.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In 2004, AWA restated its consolidated financial statements to
eliminate hedge accounting under SFAS&nbsp;133 for its fuel
hedging transactions. As part of this restatement,
$2&nbsp;million of unrealized gains previously reported as a
component of accumulated other comprehensive income in 2002 were
eliminated in the 2003 financial statements.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">109

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 24pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(l)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Deferred gains and credits, net</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with fresh-start reporting and purchase
accounting, US&nbsp;Airways&#146; aircraft operating leases were
adjusted to fair value and deferred credits of $190&nbsp;million
were established in the accompanying balance sheet representing
the net present value of the difference between the stated lease
rates and the fair market rates. These deferred credits will be
decreased on a straight-line basis as a reduction in rent
expense over the applicable lease periods. Gains on aircraft
sale and leaseback transactions are deferred and amortized over
the terms of the leases as a reduction of the related aircraft
rent expense.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Rents for operating leases were adjusted to fair market value
when AWA emerged from bankruptcy in 1994. The net present value
of the difference between the stated lease rates and the fair
market rates has been recorded as a deferred credit in the
accompanying consolidated balance sheets. The deferred credit
will be decreased on a straight-line basis as a reduction in
rent expense over the applicable lease periods. At
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, the unamortized balance of the
deferred credit was $37&nbsp;million and $38&nbsp;million,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported
by a $380&nbsp;million government loan guarantee from the ATSB.
This loan triggered aircraft rent concessions negotiated with
approximately 20 aircraft lessors. Approximately
$18&nbsp;million of aircraft rent, which was accrued as of
December&nbsp;31, 2001, was waived by the aircraft lessors. This
amount has been recorded as a deferred credit in the
accompanying consolidated balance sheet and is being amortized
over the remaining lives of the applicable leases as a reduction
in rent expense. At December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, the
unamortized balance of the deferred credit was approximately
$3&nbsp;million and $4&nbsp;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways has deferred the gain related to the exercise of
Sabre options. The gain will be amortized over the contract
period as a reduction to other operating expenses. See
Note&nbsp;8 for more information related to the Sabre options.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(m)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Passenger revenues</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Passenger revenue is recognized when transportation is provided.
Ticket sales for transportation that has not yet been provided
are initially recorded as air traffic liability on the balance
sheet. The air traffic liability represents tickets sold for
future travel dates and estimated future refunds and exchanges
of tickets sold for past travel dates. The majority of tickets
sold are nonrefundable. Tickets that are sold but not flown on
the travel date may be reused for another flight, up to a year
from the date of sale, or refunded, if the ticket is refundable,
after taking into account any cancellation penalties or change
fees. A small percentage of tickets, or partially used tickets,
expire unused. Due to complex pricing structures, refund and
exchange policies, and interline agreements with other airlines,
certain amounts are recognized in revenue using estimates
regarding both the timing of the revenue recognition and the
amount of revenue to be recognized. These estimates are
generally based on the analysis of our historical data.
US&nbsp;Airways Group and members of the airline industry have
consistently applied this accounting method to estimate revenue
from forfeited tickets at the date travel was to be provided.
Estimated future refunds and exchanges included in the air
traffic liability are routinely evaluated based on subsequent
activity to validate the accuracy of the Company&#146;s
estimates. Any adjustments resulting from periodic evaluations
of the estimated air traffic liability are included in results
of operations during the period in which the evaluations are
completed.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Passenger traffic commissions and related fees are expensed when
the related revenue is recognized. Passenger traffic commissions
and related fees not yet recognized are included as a prepaid
expense.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group purchases capacity, or ASMs, generated by
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned regional air carriers
and the capacity of Air Wisconsin Airlines Corp. (&#147;Air
Wisconsin&#148;), Republic Airline
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">110
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
Inc. (&#147;Republic&#148;), Mesa and Chautauqua Airlines, Inc.
(&#147;Chautauqua&#148;) in certain markets. Air Wisconsin,
Mesa, Chautauqua and Republic operate regional jet aircraft in
these markets as part of US&nbsp;Airways Group Express and AWA
Express. US&nbsp;Airways Group classifies revenues related to
capacity purchase arrangements as Express passenger revenues.
Liabilities related to tickets sold for travel on these air
carriers are also included in US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s air
traffic liability and are subsequently relieved in the same
manner as described above.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA and US&nbsp;Airways also sell mileage credits to companies
participating in the FlightFund and Dividend Miles programs,
such as participating airlines, hotels, car rental agencies and
credit card companies. Transportation-related revenue from the
sale of mileage credits is deferred and recognized as mainline
passenger revenue when transportation is provided. The remaining
portion of sales proceeds is recognized immediately as a
component of other operating revenues.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(n)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Stock-based compensation</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company had two stock-based
employee compensation plans and one expired stock-based employee
compensation plan, which are described more fully in
Note&nbsp;19 &#147;Stock Options and Awards.&#148;
US&nbsp;Airways Group accounts for its stock option plans in
accordance with the provisions of APB Opinion No.&nbsp;25,
&#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees&#148;
(&#147;APB&nbsp;25&#148;), and related interpretations. As such,
compensation expense for options granted would be recorded on
the date of grant only if the current market price of the
underlying stock exceeded the exercise price. Stock options are
issued at a price equal to fair market value on the date of
grant. Accordingly, no compensation cost has been recognized for
stock options in the consolidated financial statements.
Compensation expense, calculated using the provisions of
APB&nbsp;25, has been recorded for stock appreciation rights and
restricted stock units granted to US&nbsp;Airways Group
employees.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Had US&nbsp;Airways Group determined compensation cost based on
the fair value at the grant date for its stock options, stock
appreciation rights and restricted stock units under
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123, &#147;Accounting for Stock Based
Compensation,&#148; the Company&#146;s net income (loss) and
earnings (loss) per share would have been adjusted as indicated
below (in million, except per share data):
</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(o)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Maintenance and repair costs</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Maintenance and repair costs for owned and leased flight
equipment are charged to operating expense as incurred. AWA
historically recorded the cost of major scheduled airframe,
engine and certain component overhauls as capitalized assets
that were subsequently amortized over the periods benefited,
referred to as the deferral method. US&nbsp;Airways Group
charges maintenance and repair costs for owned
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">111

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
and leased flight equipment to operating expense as incurred. In
2005, AWA changed its accounting policy from the deferral method
to the direct expense method. While the deferral method is
permitted under accounting principles generally accepted in the
United States of America, US&nbsp;Airway Group and AWA believe
that the direct expense method is preferable and the predominant
method used in the airline industry. The effect of this change
in accounting for aircraft maintenance and repairs is recorded
as a cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle (see
also Note&nbsp;4).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(p)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Selling expenses</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Selling expenses include commissions, credit card fees,
computerized reservations systems fees and advertising and
promotional expenses. Advertising and promotional expenses are
expensed when incurred. Advertising and promotional expenses for
the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 were
$13&nbsp;million, $10&nbsp;million and $11&nbsp;million,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(q)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Express expenses</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Expenses associated with US&nbsp;Airways&#146; MidAtlantic
division, US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned regional
airlines and affiliate regional airlines operating as
US&nbsp;Airways Express and expenses associated with AWA&#146;s
regional alliance agreement with Mesa are classified as Express
expenses on the statements of operations. Expenses associated
with prior periods have been reclassified as discussed in
Note&nbsp;5. Express expenses on the statements of operations
consists of the following (in millions):
</DIV>

    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>&#151;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff">
    <TD align="left" valign="top">

    Other expenses</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>

</CENTER>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(r)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Variable interest entities</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group has adopted Financial Accounting Standards
Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) Interpretation No.&nbsp;46
&#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; as
revised (&#147;FIN&nbsp;46(R)&#148;). As described below, the
adoption of FIN&nbsp;46 did not materially affect
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s, AWA&#146;s or
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; financial statements. In the fourth
quarter of 2005, as a result of entering into new jet service
agreements, US&nbsp;Airways determined that certain entities
with which the Company has capacity purchase agreements are
considered variable interest entities under FIN&nbsp;46(R). The
Company has determined that it is not the primary beneficiary of
any of these variable interest entities, and accordingly, does
not consolidate any of the entities with which it has jet
service agreements. (See also Notes&nbsp;12(b), 12(c) and 12(e)).
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">112

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 24pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(s)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>New accounting pronouncements</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In December 2004, the FASB issued SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123R,
&#147;Share-Based Payment&#148; (&#147;SFAS&nbsp;123R&#148;).
SFAS&nbsp;123R is a revision of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123,
&#147;Accounting for Stock Based Compensation,&#148; and
supersedes APB&nbsp;25. Among other items, SFAS&nbsp;123R
eliminates the use of APB&nbsp;25 and the intrinsic value method
of accounting, and requires the Company to recognize the cost of
employee services received in exchange for awards of equity
instruments, based on the grant date fair value of those awards,
in the financial statements. Pro forma disclosure is no longer
an alternative under the new standard. Although early adoption
was allowed, the Company adopted SFAS&nbsp;123R as of
January&nbsp;1, 2006, the required effective date for calendar
year companies.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
SFAS&nbsp;123R permits companies to adopt its requirements using
either a &#147;modified prospective&#148; method, or a
&#147;modified retrospective&#148; method. Under the
&#147;modified prospective&#148; method, compensation cost is
recognized in the financial statements beginning with the
effective date, based on the requirements of SFAS&nbsp;123R for
all share-based payments granted after that date, and based on
the requirements of SFAS&nbsp;123 for all unvested awards
granted prior to the effective date of SFAS&nbsp;123R. Under the
&#147;modified retrospective&#148; method, the requirements are
the same as under the &#147;modified prospective&#148; method,
but also permit entities to restate financial statements of
previous periods based on pro forma disclosures made in
accordance with SFAS&nbsp;123. The Company adopted the
requirements of SFAS&nbsp;123R using the modified prospective
method.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company currently utilizes a standard option pricing model
(i.e., Black-Scholes) to measure the fair value of stock options
granted to employees. While SFAS&nbsp;123R permits entities to
continue to use such a model, the standard also permits the use
of a more complex binomial, or &#147;lattice&#148; model. Based
upon research done by the Company on the alternative models
available to value option grants, the Company has determined
that it will continue to use the Black-Scholes model for option
valuation as of the current time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
SFAS&nbsp;123R includes several modifications to the way that
income taxes are recorded in the financial statements. The
expense for certain types of option grants is only deductible
for tax purposes at the time that the taxable event takes place,
which could cause variability in effective tax rates.
SFAS&nbsp;123R does not allow companies to &#147;predict&#148;
when these taxable events will take place. Furthermore, it
requires that the benefits associated with the tax deductions in
excess of recognized compensation cost be reported as a
financing cash flow, rather than as an operating cash flow as
required under current literature. This requirement will reduce
net operating cash flows and increase net financing cash flows
in periods after the effective date. These future amounts cannot
be estimated, because they depend on, among other things, when
employees exercise stock options.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
America West Holdings and AWA employee stock options outstanding
at the time of the merger were fully vested in accordance with
the change of control provisions of America West Holdings&#146;
stock option plans. US&nbsp;Airways outstanding stock options
were cancelled as part of the plan of reorganization.
Accordingly, as of January&nbsp;1, 2006, only unvested director
stock options, employee stock options, and stock appreciation
rights granted subsequent to the merger are subject to the
transition provisions of SFAS&nbsp;123R.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of January&nbsp;1, 2006, approximately 2,865,925 unvested
stock options and stock-based awards with weighted average fair
values ranging from $7.94 to $11.34 are subject to the
recognition provisions of SFAS&nbsp;123R. The Company expects
that the impact of adoption of SFAS&nbsp;123R will be
significant to the 2006 results of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In May 2005, the FASB issued SFAS&nbsp;No 154, &#147;Accounting
Changes and Error Corrections&nbsp;&#151; A replacement of APB
Opinion No.&nbsp;20 and FASB Statement No.&nbsp;3&#148;
(&#147;SFAS&nbsp;154&#148;). SFAS&nbsp;154 applies to all
voluntary changes in accounting principle, and changes the
requirements for accounting for and
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">113

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
reporting of a change in accounting principle. SFAS&nbsp;154
requires retrospective application to prior periods&#146;
financial statements of a voluntary change in accounting
principle unless it is impracticable. APB Opinion 20 previously
required that most voluntary changes in accounting principle be
recognized by including in net income of the period of the
change the cumulative effect of changing to the new accounting
principle. The provisions in SFAS&nbsp;154 are effective for
accounting changes and correction of errors made in fiscal years
beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2005. The adoption of
SFAS&nbsp;154 is not expected to have a material effect on the
results of operations of the Company.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>3.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>New equity structure and conversion</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Pursuant to US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s plan of reorganization,
all securities of US&nbsp;Airways Group outstanding prior to
September&nbsp;27, 2005 were cancelled upon emergence from
Chapter&nbsp;11. In connection with the merger, US&nbsp;Airways
Group adopted an Amended and Restated Certificate of
Incorporation and Amended and Restated Bylaws effective
September&nbsp;27, 2005. US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s authorized
capital stock, following the merger, consists of
200&nbsp;million shares of common stock, par value
$0.01&nbsp;per share. Holders of new US&nbsp;Airways Group
common stock are entitled to one vote per share on all matters
submitted to a vote of common shareholders, except that voting
rights of
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">non-U.S.&nbsp;</FONT>citizens
are limited to the extent that the shares of common stock held
by such
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">non-U.S.&nbsp;</FONT>persons
would otherwise be entitled to more than 24.9% of the aggregate
votes of all outstanding equity securities of US&nbsp;Airways
Group.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the merger, holders of America West Holdings Class&nbsp;A
common stock received 0.5362 of a share of new US&nbsp;Airways
Group common stock for each share of America West Holdings
Class&nbsp;A common stock they owned, and holders of America
West Holdings Class&nbsp;B common stock received 0.4125 of a
share of new US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock for each share
of America West Holdings Class&nbsp;B common stock they owned,
according to the terms specified in the merger agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As noted in Note&nbsp;1 above, the new equity investors acquired
an aggregate of approximately 44&nbsp;million shares of common
stock, including the shares acquired upon exercise of their
options. In connection with these new equity investments, the
new equity investors entered into stockholders agreements that
prohibit the equity investors&#146; sale of US&nbsp;Airways
Group common stock for a period of six months following the
closing date of the investment. Under the terms of the Pension
Benefit Guaranty Corporation (&#147;PBGC&#148;) settlement
agreement, shares issued to the PBGC in connection with the
reorganization could not be sold, assigned, transferred or
pledged prior to five months after the merger effective date.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Upon expiration of each tranche of the investor options,
US&nbsp;Airways Group was required to make an additional offer
to Eastshore, in an amount equal to one-third of the proceeds
received from exercise of the options, to repurchase shares of
common stock held by Eastshore at a purchase price of
$15.00&nbsp;per share. Eastshore had the right, but not the
obligation, to accept that offer to repurchase in whole or in
part for a period of at least 30&nbsp;days after the receipt of
the offer. On October&nbsp;4, 2005, the Company made the offer
in connection with the first expiration date, and on
November&nbsp;3, 2005 the offer expired. On November&nbsp;8,
2005, the Company made the offer to Eastshore in connection with
the second expiration date and on December&nbsp;8, 2005 the
offer expired.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>4.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Change in accounting policy for maintenance costs</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA historically recorded the cost of major scheduled airframe,
engine and certain component overhauls as capitalized assets
that were subsequently amortized over the periods benefited
(referred to as the deferral method). US&nbsp;Airways Group
charges maintenance and repair costs for owned and leased flight
equipment to operating expense as incurred (direct expense
method). During the fourth quarter of 2005, AWA changed its
accounting policy from the deferral method to the direct expense
method. While the deferral method is permitted under accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States of America,
US&nbsp;Airways Group believes that the direct expense method is
preferable because the direct
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">114

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
expense method is the predominant method used in the airline
industry and because it eliminates significant judgment and
estimation inherent under the deferral method.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The effect of this change in accounting for aircraft maintenance
and repairs is recorded as a cumulative effect of a change in
accounting principle. The effect of the change in 2005 was to
increase net loss by approximately $48&nbsp;million (or
$1.52&nbsp;per share). The increase in the 2005&nbsp;net loss of
$202&nbsp;million is the cumulative effect on retained earnings
of the adoption as of January&nbsp;1, 2005. The cumulative
effect of the change in accounting principle is not presented
net of tax as any tax effects resulting from the change have
been immediately offset by the recording of a valuation
allowance through the same financial statement caption.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The pro forma net income (loss) shown on the consolidated
statements of operations have been adjusted for the effects of
retroactive application of the impact of maintenance costs. The
following pro forma earnings (loss) per share amounts show the
effect of the retroactive application of the change in
accounting.
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

<TR style="font-size: 1pt;">
    <TD width="71%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 2005 quarterly financial data presented in Note&nbsp;21 has
been adjusted to reflect the change in accounting policy as if
the change occurred on January&nbsp;1, 2005. In addition, pro
forma quarterly financial data for 2004 has been presented to
reflect comparable information as if the newly adopted
accounting policy for maintenance costs had been applied during
all periods affected.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>5.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Change in method of reporting for America West Express
    results and other reclassifications</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform
with the 2005 presentation. These reclassifications include
reclassing: fuel hedging activities from nonoperating to
operating expenses, fuel-related tax expenses from other
expenses to aircraft fuel and related taxes expense and the sale
of frequent flier miles and related marketing services to
affinity partners from other operating expense to mainline
passenger and other revenue. The portion of the affinity partner
revenue related to passenger ticket sales is classified as
mainline passenger revenue and the marketing portion of the
affinity partner revenue is classified as other revenue.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA has a regional airline alliance agreement with Mesa (the
&#147;Mesa Agreement&#148;) that commenced in February 2001.
Mesa, operating as America West Express, provides feeder service
for AWA. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, the America West Express
fleet included 62&nbsp;aircraft comprised of
38&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">86-seat</FONT>
CRJ&nbsp;900 aircraft, 18&nbsp;50-seat CRJ 200 aircraft and six
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">37-seat</FONT> Dash&nbsp;8
turboprop aircraft. The Mesa Agreement is anticipated to expire
in June 2012.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the Mesa Agreement, Mesa is required to fly the routes and
flights designated by AWA using Mesa&#146;s aircraft, flight
crews and other related services. Mesa maintains and operates
the aircraft; employs, trains, manages and compensates personnel
necessary to provide the flight services; and provides related
passenger handling services for and on the flights. AWA is
responsible for establishing the routes, scheduling Express
flights, pricing of the tickets, marketing and selling the
tickets, collecting all sales
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">115

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
amounts, paying all costs of sales and marketing and taking
inventory risk on the inventory of seats for sale on Mesa. The
ground handling of aircraft is performed by either AWA or Mesa,
depending upon the airport.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA collects the revenue and income generated from the services
provided by Mesa pursuant to the Mesa Agreement. In return, AWA:
(i)&nbsp;reimburses Mesa for actual non-controllable costs
incurred by Mesa such as fuel, insurance, taxes, fees and
security; (ii)&nbsp;pays Mesa for actual controllable
non-maintenance costs, subject to a cap, such as aircraft lease
expense and crew expense; (iii)&nbsp;pays Mesa for controllable
maintenance costs at fixed rates (subject to reimbursement of
excess costs if actual costs during the term are less than fixed
amounts paid by AWA); (iv)&nbsp;reimburses Mesa costs and
expenses incurred at stations maintained and operated by Mesa;
and (v)&nbsp;shares with Mesa a percentage of the revenue
allocated to the flight segments flown by Mesa on a pro rata
basis.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
To improve the visibility of mainline and America West Express
operating results, effective in the first quarter of 2005,
America West Holdings changed its method of accounting for the
Mesa Agreement from the net basis to the gross basis of
presentation. Under the gross basis of presentation, passenger
revenues and operating expenses associated with the Mesa
agreement are reported gross (i.e., in operating revenues as
Express passenger and within operating expenses as Express
expenses) in the condensed consolidated statement of operations.
Under the net basis of presentation, America West Express
passenger revenues and the associated operating expenses were
netted and classified in operating revenues in other. Prior
period amounts have been reclassified to be consistent with the
2005 presentation. The America West Express reclassifications
did not impact operating income or net income (loss) for the
periods presented.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The following table presents the effect of this reclassification
for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003 (in
millions):
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The operating margin that results from using the gross basis of
presentation for Express revenues and expenses does not include
passenger revenue generated by feed into AWA&#146;s mainline
operations from Express flights, which is referred to as beyond
contribution passenger revenue.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">117

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 24pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>6.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Earning/ loss per common share</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Basic earnings (loss) per common share (&#147;EPS&#148;) is
computed by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted average
number of shares of common stock outstanding during the period.
Diluted EPS reflects the maximum dilution that would result
after giving effect to all potential dilutive common shares from
stock options, warrants and convertible debt. The number of
additional shares is calculated by assuming that outstanding,
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">in-the</FONT>-money stock
options and warrants were exercised and the proceeds from such
exercises were used to buy back shares of common stock at the
average market price for the reporting period. The following
table presents the computation of basic and diluted EPS (in
millions, except per share amounts):
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

<TR style="font-size: 1pt;">

    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2,656,804 stock
options are not included in the computation of diluted EPS
because the option exercise prices were greater than the average
market price of common stock for the period. Options to acquire
930,976 common shares are not included in the computation of
diluted EPS because of the antidilutive effect on EPS. In
addition, 3,021,908 warrants issued in conjunction with the AWA
ATSB Loan and related transactions are not included in the
computation of diluted EPS because of the antidilutive effect on
EPS. In addition, 1,506,141 incremental shares from assumed
conversion of the 7%&nbsp;senior convertible notes, 3,860,289
incremental shares from assumed conversion of the
7.5%&nbsp;senior convertible notes and 3,042,555 incremental
shares from assumed conversion of the 7.25%&nbsp;senior
exchangeable notes are not included in the computation of
diluted EPS because of the antidilutive effect on EPS.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2,165,168 stock
options and 3,033,108 warrants issued in conjunction with the
AWA ATSB Loan and related transactions are not included in the
computation of diluted EPS because the option and warrant
exercise prices were greater than the average market price of
common stock for the period. In addition, 3,339,535&nbsp;shares
issuable upon conversion of the 7.25%&nbsp;senior exchangeable
notes due 2023 and 3,586,275 issuable upon conversion of the
7.5%&nbsp;convertible senior notes are not included in the
computation of diluted EPS because of the antidilutive effect on
EPS.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2,168,146 stock
options and 4,706,756 warrants issued in conjunction with the
AWA ATSB Loan and related transactions are not included in the
computation of diluted EPS because the option and warrant
exercise prices were greater than the average market price of
common stock for the period. In November 2004, the Emerging
Issues Task Force (&#147;EITF&#148;) of the FASB reached a
consensus on
EITF&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">04-08,</FONT>
&#147;The Effect of Contingently Convertible Instruments on
Diluted Earnings per Share,&#148; which requires that issuers of
convertible securities with contingent conversion features use
the &#147;if-converted&#148; method to calculate reported EPS
irrespective of the contingent conversion trigger being met. As
approved by the FASB, this change is effective for years ending
after December&nbsp;15, 2004. The Company applied this
methodology in the accompanying consolidated statement of
operations. The impact of using the &#147;if-converted&#148;
method for the Company&#146;s 7.25%&nbsp;senior exchangeable
notes is antidilutive for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004
and 2002. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, the
inclusion of the 7.25%&nbsp;senior exchangeable notes reduced
diluted EPS by $0.06 from $3.13 to $3.07.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">119

    <TD><B>7.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Special charges (credits), net</B></TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Special charges (credits), net included within the statements of
operations include the following components (in millions):
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

<TR style="font-size: 1pt;">
    <TD width="68%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In the third quarter of 2005, in connection with the merger and
    the Airbus MOU executed between Airbus, US&nbsp;Airways Group,
    US&nbsp;Airways and AWA, certain aircraft firm orders were
    restructured. In connection with that restructuring,
    US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West Holdings were required to
    pay non-refundable restructuring fees. AWA&#146;s restructuring
    fee of $50&nbsp;million has been classified as a special charge,
    along with $7&nbsp;million in associated capitalized interest.
    The restructuring fee was paid by means of set-off against
    existing equipment deposits of AWA held by Airbus.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with the merger, America West Holdings and
    US&nbsp;Airways incurred $13&nbsp;million and $15&nbsp;million,
    respectively, of transition and merger integration costs in the
    fourth quarter of 2005 related to transitioning the employees,
    systems and facilities of AWA and US&nbsp;Airways into one
    consolidated company. The $13&nbsp;million includes insurance
    premiums of $4&nbsp;million related to policies for former
    officers and directors, compensation expense of $3&nbsp;million
    for special stock awards granted under a program designed to
    retain key employees through the integration period,
    professional and technical fees of $3&nbsp;million and sales and
    marketing program expenses of $2&nbsp;million related to
    notifying frequent traveler program members about the merger.
    The $15&nbsp;million includes $7&nbsp;million in insurance
    premiums related to policies for former officers and directors,
    $5&nbsp;million for severance, retention and stock awards,
    $1&nbsp;million of aircraft livery costs, $1&nbsp;million of
    programming service expense and $1&nbsp;million in other
    expenses.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In the third quarter of 2005, a $27&nbsp;million loss was
    incurred related to the sale-leaseback of six Boeing 737-200
    aircraft and two Boeing 757 aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In the fourth quarter of 2005, in connection with the return of
    certain leased aircraft, AWA incurred expenses of
    $7&nbsp;million related to penalties incurred under an
    outsourced maintenance arrangement.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In the third and fourth quarter of 2005, AWA recorded severance
    expense totaling approximately $2&nbsp;million for terminated
    employees resulting from the merger. The majority of the
    $2&nbsp;million will be paid in the first quarter of 2006.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In August 2004, AWA entered into definitive agreements with two
    lessors to return six Boeing 737-200 aircraft. Three of these
    aircraft were returned to the lessors in the third quarter of
    2004, two were</TD>
</TR>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">120
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    returned in the fourth quarter of 2004 and one was returned in
    January 2005. In addition, AWA continues negotiating with one
    lessor on the return of its remaining two Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT> aircraft, one
    of which was parked in March 2002. The other aircraft was
    removed from service in January 2005. In connection with the
    return of the aircraft, AWA recorded $2&nbsp;million of special
    charges in 2004, which include lease termination payments of
    $2&nbsp;million and the write-down of leasehold improvements and
    aircraft rent balances of $3&nbsp;million, offset by the net
    reversal of lease return provisions of $3&nbsp;million. In the
    first quarter of 2005, AWA recorded $1&nbsp;million in special
    charges related to the final Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT> aircraft, which
    was removed from service in January 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (g)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In the first quarter of 2004, AWA recorded a $1&nbsp;million
    reduction in special charges related to the revision of
    estimated costs associated with the sale and leaseback of
    certain aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (h)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In December 2004, AWA and GE mutually agreed to terminate the
    V2500&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A-1</FONT> power by
    hour (&#147;PBH&#148;) agreement effective January&nbsp;1, 2005.
    This agreement was entered into March 1998 with an original term
    of ten years. For terminating the agreement early, AWA received
    a $20&nbsp;million credit to be applied to amounts due for other
    engines under the 1998 agreement. AWA had capitalized PBH
    payments for
    V2500&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A-1</FONT> engines
    in excess of the unamortized cost of the overhauls performed by
    GE of approximately $4&nbsp;million. With the termination of
    this agreement, these payments were not realizable and as a
    result, AWA wrote off this amount against the $20&nbsp;million
    credit referred to above, resulting in a $16&nbsp;million net
    gain.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (i)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In the first quarter of 2003, AWA recorded a $1&nbsp;million
    reduction in special charges related to the earlier-than-planned
    return of certain leased aircraft in 2001 and 2002, as all
    payments related to these aircraft returns had been made.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (j)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In February 2003, AWA announced the elimination of its hub
    operations in Columbus, Ohio. As a result, 12 regional jets, all
    of which were operated by Chautauqua Airlines under the America
    West Express banner, were phased out of the fleet. In addition,
    the hub was downsized from 49 daily departures to 15
    destinations to four flights per day to Phoenix and Las Vegas.
    Service to New York City LaGuardia Airport was also eliminated
    because perimeter rules at the airport prohibit flights beyond
    1,500&nbsp;miles, precluding service from AWA&#146;s hubs in
    Phoenix and Las Vegas. In the first, second and third quarters
    of 2003, AWA recorded special charges totaling $11&nbsp;million
    related to the costs associated with the termination of certain
    aircraft and facility contracts, employee transfer and severance
    expenses and the write-off of leasehold improvements in
    Columbus, Ohio. All payments were completed as of
    December&nbsp;31, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (k)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In April 2003, as part of a cost reduction program, AWA
    implemented a plan to reduce management, professional and
    administrative payroll costs that resulted in 161 fewer
    employees within these workgroups. As a result, AWA recorded a
    special charge of $2&nbsp;million related to this
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">reduction-in</FONT>-force. All
    payments were completed as of December&nbsp;31, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (l)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In June 2003, AWA recorded an impairment loss of $3&nbsp;million
    related to three owned Boeing 737-200 aircraft that were
    grounded and subsequently sold.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>8.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Financial instruments</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>General</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On January&nbsp;1, 1998, as part of a comprehensive information
technology services agreement with Sabre, US&nbsp;Airways was
granted two tranches of stock options (SHC Stock Options) to
acquire up to 6,000,000&nbsp;shares of Class&nbsp;A Common
Stock, $.01&nbsp;par value, of Sabre Holdings Corporation (SHC
Common Stock), Sabre&#146;s parent company. Each tranche
included 3,000,000 stock options. In December 1999,
US&nbsp;Airways exercised the first tranche of stock options at
an exercise price of $27&nbsp;per option and received proceeds
of $81&nbsp;million in January 2000 in lieu of receiving SHC
Common Stock. Realized gains resulting from the exercise of
Sabre options are subject to a clawback provision. Under the
clawback
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">121

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
provision, if US&nbsp;Airways elects to terminate its
information technology service agreement with Sabre it will be
required to pay Sabre an amount equal to the gain multiplied by
the ratio of the remaining months in the contract period over
180&nbsp;months. The deferred gain from the 1999 exercise is
amortized on a straight-line basis over a contractually
determined period ending December 2012. In February 2000, SHC
declared a cash dividend resulting in a dilution adjustment to
the terms of the second tranche. The adjusted terms of the
second tranche include stock options to acquire
3,406,914&nbsp;shares of SHC Common Stock at an exercise price
of $23.78 subject to an $111.83&nbsp;per share cap on the fair
market value of the underlying common stock. These options are
exercisable during a ten-year period beginning January&nbsp;2,
2003.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under its fuel hedging program, AWA may enter into certain
hedging transactions with approved counterparties for a period
generally not exceeding 12&nbsp;months. As of December&nbsp;31,
2005, AWA had entered into costless collar transactions hedging
approximately 20% of the Company&#146;s or 68% of AWA&#146;s
projected 2006 fuel requirements. The fair value of AWA&#146;s
financial derivative instruments was a net asset of
approximately $4&nbsp;million and $0.2&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively. For the period
from September&nbsp;27, 2005 through December&nbsp;31, 2005,
US&nbsp;Airways had no open fuel hedge positions in place.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA is exposed to credit risks in the event any counterparty to
a hedge transaction fails to meet its obligations. AWA does not
anticipate such non-performance as counterparties are selected
based on credit ratings and exposure to any one counterparty is
closely monitored.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">122

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The carrying values of available-for-sale and
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">held-to</FONT>-maturity
securities approximate fair value. There were no unrealized
gains or losses on these investments for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003. Gross proceeds from sales
of available-for-sale securities for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 were $411&nbsp;million,
$589&nbsp;million and $322&nbsp;million, respectively.
Contractual maturities of all
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">held-to</FONT>-maturity
securities mature in one year or less. Contractual maturities
for available-for-sale securities are greater than 10&nbsp;years
with a reset date approximately every 28&nbsp;days.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group had no long-term investments in debt
securities as of December&nbsp;31, 2005 and had $30&nbsp;million
as of December&nbsp;31, 2004. At December&nbsp;31, 2004,
long-term investments consisted of cash invested in certain debt
securities with maturities greater than one year. The debt
securities are classified as held to maturity and are carried at
amortized cost that approximates fair value.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Long-term debt</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
At December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, the fair value of long-term
debt was approximately $3.07&nbsp;billion and $722&nbsp;million,
respectively. US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s variable rate
long-term debt approximates fair value because these borrowings
have variable interest rate terms that approximate market
interest rates for similar debt instruments. The fair value of
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s other long-term debt is determined
based on quoted market prices if available or market prices for
comparable debt instruments.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan backed by a
    $380&nbsp;million federal loan guarantee provided by the ATSB.
    Certain third-party counter-guarantors fully and unconditionally
    guaranteed the payment of an aggregate of $45&nbsp;million of
    the outstanding principal amount under the government guaranteed
    loan plus accrued and unpaid interest thereon. In addition,
    America West Holdings fully and unconditionally guaranteed the
    payment of all principal, premium, interest and other
    obligations outstanding under the government guaranteed loan and
    pledged the stock of AWA to secure its obligations under such
    guarantee. Principal amounts under this loan were scheduled to
    become due in ten installments of $43&nbsp;million on each
    March&nbsp;31 and September&nbsp;30, commencing on
    March&nbsp;31, 2004 and ending on September&nbsp;30, 2008. In
    addition, AWA was charged an annual guarantee fee in respect of
    the ATSB guarantee equal to 8.0% of the guaranteed amount in
    2005. On September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA made a voluntary
    prepayment of $9&nbsp;million in principal, thus reducing the
    remaining semi-annual installments due to $42&nbsp;million.
    Principal amounts outstanding under the government guaranteed
    loan bear interest at a rate per annum equal to LIBOR plus
    40&nbsp;basis points.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with the consummation of the merger, on
    September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA, as borrower, entered into an
    Amended and Restated Loan Agreement (the &#147;AWA ATSB
    Loan&#148;) with the ATSB. The ATSB Loan amended and restated
    the previously outstanding loans of AWA guaranteed in part by
    the ATSB. On October&nbsp;19, 2005, $238&nbsp;million of the AWA
    ATSB Loan, of which $228&nbsp;million was guaranteed by the
    ATSB, was sold by the lender by order of the ATSB to 13 fixed
    income investors. The sale of the debt removed the ATSB
    guaranty. Due to the sale on October&nbsp;19, 2005, the ATSB no
    longer guarantees any portion of the loan and has no interest in
    any of AWA&#146;s debt. As a result of the sale of the loan,
    $11&nbsp;million of the outstanding principal balance remains
    guaranteed by certain third party counter- guarantors. The
    non-guaranteed portion of the loan is no longer subject to
    payment of the annual guarantee fee; rather, as of the date of
    the loan sale, those principal amounts</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">124

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    bear interest at a rate per annum equal to LIBOR plus
    840&nbsp;basis points increasing by 5&nbsp;basis points on
    January 18 of each year, beginning January&nbsp;18, 2006 through
    the end of the loan term, payable on a quarterly basis. All
    other terms associated with this loan remain unchanged. As a
    result of the sale of the loan, the AWA ATSB Loan is now
    referred to as the AWA Citibank Loan, and had an outstanding
    balance of $250&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">

    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The AWA Citibank Loan is now secured debt. It requires certain
    prepayments from the proceeds of specified asset sales by
    US&nbsp;Airways Group and the other loan parties, and
    US&nbsp;Airways Group is required to maintain consolidated
    unrestricted cash and cash equivalents, less: (a)&nbsp;the
    amount of all outstanding advances by credit card processors and
    clearing houses in excess of 20% of the air traffic liabilities;
    (b)&nbsp;$250&nbsp;million presumed necessary to fund a
    subsequent tax trust (to the extent not otherwise funded by
    US&nbsp;Airways Group); (c)&nbsp;$35&nbsp;million presumed
    necessary to post collateral to clearing houses (to the extent
    not posted); and (d)&nbsp;any unrestricted cash or cash
    equivalents held in unperfected accounts; in an amount (subject
    to partial reduction under certain circumstances upon mandatory
    prepayments made with the net proceeds of future borrowings and
    issuances of capital stock) not less than:</TD>
</TR>
