    (b)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    On September&nbsp;10, 2004, AWA entered into a term loan
    financing with GECC providing for loans in an aggregate amount
    of $111&nbsp;million. AWA used approximately $77&nbsp;million of
    the proceeds from this financing to repay in full its term loan
    with Mizuho Corporate Bank, Ltd. and certain other lenders and
    to pay certain costs associated with this transaction. AWA used
    the remaining proceeds for general corporate purposes. The new
    term loan financing consists of two secured term loan
    facilities: a $76&nbsp;million term loan facility secured
    primarily by spare parts, rotables and appliances (the
    &#147;Spare Parts Facility&#148;); and a $35&nbsp;million term
    loan facility secured primarily by aircraft engines and parts
    installed in such engines (the &#147;Engine Facility&#148;).</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The facilities are cross-collateralized on a subordinated basis,
    and the collateral securing the facilities also secures on a
    subordinated basis certain of AWA&#146;s other existing debt and
    lease obligations to GECC and its affiliates.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The loans under the Spare Parts Facility are payable in full at
    maturity on September&nbsp;10, 2010. The loans under the Engine
    Facility are payable in equal quarterly installments of
    approximately $1&nbsp;million beginning on March&nbsp;10, 2006
    through June&nbsp;10, 2010, with the remaining loan amount of
    $12&nbsp;million payable at maturity on September&nbsp;10, 2010.
    The loans under each facility may be prepaid in an amount not
    less than $5&nbsp;million at any time after the
    30th&nbsp;monthly anniversary of the funding date under such
    facility. If AWA fails to maintain a certain ratio of rotables
    to loans under the Spare Parts Facility, it may be required to
    pledge additional rotables or cash as collateral, provide a
    letter of credit or prepay some or all of the loans under the
    Spare Parts Facility. In addition, the loans under the Engine
    Facility are subject to mandatory prepayment upon the occurrence
    of certain events of loss applicable to, or certain dispositions
    of, aircraft engines securing the facility. Principal amounts
    outstanding under the loans bear interest at a rate per annum
    based on three-month LIBOR plus a</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

    margin. Both facilities contain customary events of default,
    including payment defaults, cross-defaults, breach of covenants,

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    On December&nbsp;27, 2004, AWA raised additional capital by
    financing its Phoenix maintenance facility and flight training
    center. The flight training center was previously unencumbered,
    and the maintenance facility became unencumbered earlier in 2004
    when AWA refinanced its term loan. Using its leasehold interest
    in these two facilities as collateral, AWA, through a wholly
    owned subsidiary named FTCHP LLC, raised $31&nbsp;million
    through the issuance of senior secured discount notes. The notes
    were issued by FTCHP at a discount pursuant to the terms of a
    senior secured term loan agreement among the Company, FTCHP,
    Heritage Bank SSB, as administrative agent, Citibank, N.A., as
    the initial lender, and the other lenders from time to time
    party thereto. Citibank, N.A. subsequently assigned all of its
    interests in the notes to third party lenders.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    AWA has fully and unconditionally guaranteed the payment and
    performance of FTCHP&#146;s obligations under the notes and the
    loan agreement. The notes require aggregate principal payments
    of $36&nbsp;million with principal payments of $2&nbsp;million
    due on each of the first two anniversary dates and the remaining
    principal amount due on the fifth anniversary date. The notes
    may be prepaid in full at any time (subject to customary LIBOR
    breakage costs) and in partial amounts of $2&nbsp;million on the
    third and fourth anniversary dates. The unpaid principal amount
    of the notes bears interest based on LIBOR plus a margin subject
    to adjustment based on a loan to collateral value ratio.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The loan agreement contains customary covenants applicable to
    loans of this type, including obligations relating to the
    preservation of the collateral and restrictions on the
    activities of FTCHP. In addition, the loan agreement contains
    events of default, including payment defaults, cross-defaults to
    other debt of FTCHP, if any, breach of covenants, bankruptcy and
    insolvency defaults and judgment defaults.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with this financing, AWA sold all of its leasehold
    interests in the maintenance facility and flight training center
    to FTCHP and entered into subleases for the facilities with
    FTCHP at lease rates expected to approximate the interest
    payments due under the notes. In addition, AWA agreed to make
    future capital contributions to FTCHP in amounts sufficient to
    cover principal payments and other amounts owing pursuant to the
    notes and the loan agreement.</TD>
</TR>

    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD></TD>

    from operating cash flow, were irrevocably deposited with the
    trustee for AWA&#146;s
    10<FONT style="font-size: 70%"><SUP>3</SUP></FONT>/<FONT style="font-size: 60%">4</FONT>%&nbsp;senior
    unsecured notes due 2005, and the notes were subsequently
    redeemed on January&nbsp;26, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA entered into
    two loan agreements with Airbus Financial Services
    (&#147;AFS&#148;), an affiliate of Airbus, with commitments in
    initial aggregate amounts of up to $161&nbsp;million and up to
    $89&nbsp;million. The Airbus loans bear interest at a rate of
    LIBOR plus a margin, subject to adjustment during the term of
    the loans under certain conditions, and have been recorded as an
    obligation of US&nbsp;Airways Group. Amounts drawn upon the
    Airbus loans are drawn first upon the Airbus $161&nbsp;million
    loan until it has been drawn in its full amount, in which event
    the remaining portion of the $250&nbsp;million total commitment
    is drawn upon the Airbus $89&nbsp;million loan.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    On September&nbsp;27, 2005, all of the Airbus $161&nbsp;million
    loan and $14&nbsp;million of the Airbus $89&nbsp;million loan
    were drawn and are available for use for general corporate
    purposes. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, a total of
    $186&nbsp;million was drawn under the Airbus loans. The
    remaining portion of the Airbus loans is payable in multiple
    draws upon the occurrence of certain conditions, including the
    taking of delivery of certain aircraft, on the due dates for
    certain amounts owing to AFS or its affiliates to refinance such
    amounts, after payment of certain invoices for goods and
    services provided by AFS or its affiliates, or upon receipt by
    AFS of certain amounts payable in respect of existing aircraft
    financing transactions. The full amount of the Airbus loans is
    expected to be available by the end of 2006.</TD>
</TR>

    (e)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with the consummation of the merger, on
    September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways, as borrower, entered
    into the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan with the ATSB. Also on
    September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA entered into the Amended and
    Restated AWA Loan Agreement. The ATSB Loans amended and restated
    the previously outstanding loans of both US&nbsp;Airways and
    AWA, each guaranteed in part by the ATSB. On October&nbsp;19,
    2005, $539&nbsp;million of US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan, of which
    $525&nbsp;million was guaranteed by the ATSB, was sold by the
    lender by order of the ATSB to 13 fixed income investors. Due to
    the sale on October&nbsp;19, 2005, the ATSB no longer guarantees
    any portion of the loan and has no interest in any of
    US&nbsp;Airways&#146; debt. As a result of the sale of the loan,
    the principal amounts bear interest as a rate per annum equal to
    LIBOR plus 600&nbsp;basis points, payable on a quarterly basis,
    and are no longer subject to payment of the quarterly guarantee
    fee. All other terms associated with this loan remain unchanged.
    As a result of the sale of the loan, the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB
    Loan is now referred to as the US&nbsp;Airways Citibank Loan,
    and had an outstanding balance of $551&nbsp;million at
    December&nbsp;31, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    commercial paper conduit program and bears interest at a rate
    equal to the conduit provider&#146;s weighted average cost
    related to the issuance of certain commercial paper notes and
    other short term borrowings plus 0.30%, provided that portions
    of Tranche&nbsp;A that are held by the US&nbsp;Airways Citibank
    Loan or by an assignee and no longer subject to such commercial
    paper conduit program bear interest at LIBOR plus 40&nbsp;basis
    points, and portions of Tranche&nbsp;A that are under certain
    circumstances assigned free of the ATSB guarantee bear interest
    at LIBOR plus 6.0%. Ten percent of the US&nbsp;Airways Citibank
    Loan (Tranche&nbsp;B) bears interest at the greater of the
    Tranche&nbsp;A interest rate plus 6.0% and LIBOR plus 6.0%, as
    compared with the previous rate of LIBOR plus 4.0%. The
    US&nbsp;Airways Citibank loan also reschedules amortization
    payments for US&nbsp;Airways with semi-annual payments beginning
    on March&nbsp;31, 2007 and continuing through September&nbsp;30,
    2010.</TD>

    <TD valign="top">
    US&nbsp;Airways was required to pay down the principal of its
    loan with the first $125&nbsp;million of net proceeds from
    specified asset sales identified in connection with its
    Chapter&nbsp;11 proceedings, whether completed before or after
    emergence. US&nbsp;Airways then retains the next
    $83&nbsp;million of net proceeds from specified assets sales,
    and must prepay the principal of the loan with 60% of net
    proceeds in excess of an aggregate of $208&nbsp;million from
    specified asset sales to the ATSB. Any such asset sales proceeds
    up to $275&nbsp;million are to be applied to the outstanding
    principal balance in order of maturity, and any such asset sales
    proceeds in excess of $275&nbsp;million are to be applied to the
    outstanding principal balance on a pro rata across all
    maturities in accordance with the loan&#146;s early amortization
    provisions. As a result, semi-annual payments are now scheduled
    to begin on September&nbsp;30, 2007, instead of March&nbsp;31,
    2007, as originally scheduled in the loan agreement.
    US&nbsp;Airways made prepayments totaling $156&nbsp;million in
    connection with these specified asset sales completed during
    2005.</TD>

    <TD></TD>

    In September 2005, US&nbsp;Airways entered into an agreement to
    sell and leaseback certain of its commuter slots at Ronald
    Reagan Washington National Airport and New York LaGuardia
    Airport. US&nbsp;Airways continues to hold the right to
    repurchase the slots anytime after the second anniversary of the
    slot sale/leaseback transaction. These transactions were
    accounted for as secured financings. Installments are due
    monthly through 2015.</TD>

    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (h)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    GE, together with its affiliates, is US&nbsp;Airways
    Group&#146;s largest aircraft creditor, having financed or
    leased a substantial portion of its aircraft prior to the most
    recent Chapter&nbsp;11 filing. In June 2005, GE purchased the
    assets securing the GE Credit Facility in a sale-leaseback
    transaction. The sale proceeds realized from the sale-leaseback
    transaction were applied to repay the 2003 GE Liquidity
    Facility, the mortgage financing associated with the CRJ
    aircraft and a portion of the 2001 GE Credit Facility. The
    balance of the GECC Credit Facility was amended to allow
    additional borrowings of $21&nbsp;million in July 2005, which
    resulted in a total principal balance outstanding thereunder of
    $28&nbsp;million. The operating leases are cross-defaulted with
    all other GE obligations, other than excepted obligations, and
    are subject to agreed upon return conditions.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (i)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    On September&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group issued
    $144&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of 7%&nbsp;Senior
    Convertible Notes due 2020 (the &#147;7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible
    Notes&#148;) for proceeds, net of expenses, of approximately
    $139&nbsp;million. The 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes are
    US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s senior unsecured obligations and
    rank equally in right of payment to its other senior unsecured
    and unsubordinated indebtedness and are effectively subordinated
    to its secured indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets
    securing such indebtedness. The 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes
    are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally
    and on a senior unsecured basis, by US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
    two major operating subsidiaries, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. The
    guarantees are the guarantors&#146; unsecured obligations and
    rank equally in right of payment to the other senior unsecured
    and unsubordinated indebtedness of the guarantors and are
    effectively subordinated to the guarantors&#146; secured
    indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets securing such
    indebtedness.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes bear interest at the rate
    of 7%&nbsp;per year payable in cash semiannually in arrears on
    March&nbsp;30 and September&nbsp;30 of each year, beginning
    March&nbsp;30, 2006. The 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes mature
    on September&nbsp;30, 2020.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">128

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Holders may convert, at any time on or prior to maturity or
    redemption, any outstanding notes (or portions thereof) into
    shares of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s common stock, initially
    at a conversion rate of 41.4508&nbsp;shares of US&nbsp;Airways
    Group&#146;s common stock per $1,000 principal amount of notes
    (equivalent to an initial conversion price of approximately
    $24.12&nbsp;per share of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s common
    stock). If a holder elects to convert its notes in connection
    with certain specified fundamental changes that occur prior to
    October&nbsp;5, 2015, the holder will be entitled to receive
    additional shares of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s common stock
    as a make whole premium upon conversion. In lieu of delivery of
    shares of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s common stock upon
    conversion of all or any portion of the notes, US&nbsp;Airways
    Group may elect to pay holders surrendering notes for conversion
    cash or a combination of shares and cash.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">

    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Holders may require US&nbsp;Airways Group to purchase for cash
    or shares or a combination thereof, at US&nbsp;Airways
    Group&#146;s election, all or a portion of their 7%&nbsp;Senior
    Convertible Notes on September&nbsp;30, 2010 and
    September&nbsp;30, 2015 at a purchase price equal to 100% of the
    principal amount of the 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes to be
    repurchased plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the
    purchase date. In addition, if US&nbsp;Airways Group experiences
    a specified fundamental change, holders may require
    US&nbsp;Airways Group to purchase for cash, shares or a
    combination thereof, at its election, all or a portion of their
    7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes, subject to specified
    exceptions, at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount of
    the 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes plus accrued and unpaid
    interest, if any, to the purchase date. Prior to October&nbsp;5,
    2010, the 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes will not be
    redeemable at US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s option.
    US&nbsp;Airways Group may redeem all or a portion of the
    7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes at any time on or after
    October&nbsp;5, 2010, at a price equal to 100% of the principal
    amount of the 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes plus accrued and
    unpaid interest, if any, to the redemption date if the closing
    price of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s common stock has exceeded
    115% of the conversion price for at least 20 trading days in the
    30 consecutive trading day period ending on the trading day
    before the date on which US&nbsp;Airways Group mails the
    optional redemption notice.</TD>
</TR>

    (j)</TD>

    <TD valign="top">
    In August 1995, AWA issued $75&nbsp;million principal amount of
    10<FONT style="font-size: 70%"><SUP>3</SUP></FONT>/<FONT style="font-size: 60%">4</FONT>%&nbsp;senior
    unsecured notes due 2005, of which $40&nbsp;million remained
    outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2004. Interest on the
    10<FONT style="font-size: 70%"><SUP>3</SUP></FONT>/<FONT style="font-size: 60%">4</FONT>%&nbsp;senior
    unsecured notes was payable semi-annually in arrears on
    March&nbsp;1 and September&nbsp;1 of each year. On
    December&nbsp;27, 2004, AWA called for the redemption on
    January&nbsp;26, 2005 of all of the senior unsecured notes at a
    redemption price of 100% of the principal amount thereof plus
    accrued and unpaid interest through the redemption date. In
    addition, AWA irrevocably deposited the $31&nbsp;million raised
    through the maintenance facility and flight training center
    financing, as discussed in note&nbsp;(c) above, together with an
    additional $11&nbsp;million from its operating cash flow, with
    the trustee for the senior unsecured notes. The senior notes
    were subsequently redeemed on January&nbsp;26, 2005.</TD>

    Beginning January&nbsp;18, 2005, these notes are convertible
    into shares of common stock of US&nbsp;Airways Group, at the
    option of the holders, at an initial conversion price of
    $29.09&nbsp;per share or a conversion ratio of approximately
    34.376&nbsp;shares per $1,000 principal amount of such notes,
    subject to standard anti-dilution adjustments. Interest on the
    7.5% convertible senior notes is payable semiannually in arrears
    on June&nbsp;1 and December&nbsp;1 of each year. At America West
    Holdings&#146; option, the first six interest payments were
    payable in the form of a deemed loan added to the principal
    amount of these notes. The 7.5%&nbsp;convertible senior notes
    will mature on January&nbsp;18, 2009 unless earlier converted or
    redeemed. The payment of principal, premium and interest on the
    7.5%&nbsp;convertible senior notes is fully and unconditionally
    guaranteed by AWA and US&nbsp;Airways Group. For financial
    reporting purposes, America West Holdings recorded the
    convertible senior notes at their fair</TD>

    (l)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In July and August of 2003, AWA completed a private placement of
    approximately $87&nbsp;million issue price of 7.25%&nbsp;Senior
    Exchangeable Notes due 2023. The notes bore cash interest at a
    rate of 2.49%&nbsp;per year, and were redeemable or exchangeable
    under certain conditions. Completion of the merger between
    US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West Holdings on
    September&nbsp;27, 2005 constituted a &#147;change of
    control&#148; under these notes and required AWA to make an
    offer to holders to purchase those notes within 30 business days
    after the effective time of the merger at a purchase price of
    $343.61&nbsp;per $1,000 principal amount at maturity. Under the
    terms of the notes and the related Guarantee and Exchange
    Agreement, dated as of July&nbsp;30, 2003, between America West
    Holdings and U.S.&nbsp;Bank National Association, as Trustee, as
    supplemented by the Guarantee and Exchange Agreement Supplement
    No.&nbsp;1 among America West Holdings, US&nbsp;Airways Group
    and the Trustee, dated as of September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA&#146;s
    obligation to purchase the notes was satisfied at
    US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s election by delivery of shares of
    US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock having a &#147;fair market
    value&#148; of not less than $343.61&nbsp;per $1,000 principal
    amount at maturity. For this purpose, &#147;fair market
    value&#148; means 95% of the market price of US&nbsp;Airways
    Group common stock calculated as the average closing prices over
    the five business days ending on and including the third
    business day before the purchase date.</TD>
</TR>

    On October&nbsp;24, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group issued a total
    of 4,156,411&nbsp;shares of its common stock in exchange for
    approximately $250&nbsp;million in principal amount at maturity
    of AWA&#146;s Senior Exchangeable Notes due 2023, which notes
    were fully and unconditionally guaranteed by US&nbsp;Airways
    Group. The shares were exchanged at a rate of 16&nbsp;shares of
    US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock per $1,000 principal amount
    at maturity, in full satisfaction of the purchase price of the
    notes. The amount of notes exchanged represented approximately
    99% of the outstanding principal amount, and approximately
    $2&nbsp;million in principal amount at maturity of the notes
    remained outstanding after the exchange. On November&nbsp;30,
    2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group issued a total of 38,864&nbsp;shares
    of its common stock to repurchase the remaining outstanding
    principal amount of the notes.</TD>

    In connection with the merger, AWA, US&nbsp;Airways Group and
    Juniper, entered into an agreement on August&nbsp;8, 2005
    amending AWA&#146;s co-branded credit card agreement with
    Juniper, dated January&nbsp;25, 2005. Pursuant to the amended
    credit card agreement, Juniper agreed to offer and market an
    airline mileage award credit card program to the general public
    to participate in US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s Dividend Miles
    program through the use of a co-branded credit card.</TD>

    <TD valign="top">
    US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s credit card program is currently
    administered by Bank of America, N.A. (USA). On
    December&nbsp;28, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways issued a notice of
    termination under its agreement with Bank of America and that
    notice will become effective on December&nbsp;28, 2007. Pending
    termination of the Bank of America agreement, both Juniper and
    Bank of America will run separate credit card programs for
    US&nbsp;Airways Group. The amended credit card agreement is the
    subject of pending litigation filed by Bank of America against
    US&nbsp;Airways Group, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA (See
    Note&nbsp;12(d)).</TD>

    time of the merger. The credit card services provided by Juniper
    under the amended credit card agreement began in January 2006,
    and will continue until the expiration date, which is the later
    of December&nbsp;31, 2012 or seven years from the date on which
    Juniper commences marketing to the general public.</TD>

</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>

<DIV style="margin-top: 15pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Under the amended credit card agreement, Juniper will pay to
    US&nbsp;Airways Group fees for each mile awarded to each credit
    card account administered by Juniper, subject to certain
    exceptions. Pursuant to the original credit card agreement,
    Juniper paid to AWA a bonus of $20&nbsp;million. Juniper also
    agreed to pay a one-time bonus payment of $130&nbsp;million,
    following the effectiveness of the merger, subject to certain
    conditions. The $130&nbsp;million bonus payment was made to AWA
    on October&nbsp;3, 2005. The entire $150&nbsp;million balance
    for bonus payments are included in &#147;Deferred gains and
    other liabilities&#148; in the accompanying consolidated balance
    sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2005. US&nbsp;Airways Group will
    not recognize any revenue from the bonus payments until the dual
    branding period has expired, approximately February 2008. At
    that time the Company expects to begin recognizing revenue from
    the bonus payments on a straight-line basis through December
    2012, the expiration date of the Juniper agreement. Further, if
    Juniper is not granted exclusivity to offer a co-branded credit
    card after the dual branding period, US&nbsp;Airways Group must
    repay the bonus payments and repurchase unused pre-paid miles
    with interest, plus $50&nbsp;million in liquidated damages.
    Juniper will pay an annual bonus of $5&nbsp;million to
    US&nbsp;Airways Group, subject to certain exceptions, for each
    year after Juniper becomes the exclusive issuer of the
    co-branded credit card.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In addition, Juniper pre-paid for miles from US&nbsp;Airways
    Group for an aggregate of $325&nbsp;million, subject to the same
    conditions as apply to the $130&nbsp;million bonus payment. To
    the extent that the miles are not used by Juniper as allowed
    under with the co-branded credit card program in certain
    circumstances, US&nbsp;Airways Group will repurchase these miles
    in 12 equal quarterly installments beginning on the fifth year
    prior to the expiration date of the amended credit card
    agreement until paid in full. US&nbsp;Airways Group will make
    monthly interest payments at LIBOR plus 4.75% to Juniper,
    beginning on November&nbsp;1, 2005, based on the amount of pre-
    purchased miles that have not been used by Juniper in connection
    with the co-branded credit card program and have not been
    repurchased by US&nbsp;Airways Group. US&nbsp;Airways Group will
    be required to repurchase pre-purchased miles under certain
    reductions in the collateral held under the credit card
    processing agreement with JP Morgan Chase Bank, N.A.
    Accordingly, the prepayment has been recorded as additional
    indebtedness.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Juniper requires US&nbsp;Airways Group to maintain an average
    quarterly balance of cash, cash equivalents and short-term
    investments of at least $1&nbsp;billion for the entirety of the
    agreement. Further, the agreement requires US&nbsp;Airways Group
    to maintain certain financial ratios beginning January&nbsp;1,
    2006. Juniper may, at its option, terminate the amended credit
    card agreement, make payments to US&nbsp;Airways Group under the
    amended credit card agreement in the form of pre-purchased miles
    rather than cash, or require US&nbsp;Airways Group to repurchase
    the pre-purchased miles before the fifth year prior to the
    expiration date in the event that US&nbsp;Airways Group breaches
    its obligations under the amended credit card agreement, or upon
    the occurrence of certain events.</TD>
</TR>

    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>10.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Employee pension and benefit plans</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Substantially all of the Company&#146;s employees meeting
certain service and other requirements are eligible to
participate in various pension, medical, dental, life insurance,
disability and survivorship plans.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">132

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Defined benefit and other postretirement benefit
    plans</I></B></TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

for defined benefit or other postretirement benefit plans. The
following table sets forth changes in the fair value of plan
assets, benefit obligations and the funded status of the plans
acquired by the Company on September&nbsp;27, 2005 as of the
measurement date of September&nbsp;30, 2005 recognized in the
balance sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2005 (in millions):

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">133

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The following table presents the weighted average assumptions
used to determine benefit obligations:
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

<TR style="font-size: 1pt;">
    <TD width="63%">&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company discounted its pension
obligations using a rate of 5.75% based on the current rates
earned on long-term bonds that received one of the two highest
ratings given by a recognized rating agency.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
At the measurement date of September&nbsp;30, 2005, the Company
assumed a discount rate of 5.30% for measuring its other
postretirement benefit obligations, based on a hypothetical
portfolio of high quality publicly traded U.S.&nbsp;bonds (Aa
rated, non-callable or callable with make-whole provisions), for
which the timing and cash outflows approximate the estimated
benefit payments of the other postretirement benefit plans.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The assumed health care cost trend rates are 10% in 2006 and 9%
in 2007, decreasing to 5% in 2011 and thereafter. The assumed
health care cost trend rates have a significant effect on
amounts reported for retiree health care plans. A one-percentage
point change in the health care cost trend rates would have the
following effects on other postretirement benefits as of
September&nbsp;30, 2005 (in millions):
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

The Company assumed that its pension plans&#146; assets would
generate a long-term rate of return of 8.00% at
December&nbsp;31, 2005. The expected long-term rate of return
assumption was developed by evaluating input from the
plan&#146;s investment consultants, including their review of
asset class return expectations and long-term inflation
assumptions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s targeted asset allocation as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005 is approximately 70% equity securities,
25% debt securities and 5% other. The Company believes that its
long-term asset allocation on average will approximate the
targeted allocation. The Company regularly reviews its actual
asset allocation and periodically rebalances its investments to
its targeted allocation when considered appropriate.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Defined contribution pension plans</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company sponsors several defined contribution pension plans
for certain employees. The Company makes cash contributions to
certain plans based on the employee&#146;s age, compensation, a
match that is annually determined by the Board of Directors, and
elected contributions. The Company also participates in a
multi-employer plan for certain employees. Expenses related to
these plans, excluding expenses related to the Company&#146;s
pilot defined contribution plans (see below), were approximately
$16&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005,
$11&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 and
$9&nbsp;million for the year ended December 2003.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">135

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with its previous reorganization under
Chapter&nbsp;11 of the Bankruptcy Code, US&nbsp;Airways
terminated the Retirement Income Plan for Pilots of
US&nbsp;Airways, Inc. and the related nonqualified pilot plan
effective March&nbsp;31, 2003. The Company implemented a
qualified and nonqualified defined contribution plan for pilots
effective April&nbsp;1, 2003. The defined contribution amount
was individually determined based on a target normal retirement
date balance of approximately $1&nbsp;million for a career
US&nbsp;Airways pilot. The target balance included the estimated
value of other retirement benefits including, but not limited
to, the estimated benefit pilots are expected to receive from
the PBGC, the trustee for the terminated pilot defined benefit
plan. Effective October&nbsp;15, 2004, each pilot&#146;s
contribution rate became the lessor of the original rate or 10%
of eligible compensation. Expenses for this plan of
$10&nbsp;million for the three months ended December&nbsp;31,
2005 are included in the Company&#146;s consolidated results for
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Effective January&nbsp;1, 2005 America West Holdings initiated a
new defined contribution plan covering pilots under the
collective bargaining agreement with the Air Line Pilots
Association. Under this plan, AWA is required to make a
non-elective discretionary employer contribution equal to 7% of
each pilot&#146;s compensation (as defined in the plan and
subject to statutory annual maximums). Such contributions are in
addition to the existing AWA company match under the 401(k)
defined contribution plan covering all employees discussed
above. AWA&#146;s contribution expense to this plan totaled
$13&nbsp;million for 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Postemployment benefits</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company provides certain postemployment benefits to its
employees. These benefits include disability-related and
workers&#146; compensation benefits for certain employees. The
Company accrues for the cost of such benefit expenses once an
appropriate triggering event has occurred.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(d)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Profit sharing plans</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the Defined Contribution Retirement Program, the Company
makes additional contributions to participant accounts for
certain employees when certain prescribed pre-tax margin levels
are achieved. The Company did not make any profit sharing
contributions relating to 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Since the emergence from bankruptcy in September 2005, most
non-executive employees of US&nbsp;Airways are eligible to
participate in the 2005 Profit Sharing Plan, an annual bonus
program. Annual bonus awards are paid from a profit-sharing pool
equal to (i)&nbsp;ten percent of the annual profits of
US&nbsp;Airways Group (excluding unusual items) for pre-tax
profit margins up to ten percent, plus (ii)&nbsp;15% of the
annual profits of US&nbsp;Airways Group (excluding unusual
items) for pre-tax profit margins greater than ten percent.
Awards are paid as a lump sum no later than March 15 after the
end of each fiscal year. The profit-sharing pool is shared among
eligible employee groups in proportion to each group&#146;s
share of overall cost savings achieved through
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; 2005 transformation plan; however, the
represented pilots&#146; and flight attendants&#146; portions of
the pool will not be less than 36% and 14.5%, respectively. An
employee&#146;s share of the pool is based on the ratio that the
employee&#146;s compensation bears to the respective employee
group&#146;s aggregate compensation. Because of significant
losses, no benefits are accrued under the plan in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>11.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Income Taxes</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA is included in America West Holdings&#146; consolidated
income tax returns for the periods ending on December&nbsp;31,
2004 and for the period beginning January&nbsp;1, 2005 ending on
September&nbsp;27, 2005, the date of the merger. America West
Holdings and AWA, as part of the merger, became members of the
consolidated US&nbsp;Airways Group on September&nbsp;28, 2005.
Income tax expense in the accompanying statements of operations
has been determined on a consolidated basis which includes the
full year financial
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">136

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <DIV style="margin-left: 10px; text-indent: -10px">
    Total</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>&#151;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>&#151;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>&#151;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group has
available net operating loss carryforwards (&#147;NOLs&#148;)
and tax credit carryforwards for federal income tax purposes of
approximately $1.43&nbsp;billion and $25&nbsp;million,
respectively. The NOLs expire during the years 2020 through
2026. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group also
had capital loss carryforwards for federal income tax purposes
of approximately $1&nbsp;million which expire in 2008. Further,
as a result of a statutory &#147;ownership change&#148; (as
defined for purposes of Section&nbsp;382 of the Internal Revenue
Code) that occurred as a result of America West Holdings&#146;
merger with US&nbsp;Airways Group on September&nbsp;27, 2005,
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s ability to utilize its NOLs and tax
credit carryforwards may be restricted.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA and the IRS favorably reached an agreement to carryforward
all <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">pre-1994</FONT> NOLs that
were restricted, as a result of a statutory &#147;ownership
change&#148; (as defined for purposes of Section&nbsp;382 of the
Internal Revenue Code) that occurred as a result of AWA&#146;s
reorganization in 1994.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The settlement with the IRS allowed AWA to utilize all
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">pre-1994</FONT> NOLs of
$546&nbsp;million in total by the end of tax year 1999, as well
$36&nbsp;million of the 1994 NOL. The balance of the 1994 NOL of
$9&nbsp;million and the 1996 NOL of $5&nbsp;million were used in
total during the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2000. The
remaining December&nbsp;31, 2000 taxable income was reduced by
2001 NOL carry back of $27&nbsp;million. After the settlement,
the balance of the NOL carryforward into December&nbsp;31, 2003
is $337&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">137

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

differences between the carrying amounts of assets and
liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts
used for income tax purposes. As of December&nbsp;31, the
significant components of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s deferred
tax assets and liabilities are a result of the temporary
differences related to the items described as follows (in
millions):

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;109, &#147;Accounting for Income Taxes,&#148;
(&#147;SFAS&nbsp;109&#148;) requires that a valuation allowance
be established when it is &#147;more likely than not&#148; that
all or a portion of deferred tax assets will not be realized. A
review of all available positive and negative evidence needs to
be considered, including US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
performance, the market environment in which the Company
operates, forecasts of future profitability, the utilization of
past tax credits, length of carryforward periods and similar
factors. SFAS&nbsp;109 further states that it is difficult to
conclude that a valuation allowance is not needed when there is
negative evidence such as cumulative losses in recent years.
Therefore, cumulative losses weigh heavily in the overall
assessment.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company was in a cumulative loss position three out of four
years between December&nbsp;31, 2002 through December&nbsp;31,
2005, which weighed heavily in the overall determination that a
valuation allowance was needed. The Company expects to continue
to record a full valuation allowance on any future tax benefits
until it has achieved several quarters of consecutive profitable
results coupled with an expectation of continued profitability.
As of December 2005 and 2004, the valuation allowance totaled
$446&nbsp;million and $129&nbsp;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">138

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 24pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>12.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Commitments and Contingencies</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Commitments to purchase flight equipment and maintenance
    services</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Airbus Purchase Commitments</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group,
US&nbsp;Airways and AWA entered into an Airbus A350 Purchase
Agreement with Airbus. This agreement provides for the delivery
of 20 A350 aircraft during the period 2011 through 2014. The
agreement contains terms and conditions with respect to aircraft
price, escalation, payment terms and pre-delivery payments,
inspection and certification, technical acceptance, excusable
and inexcusable delays, warranties and service life policy,
patent and copyright indemnity, technical data and training
aids, training, supplier product support, indemnities and
insurance, assignments and transfers, and termination events.
Airbus also agreed to provide backstop financing with respect to
a substantial number of these A350 aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group entered into
Amendment 16 to the A319/ A320/ A321 Purchase Agreement dated as
of October&nbsp;31, 1997 among US&nbsp;Airways Group and AVSA,
S.A.R.L. The amendment provides for the rescheduling of 19 firm
order A320-family aircraft for delivery during the period 2009
and 2010. The amendment also modifies other provisions of the
Purchase Agreement relating to the deletion of certain aircraft
cancellation rights and the rescheduling of aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group entered into
Amendment 10 to the A330/340 Purchase Agreement dated as of
November&nbsp;24, 1998 among US&nbsp;Airways Group and AVSA,
S.A.R.L. The amendment provides for the rescheduling of ten firm
order A330-200 aircraft for delivery during the period 2009 and
2010 and allows for cancellation in the event that
US&nbsp;Airways takes certain deliveries under the A350 Purchase
Agreement described above. Other provisions of the Purchase
Agreement which have been modified by the amendment relate to
the application of existing pre-delivery payments, adjustments
to various cancellation rights and the cancellation of the right
for additional A330 aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA entered into Amendment
No.&nbsp;9 and Amendment No.&nbsp;10 to the Airbus A320/ A319
Purchase Agreement dated as of September&nbsp;12, 1997 between
AWA and AVSA, S.A.R.L. Amendment No.&nbsp;9 provides for the
rescheduling of 11 firm order A320 family aircraft for delivery
during 2009. Amendment No.&nbsp;10 sets forth provisions for
restructuring fees and adjustments to escalation provisions and
added purchase rights for aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA has an agreement with International Aero Engines
(&#147;IAE&#148;) which provides for the purchase by AWA of five
new V2500-A5 spare engines scheduled for delivery through 2007
for use on certain of the Airbus A320 fleet. At
December&nbsp;31, 2005, the five engines have an estimated gross
cost of $34&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Embraer Purchase Commitments</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On February&nbsp;16, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court approved a
settlement and assumption term sheet between the Company and
Embraer, executed by the Company on February&nbsp;9, 2006, which
amends the purchase agreement dated as of May&nbsp;9, 2003, as
amended, between the Company and Embraer and contemplates an
amended and restated financing letter with Embraer. The
Bankruptcy Court also authorized the assumption of the purchase
agreement, as amended by the term sheet, and a related
maintenance agreement, and disallowed certain proofs of claim
filed by Embraer in the bankruptcy proceedings related to these
agreements. The purchase agreement, as amended by the term
sheet, provides that Embraer will retain approximately
$18&nbsp;million in non-refundable progress and deposit payments
(&#147;PDPs&#148;) previously paid by the Company. The Company
has agreed to place an initial firm order for 25&nbsp;Embraer
190&nbsp;aircraft and an additional firm order for
32&nbsp;Embraer 190&nbsp;aircraft. The outstanding PDPs will be
applied to these orders in accordance with the terms of the
amended purchase agreement. In
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">139

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
addition, upon assumption of the amended purchase agreement,
Embraer granted the Company the right to purchase up to 50
additional Embraer 190 aircraft in accordance with the term
sheet. The term sheet also provides that the Company will be
allowed to convert certain of the Embraer 190 aircraft to
Embraer 170, Embraer 175 or Embraer 195 aircraft, subject to
availability and upon agreed notice. Embraer has agreed to
provide financing for certain of the aircraft scheduled for
delivery under the amended purchase agreement, under the terms
of the amended and restated financing letter.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Bombardier Purchase Commitments</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under its agreement with Bombardier, US&nbsp;Airways Group
acquired three new
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">CRJ-700</FONT> aircraft in
January 2005. The purchase was financed through the application
of $28&nbsp;million of existing purchase deposits held by
Bombardier, $2&nbsp;million in cash and a financed lease
facility with DVB&nbsp;Bank&nbsp;AG. Additionally,
$7&nbsp;million of purchase deposits held by Bombardier were
used to satisfy existing defaults, cure payments and liquidated
damages. While US&nbsp;Airways Group continued to operate under
the protection of Chapter&nbsp;11 in compliance with the
Bankruptcy Code and until a decision is reached to assume or
reject the Bombardier regional jet purchase agreement, no
obligations arise on the part of US&nbsp;Airways Group or
Bombardier with respect to the purchase and delivery of any
aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Engine Maintenance Commitments</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the merger, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA
restructured their rate per engine hour agreements with General
Electric Engine Services for overhaul maintenance services.
Under the restructured agreements, the minimum monthly payment
on account of accrued engine flight hours for both the
US&nbsp;Airways and AWA agreements together will equal
$3&nbsp;million as long as both agreements remain in effect
through October 2009.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Leases</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company leases certain aircraft, engines, and ground
equipment, in addition to the majority of its ground facilities.
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company had 426 aircraft under
operating leases, excluding two aircraft that will be delivered
in 2006, with remaining terms ranging from one month to
approximately 19&nbsp;years. Ground facilities include executive
offices, maintenance facilities and ticket and administrative
offices. Public airports are utilized for flight operations
under lease arrangements with the municipalities or agencies
owning or controlling such airports. Substantially all leases
provide that the lessee must pay taxes, maintenance, insurance
and certain other operating expenses applicable to the leased
property. Some leases also include renewal and purchase options.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003,
rental expense under operating leases, excluding landing fees,
was $632&nbsp;million, $421&nbsp;million and $407&nbsp;million,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As discussed in Note&nbsp;9, in January 2002, AWA closed a
$429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380&nbsp;million
government loan guarantee from the ATSB that resulted in a
restructuring of its aircraft lease commitments. Under the
restructured lease agreements, annual rent payments have been
reduced through January 2007. Certain of these leases contain
put options pursuant to which the lessors could require AWA to
renew the leases for periods ranging from eight months to
approximately nine years or call options pursuant to which the
lessors could require AWA to return the aircraft to the lessors
upon receipt of six to nine months written notice. The Company
also has options to purchase certain of the aircraft at fair
market values at the end of the lease terms. Certain of the
agreements require security deposits, minimum return provisions
and supplemental rent payments.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

property and equipment as of December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004 (in
