    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>31</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA and US&nbsp;Airways have set up pass through trusts, which
have issued pass through trust certificates (also known as
&#147;Enhanced Equipment Trust&nbsp;Certificates&#148; or
&#147;EETCs&#148;) covering the leveraged lease financing of 54
AWA aircraft. On September&nbsp;27, 2005, the Company acquired
debt on 19 aircraft and assumed leases on 62 aircraft that were
financed through US&nbsp;Airways&#146; use of EETCs.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
These trusts are off-balance sheet entities, the primary purpose
of which is to finance the acquisition of aircraft. Rather than
finance each aircraft separately when such aircraft is purchased
or delivered, these trusts allow the Company to raise the
financing for several aircraft at one time and place such funds
in escrow pending the purchase or delivery of the relevant
aircraft. The trusts are also structured to provide
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">141
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
for certain credit enhancements, such as liquidity facilities to
cover certain interest payments, that reduce the risks to the
purchasers of the trust certificates and, as a result, reduce
the cost of aircraft financings to the Company.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Each trust covered a set amount of aircraft scheduled to be
delivered within a specific period of time. At the time of each
covered aircraft financing, the relevant trust used the funds in
escrow to purchase equipment notes relating to the financed
aircraft. The equipment notes were issued, at AWA or
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; election, either by AWA or US&nbsp;Airways
in connection with a mortgage financing of the aircraft or by a
separate owner trust in connection with a leveraged lease
financing of the aircraft. In the case of a leveraged lease
financing, the owner trust then leased the aircraft to AWA or
US&nbsp;Airways. In both cases, the equipment notes are secured
by a security interest in the aircraft. The pass through trust
certificates are not direct obligations of, nor are they
guaranteed by, US&nbsp;Airways Group, AWA or US&nbsp;Airways.
However, in the case of mortgage financings, the equipment notes
issued to the trusts are direct obligations of AWA and
US&nbsp;Airways and in the case of leveraged lease financings,
the leases are direct obligations of AWA and US&nbsp;Airways.
None of US&nbsp;Airways Group, AWA or US&nbsp;Airways guarantee
or participate in any way in the residual value of the leased
aircraft. All of the AWA aircraft financed by these trusts are
currently structured as leveraged lease financings, which are
not reflected as debt on the balance sheet of AWA. AWA does not
provide residual value guarantees under these lease
arrangements. A portion of the US&nbsp;Airways aircraft financed
by these trusts are mortgage financings and as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005, $652&nbsp;million is reflected as debt
in the accompanying balance sheet.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
These leasing entities meet the criteria for variable interest
entities. However, they do not meet the consolidation criteria
under FIN&nbsp;46(R) because the Company is not the primary
beneficiary under these arrangements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Regional jet capacity purchase agreements</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company has entered into capacity purchase agreements with
certain regional jet operators. The capacity purchase agreements
provide that all revenues (passenger, mail and freight) go to
the Company. In return, the Company agrees to pay predetermined
fees to the regional airlines for operating an agreed upon
number of aircraft, without regard to the number of passengers
onboard. In addition, these agreements provide that certain
variable costs, such as fuel and airport landing fees, will be
reimbursed 100% by the Company. The Company controls marketing,
scheduling, ticketing, pricing and seat inventories. The
regional jet capacity purchase agreements have expirations from
2008 to 2015 and provide for optional extensions at the
Company&#146;s discretion. The future minimum noncancelable
commitments under the regional jet capacity purchase agreements
are $1.17&nbsp;billion in 2006, $1.18&nbsp;billion in 2007,
$1.21&nbsp;billion in 2008, $1.23&nbsp;billion in 2009,
$1.26&nbsp;billion in 2010 and $3.86&nbsp;billion thereafter.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain entities with which the Company has capacity purchase
agreements are considered variable interest entities under
FIN&nbsp;46(R). In connection with its restructuring and
emergence from bankruptcy, US&nbsp;Airways contracted with Air
Wisconsin, a related party, and Republic to purchase a
significant portion of these companies&#146; regional jet
capacity for a period of ten years. The Company has determined
that it is not the primary beneficiary of these variable
interest entities, based on cash flow analyses. Additionally,
other carriers with which US&nbsp;Airways has long-term capacity
purchase agreements fall under the business scope exception of
FIN&nbsp;46(R); therefore, US&nbsp;Airways does not consolidate
any of the entities with which it has jet service agreements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(d)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Legal proceedings</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;12, 2004, US&nbsp;Airways Group and its
domestic subsidiaries (the &#147;Debtors&#148;) filed voluntary
petitions for relief under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the Bankruptcy
Code in the United States bankruptcy court for the Eastern
District of Virginia, Alexandria Division (the &#147;Bankruptcy
Court&#148;) (Case
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">142

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
Nos.&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">04-13819-SSM</FONT>
through <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">03-13823-SSM)</FONT>
(the &#147;2004 Bankruptcy&#148;). On September&nbsp;16, 2005,
the Bankruptcy Court issued an order confirming the plan of
reorganization submitted by the Debtors and on
September&nbsp;27, 2005, the Debtors emerged from the 2004
Bankruptcy. The court&#146;s order confirming the plan included
a provision called the plan injunction, which forever bars other
parties from pursuing most claims against the Debtors that arose
prior to September&nbsp;27, 2005 in any forum other than the
Bankruptcy Court. The great majority of these claims are
pre-petition claims that, if paid out at all, will be paid out
in common stock of the post-bankruptcy US&nbsp;Airways Group at
a fraction of the actual claim amount.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On February&nbsp;26, 2004, a company called I.A.P. Intermodal,
LLC filed suit against US&nbsp;Airways Group and its wholly
owned airline subsidiaries in the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Texas alleging that the
defendants&#146; computer scheduling system infringes upon three
patents held by plaintiffs, all of which patents are entitled,
&#147;Method to Schedule a Vehicle in Real-Time to Transport
Freight and Passengers.&#148; Plaintiff seeks various injunctive
relief as well as costs, fees and treble damages.
US&nbsp;Airways Group and its subsidiaries were formally served
with the complaint on June&nbsp;21, 2004. US&nbsp;Airways Group
is unable to ascertain at this time the likelihood or potential
scale of liability. On the same date, the same plaintiff filed
what US&nbsp;Airways Group believes to be substantially similar
cases against nine other major airlines, including British
Airways, Northwest Airlines Corporation, Korean Airlines Co.,
Ltd., Deutsche Lufthansa AG, Air France, Air Canada, Singapore
Airlines Ltd., Delta Air Lines and Continental Airlines, Inc.,
and had filed a suit against AMR Group, Inc., the parent company
of American Airlines, along with its airline subsidiaries, in
December 2003. This action has been stayed as to US&nbsp;Airways
Group and its wholly owned subsidiaries as a result of the 2004
Bankruptcy. In the meantime, several foreign airline defendants
were dismissed from the case for reasons unique to their status
as foreign operators, and the remaining defendants in September
2005 obtained a ruling that there had been no infringement of
any of I.A.P.&#146;s patents. In October 2005, I.A.P. entered
into consent judgments with several defendants but has since
filed a notice of appeal against Continental Airlines and the
AMR Group defendants. I.A.P. did not file any claims against
US&nbsp;Airways Group or any of its subsidiaries in the 2004
Bankruptcy.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey filed a proof of
claim against US&nbsp;Airways in the bankruptcy case filed on
August&nbsp;11, 2002 (the &#147;2002 Bankruptcy&#148;). The
claim was in the amount of $8.5&nbsp;million and it alleged
environmental contamination and building deficiencies at
LaGuardia Airport. US&nbsp;Airways&#146; liability and defenses
to this liability were unaffected by the 2002 Bankruptcy. In
connection with the 2004 Bankruptcy, the Port Authority filed a
proof of claim in the amount of approximately $24&nbsp;million
again alleging environmental contamination and building
deficiencies at LaGuardia Airport, of which approximately
$2&nbsp;million is related to alleged environmental
contamination.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On January&nbsp;7, 2003, the Internal Revenue Service (the
&#147;IRS&#148;) issued a notice of proposed adjustment to
US&nbsp;Airways Group proposing to disallow $573&nbsp;million of
capital losses that US&nbsp;Airways Group sustained in the tax
year 1999 on the sale of stock of USLM Corporation (the
&#147;USLM matter&#148;). On February&nbsp;5, 2003, the IRS
filed a proof of claim with the Bankruptcy Court in connection
with the 2002 Bankruptcy asserting the following claims against
US&nbsp;Airways with respect to the USLM matter:
(1)&nbsp;secured claims for U.S.&nbsp;federal income tax and
interest of $1&nbsp;million; (2)&nbsp;unsecured priority claims
for U.S.&nbsp;federal income tax of $68&nbsp;million and
interest of $14&nbsp;million; and (3)&nbsp;an unsecured general
claim for penalties of $25&nbsp;million. On May&nbsp;8, 2003,
US&nbsp;Airways Group reached a tentative agreement with the IRS
on the amount of U.S.&nbsp;federal income taxes, interest and
penalties due subject to final approval from the Joint Committee
on Taxation. By letter dated September&nbsp;11, 2003,
US&nbsp;Airways Group was notified that the Joint Committee on
Taxation had accepted the tentative agreement with the IRS,
including a settlement of all federal income taxes through the
end of 2002. Due to the 2004 Bankruptcy filing, which suspended
payment of prepetition liabilities, final payment terms under
the agreement have not been submitted to the Bankruptcy Court
for approval. The IRS has submitted a proof of claim relating to
the USLM matter in the 2004 Bankruptcy in the amount of
approximately $31&nbsp;million, and on August&nbsp;2, 2005
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">143

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
the IRS filed a motion for relief from the automatic stay
seeking to setoff against approximately $4&nbsp;million of tax
refunds due to the Debtors. On October&nbsp;20, 2005, the IRS
filed an amended proof of claim reducing its claim in the USLM
matter to $11&nbsp;million. On November&nbsp;3, 2005, the IRS
filed an amended motion continuing to seek relief for the
$4&nbsp;million setoff. A hearing was set for December&nbsp;15,
2005 on this matter, but was continued to March&nbsp;16, 2006
for a status hearing. The Debtors are in the process of
analyzing the IRS&#146; amended motion.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Williard, Inc. and the joint venture of Williard, Inc. and Len
Parker Associates, was awarded construction contracts with
US&nbsp;Airways for work to be performed at the Philadelphia
International Airport. On May&nbsp;29, 2002, US&nbsp;Airways
terminated the largest contracts between the parties. Williard,
Inc. and the joint venture sued US&nbsp;Airways in Pennsylvania
state court for over $14&nbsp;million in damages representing
termination costs and lost profits, along with other alleged
contractual damage claims. Subsequently, Limbach Company, LLC
alleged that it purchased the claims of Williard, Inc. After a
trial, the Bankruptcy Court in the 2002 Bankruptcy, on
June&nbsp;7, 2004, determined the value of the Limbach Company
and the joint venture claims to be approximately
$2.5&nbsp;million. Limbach Company and the joint venture are
challenging on appeal various rulings of the Bankruptcy Court,
including the amount of the claim and its status as an unsecured
claim. US&nbsp;Airways has also filed an appeal regarding the
denial of its right to offset the claims with asserted
backcharges.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Limbach Company and the joint venture have filed an action in
state court against the City of Philadelphia and the
Philadelphia Authority for Industrial Development, as well as
US&nbsp;Airways, but did not assert any claims against
US&nbsp;Airways in that action. In the lawsuit against the City
of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority for Industrial
Development, Limbach Company and the joint venture are seeking
the same sums as in their earlier lawsuit and proofs of claim
against US&nbsp;Airways, but this time under the equitable
theories of third-party beneficiary, quantum meruit and
constructive trust. On a
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">pre-answer</FONT> motion to
dismiss, the court in the Philadelphia action dismissed
US&nbsp;Airways from the lawsuit and dismissed the third-party
beneficiary claims against the City of Philadelphia and the
Philadelphia Authority for Industrial Development.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On May&nbsp;21, 2004, the City of Philadelphia and the
Philadelphia Authority for Industrial Development filed a Motion
for Summary Judgment seeking dismissal of the remaining claims
for constructive trust and quantum meruit. On October&nbsp;18,
2004, the City of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority
for Industrial Development also filed an alternative Motion for
Partial Summary Judgment that the damages claimed by Limbach
Company and the joint venture, if any, are capped at the amount
determined by the Bankruptcy Court on the prior trial of its
claims. On June&nbsp;29, 2005, the court granted the Motion for
Summary Judgment and dismissed the alternative Motion for
Partial Summary Judgment as moot. Limbach Company and the joint
venture have appealed the dismissal of these claims, as well as
the prior dismissal of its third party beneficiary claim, but
have not appealed the dismissal of US&nbsp;Airways from the
lawsuit.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Should the Philadelphia court&#146;s rulings be reversed on
appeal and Limbach Company and/or the joint venture subsequently
recover in the Philadelphia action against the City of
Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority for Industrial
Development, that award would be paid by them at 100 cents on
the dollar. Although US&nbsp;Airways&#146; agreements with the
City of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority for
Industrial Development related to the airport development have
neither been assumed nor rejected as part of the 2004
Bankruptcy, if assumed, US&nbsp;Airways may have an obligation,
under those agreements, to indemnify the City of Philadelphia
and the Philadelphia Authority for Industrial Development, at
full value, for any recovery against them by Limbach Company
and/or the joint venture. Proceedings in the Bankruptcy Court
related to the claims in the 2002 Bankruptcy remain stayed by
the 2004 Bankruptcy filing.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">144

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group and US&nbsp;Airways have been named as
defendants in two lawsuits filed in federal district court for
the Eastern District of Michigan in May 1999. Delta Air Lines is
also named as a defendant in both actions, while Northwest
Airlines and the Airlines Reporting Corporation were sued
separately in a third action. The complaints were filed on
behalf of a class of airline passengers who originated or
terminated their trips at the defendant carriers&#146;
respective hubs. These passengers allege that they paid
excessive fares due to the respective airlines&#146; enforcement
of ticketing rules that prohibit the use of a connecting segment
coupon that is part of a through-fare ticket where the passenger
does not fly or intend to fly the entire ticketed itinerary.
Plaintiffs allege monopolization and restraint of trade in
violation of federal antitrust laws. They seek recovery of
treble damages from all named defendants in the amount of
$390&nbsp;million and an injunction prohibiting future
enforcement of the rules at issue. On May&nbsp;16, 2002, the
court denied the defendant airlines&#146; Motion for Summary
Judgment and granted the plaintiffs&#146; Motion for
Class&nbsp;Certification in each of the cases. On May&nbsp;31,
2002, US&nbsp;Airways Group and US&nbsp;Airways filed a petition
with the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
seeking a discretionary review of the certification order. On
November&nbsp;21, 2002, the petition for permission to appeal
the class certification decision was denied. On December&nbsp;4,
2002, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines filed a rehearing
petition seeking en banc review of the initial Sixth Circuit
denial. On February&nbsp;24, 2003, Northwest Airlines&#146; and
Delta Air Lines&#146; petition for rehearing en banc was denied.
Notwithstanding the district court&#146;s denial of summary
judgment and the petition, US&nbsp;Airways Group and
US&nbsp;Airways believe the claims are without merit and intend
to pursue a vigorous defense. The action was stayed as to
US&nbsp;Airways during the 2002 Bankruptcy and again during the
2004 Bankruptcy. On April&nbsp;29, 2005, Northwest Airlines and
Delta Air Lines filed a renewed motion for summary judgment on
all counts. That motion was denied. Delta Air Lines and
Northwest Airlines filed two additional motions: one seeking
decertification of the class and the other seeking dismissal of
all class members who received ticket refunds. While those
motions were pending, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines
filed for bankruptcy. The federal district court has now
deactivated the case because of the bankruptcy filings. However,
in January 2006, plaintiffs filed a motion for relief from the
stay imposed by the Northwest Airlines bankruptcy filing to
pursue litigation against that defendant only. On
December&nbsp;1, 2005, plaintiffs withdrew the claims filed
against US&nbsp;Airways in the 2002 and 2004 Bankruptcies, thus
effectively cutting off their right to obtain any relief against
US&nbsp;Airways for damages that might have accrued prior to
September&nbsp;27, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;29, 2000, US&nbsp;Airways intervened in a
proceeding that was originally brought on January&nbsp;26, 1998
by the Pennsylvania Department of Environment Protection against
Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, and the Allegheny County
Aviation Administration alleging that a variety of airfield and
aircraft de-icing activities at Pittsburgh International Airport
violated the requirements of (a)&nbsp;a 1994 Consent Order and
Adjudication issued to Allegheny County and air carrier tenants
at the Pittsburgh International Airport, (b)&nbsp;the Pittsburgh
International Airport&#146;s National Pollutant Discharge
Elimination System Permit, and (c)&nbsp;the Pennsylvania Clean
Streams Law. The action was brought before the Pennsylvania
Environmental Hearing Board. During March 2001, the
Environmental Hearing Board approved Allegheny County&#146;s
Motion to Withdraw the Appeal without Prejudice, thereby
terminating the appeal. However, during the course of settlement
discussions leading to the termination of the appeal, the
Pennsylvania Department of Environment Protection advised
Allegheny County and US&nbsp;Airways that the Department of
Environment Protection will require additional measures to be
taken to control de-icing materials at the Pittsburgh
International Airport, and will assess a civil penalty against
Allegheny County and US&nbsp;Airways for the alleged violations
described above. The Allegheny County Aviation Administration,
US&nbsp;Airways and the Pennsylvania Department of Environment
Protection have continued to work together with the goal of
fashioning an ultimate resolution to the de-icing issues.
US&nbsp;Airways Group does not believe that the settlement of
this matter will have a material adverse effect on its financial
condition, results of operations or liquidity.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">145

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;7, 2005, 240 pilots employed by the MidAtlantic
division of US&nbsp;Airways filed a complaint in the federal
district court for the Eastern District of New York against
ALPA, US&nbsp;Airways, US&nbsp;Airways Group, Republic Airways
Holdings, Inc., Wexford Capital LLC and AWA, alleging that
defendants conspired to deceive plaintiffs into believing that
MidAtlantic was a separate entity from US&nbsp;Airways in order
to deprive them of the benefits they are due as US&nbsp;Airways
pilots pursuant to the US&nbsp;Airways collective bargaining
agreement. Plaintiffs&#146; claims against the airline
defendants include breach of collective bargaining agreement,
violation of the Railway Labor Act and racketeering under the
Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act
(&#147;RICO&#148;). Plaintiffs&#146; complaint requests
$2&nbsp;billion in damages from the airline defendants and
injunctive relief.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On February&nbsp;8, 2006, 103 flight attendants employed by the
MidAtlantic division of US&nbsp;Airways filed a complaint
against AFA, AFA&#146;s international president Pat Friend and
US&nbsp;Airways, alleging that defendants conspired to deceive
plaintiffs into believing that MidAtlantic was a separate entity
from US&nbsp;Airways in order to deprive them of the benefits
they are due as US&nbsp;Airways flight attendants pursuant to
the US&nbsp;Airways collective bargaining agreement.
Plaintiffs&#146; claims against US&nbsp;Airways include breach
of collective bargaining agreement, violation of the Railway
Labor Act and racketeering under RICO. Plaintiffs&#146;
complaint requests $400&nbsp;million in damages from
US&nbsp;Airways and injunctive relief. Because the complaint has
not yet been served on US&nbsp;Airways, no action is due on its
part at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;12, 2005, Bank of America, N.A., which is the
issuing bank of the US&nbsp;Airways frequent flier program
credit card and also acts as the processing bank for most
airline ticket purchases paid for with credit cards, filed suit
in the Delaware Chancery Court in New Castle County, against
US&nbsp;Airways, US&nbsp;Airways Group and AWA, alleging that
US&nbsp;Airways breached its frequent flier credit card contract
with Bank of America by entering into a similar, competing
agreement with Juniper and allowing Juniper to issue a
US&nbsp;Airways frequent flier credit card. Bank of America also
alleges that US&nbsp;Airways Group and AWA induced these
breaches. Bank of America seeks an order requiring
US&nbsp;Airways to market the Bank of America card and prohibit
Juniper from issuing a US&nbsp;Airways credit card, as well as
unspecified damages. On October&nbsp;27, 2005, Juniper, which
was not originally a party to the lawsuit, sought and later
received court permission to intervene as a defendant in the
case and has made counterclaims against Bank of America. Juniper
seeks an order declaring the validity of its new agreement to
issue a US&nbsp;Airways frequent flier credit card. On
November&nbsp;3, 2005, Bank of America filed a motion for
partial summary judgment on the breach of contract claim against
US&nbsp;Airways. After a series of procedural steps, Bank of
America&#146;s motion, along with a cross-motion for summary
judgment filed by Juniper, was heard in the Bankruptcy Court,
where the case is now pending as an adversary proceeding. On
January&nbsp;30, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court ruled that Bank of
America is equitably estopped from pursuing its claims that
US&nbsp;Airways breached its agreement with Bank of America by
negotiating and entering into the agreement with Juniper. Bank
of America is seeking appeal of that ruling while it continues
to pursue its claim that US Airways failed to fulfill
contractual marketing obligations to Bank of America. The
resolution of the final two claims that Bank of America made in
the lawsuit, which are (i)&nbsp;that AWA tortiously interfered
with the contractual relationship between US Airways and Bank of
America and (ii)&nbsp;that US Airways Group and AWA tortiously
interfered with Bank of America&#146;s right to future economic
benefit under its agreement with US Airways, are dependent on
the outcome of the pending appeal. Bank of America will pursue
those two claims only if its appeal of the January&nbsp;30, 2006
order is successful.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company is unable to estimate at this time the amount of
loss or probable losses, if any, that might result from an
adverse resolution of the proceedings discussed above, and
currently is unable to predict whether the outcome of these
proceedings will have a material adverse effect on its results
of operations or financial condition. The Company intends,
however, to vigorously pursue all available defenses and claims
in these matters.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">146

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group and its subsidiaries are parties to
various legal proceedings, including some purporting to be class
action suits, and some that demand large monetary damages or
other relief, which, if granted, would require significant
expenditures. In certain cases where it is probable that the
outcome will result in monetary damages, the Company will
consider all available information and record an accrual. For
those cases where a range of loss is probable but no amount
within the range is a better estimate than any other amount, the
Company will record an accrual at the low end of the range.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(e)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Guarantees (including revenue bonds)</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company guarantees the payment of principal and interest on
certain special facility revenue bonds issued by municipalities
to build or improve certain airport and maintenance facilities
which are leased to US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. Under such leases,
US&nbsp;Airways and AWA are required to make rental payments,
sufficient to pay maturing principal and interest payments on
the related bonds. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, the principal
amount outstanding of these bonds was $99&nbsp;million.
Remaining lease payments guaranteeing the principal and interest
on these bonds will be $171&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company enters into real estate leases in substantially all
cities that it serves. It is common in such commercial lease
transactions for the Company as the lessee to agree to indemnify
the lessor and other related third parties for tort liabilities
that arise out of or relate to the use or occupancy of the
leased premises. In some cases, this indemnity extends to
related liabilities arising from the negligence of the
indemnified parties, but usually excludes any liabilities caused
by their gross negligence or willful misconduct. With respect to
certain special facility bonds, the Company agreed to indemnify
the municipalities for any claims arising out of the issuance
and sale of the bonds and the use and occupancy of the
concourses financed by these bonds and the old bonds
Additionally, the Company typically indemnifies such parties for
any environmental liability that arises out of or relates to its
use of the leased premises.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company is the lessee under many aircraft financing
agreements (including leveraged lease financings of aircraft
under the pass through trusts) and real estate leases. It is
common in such transactions for the Company as the lessee to
agree to indemnify the lessor and other related third parties
for the manufacture, design, ownership, financing, use,
operation and maintenance of the aircraft, and for tort
liabilities that arise out of or relate to the Company&#146;s
use or occupancy of the leased asset. In some cases, this
indemnity extends to related liabilities arising from the
negligence of the indemnified parties, but usually excludes any
liabilities caused by their gross negligence or willful
misconduct.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company expects that it would be covered by insurance
(subject to deductibles) for most tort liabilities and related
indemnities described above with respect to leased real estate
and operated aircraft. The Company cannot estimate the potential
amount of future payments under the foregoing indemnities and
guarantees
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company reviewed its long-term operating leases at a number
of airports, including leases where the Company is also the
guarantor of the underlying debt. Such leases are typically with
municipalities or other governmental entities. The arrangements
are not required to be consolidated based on the provisions of
FIN&nbsp;46(R).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes
are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally
and on a senior unsecured basis, by US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
two major operating subsidiaries, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">147

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">

(Continued)</B>

<DIV style="margin-top: 24pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(e)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Concentration of credit risks</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company invests available cash in money market securities of
various banks, commercial paper and asset-backed securities of
various financial institutions, other companies with high credit
ratings and securities backed by the U.S.&nbsp;Government.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company does not believe it is subject to any significant
concentration of credit risk. Most of the Company&#146;s
receivables result from tickets sold to individual passengers
through the use of major credit cards or from tickets sold by
other airlines and used by passengers. These receivables are
short-term, generally being settled shortly after the sale.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>13.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Nonoperating income (expenses)&nbsp;&#151; other, net</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the fourth quarter of 2005, the Company recorded
$4&nbsp;million of derivative gain attributable to stock options
in Sabre and warrants in a number of
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">e-commerce</FONT> companies.
On an ongoing basis, the Company adjusts its balance sheet to
reflect changes in the current fair market value of the stock
options and warrants according to SFAS&nbsp;133.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the fourth quarter of 2005, the Company repurchased warrants
issued to the ATSB. In connection with this repurchase, the
Company recorded $8&nbsp;million of nonoperating expense. This
amount represented the unamortized balance recorded as an other
asset, which was being amortized over the life of the government
guaranteed loan as an increase to interest expense.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the fourth quarter of 2005, the Company wrote off
$2&nbsp;million in issuance costs in connection with the
conversion of the 7.25% exchangeable notes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the term loan refinancing with GECC, the
Company wrote off $1&nbsp;million of debt issue costs associated
to the term loan with Mizuho in 2004. This amount was recorded
in nonoperating expenses.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In April 2003, Congress passed, and the President signed, the
Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act to provide
certain aviation-related assistance. $2.3&nbsp;billion of the
appropriation was for grants by the Transportation Security
Administration (&#147;TSA&#148;) to U.S.&nbsp;air carriers based
on the proportional share each carrier had paid or collected as
of the date of enactment of the legislation for passenger
security and air carrier security fees. In May 2003, AWA
received approximately $81&nbsp;million representing its
proportional share of passenger security and air carrier
security fees paid or collected as of April 2003, which has been
classified as Federal government assistance in the accompanying
statements of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the fourth quarter of 2003, IAC/ InterActiveCorp completed
its acquisition of Hotwire.com, a discount travel website.
Hotwire was founded by the Texas Pacific Group, American
Airlines, Continental Airlines, Northwest Airlines, United
Airlines, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA in October 2000. AWA had an
ownership interest of approximately 1.5% in Hotwire.com with a
carrying value of approximately $0.03&nbsp;million. Upon closing
of the transaction, AWA received cash of $10&nbsp;million.
Accordingly, AWA recognized a nonoperating gain of
$10&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter of 2003.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">148

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>15.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Related party transactions</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Richard A. Bartlett, a member of the board of directors of
US&nbsp;Airways Group, is a greater than 10% minority owner and
director of Eastshore. In February 2005, Eastshore entered into
an agreement with US&nbsp;Airways Group to provide a
$125&nbsp;million financing commitment to provide equity funding
for a plan of reorganization, in the form of a debtor in
possession term loan. Under the terms of US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s plan of reorganization, Eastshore received a cash
payment in the amount of all accrued interest on the loan, and
the principal amount of $125&nbsp;million was satisfied by
delivery of 8,333,333&nbsp;shares of US&nbsp;Airways Group
common stock, representing a price of $15.00&nbsp;per share.
Mr.&nbsp;Bartlett is also a greater than 10% owner of Air
Wisconsin. US&nbsp;Airways and Air Wisconsin also entered into a
regional jet services agreement under which Air Wisconsin may,
but is not required to, provide regional jet service under a
US&nbsp;Airways Express code share arrangement. On April&nbsp;8,
2005, Air Wisconsin notified US&nbsp;Airways Group of its
intention to deploy 70 regional jets, the maximum number
provided for in the agreement, into the US&nbsp;Airways Express
network. The amount paid to Air Wisconsin in 2005 was
approximately $55&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Robert A. Milton, a member of the board of directors of
US&nbsp;Airways Group, is the Chairman, President and Chief
Executive Officer of ACE. ACE purchased 5,000,000&nbsp;shares of
US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock at a purchase price of
$15.00&nbsp;per share, for a total investment of
$75&nbsp;million. ACE or its subsidiaries entered into
commercial agreements with US&nbsp;Airways Group and America
West Holdings for various services including maintenance and
airport handling. The amount paid in 2005 for these commercial
agreements was approximately $2&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Edward L. Shapiro, a member of the board of directors of
US&nbsp;Airways Group, is a Vice President and partner of PAR
Capital Management, the general partner of PAR. PAR received
10,768,485&nbsp;shares of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock,
including shares received pursuant to Participation Agreements
with America West Holdings, for a total investment of
$160&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">149

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Richard P. Schifter, a member of the board of directors of
US&nbsp;Airways Group, is a partner of Texas Pacific Group,
which was a controlling stockholder of America West Holdings
prior to the completion of the merger. An affiliate of Texas
Pacific Group received $6.4&nbsp;million as an advisory fee for
providing financial advisory services rendered in connection
with the merger and in contribution for and reimbursement for
certain expenses incurred by Texas Pacific Group and its
affiliates in connection with the merger. In addition, Texas
Pacific Group had agreed to reimburse America West Holdings
approximately $3&nbsp;million for expenses incurred by America
West Holdings in the second half of 2004 on its behalf. The full
amount was reimbursed to America West Holdings in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

    <TD width="95%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>16.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Merger Accounting and Pro Forma Information</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Purchase price allocation</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The value of the merger consideration was determined based upon
America West Holdings&#146; traded market price per share due to
the fact that US&nbsp;Airways Group was operating under
bankruptcy protection prior to the merger. The outstanding
shares in America West Holdings at September&nbsp;27, 2005 were
valued at $4.82&nbsp;per share, resulting in an aggregate value
assigned to the shares of $175&nbsp;million. The $4.82&nbsp;per
share value was based on the five-day average share price of
America West Holdings, with May&nbsp;19, 2005, the merger
announcement date, as the midpoint. The outstanding shares of
America West Holdings Class&nbsp;A and Class&nbsp;B common stock
were converted into shares of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock
at a conversion rate of 0.5362 and 0.4125, respectively. Certain
unsecured creditors of US&nbsp;Airways Group have been or will
be issued an aggregate of approximately 8.2&nbsp;million shares
of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock in settlement of their
claims, including stock issued to the PBGC and ALPA. The fair
value of that common stock valued at an equivalent price based
on the $4.82 value of the America West Holdings stock is
$96&nbsp;million. America West Holdings incurred
$21&nbsp;million of direct acquisition costs in connection with
the merger. The following table summarizes the components of
purchase price (in millions):
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

<TR style="font-size: 1pt;">
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="88%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s emergence from
bankruptcy, significant prepetition liabilities were discharged.
The surviving liabilities and the assets acquired in the merger
are shown at estimated fair value. The Company used an outside
appraisal firm to assist in determining the fair value of
long-lived tangible and identifiable intangible assets.
Significant assets and liabilities adjusted to fair market value
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">150

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
include expendable spare parts and supplies, property and
equipment, airport take-off and landing slots, aircraft leases,
deferred revenue and continuing debt obligations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In accordance with SFAS&nbsp;141, the allocation of equity
values is subject to adjustment for up to one year after the
date of acquisition when additional information on asset and
liability valuations becomes available. The Company expects that
there may be further adjustments to recorded fair values
including those related to its air traffic liability, tax
liabilities, and accrued expenses. Accrued expenses may change
based on identification of final fees and costs associated with
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s emergence from bankruptcy,
resolution of disputed claims and completion of the
Chapter&nbsp;11 cases. In connection with the merger, primarily
due to the relocation of the corporate headquarters from
Arlington, Virginia to Tempe, Arizona, US&nbsp;Airways accrued
in purchase accounting $24&nbsp;million of severance and
benefits related to planned reductions in force for its non
union employees. The Company expects to incur additional
severance and benefits for reductions in force related to the
merger, however, due to requirements for continued service
during the integration period, these severance and benefits will
not be an adjustment to the purchase price allocation but will
be expensed in future periods. See Note&nbsp;7 for discussion of
amounts expensed for severance and benefits in the fourth
quarter of 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

values reported as of September&nbsp;30, 2005 are as follows (in
millions):

</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Adjustments to other assets and deferred gains and credits
primarily represent fair market value adjustments for above and
below market aircraft leases. Adjustments to Other accrued
expenses primarily represent fair market value adjustments to
the acquired frequent traveler liability and identified
pre-acquisition liabilities for return conditions liabilities
and related power by the hour program penalties associated with
the return of certain aircraft, and a retroactive TSA assessment
received in the fourth quarter.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Pro forma information</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The following information is presented assuming the merger and
the conversion of America West Holdings&#146; Class&nbsp;A and
Class&nbsp;B common stock had been completed as of
January&nbsp;1, 2004. The pro forma consolidated results of
operations include purchase accounting adjustments, such as fair
market value adjustments of the assets and liabilities of
US&nbsp;Airways Group, adjustments to reflect the disposition of
prepetition liabilities upon US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
emergence from bankruptcy, and adjustments to conform certain
accounting policies of US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West
Holdings, together with related income tax effects. Certain
other transactions critical to US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
emergence from bankruptcy and the completion of the merger that
became effective either before, at or immediately following the
merger have also been reflected in the pro forma financial
information. These transactions include the new equity
investments, the comprehensive agreements with GECC, the
comprehensive agreement with Airbus, the restructuring of the
ATSB Loans, and the restructuring of the credit card partner and
credit card
</DIV>

    <TD><B>17.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Operating segments and related disclosures</B></TD>
</TR>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group is managed as a single business unit that
provides air transportation for passengers and cargo. This
allows it to benefit from an integrated revenue pricing and
route network that includes US&nbsp;Airways, AWA, Piedmont, PSA
and third-party carriers that fly under capacity purchase
agreements as part of the Company&#146;s Express operations. The
flight equipment of all these carriers is combined to form one
fleet that is deployed through a single route scheduling system.
When making resource allocation decisions, the chief operating
decision maker evaluates flight profitability data, which
considers aircraft type and route economics, but gives no weight
to the financial impact of the resource allocation decision on
an individual carrier basis. The objective in making resource
allocation decisions is to maximize consolidated financial
results, not the individual results of US&nbsp;Airways, AWA,
Piedmont and PSA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Information concerning operating revenues in principal
geographic areas is as follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Holders of common stock are entitled to one vote per share on
all matters submitted to a vote of common shareholders, except
that voting rights of
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">non-U.S.&nbsp;</FONT>citizens
are limited to the extent that the shares of common stock held
by such
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">non-U.S.&nbsp;</FONT>persons
would otherwise be entitled to more than 24.9% of the aggregate
votes of all outstanding equity securities of US&nbsp;Airways
Group. Holders of common stock have no right to cumulate their
votes. Holders of common stock participate equally as to any
dividends or distributions on the common stock.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Warrants</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As compensation for various elements of AWA&#146;s financial
restructuring completed in January 2002, America West Holdings
issued a warrant to purchase&nbsp;18.8&nbsp;million shares of
its Class&nbsp;B common stock to
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">152

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
the ATSB and additional warrants to
purchase&nbsp;3.8&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;B common
stock to other loan participants, in each case at an exercise
price of $3&nbsp;per share and a term of ten years. For
accounting purposes, the warrants were valued at
$35.4&nbsp;million, or $1.57&nbsp;per share, using the
Black-Scholes pricing model with the following assumptions:
expected dividend yield of 0.0%, risk-free interest rate of
4.8%, volatility of 44.9% and an expected life of ten years. The
warrants were recorded by AWA as a non-cash capital contribution
in the accompanying consolidated statements of
stockholder&#146;s equity and comprehensive income and
classified as other assets, net in the accompanying consolidated
balance sheets. The warrants will be amortized over the life of
the AWA ATSB Loan as an increase to interest expense. In the
first quarter of 2004, approximately 220,000 warrants were
exercised at $3&nbsp;per share. In the third quarter of 2003,
approximately 2.6&nbsp;million warrants were exercised at
$3&nbsp;per share. These warrant exercises were cashless
transactions resulting in the issuance of approximately
1.6&nbsp;million shares of America West Holdings&#146;
Class&nbsp;B common stock.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the fourth quarter of 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group announced
an agreement to repurchase all of the replacement warrants
issued to the ATSB in connection with the merger with America
West Holdings. US&nbsp;Airways Group repurchased approximately
7.7&nbsp;million warrants to purchase shares of common stock
that had an exercise price of $7.27&nbsp;per share. The total
purchase price for the warrants was $116&nbsp;million, which
approximated their fair value at the purchase date. In
connection with this repurchase, AWA recorded $8&nbsp;million of
nonoperating expense. This amount represented the unamortized
balance recorded as an other asset, which was being amortized
over the life of the AWA ATSB Loan as an increase to interest
expense.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>19.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Stock options and awards</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
At the effective time of the merger all outstanding options to
purchase America West Holdings Class&nbsp;B common stock under
America West Holdings&#146; stock-based benefit plans and under
individual employment agreements were converted into options to
acquire US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock in accordance with
the merger agreement. At the effective time of the merger,
options were outstanding under America West Holding&#146;s 1994
Incentive Equity Plan (the &#147;1994 Incentive Plan&#148;) and
2002 Incentive Equity Plan (the &#147;2002 Incentive
Plan&#148;). Pursuant to those plans, these options outstanding
became fully vested.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the merger, each outstanding America West
Holdings stock option was converted into an option to purchase
the number of shares of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock that
is equal to the product of the number of shares of America West
Holdings Class&nbsp;B common stock that could have been
purchased before the merger upon the exercise of the option
multiplied by 0.4125 and rounded up to the nearest whole share.
The exercise price per share of US&nbsp;Airways Group common
stock for the converted option is equal to the exercise price
per share of America West Holdings Class&nbsp;B common stock
subject to the option before the conversion divided by 0.4125
and rounded down to the nearest whole cent. The other terms of
each America West Holdings stock option applicable before the
conversion continue to apply to the converted option after the
conversion. Except as specifically provided above and to the
extent the terms, conditions and restrictions may be altered in
accordance with their terms as a result of the merger, following
the effective time of the merger, each America West Holdings
stock option is governed by the same terms and conditions as
were applicable under that America West Holdings stock option
immediately prior to the effective time of the merger, including
its vesting schedule and expiration date.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As part of the plan of reorganization, the Bankruptcy Court
approved a new equity incentive plan, referred to as the 2005
Incentive Equity Plan (the &#147;2005 Incentive Plan&#148;). The
2005 Incentive Plan provides for the grant of incentive stock
options, nonstatutory stock options, stock appreciation rights,
stock purchase awards, stock bonus awards, stock unit awards,
and other forms of equity compensation, collectively referred to
as stock awards, as well as performance-based cash awards.
Incentive stock options
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">153

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#151;
(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
granted under the 2005 Incentive Plan are intended to qualify as
&#147;incentive stock options&#148; within the meaning of
Section&nbsp;422 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as
amended. Nonstatutory stock options granted under the 2005
Incentive Plan are not intended to qualify as incentive stock
options under the Internal Revenue Code.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
A maximum of 12.5% of the fully-diluted shares (as of the
completion of the merger) of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock
is available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan,
totaling 10,969,191&nbsp;shares. Any or all of these shares may
be granted pursuant to incentive stock options. Shares of
US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock issued under the 2005
Incentive Plan may be unissued shares or reacquired shares,
purchased on the open market or otherwise.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The number of shares of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock
available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan will be
reduced by (i)&nbsp;one share for each share of stock issued
pursuant to a stock option or a stock appreciation right, and
(ii)&nbsp;three shares for each share of stock issued pursuant
to a stock purchase award, stock bonus award, stock unit award,
and other full-value types of stock awards. Stock awards that
are terminated, forfeited or repurchased will result in an
increase in the share reserve of the 2005 Incentive Plan
corresponding to the reduction originally made in respect of the
award.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
If a stock award granted under the 2005 Incentive Plan or the
2002 Incentive Plan expires or otherwise terminates without
being exercised in full, or if any shares of US&nbsp;Airways
Group common stock issued pursuant to a stock award under the
2005 Incentive Plan are forfeited to or repurchased by
US&nbsp;Airways Group, including, but not limited to, any
repurchase or forfeiture caused by the failure to meet a
contingency or condition required for the vesting of such
shares, then the shares of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock
not issued under that stock award, or forfeited to or
repurchased by US&nbsp;Airways Group, will revert to and again
become available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan. If
any shares subject to a stock award are not delivered to a
participant because those shares are withheld for the payment of
taxes or the stock award is exercised through a reduction of
shares subject to the stock award (<I>i.e</I>., &#147;net
exercised&#148;), the number of shares that are not delivered
will remain available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive
Plan. If the exercise price of any stock award is satisfied by
tendering shares of US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock held by
the participant, then the number of shares so tendered (whether
by actual tender or by attestation of ownership) will remain
available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan. Shares of
US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock subject to stock awards
issued in substitution for previously outstanding awards assumed
in connection with a merger, consolidation or similar
transaction will not reduce the number of shares available for
issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Stock options are granted with an exercise price equal to the
stock&#146;s fair market value at the date of grant, generally
become exercisable over a three-year period and expire if
unexercised at the end of 10&nbsp;years. At December&nbsp;31,
2005, approximately 6.9&nbsp;million shares are available for
grant under the 2005 Incentive Plan.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">154

    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>21.58</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>3,108,528</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>25.40</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
There were 2,428,880 and 2,041,680 stock options exercisable as
of December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. The per share
weighted-average fair value of stock options granted during
2005, 2004 and 2003 was $8.50, $10.90 and $4.67, respectively,
on the date of grant using the Black-Scholes option pricing
model with the following weighted-average assumptions:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The stock option plans also provide for the issuance of stock
and grant of stock options to non-employee directors.
US&nbsp;Airways Group has granted options to
purchase&nbsp;273,442&nbsp;shares of US&nbsp;Airways Group
common stock to members of the Board of Directors who are not
employees of US&nbsp;Airways Group. The options have a ten-year
contractual term and are exercisable six months after the date
of grant. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, 165,394 options were
outstanding and exercisable at prices ranging from $4.68 to
$70.76&nbsp;per share.
</DIV>

</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>21.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Select quarterly financial information (unaudited)</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 2005 and 2004 unaudited quarterly financial data has been
adjusted to reflect certain reclassifications. These
reclassifications include reclassing: fuel hedging activities
from nonoperating to operating expenses, reclassing the sale of
frequent flier miles and related marketing services to affinity
partners from other operating expenses to operating revenues and
reclassing Express expenses from operating revenues to operating
expenses. See also Note&nbsp;5 &#147;Change in method of
reporting for America West Express results and other
reclassifications.&#148; In addition, 2005 quarterly financial
data has been adjusted to reflect the change in accounting
policy for maintenance costs as if the change occurred on
January&nbsp;1, 2005. Pro forma adjustments have been made to
the 2004 quarterly financial data to reflect
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">157

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

(Continued)</B>

comparable information relating to the effect of the change in
accounting policy for maintenance costs. See also Note&nbsp;4.

    expenses to &#147;Mainline passenger&#148; and &#147;Other&#148;
    revenues. Reflects $5&nbsp;million additional maintenance

    method.</TD>

    <TD width="6%"></TD>
