<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>22.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Subsequent event</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Purchase of 757 aircraft</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On February&nbsp;23, 2006, US&nbsp;Airways executed an agreement
to purchase three Boeing 757-200 aircraft for delivery on
February&nbsp;24, 2006. US&nbsp;Airways purchased the aircraft
for cash and anticipates arranging financing for all three
aircraft through asset-based financing or sale leasebacks at a
later date. The Company plans to utilize these aircraft
primarily in the US&nbsp;Airways fleet.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">161

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<A name='114'></A>
</DIV>

<!-- link1 "Item 8B. Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data of America West Airlines, Inc." -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>Item&nbsp;8B.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data
    of America West Airlines, Inc.</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
The Board of Directors and Stockholder
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
America West Airlines, Inc.:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of
America West Airlines, Inc. and subsidiary as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, and the related consolidated
statements of operations, stockholder&#146;s equity
(deficiency)&nbsp;and comprehensive income, and cash flows for
each of the years in the three-year period ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005. These consolidated financial statements
are the responsibility of the Company&#146;s management. Our
responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated
financial statements based on our audits.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the
Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those
standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are
free of material misstatement. An audit includes examining, on a
test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in
the financial statements. An audit also includes assessing the
accounting principles used and significant estimates made by
management, as well as evaluating the overall financial
statement presentation. We believe that our audits provide a
reasonable basis for our opinion.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred
to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial
position of America West Airlines, Inc. and subsidiary as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, and the results of their
operations and their cash flows for each of the years in the
three-year period ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, in conformity
with U.S.&nbsp;generally accepted accounting principles.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As discussed in Note&nbsp;3 to the consolidated financial
statements, the Company changed its method of accounting for
major scheduled airframe, engine and certain component overhaul
costs from the deferral method to the direct expense method in
2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
/s/ KPMG LLP
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
Phoenix, Arizona
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
March&nbsp;14, 2006
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">162

<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

    <TD colspan="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap><B>2005</B></TD><TD></TD>

    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap><B>2004</B></TD><TD></TD>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">165
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Consolidated Statements of Stockholder&#146;s Equity
(Deficiency)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>and Comprehensive Income</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>For the Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>(in millions)</B>
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">166

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>1.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Merger Agreement between US&nbsp;Airways Group and America
    West Holdings</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On May&nbsp;19, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group signed a merger
agreement with America West Holdings pursuant to which America
West Holdings merged with a wholly owned subsidiary of
US&nbsp;Airways Group upon US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
emergence from bankruptcy on September&nbsp;27, 2005. The
Debtors&#146; plan of reorganization was confirmed by the
Bankruptcy Court on September&nbsp;16, 2005 and became effective
on September&nbsp;27, 2005, the same day that the merger with
America West Holdings became effective.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Critical to US&nbsp;Airways&#146; emergence from bankruptcy and
the merger with America West Holdings was additional financing
and liquidity to fund operations. The financing and liquidity
was provided through a combination of new equity investments in
US&nbsp;Airways Group, new and restructured debt instruments and
agreements with significant stakeholders as described below.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>New equity investments</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; On
September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group received new
equity investments of $565&nbsp;million in the aggregate from
ACE Aviation Holdings Inc. (&#147;ACE&#148;); Par Investment
Partners, L.P. (&#147;Par&#148;); Peninsula Investment Partners,
L.P. (&#147;Peninsula&#148;); a group of investors under the
management of Wellington Management Company, LLP
(&#147;Wellington&#148;); Tudor Proprietary Trading, L.L.C. and
certain investors advised by Tudor Investment Corp.
(&#147;Tudor&#148;); and Eastshore Aviation, LLC
(&#147;Eastshore&#148;). In addition, the equity investors were
granted options to acquire 7,533,334 additional shares of
US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock at $15&nbsp;per share. All
such options were exercised in 2005 for proceeds of
$113&nbsp;million. Proceeds from these new equity investments
totaled approximately $678&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Public stock offering</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; On
September&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group completed a
public offering of common stock in which it issued
9,775,000&nbsp;shares of its common stock at a price of
$19.30&nbsp;per share. The Company received net proceeds of
$180&nbsp;million from the offering.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>GE Merger MOU</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; US&nbsp;Airways Group
and America West Holdings reached a comprehensive agreement with
General Electric Capital Corporation (&#147;GECC&#148;), and its
affiliates as described in the Master Merger Memorandum of
Understanding (&#147;GE Merger MOU&#148;). The key aspects of
the GE Merger MOU as it related to AWA are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    GE agreed to the early return to GECC of ten leased aircraft
    including six Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT> and four Airbus
    A320-200 aircraft. Five of these aircraft, including one Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300s</FONT> and four
    Airbus <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A320-200s</FONT> were
    already returned and the remaining aircraft are scheduled for
    return by the fourth quarter of 2006.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    GE also agreed to waive certain return conditions, as provided
    in the underlying lease agreements, related to the early return
    aircraft described above.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Airbus MOU</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; In connection with the
merger, a Memorandum of Understanding was executed between AVSA
S.A.R.L., an affiliate of Airbus S.A.S. (&#147;Airbus&#148;),
US&nbsp;Airways Group, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. The key aspects
of the Airbus Memorandum of Understanding as it relates to AWA
are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA entered into
    two loan agreements with Airbus Financial Services, as Initial
    Lender and Loan&nbsp;Agent, Wells Fargo Bank Northwest, National
    Association, as Collateral Agent, and US&nbsp;Airways Group, as
    guarantor, with commitments in initial aggregate amounts of up
    to $161&nbsp;million and up to $89&nbsp;million. The Airbus
    loans bear interest at a rate of LIBOR plus a margin, subject to
    adjustment, and have been recorded as an obligation of
    US&nbsp;Airways Group.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    AVSA and AWA agreed to reschedule the delivery dates of 11
    aircraft to be purchased under an existing amended agreement,
    including three
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A319-100</FONT> and eight
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A320-200</FONT> aircraft. All
    of the A320-200 aircraft and two of the A319-100 aircraft were
    originally scheduled for delivery in 2006</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

    <TD width="3%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">

    <TD></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    with the last A319-100 to be delivered in the first quarter of
    2007. As rescheduled, these aircraft will be from March through
    December 2009.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    In connection with the restructuring of aircraft firm orders,
    US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West Holdings were required to
    pay an aggregate non-refundable restructuring fee which was paid
    by means of set-off against existing equipment purchase deposits
    of US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West Holdings held by
    Airbus. The America West Holdings restructuring fee of
    $50&nbsp;million has been recorded as a special charge in the
    accompanying consolidated statement of operations, along with
    $7&nbsp;million in related capitalized interest.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Restructuring of the ATSB
Loan&nbsp;Guarantees</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; US&nbsp;Airways Group
and America West Holdings each had loans outstanding guaranteed
under the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act
by the Air Transportation Stabilization Board (&#147;ATSB&#148;
and the loans, the &#147;ATSB Loans&#148;).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On July&nbsp;22, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West
Holdings announced that the ATSB approved the proposed merger.
Under the negotiated new loan terms, the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB
Loan is guaranteed by US&nbsp;Airways Group (including all
domestic subsidiaries, with certain limited exceptions) and is
secured by substantially all of the present and future assets of
US&nbsp;Airways Group not otherwise encumbered, other than
certain specified assets, including assets which are subject to
other financing agreements. The AWA ATSB Loan is also guaranteed
by US&nbsp;Airways Group (including all domestic subsidiaries,
with certain limited exceptions) and is secured by a second lien
in the same collateral. The loans continue to have separate
repayment schedules and interest rates; however, the loans are
subject to similar repayments and mandatory amortization in the
event of additional debt issuances, with certain limited
exceptions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;19, 2005, $238&nbsp;million of AWA&#146;s ATSB
Loan, of which $228&nbsp;million was guaranteed by the ATSB, was
sold by the lender by order of the ATSB to 13 fixed income
investors. The sale of the debt removed the ATSB guarantee. Due
to the sale on October&nbsp;19, 2005, the ATSB no longer
guarantees any portion of the loan and has no interest in any of
AWA&#146;s debt. Terms associated with this loan remain
unchanged. As a result of the sale of the loan, the AWA ATSB
Loan is now referred to as the AWA Citibank Loan, and had an
outstanding balance of $250&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31,
2005. See Note&nbsp;8 for additional information related to the
AWA Citibank Loan.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>New Convertible Notes</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; On
September&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group issued
$144&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of 7%&nbsp;Senior
Convertible Notes due 2020 (the &#147;7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible
Notes&#148;) for proceeds, net of expenses, of approximately
$139&nbsp;million. The 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes are
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s senior unsecured obligations and
rank equally in right of payment to its other senior unsecured
and unsubordinated indebtedness and are effectively subordinated
to its secured indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets
securing such indebtedness. The 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes
are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally
and on a senior unsecured basis, by US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
two major operating subsidiaries, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. The
guarantees are the guarantors&#146; unsecured obligations and
rank equally in right of payment to the other senior unsecured
and unsubordinated indebtedness of the guarantors and are
effectively subordinated to the guarantors&#146; secured
indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets securing such
indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Restructuring of Affinity Credit Card Partner
Agreement</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; In connection with the merger,
AWA, US&nbsp;Airways Group and Juniper Bank, a subsidiary of
Barclays PLC (&#147;Juniper&#148;), entered into an agreement on
August&nbsp;8, 2005 amending AWA&#146;s co-branded credit card
agreement with Juniper, dated January&nbsp;25, 2005. Pursuant to
the amended credit card agreement, Juniper agreed to offer and
market an airline mileage award credit card program to the
general public to participate in US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
Dividend Miles program through the use of a co-branded credit
card.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">168

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s credit card program is currently
administered by Bank of America, N.A. (USA). On
December&nbsp;28, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways issued a notice of
termination under its agreement with Bank of America and that
notice will become effective on December&nbsp;28, 2007. Pending
termination of the Bank of America agreement, both Juniper and
Bank of America will run separate credit card programs for
US&nbsp;Airways Group. The amended credit card agreement is the
subject of pending litigation filed by Bank of America against
US&nbsp;Airways Group, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA (See
Note&nbsp;9(e)).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The amended credit card agreement took effect at the effective
time of the merger. The credit card services provided by Juniper
under the amended credit card agreement began in January 2006,
and will continue until the expiration date, which is the later
of December&nbsp;31, 2012 or seven years from the date on which
Juniper commences marketing to the general public.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the amended credit card agreement, Juniper will pay to
US&nbsp;Airways Group fees for each mile awarded to each credit
card account administered by Juniper, subject to certain
exceptions. Pursuant to the original credit card agreement,
Juniper paid to AWA a bonus of $20&nbsp;million. Juniper also
agreed to pay a one-time bonus payment of $130&nbsp;million,
following the effectiveness of the merger, subject to certain
conditions. The $130&nbsp;million bonus payment was made to AWA
on October&nbsp;3, 2005. The entire $150&nbsp;million balance
for bonus payments are included in &#147;Deferred gains and
other liabilities&#148; in the accompanying consolidated balance
sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2005. US&nbsp;Airways Group will
not recognize any revenue from the bonus payments until the dual
branding period has expired, approximately February 2008. At
that time the Company expects to begin recognizing revenue from
the bonus payments on a straight-line basis through December
2012, the expiration date of the Juniper agreement. Further, if
Juniper is not granted exclusivity to offer a co-branded credit
card after the dual branding period, US&nbsp;Airways Group must
repay the bonus payments and repurchase unused pre-paid miles
with interest, plus $50&nbsp;million in liquidated changes.
Juniper will pay an annual bonus of $5&nbsp;million to
US&nbsp;Airways Group, subject to certain exceptions, for each
year after Juniper becomes the exclusive issuer of the
co-branded credit card.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;3, 2005, Juniper pre-paid for miles from
US&nbsp;Airways Group totaling $325&nbsp;million, subject to the
same conditions as apply to the $130&nbsp;million bonus payment.
The $325&nbsp;million was received by AWA. To the extent that
these miles are not used by Juniper as allowed under the
co-branded credit card program in certain circumstances,
US&nbsp;Airways Group will repurchase these miles in 12 equal
quarterly installments beginning on the fifth year prior to the
expiration date of the co-branded credit card agreement with
Juniper until paid in full. US&nbsp;Airways Group makes monthly
interest payments at LIBOR plus 4.75% to Juniper, beginning on
November&nbsp;1, 2005, based on the amount of pre-purchased
miles that have not been used by Juniper in connection with the
co-branded credit card program and have not been repurchased by
US&nbsp;Airways Group. US&nbsp;Airways Group will be required to
repurchase pre-purchased miles under certain reductions in the
collateral held under the credit card processing agreement with
JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. Accordingly, the prepayment has been
recorded as additional indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Juniper requires US&nbsp;Airways Group to maintain an average
quarterly balance of cash, cash equivalents and short-term
investments of at least $1&nbsp;billion for the entirety of the
agreement. Further, the agreement requires US&nbsp;Airways Group
to maintain certain financial ratios beginning January&nbsp;1,
2006. Juniper may, at its option, terminate the amended credit
card agreement, make payments to US&nbsp;Airways Group under the
amended credit card agreement in the form of pre-purchased miles
rather than cash, or require US&nbsp;Airways Group to repurchase
the pre-purchased miles before the fifth year prior to the
expiration date of the co-branded credit card agreement with
Juniper in the event that US&nbsp;Airways Group breaches its
obligations under the amended credit card agreement, or upon the
occurrence of certain events.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Restructuring of Credit Card Processing
Agreement</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; In connection with the merger,
AWA, JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A.,
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">successor-in</FONT>-interest
to JPMorgan Chase Bank, and Chase Merchant
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">169

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
Services, L.L.C. (collectively, &#147;Chase&#148;), entered into
the First Amendment to the Merchant Services Bankcard Agreement
on August&nbsp;8, 2005. Pursuant to the amended card processing
agreement, Chase will perform authorization, processing and
settlement services for sales on Visa and Mastercard for AWA and
US&nbsp;Airways following the merger. The original card
processing agreement is guaranteed by America West Holdings, and
US&nbsp;Airways Group executed a guaranty of the amended card
processing agreement on the effective date of the merger.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The amended card processing agreement took effect at the
effective time of the merger and continues until the expiration
of the initial term, which is three years from the effective
date. Upon expiration of the initial term, the amended card
processing agreement will automatically renew for successive
one-year periods pursuant to the terms of the agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the amended card processing agreement, AWA will pay to
Chase fees in connection with card processing services such as
sales authorization, settlement services and customer service.
AWA and US&nbsp;Airways are also required to maintain a reserve
account to secure Chase&#146;s exposure to outstanding air
traffic liability.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Asset Based Financings</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; For 2005, AWA
also executed flight equipment asset sale and leaseback
transactions resulting in net proceeds of $23&nbsp;million and a
reduction in aircraft related debt of $38&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>2.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Basis of Presentation and Summary of Significant Accounting
    Policies</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Nature of operations and operating environment</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA is a certificated air carrier engaged primarily in the
business of transporting passengers, property and mail. AWA
enplaned approximately 22.1&nbsp;million passengers in 2005 and
was the eighth largest U.S.&nbsp;air carrier, as ranked by
revenue passenger miles (&#147;RPMs&#148;) and available seat
miles (&#147;ASMs&#148;). As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, AWA
operated 141 jet aircraft and 62 regional jet aircraft and
provided regularly scheduled service at 93 airports in North
America, including eight in Mexico, four in Canada and one in
Costa Rica.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Most of AWA&#146;s operations are in competitive markets.
Competitors include other air carriers along with other modes of
transportation. Although a competitive strength in some regards,
the concentration of significant operations in the western
U.S.&nbsp;results in AWA being susceptible to changes in certain
regional conditions that may have an adverse effect on
AWA&#146;s financial condition and results of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, AWA employed approximately 12,100
active full-time equivalent employees. Approximately 80% of
AWA&#146;s employees are covered by collective bargaining
agreements with various labor unions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Basis of Presentation</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the
accounts of AWA and its wholly owned subsidiary Flight Training
Center Hangar Plan, LLC (&#147;FTCHP&#148;). AWA is a wholly
owned subsidiary of America West Holdings, which is a wholly
owned subsidiary of US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc, as discussed in
Note&nbsp;1. US&nbsp;Airways Group has the ability to move funds
freely between its operating subsidiaries, to support
operations. These transfers are recognized as intercompany
transactions. In the accompanying consolidated statement of cash
flows, these intercompany transactions are designated as payable
to affiliate and are classified as operating activities as it is
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s intent to settle these transactions
in the near term. All significant intercompany balances and
transactions have been eliminated in consolidation. As discussed
further in Note&nbsp;16, AWA&#146;s consolidated financial
statements include certain related party transactions.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">170

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform
with the 2005 presentation. In the first quarter of 2005, AWA
changed its method of reporting for its regional alliance
agreement with Mesa Airlines (&#147;Mesa&#148;) from the net
basis of presentation to the gross basis of presentation. See
also Note&nbsp;4, &#147;Change in Method of Reporting for
America West Express Results and Other Reclassifications.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The preparation of financial statements in conformity with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of
America requires management to make estimates and assumptions
that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and
disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of
the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues
and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could
differ from those estimates. The principal areas of judgment
relate to impairment of long-lived assets and intangible assets,
passenger revenue recognition and the frequent traveler program.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Cash, Cash Equivalents and Short-term Investments</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Cash equivalents consist of all highly liquid debt instruments
purchased with original maturities of three months or less.
Short-term investments consist of cash invested in certain debt
securities with original maturities greater than 90&nbsp;days
and less than one year. Investments in auction rate securities
are classified as short-term investments on the accompanying
consolidated balance sheets.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Debt securities are classified as &#147;held to maturity&#148;
in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;115, &#147;Accounting for
Certain Investments in Debt and Equity Securities&#148;
(&#147;SFAS&nbsp;115&#148;). Held to maturity investments are
carried at amortized cost which approximates fair value.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company classifies auction rate securities as
&#147;available-for-sale&#148; in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;115.
Cash equivalents are stated at cost, which approximates fair
value due to the highly liquid nature and short maturities of
the underlying securities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(d)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Restricted Cash</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Restricted cash includes cash deposits securing certain letters
of credit and surety bonds and cash deposits held by
institutions that process credit card sales transactions.
Restricted cash is stated at cost, which approximates fair value.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(e)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Materials and supplies, net</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Inventories of materials and supplies are valued at the lower of
cost or fair value. Costs are determined using average costing
methods. An allowance for obsolescence is provided for flight
equipment expendable and repairable parts.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(f)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Property and Equipment</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Property and equipment is stated at cost. Interest expenses
related to the acquisition of certain property and equipment are
capitalized as an additional cost of the asset or as a leasehold
improvement if the asset is leased. Interest capitalized for the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 was
$3&nbsp;million, $2&nbsp;million and $2&nbsp;million,
respectively. Property and equipment is depreciated and
amortized to residual values over the estimated useful lives or
the lease term, whichever is less, using the straight-line
method. Costs of major improvements that enhance the usefulness
of the asset are capitalized and depreciated over the estimated
useful life of the asset or the modifications, whichever is less.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The estimated useful lives for AWA&#146;s ground property and
equipment range from three to 12&nbsp;years for owned property
and equipment and up to 30&nbsp;years for the flight training
facility. The estimated useful lives of AWA&#146;s owned
aircraft, jet engines, flight equipment and rotable parts range
from five to 25&nbsp;years.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">171

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
Leasehold improvements relating to flight equipment and other
property on operating leases are amortized over the life of the
lease or the life of the asset, whichever is shorter.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA records impairment losses on long-lived assets used in
operations when events and circumstances indicate that the
assets might be impaired as defined by SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;144,
&#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived
Assets.&#148; Recoverability of assets to be held and used is
measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of an asset to
undiscounted future net cash flows expected to be generated by
the asset. If such assets are considered to be impaired, the
impairment to be recognized is measured by the amount by which
the carrying amount of the assets exceeds the fair value of the
assets. Assets to be disposed of are reported at the lower of
the carrying amount or fair value less cost to sell.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(g)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Income Taxes</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability
method. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for
the future tax consequences attributable to differences between
the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and
liabilities and their respective tax bases and operating loss
and tax credit carryforwards. A valuation allowance is
established, if necessary, for the amount of any tax benefits
that, based on available evidence, are not expected to be
realized.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(h)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Other assets, net</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Other assets, net consist primarily of deposits held by vendors,
unamortized debt issuance costs and long-term investments.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(i)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Frequent Traveler Program</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA maintains a frequent travel award program known as
&#147;FlightFund&#148; that provides a variety of awards to
program members based on accumulated mileage. The estimated cost
of providing the free travel, using the incremental cost method
as adjusted for estimated redemption rates, is recognized as a
liability and charged to operations as program members
accumulate mileage.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(j)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Derivative Instruments</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA utilizes financial derivative instruments primarily to
manage its risk associated with changing jet fuel prices. AWA
utilizes heating oil-based derivative instruments to hedge a
portion of its exposure to jet fuel price increases. These
instruments primarily consist of costless collars which hedge
approximately 20% of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s or
68&nbsp;percent of AWA&#146;s 2006 total anticipated jet fuel
requirements at average crude oil equivalent prices of no higher
than $67&nbsp;per barrel as of December&nbsp;31, 2005. AWA does
not purchase or hold any derivative financial instruments for
trading purposes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
SFAS&nbsp;133, &#147;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and
Hedging Activities, as amended,&#148;
(&#147;SFAS&nbsp;133&#148;) requires that all derivatives be
marked to market (fair value) and recorded on the balance sheet.
Derivatives that are not hedges must be adjusted to fair value
through income.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA&#146;s fuel hedging contracts do not currently qualify for
hedge accounting under SFAS&nbsp;133. Accordingly, the
derivative hedging instruments are recorded as an asset or
liability on the balance sheet at fair value and any changes in
fair value are recorded as gains in fuel hedging instruments,
net in operating expenses in the accompanying consolidated
statements of operations in the period of change.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During 2005, 2004 and 2003, AWA recognized gains of
$75&nbsp;million, $24&nbsp;million and $11&nbsp;million,
respectively, related to hedging activities. The fair value of
AWA&#146;s financial derivative instruments at December&nbsp;31,
2005 and 2004 was a net asset of approximately $4&nbsp;million
and $0.2&nbsp;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">172

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Since AWA&#146;s financial derivative instruments are not traded
on a market exchange, the values are determined by the use of
valuation models with assumptions about commodity prices based
on those observed in the underlying markets.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In 2004 AWA restated its consolidated financial statements to
eliminate hedge accounting under SFAS&nbsp;133 for its fuel
hedging transactions. As part of this restatement,
$2&nbsp;million of unrealized gains previously reported as a
component of accumulated other comprehensive income in 2002 were
eliminated in the 2003 financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(k)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Deferred Credits</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Rents for operating leases were adjusted to fair market value
when AWA emerged from bankruptcy in 1994. The net present value
of the difference between the stated lease rates and the fair
market rates has been recorded as a deferred credit in the
accompanying balance sheets. The deferred credit will be
decreased on a straight-line basis as a reduction in rent
expense over the applicable lease periods. At December&nbsp;31,
2005 and 2004, the unamortized balance of the deferred credit
was $37&nbsp;million and $38&nbsp;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported
by a $380&nbsp;million government loan guarantee. This loan
triggered aircraft rent concessions negotiated with
approximately 20 aircraft lessors. Approximately
$18&nbsp;million of aircraft rent, which was accrued as of
December&nbsp;31, 2001, was waived by the aircraft lessors. This
amount has been recorded as a deferred credit in the
accompanying consolidated balance sheet and is being amortized
over the remaining lives of the applicable leases as a reduction
in rent expense. At December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, the
unamortized balance of the deferred credit was approximately
$3&nbsp;million and $4&nbsp;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(l)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Passenger Revenue</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Passenger revenue is recognized when transportation is provided.
Passenger ticket sales are recorded as an air traffic liability
and are subsequently relieved either through carriage of the
passenger, refund to the passenger, expiration of the passenger
ticket or billing from another air carrier that provided the
service. Passenger traffic commissions and related fees are
expensed when the related revenue is recognized. Passenger
traffic commissions and related fees not yet recognized are
recorded as a prepaid expense.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Due to various factors including complex pricing structures,
refunds, exchanges, unused tickets and transactions involving
other carriers, certain amounts are recorded in revenue based on
estimates regarding both the timing of the revenue recognition
and the amount of revenue to be recognized. These estimates are
based upon historical experience and have been consistently
applied to record revenue. AWA routinely performs evaluations of
the liability, which may result in adjustments that are
recognized as a component of mainline passenger revenue. Actual
refund, exchange and expiration activity may vary from estimated
amounts.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA also sells mileage credits to companies participating in its
FlightFund program, such as hotels, car rental agencies and
credit card companies. Transportation-related revenue from the
sale of mileage credits is deferred and recognized when
transportation is provided. The remaining portion of sales
proceeds is recognized immediately as a component of other
operating revenues.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(m)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Stock-based Compensation</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain of AWA&#146;s employees are eligible to participate in
the stock option plans of US&nbsp;Airways Group. US&nbsp;Airways
Group accounts for its stock option plans in accordance with the
provisions of APB Opinion No.&nbsp;25, &#147;Accounting for
Stock Issued to Employees,&#148; and related interpretations. As
such,
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">173

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
compensation expense for options granted would be recorded on
the date of grant only if the current market price of the
underlying stock exceeded the exercise price. Stock options are
issued at a price equal to fair market value on the date of
grant. Accordingly, no compensation cost has been recognized for
stock options in the consolidated financial statements.
Compensation expense, calculated using the provisions of
APB&nbsp;25, has been recorded for stock appreciation rights and
restricted stock units granted to AWA employees.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Had US&nbsp;Airways Group determined compensation cost based on
the fair value at the grant date for its stock options, stock
appreciation rights and restricted stock units under
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123, &#147;Accounting for Stock Based
Compensation,&#148; and allocated the compensation expense to
AWA for its employees participating in the stock option plans,
AWA&#146;s net income (loss) would have been adjusted to the pro
forma amounts indicated below (in millions):
</DIV>

<CENTER>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(n)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Maintenance and Repair Costs</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Maintenance and repair costs for owned and leased flight
equipment are charged to operating expense as incurred. AWA
historically recorded the cost of major scheduled airframe,
engine and certain component overhauls as capitalized assets
that were subsequently amortized over the periods benefited
(referred to as the deferral method). US&nbsp;Airways Group
charges maintenance and repair costs for owned and leased flight
equipment to operating expense as incurred. In 2005, AWA changed
its accounting policy from the deferral method to the direct
expense method. While the deferral method is permitted under
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of
America, US&nbsp;Airways Group and AWA believe that the direct
expense method is preferable and the predominant method used in
the airline industry. The effect of this change in accounting
for aircraft maintenance and repairs is recorded as a cumulative
effect of a change in accounting principle (see also
Note&nbsp;3, &#147;Change in Accounting Policy for Maintenance
Costs&#148;).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(o)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Selling expenses</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Selling expenses include commissions, credit card fees,
computerized reservations systems fees and advertising and
promotional expenses. Advertising and promotional expenses are
expensed when incurred. Advertising and promotional expenses for
the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 were
$12&nbsp;million, $10&nbsp;million and $8&nbsp;million,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(p)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Express expenses</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Expenses associated with AWA&#146;s regional alliance agreement
with Mesa are classified as &#147;Express expenses&#148; on the
statements of operations. Expenses associated with prior periods
have been reclassified as
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">174

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(q)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Recent Accounting Pronouncements</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In December 2004, the FASB issued SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123R,
&#147;Share-Based Payment&#148; (&#147;SFAS&nbsp;123R&#148;).
SFAS&nbsp;123R is a revision of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123,
&#147;Accounting for Stock Based Compensation&#148;, and
supersedes APB&nbsp;25. Among other items, SFAS&nbsp;123R
eliminates the use of APB&nbsp;25 and the intrinsic value method
of accounting, and requires AWA to recognize the cost of
employee services received in exchange for awards of equity
instruments, based on the grant date fair value of those awards,
in the financial statements. Pro forma disclosure is no longer
an alternative under the new standard. Although early adoption
was allowed, AWA adopted SFAS&nbsp;123R as of January&nbsp;1,
2006, the required effective date for calendar year companies.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
SFAS&nbsp;123R permits companies to adopt its requirements using
either a &#147;modified prospective&#148; method, or a
&#147;modified retrospective&#148; method. Under the
&#147;modified prospective&#148; method, compensation cost is
recognized in the financial statements beginning with the
effective date, based on the requirements of SFAS&nbsp;123R for
all share-based payments granted after that date, and based on
the requirements of SFAS&nbsp;123 for all unvested awards
granted prior to the effective date of SFAS&nbsp;123R. Under the
&#147;modified retrospective&#148; method, the requirements are
the same as under the &#147;modified prospective&#148; method,
but also permit entities to restate financial statements of
previous periods based on pro forma disclosures made in
accordance with SFAS&nbsp;123. AWA adopted the requirements of
SFAS&nbsp;123R using the modified prospective method.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA currently utilizes a standard option pricing model (i.e.,
Black-Scholes) to measure the fair value of stock options
granted to employees. While SFAS&nbsp;123R permits entities to
continue to use such a model, the standard also permits the use
of a more complex binomial, or &#147;lattice&#148; model. Based
upon research done by AWA on the alternative models available to
value option grants, AWA has determined that it will continue to
use the Black-Scholes model for option valuation as of the
current time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
SFAS&nbsp;123R includes several modifications to the way that
income taxes are recorded in the financial statements. The
expense for certain types of option grants is only deductible
for tax purposes at the time that the taxable event takes place,
which could cause variability in effective tax rates.
SFAS&nbsp;123R does not allow companies to &#147;predict&#148;
when these taxable events will take place. Furthermore, it
requires that the benefits associated with the tax deductions in
excess of recognized compensation cost be reported as a
financing cash flow, rather than as an operating cash flow as
required under current literature. This requirement will reduce
net operating cash flows and increase net financing cash flows
in periods after the effective date. These future amounts cannot
be estimated, because they depend on, among other things, when
employees exercise stock options.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
America West Holdings and AWA employee stock options outstanding
at the time of the merger were fully vested in accordance with
the change of control provisions of America West Holdings&#146;
stock
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">175

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
option plans. US&nbsp;Airways outstanding stock options were
cancelled as part of the plan of reorganization. Accordingly, as
of January&nbsp;1, 2006, only unvested director stock options,
employee stock options, and stock appreciation rights granted
subsequent to the merger are subject to the transition
provisions of SFAS&nbsp;123R.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of January&nbsp;1, 2006, approximately 2,865,925 unvested
stock options and stock-based awards with weighted average fair
values ranging from $7.94 to $11.34 are subject to the
recognition provisions of SFAS&nbsp;123R. AWA expects that the
impact of adoption of SFAS&nbsp;123R will be significant to the
2006 results of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In May 2005, the FASB issued SFAS&nbsp;No 154, &#147;Accounting
Changes and Error Corrections&nbsp;&#151; A replacement of APB
Opinion No.&nbsp;20 and FASB Statement No.&nbsp;3&#148;
(&#147;SFAS&nbsp;154&#148;). SFAS&nbsp;154 applies to all
voluntary changes in accounting principle, and changes the
requirements for accounting for and reporting of a change in
accounting principle. SFAS&nbsp;154 requires retrospective
application to prior periods&#146; financial statements of a
voluntary change in accounting principle unless it is
impracticable. APB Opinion 20 previously required that most
voluntary changes in accounting principle be recognized by
including in net income of the period of the change the
cumulative effect of changing to the new accounting principle.
The provisions in SFAS&nbsp;154 are effective for accounting
changes and correction of errors made in fiscal years beginning
after December&nbsp;15, 2005. The adoption of SFAS&nbsp;154 is
not expected to have a material effect on the results of
operations of AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>3.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Change in Accounting Policy for Maintenance Costs</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA historically recorded the cost of major scheduled airframe,
engine and certain component overhauls as capitalized assets
that were subsequently amortized over the periods benefited
(referred to as the deferral method). US&nbsp;Airways Group
charges maintenance and repair costs for owned and leased flight
equipment to operating expense as incurred (direct expense
method). During the fourth quarter of 2005, AWA changed its
accounting policy from the deferral method to the direct expense
method. While the deferral method is permitted under accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States of America,
AWA believes that the direct expense method is preferable
because the direct expense method is the predominant method used
in the airline industry and because it eliminates significant
judgment and estimation inherent under the deferral method.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The effect of this change in accounting for aircraft maintenance
and repairs is recorded as a cumulative effect of a change in
accounting principle. The effect of the change in 2005 was to
increase net loss by approximately $48&nbsp;million. The
increase in the 2005&nbsp;net loss of $202&nbsp;million is the
cumulative effect on retained earnings of the adoption as of
January&nbsp;1, 2005. The cumulative effect of the change in
accounting principle is not presented net of tax as any tax
effects resulting from the change have been immediately offset
by the recording of a valuation allowance through the same
financial statement caption.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 2005 quarterly financial data presented in Note&nbsp;18, has
been adjusted to reflect the change in accounting policy as if
the change occurred on January&nbsp;1, 2005. In addition, pro
forma quarterly financial data for 2004 has been presented to
reflect comparable information as if the newly adopted
accounting policy for maintenance costs had been applied during
all periods affected.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>4.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Change in Method of Reporting for America West Express
    Results and Other Reclassifications</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform
with the 2005 presentation. These reclassifications include
reclassing: fuel hedging activities from nonoperating to
operating expenses, fuel-related tax expenses from other
expenses to aircraft fuel and related taxes expense and the sale
of frequent flier miles and related marketing services to
affinity partners from other operating expense to mainline
passenger and other revenue. The portion of the affinity partner
revenue related to passenger ticket sales is
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">176
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
classified as mainline passenger revenue and the marketing
portion of the affinity partner revenue is classified as other
revenue.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA has a regional airline alliance agreement with Mesa (the
Mesa Agreement) that commenced in February 2001. Mesa, operating
as America West Express, provides feeder service for AWA. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2005, the America West Express fleet included
62 aircraft comprised of 38 86-seat CRJ 900 aircraft, 18 50-seat
CRJ 200 aircraft and six 37-seat Dash 8 turbo prop aircraft. The
Mesa Agreement is anticipated to expire in June 2012.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the Mesa Agreement, Mesa is required to fly the routes and
flights designated by AWA using Mesa&#146;s aircraft, flight
crews and other related services. Mesa maintains and operates
the aircraft; employs, trains, manages and compensates personnel
necessary to provide the flight services; and provides related
passenger handling services for and on the flights. AWA is
responsible for establishing the routes, scheduling Express
flights, pricing of the tickets, marketing and selling the
tickets, collecting all sales amounts, paying all costs of sales
and marketing and taking inventory risk on the inventory of
seats for sale on Mesa. The ground handling of aircraft is
performed by either AWA or Mesa, depending upon the airport.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA collects the revenue and income generated from the services
provided by Mesa pursuant to the Mesa Agreement. In return, AWA:
(i)&nbsp;reimburses Mesa for actual non-controllable costs
incurred by Mesa such as fuel, insurance, taxes, fees and
security; (ii)&nbsp;pays Mesa for actual controllable
non-maintenance costs, subject to a cap, such as aircraft lease
expense and crew expense; (iii)&nbsp;pays Mesa for controllable
maintenance costs at fixed rates (subject to reimbursement of
excess costs if actual costs during the term are less than fixed
amounts paid by AWA); (iv)&nbsp;reimburses Mesa costs and
expenses incurred at stations maintained and operated by Mesa;
and (v)&nbsp;shares with Mesa a percentage of the revenue
allocated to the flight segments flown by Mesa on a pro rata
basis.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
To improve the visibility of Mainline and America West Express
operating results, effective in the first quarter of 2005,
America West Holdings changed its method of accounting for the
Mesa Agreement from the net basis to the gross basis of
presentation. Under the gross basis of presentation, passenger
revenues and operating expenses associated with the Mesa
agreement are reported gross (i.e. in operating revenues as
&#147;Express revenue&#148; and within operating expenses as
&#147;Express expenses&#148;) in the condensed consolidated
statement of operations. Under the net basis of presentation,
America West Express passenger revenues and the associated
operating expenses were netted and classified in operating
revenues in &#147;Other.&#148; Prior period amounts have been
reclassified to be consistent with the 2005 presentation. The
America West Express reclassifications did not impact operating
income or net income for the periods
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">177

presentation for Express revenues and expenses does not include
passenger revenue generated by feed into AWA&#146;s mainline
operations from Express flights, which is referred to as beyond
contribution passenger revenue.
