<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In the third quarter of 2005, in connection with the merger and
    the Airbus MOU executed between Airbus, US&nbsp;Airways Group,
    US&nbsp;Airways and AWA, certain aircraft firm orders were
    restructured. In connection with that restructuring,
    US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West Holdings were required to
    pay non-refundable restructuring fees. AWA&#146;s restructuring
    fee of $50&nbsp;million has been classified as a special charge,
    along with $7&nbsp;million in associated capitalized interest.
    The restructuring fee was paid by means of set-off against
    existing equipment deposits of AWA held by Airbus.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In the third quarter of 2005, a $27&nbsp;million loss was
    incurred related to the sale-leaseback of six
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT> aircraft and
    two 757 aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">179

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 15pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In the fourth quarter of 2005, AWA recorded $13&nbsp;million of
    merger related expenses related to transitioning the employees,
    systems and facilities of AWA and US&nbsp;Airways into one
    consolidated company. The $13&nbsp;million includes insurance
    premiums of $4&nbsp;million related to policies for former
    officers and directors, compensation expense of $3&nbsp;million
    for special stock awards, granted under a program designed to
    retain key employees through the integration period,
    professional and technical fees of $3&nbsp;million and sales and
    marketing program expenses of $2&nbsp;million related to
    notifying frequent traveler program members about the merger.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In the fourth quarter of 2005, in connection with the return of
    certain leased aircraft, AWA incurred expenses of
    $7&nbsp;million related to penalties incurred under the
    outsourced maintenance arrangement.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In the third and fourth quarter of 2005, AWA recorded severance
    expense totaling approximately $2&nbsp;million for terminated
    employees resulting from the merger. The majority of the
    $2&nbsp;million will be paid in the first quarter of 2006.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In August 2004, AWA entered into definitive agreements with two
    lessors to return six Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT> aircraft. Three
    of these aircraft were returned to the lessors in the third
    quarter of 2004, two were returned in the fourth quarter of 2004
    and one was returned in January 2005. In addition, AWA continues
    negotiating with one lessor on the return of its remaining two
    Boeing 737-200 aircraft, one of which was parked in March 2002.
    The other aircraft was removed from service in January 2005. In
    connection with the return of the aircraft, AWA recorded
    $2&nbsp;million of special charges in 2004, which include lease
    termination payments of $2&nbsp;million and the write-down of
    leasehold improvements and aircraft rent balances of
    $3&nbsp;million, offset by the net reversal of lease return
    provisions of $3&nbsp;million. In the first quarter of 2005, AWA
    recorded $1&nbsp;million in special charges related to the final
    Boeing 737-200 aircraft which was removed from service in
    January 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (g)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In the first quarter of 2004, AWA recorded a $1&nbsp;million
    reduction in special charges related to the revision of
    estimated costs associated with the sale and leaseback of
    certain aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (h)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In December 2004, AWA and GE mutually agreed to terminate the
    V2500 <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A-1</FONT> power by hour
    (&#147;PBH&#148;) agreement effective January&nbsp;1, 2005. This
    agreement was entered into March 1998 with an original term of
    ten years. For terminating the agreement early, AWA received a
    $20&nbsp;million credit to be applied to amounts due for other
    engines under the 1998 agreement. AWA had capitalized PBH
    payments for V2500 <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A-1</FONT>
    engines in excess of the unamortized cost of the overhauls
    performed by GE of approximately $4&nbsp;million. With the
    termination of this agreement, these payments were not
    realizable and as a result, AWA wrote off this amount against
    the $20&nbsp;million credit referred to above, resulting in a
    $16&nbsp;million net gain.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (i)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In the first quarter of 2003, AWA recorded a $1&nbsp;million
    reduction in special charges related to the earlier-than-planned
    return of certain leased aircraft in 2001 and 2002, as all
    payments related to these aircraft returns had been made.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (j)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In February 2003, AWA announced the elimination of its hub
    operations in Columbus, Ohio. As a result, 12 regional jets, all
    of which were operated by Chautauqua Airlines under the America
    West Express banner, were phased out of the fleet. In addition,
    the hub was downsized from 49 daily departures to 15
    destinations to four flights per day to Phoenix and Las Vegas.
    Service to New York City La&nbsp;Guardia Airport was also
    eliminated because perimeter rules at the airport prohibit
    flights beyond 1,500&nbsp;miles, precluding service from
    AWA&#146;s hubs in Phoenix and Las Vegas. In the first, second
    and third quarters of 2003, AWA recorded special charges
    totaling $11&nbsp;million related to the costs associated with
    the termination of certain aircraft and facility contracts,
    employee transfer and severance expenses and the write-off of
    leasehold improvements in Columbus, Ohio. All payments were
    completed as of December&nbsp;31, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (k)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In April 2003, as part of a cost reduction program, AWA
    implemented a plan to reduce management, professional and
    administrative payroll costs that resulted in 161 fewer
    employees within these</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">180

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>6.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Stock Options and Awards</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain of AWA&#146;s employees are eligible to participate in
the 2005 Incentive Equity Plan (the &#147;2005 Incentive
Plan&#148;). The 2005 Incentive Plan provides for the grant of
incentive stock options, nonstatutory stock options, stock
appreciation rights, stock purchase awards, stock bonus awards,
stock unit awards, and other forms of equity compensation,
collectively referred to as stock awards, as well as
performance-based cash awards. During 2005, certain of
AWA&#146;s employees received restricted stock units and stock
appreciation rights to be settled in stock under the 2005
Incentive Plan. Compensation expense related to these awards
totaled $3&nbsp;million in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The carrying values of available-for-sale and
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">held-to</FONT>-maturity
securities approximate fair value. There were no unrealized
gains or losses on these investments for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003. Gross proceeds from sales
of available-for-sale securities for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 were $349&nbsp;million,
$589&nbsp;million and $322&nbsp;million, respectively.
Contractual maturities of all
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">181

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">held-to</FONT>-maturity
securities mature in one year or less. Contractual maturities
for available-for-sale securities are greater than 10&nbsp;years
with a reset date approximately every 28&nbsp;days.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA had no long-term investments in debt securities as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and $30&nbsp;million as of
December&nbsp;31, 2004. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, long-term
investments consist of cash invested in certain debt securities
with maturities greater than one year. The debt securities are
classified as held to maturity and are carried at amortized cost
that approximates fair value.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Long-term Debt</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
At December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, the fair value of long-term
debt was approximately $1.04&nbsp;billion and $722&nbsp;million,
respectively. AWA&#146;s variable rate long-term debt with a
carrying value of $911&nbsp;million and $546&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively, approximates fair
value because these borrowings have variable interest rate terms
that approximate market interest rates for similar debt
instruments. The fair value of AWA&#146;s other long-term debt
is determined based on quoted market prices if available or
market prices for comparable debt instruments.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Fuel Price Risk Management</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under its fuel hedging program, AWA may enter into certain
hedging transactions with approved counterparties for a period
generally not exceeding 12&nbsp;months. As of December&nbsp;31,
2005, AWA had entered into costless collar transactions hedging
approximately 20% of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s or 68% of
AWA&#146;s projected 2006 fuel requirements. The fair value of
AWA&#146;s financial derivative instruments was a net asset of
approximately $4&nbsp;million and $0.2&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA is exposed to credit risks in the event any counterparty to
a hedge transaction fails to meet its obligations. AWA does not
anticipate such non-performance as counterparties are selected
based on credit ratings and exposure to any one counterparty is
closely monitored.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>8.</B></TD>
    <TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan backed by a
    $380&nbsp;million federal loan guarantee provided by the ATSB.
    Certain third-party counter-guarantors fully and unconditionally
    guaranteed the payment of an aggregate of $45&nbsp;million of
    the outstanding principal amount under the government guaranteed
    loan plus accrued and unpaid interest thereon. In addition,
    America West Holdings fully and unconditionally guaranteed the
    payment of all principal, premium, interest and other
    obligations outstanding under the government guaranteed loan and
    pledged the stock of AWA to secure its obligations under such
    guarantee. Principal amounts under this loan were scheduled to
    become due in ten installments of $43&nbsp;million on each
    March&nbsp;31 and September&nbsp;30, commencing on
    March&nbsp;31, 2004 and ending on September&nbsp;30, 2008. In
    addition, AWA was charged an annual guarantee fee in respect of
    the ATSB guarantee equal to 8.0% of the guaranteed amount in
    2005. On September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA made a voluntary
    prepayment of $9&nbsp;million in principal, thus reducing the
    remaining semi-annual installments due to $42&nbsp;million.
    Principal amounts outstanding under the government guaranteed
    loan bear interest at a rate per annum equal to LIBOR plus
    40&nbsp;basis points.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with the consummation of the merger, on
    September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA, as borrower, entered into an
    Amended and Restated Loan Agreement (the &#147;AWA ATSB
    Loan&#148;) with the ATSB. The ATSB Loan amended and restated
    the previously outstanding loans of AWA guaranteed in part by
    the ATSB. On October&nbsp;19, 2005, $238&nbsp;million of
    AWA&#146;s ATSB Loan, of which $228&nbsp;million was guaranteed
    by the ATSB, was sold by the lender by order of the ATSB to 13
    fixed income investors. The sale of the debt removed the ATSB
    guaranty. Due to the sale on October&nbsp;19, 2005, the ATSB no
    longer guarantees any portion of the loan and has no interest in
    any of AWA&#146;s debt. As a result of the sale of the loan,
    $11&nbsp;million of the outstanding principal balance remains
    guaranteed by certain third party counter- guarantors. The
    non-guaranteed portion of the loan is no longer subject to
    payment of the annual guarantee fee; rather, as of the date of
    the loan sale, those principal amounts bear interest at a rate
    per annum equal to LIBOR plus 840&nbsp;basis points increasing
    by 5&nbsp;basis points on January 18 of each year, beginning
    January&nbsp;18, 2006 through the end of the loan term, payable
    on a quarterly basis. All other terms associated with this loan
    remain unchanged. As a result of the sale</TD>
</TR>

    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    On September&nbsp;10, 2004, AWA entered into a term loan
    financing with GECC providing for loans in an aggregate amount
    of $111&nbsp;million. AWA used approximately $77&nbsp;million of
    the proceeds from this financing to repay in full its term loan
    with Mizuho Corporate Bank, Ltd. and certain other lenders and
    to pay certain costs associated with this transaction. AWA used
    the remaining proceeds for general corporate purposes. The new
    term loan financing consists of two secured term loan
    facilities: a $76&nbsp;million term loan facility secured
    primarily by spare parts, rotables and appliances (the
    &#147;Spare Parts Facility&#148;); and a $35&nbsp;million term
    loan facility secured primarily by aircraft engines and parts
    installed in such engines (the &#147;Engine Facility&#148;).</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The facilities are cross-collateralized on a subordinated basis,
    and the collateral securing the facilities also secures on a
    subordinated basis certain of AWA&#146;s other existing debt and
    lease obligations to GECC and its affiliates.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The loans under the Spare Parts Facility are payable in full at
    maturity on September&nbsp;10, 2010. The loans under the Engine
    Facility are payable in equal quarterly installments of
    approximately $1&nbsp;million beginning on March&nbsp;10, 2006
    through June 10 2010, with the remaining loan amount of
    $12&nbsp;million payable at maturity on September&nbsp;10, 2010.
    The loans under each facility may be prepaid in an amount not
    less than $5&nbsp;million at any time after the
    30th&nbsp;monthly anniversary of the funding date under such
    facility. If AWA fails to maintain a certain ratio of rotables
    to loans under the Spare Parts Facility, it may be required to
    pledge additional rotables or cash as collateral, provide a
    letter of credit or prepay some or all of the loans under the
    Spare Parts Facility. In addition, the loans under the Engine
    Facility are subject to mandatory prepayment upon the occurrence
    of certain events of loss applicable to, or certain dispositions
    of, aircraft engines securing the facility. Principal amounts
    outstanding under the loans bear interest at a rate per annum
    based on three-month LIBOR plus a margin. Both facilities
    contain customary events of default, including payment defaults,
    cross-defaults, breach of covenants, bankruptcy and insolvency
    defaults and judgment defaults.</TD>
</TR>

    On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA entered into

    Airbus loans are drawn first upon the Airbus $161&nbsp;million
    loan until it has been drawn in its full amount, in which event
    the remaining portion of the $250&nbsp;million total commitment
    is drawn upon the Airbus $89&nbsp;million loan.</TD>

    $186&nbsp;million was drawn under the Airbus loans. The
    remaining portion of the Airbus loans is payable in multiple
    draws upon the occurrence of certain conditions, including the
    taking of delivery of certain aircraft, on the due dates for
    certain amounts owing to AFS or its affiliates to refinance such
    amounts, after payment of certain invoices for goods and
    services provided by AFS or its affiliates, or upon receipt by
    AFS of certain amounts payable in respect of existing aircraft
    financing transactions. The full amount of the Airbus loans is
    expected to be available by the end of 2006. US&nbsp;Airways and
    AWA are jointly and severally liable for the Airbus loans;
    accordingly, the full amount outstanding under the loans is
    reflected in the financial statements of US&nbsp;Airways and AWA.</TD>

    Beginning January&nbsp;18, 2005, these notes are convertible
    into shares of common stock of US&nbsp;Airways Group, at the
    option of the holders, at an initial conversion price of
    $29.09&nbsp;per share or a conversion ratio of approximately
    34.376&nbsp;shares per $1,000 principal amount of such notes,
    subject to standard anti-dilution adjustments. Interest on the
    7.5%&nbsp;convertible senior notes is payable semiannually in
    arrears on June&nbsp;1 and December&nbsp;1 of each year. At
    America West Holdings&#146; option, the first six interest
    payments were payable in the form of a deemed loan added to the
    principal amount of these notes. The 7.5%&nbsp;convertible
    senior notes will mature on January&nbsp;18, 2009 unless earlier
    converted or redeemed. The payment of principal, premium and
    interest on the 7.5%&nbsp;convertible senior notes is fully and
    unconditionally guaranteed by AWA and US&nbsp;Airways Group. For
    financial reporting purposes, America West Holdings recorded the
    convertible senior notes at their fair market value on the date
    of issuance. The balance at December&nbsp;31, 2005 is net of an
    unamortized discount of $18&nbsp;million.</TD>

    <TD valign="top">
    In July and August of 2003, AWA completed a private placement of
    approximately $87&nbsp;million issue price of 7.25%&nbsp;Senior
    Exchangeable Notes due 2023. The notes bore cash interest at a
    rate of 2.49%&nbsp;per year, and were redeemable or exchangeable
    under certain conditions. Completion of the merger between
    US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West Holdings on
    September&nbsp;27, 2005 constituted a &#147;change of
    control&#148; under these notes and required AWA to make an
    offer to holders to purchase those notes within 30 business days
    after the effective time of the merger at a purchase price of
    $343.61&nbsp;per $1,000 principal amount at maturity. Under the
    terms of the notes and the related Guarantee and Exchange
    Agreement, dated as of July&nbsp;30, 2003, between America West
    Holdings and U.S.&nbsp;Bank National Association, as Trustee, as
    supplemented by the Guarantee and Exchange Agreement Supplement
    No.&nbsp;1 among America West Holdings, US&nbsp;Airways Group
    and the Trustee, dated as of September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA&#146;s
    obligation to purchase the notes was satisfied at
    US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s election by delivery of shares of
    US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock having a &#147;fair market
    value&#148; of not less than $343.61&nbsp;per $1,000 principal
    amount at maturity. For this purpose, &#147;fair market
    value&#148; means 95% of the market price of US&nbsp;Airways
    Group common stock calculated as the average closing prices over
    the five business days ending on and including the third
    business day before the purchase date.</TD>

    October 1. The bonds are subject to optional redemption prior to
    the maturity date on or after April&nbsp;1, 2008, in whole or in
    part, on any interest payment date at the following redemption
    prices: 102% on April&nbsp;1 or October&nbsp;1, 2008; 101% on
    April&nbsp;1 or October&nbsp;1, 2009; and 100% on April&nbsp;1,
    2010 and thereafter.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (i)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with the merger, AWA, US&nbsp;Airways Group and
    Juniper Bank, a subsidiary of Barclays PLC (Juniper), entered
    into an agreement on August&nbsp;8, 2005 amending AWA&#146;s
    co-branded credit card agreement with Juniper, dated
    January&nbsp;25, 2005. Pursuant to the amended credit card
    agreement, Juniper agreed to offer and market an airline mileage
    award credit card program to the general public to participate
    in US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s Dividend Miles program through
    the use of a co-branded credit card.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s credit card program is currently
    administered by Bank of America, N.A. (USA). On
    December&nbsp;28, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways issued a notice of
    termination under its agreement with Bank of America and that
    notice will become effective on December&nbsp;28, 2007. Pending
    termination of the Bank of America agreement, both Juniper and
    Bank of America will run separate credit card programs for
    US&nbsp;Airways Group. The amended credit card agreement is the
    subject of pending litigation filed by Bank of America against
    US&nbsp;Airways Group, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA (See
    Note&nbsp;9(e)).</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The amended credit card agreement took effect at the effective
    time of the merger. The credit card services provided by Juniper
    under the amended credit card agreement began in January 2006,
    and will continue until the expiration date, which is the later
    of December&nbsp;31, 2012 or seven years from the date on which
    Juniper commences marketing to the general public.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Under the amended credit card agreement, Juniper will pay to
    US&nbsp;Airways Group fees for each mile awarded to each credit
    card account administered by Juniper, subject to certain
    exceptions. Pursuant to the original credit card agreement,
    Juniper paid to AWA a bonus of $20&nbsp;million. Juniper also
    agreed to pay a one-time bonus payment of $130&nbsp;million,
    following the effectiveness of the merger, subject to certain
    conditions. The $130&nbsp;million bonus payment was made to AWA
    on October&nbsp;3, 2005. The entire $150&nbsp;million balance
    for bonus payments are included in &#147;Deferred gains and
    other liabilities&#148; in the accompanying consolidated balance
    sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2005. US&nbsp;Airways Group will
    not recognize any revenue from the bonus payments until the dual
    branding period has expired, approximately February 2008. At
    that time the Company expects to begin recognizing revenue from
    the bonus payments on a straight-line basis through December
    2012, the expiration date of the Juniper agreement. Further, if
    Juniper is not granted exclusivity to offer a co-branded credit
    card after the dual branding period, US&nbsp;Airways Group must
    repay the bonus payments and repurchase unused pre-paid miles
    with interest, plus $50&nbsp;million in liquidated damages.
    Juniper will pay an annual bonus of $5&nbsp;million to
    US&nbsp;Airways Group, subject to certain exceptions, for each
    year after Juniper becomes the exclusive issuer of the
    co-branded credit card.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    On October&nbsp;3, 2005, Juniper pre-paid for miles from
    US&nbsp;Airways Group totaling $325&nbsp;million, subject to the
    same conditions as apply to the $130&nbsp;million bonus payment.
    To the extent that these miles are not used by Juniper as
    allowed under the co-branded credit card program in certain
    circumstances, US&nbsp;Airways Group will repurchase these miles
    in 12 equal quarterly installments beginning on the fifth year
    prior to the expiration date of the co-branded credit card
    agreement with Juniper, until paid in full. US&nbsp;Airways
    Group makes monthly interest payments at LIBOR plus 4.75% to
    Juniper, beginning on November&nbsp;1, 2005, based on the amount
    of pre-purchased miles that have not been used</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain of AWA&#146;s long-term debt agreements contain minimum
cash balance requirements and other covenants with which AWA is
in compliance at December&nbsp;31, 2005. Certain of these
covenants restrict AWA&#146;s ability to pay cash dividends on
its common stock and make certain other restricted payments (as
specified therein). Finally, AWA&#146;s long-term debt
agreements contain cross-default provisions, which may be
triggered by defaults by AWA under other agreements relating to
indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>9.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Commitments and Contingencies</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Leases</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, AWA had 141 aircraft under
operating leases, excluding two aircraft that will be delivered
in 2006, with remaining terms ranging from one month to
approximately 19&nbsp;years. As discussed in Note&nbsp;8, in
January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a
$380&nbsp;million government loan guarantee that resulted in a
restructuring of its aircraft lease commitments. Under the
restructured lease agreements, annual rent payments have been
reduced through January 2007. Certain of these leases contain
put options pursuant to which the lessors could require AWA to
renew the leases for periods ranging from eight months to
approximately nine years or call options pursuant to which the
lessors could require AWA to return the aircraft to the lessors
upon receipt of six to nine months advance written notice. AWA
also has options to purchase certain of the aircraft at fair
market values at the end of the lease terms. Certain of the
agreements require security deposits, minimum return provisions
and supplemental rent payments.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Since AWA&#146;s restructuring in 1994, AWA has set up 19 pass
through trusts, which have issued over $1.4&nbsp;billion of pass
through trust certificates (also known as &#147;Enhanced
Equipment Trust&nbsp;Certificates&#148; or &#147;EETCs&#148;)
covering the financing of 54 aircraft. These trusts are
off-balance sheet entities, the primary purpose of which is to
finance the acquisition of aircraft. Rather than finance each
aircraft separately when
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">188

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
such aircraft is purchased or delivered, these trusts allow AWA
to raise the financing for several aircraft at one time and
place such funds in escrow pending the purchase or delivery of
the relevant aircraft. The trusts are also structured to provide
for certain credit enhancements, such as liquidity facilities to
cover certain interest payments, that reduce the risks to the
purchasers of the trust certificates and, as a result, reduce
the cost of aircraft financings to AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Each trust covered a set amount of aircraft scheduled to be
delivered within a specific period of time. At the time of each
covered aircraft financing, the relevant trust used the funds in
escrow to purchase equipment notes relating to the financed
aircraft. The equipment notes were issued, at AWA&#146;s
election, either by AWA in connection with a mortgage financing
of the aircraft or by a separate owner trust in connection with
a leveraged lease financing of the aircraft. In the case of a
leveraged lease financing, the owner trust then leased the
aircraft to AWA. In both cases, the equipment notes are secured
by a security interest in the aircraft. The pass through trust
certificates are not direct obligations of, nor are they
guaranteed by AWA. However, in the case of mortgage financings,
the equipment notes issued to the trusts are direct obligations
of AWA and in the case of leveraged lease financings, the leases
are direct obligations of AWA. In addition, AWA does not
guarantee or participate in any way in the residual value of the
leased aircraft. All aircraft financed by these trusts are
currently structured as leveraged lease financings, which are
not reflected as debt on the balance sheet of AWA. AWA does not
provide residual value guarantees under these lease
arrangements. Each lease contains a purchase option that allows
AWA to purchase the aircraft at a fixed price, which at the
inception of the lease approximated the aircraft&#146;s expected
fair market value at the option date, near the end of the lease
term. These leasing entities meet the criteria for variable
interest entities. However, they do not meet the consolidation
criteria under FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46,
&#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; because
AWA is not the primary beneficiary under these arrangements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In May 2005, one aircraft lessor exercised its put rights under
the aircraft lease agreement to extend the leases on two Boeing
737-300 aircraft for an additional 14 and 15&nbsp;months,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In July 2005, one aircraft lessor exercised its put rights under
the aircraft lease agreement to extend the lease on one Boeing
737-300 aircraft for an additional 14&nbsp;months.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In November 2005, one aircraft lessor exercised its put rights
under the aircraft lease agreements to extend the lease terms on
to Boeing&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT>
aircraft for an additional&nbsp;10 and 14&nbsp;months,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA also leases certain terminal space, ground facilities and
computer and other equipment under noncancelable operating
leases.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

rental payments under noncancelable operating leases with
initial terms of more than one year are as follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Collectively, the operating lease agreements require security
deposits with lessors of $36&nbsp;million, which have been
classified as &#147;Other Assets, Net&#148; in the accompanying
balance sheets, and bank letters of credit of $33&nbsp;million.
The letters of credit are collateralized by $33&nbsp;million of
restricted cash.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Revenue Bonds</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In June 1999, Series&nbsp;1999 special facility revenue bonds
(&#147;new bonds&#148;) were issued by a municipality to fund
the retirement of the Series&nbsp;1994A bonds (&#147;old
bonds&#148;) and the construction of a new concourse with 14
gates at Terminal 4 in Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport
in support of AWA&#146;s strategic growth plan. The new bonds
are due June 2019 with interest accruing at 6.25%&nbsp;per annum
payable semiannually on June&nbsp;1 and December&nbsp;1,
commencing on December&nbsp;1, 1999. The new bonds are subject
to optional redemption prior to the maturity date on or after
June&nbsp;1, 2009 in whole or in part, on any interest payment
date at the following redemption prices: 101% on June&nbsp;1 or
December&nbsp;1, 2009; 100.5% on June&nbsp;1 or December&nbsp;1,
2010; and 100% on June&nbsp;1, 2011 and thereafter. In
accordance with EITF Issue No.&nbsp;97-10, &#147;The Effect of
Lessee Involvement in Asset Construction,&#148; AWA accounts for
its payments under this financing facility as an operating lease.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the new bonds, AWA entered into an Amended
and Restated Airport Use Agreement, pursuant to which AWA agreed
to make sufficient payments to the Phoenix Industrial
Development Authority (&#147;IDA&#148;) to cover the principal
and interest of the bonds and to indemnify the IDA for any
claims arising out of the issuance and sale of the bonds and the
use and occupancy of the concourses financed by the new bonds
and the old bonds. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the outstanding
principal amount of the bonds was $22&nbsp;million. AWA
estimates its remaining payments to cover the principal and
interest of these bonds will be approximately $40&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In addition, AWA is also the lessee under certain long-term
leases at various airports. At certain of these airports,
municipalities have issued revenue bonds to improve airport
facilities that are leased by AWA and accounted for as operating
leases. AWA does not guarantee the underlying debt related to
these operating leases.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Commitments to purchase flight equipment and maintenance
    services</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Airbus Purchase Commitments</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group,
US&nbsp;Airways and AWA entered into an Airbus A350 Purchase
Agreement with Airbus. This agreement provides for the delivery
of 20 A350 aircraft during the period 2011 through 2014. The
agreement contains terms and conditions with respect to aircraft
price, escalation, payment terms and pre-delivery payments,
inspection and certification, technical acceptance, excusable
and inexcusable delays, warranties and service life policy,
patent and copyright indemnity, technical data and training
aids, training, supplier product support, indemnities and
insurance, assignments and transfers, and termination events.
Airbus also agreed to provide backstop financing with respect to
a substantial number of these A350 aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group entered into
Amendment&nbsp;16 to the A319/ A320/ A321 Purchase Agreement
dated as of October&nbsp;31, 1997 among US&nbsp;Airways Group
and AVSA, S.A.R.L. The amendment provides for the rescheduling
of 19 firm order A320-family aircraft for delivery during the
period 2009 and 2010. The amendment also modifies other
provisions of the Purchase Agreement relating to the deletion of
certain aircraft cancellation rights and the rescheduling of
aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group entered into
Amendment&nbsp;10 to the A330/340 Purchase Agreement dated as of
November&nbsp;24, 1998 among US&nbsp;Airways Group and AVSA,
S.A.R.L. The amendment provides for the rescheduling of ten firm
order <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A330-200</FONT> aircraft
for delivery during the period 2009 and 2010 and allows for
cancellation in the event that US&nbsp;Airways takes certain
deliveries under the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">190

<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
A350 Purchase Agreement described above. Other provisions of the
Purchase Agreement which have been modified by the amendment
relate to the application of existing pre-delivery payments,
adjustments to various cancellation rights and the cancellation
of the right for additional A330 aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA entered into Amendment
No.&nbsp;9 and Amendment No.&nbsp;10 to the Airbus A320/A319
Purchase Agreement dated as of September&nbsp;12, 1997 between
AWA and AVSA, S.A.R.L. Amendment No.&nbsp;9 provides for the

delivery during 2009. Amendment No.&nbsp;10 sets forth
provisions for restructuring fees and adjustments to escalation
provisions and added purchase rights for aircraft.
</DIV>

    <TD>
    <I>Engine Purchase Commitments</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In August 2004, AWA amended its aircraft purchase contract with
AVSA S.A.R.L., an affiliate of Airbus, to acquire 22&nbsp;Airbus
A320 family aircraft (thirteen A320s and nine A319s), all
powered by V2500 engines from International Aero Engines. Of the
22&nbsp;aircraft, 18 will be purchased directly from the
manufacturer and four have been leased under noncancelable
leases from various lessors on aircraft delivered in 2005. In
the context of this incremental order, AWA also secured
extensive flexibility from Airbus with respect to its existing
A318 order, allowing AWA to better react to market conditions by
enabling it to amend its 15 A318 delivery positions to A319s and
A320s, if it so desires, or to take no additional aircraft under
certain conditions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA has an agreement with International Aero Engines
(&#147;IAE&#148;) which provides for the purchase by AWA of five
new <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">V2500-A5</FONT> spare
engines scheduled for delivery through 2007 for use on certain
of the Airbus&nbsp;A320 fleet. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the
five engines have an estimated gross cost of $34&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, in connection with the merger, AWA
amended its A320 family aircraft purchase contract with AVSA, to
reschedule 11 aircraft deliveries from 2006 and 2007 to 2009. As
a result, AWA has the contractual right to reschedule the IAE
spare engine deliveries referred to above.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

the restructured aircraft purchase agreement with AVSA and the

equipment (in millions).

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the merger, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA
restructured their rate per engine hour agreements with General
Electric Engine Services for overhaul maintenance services.
Under the restructured agreements, the minimum monthly payment
on account of accrued engine flight hours for both the
US&nbsp;Airways and AWA agreements together will equal
$3&nbsp;million as long as both agreements remain in effect or
through October 2009.
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">

<DIV style="margin-top: 24pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(d)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Sale-Leaseback Transactions</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During 2005, AWA completed fifteen separate aircraft
sale-leaseback transactions and two separate aircraft engine
sale-leaseback transactions. The resulting leases have been
accounted for as operating leases.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the first and second quarter of 2005, AWA completed two of
the fifteen aircraft sale-leaseback transactions resulting in
losses of $4&nbsp;million and $4&nbsp;million, respectively.
These amounts were recorded in &#147;Other Operating
Expenses.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the third quarter of 2005, a $27&nbsp;million loss was
incurred related to the sale-leaseback of six 737-300 aircraft
and two 757 aircraft. The loss was recorded as a special charge.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the fourth quarter of 2005, AWA completed the remaining five
aircraft sale-leaseback transactions, involving three
Airbus&nbsp;A319 aircraft and two Airbus&nbsp;A320 aircraft.
These transactions resulted in a combined gain of
$1&nbsp;million that has been deferred and will be amortized to
&#147;Aircraft Rent Expense&#148; over the lease term of twelve
years.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the second quarter of 2005, AWA completed two separate
sale-leaseback transactions both on V2524-A5 engines resulting
in a combined gain of $3&nbsp;million that has been deferred and
will be amortized to &#147;Engine Rent Expense&#148; over the
lease term of seven years.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(e)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Legal Proceedings</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;12, 2005, Bank of America, N.A., which is the
issuing bank of the US&nbsp;Airways frequent flier program
credit card and also acts as the processing bank for most
airline ticket purchases paid for with credit cards, filed suit
in the Delaware Chancery Court in New Castle County, against
US&nbsp;Airways, US&nbsp;Airways Group and AWA, alleging that
US&nbsp;Airways breached its frequent flier credit card contract
with Bank of America by entering into a similar, competing
agreement with Juniper and allowing Juniper to issue a
US&nbsp;Airways frequent flier credit card. Bank of America also
alleges that US&nbsp;Airways Group and AWA induced these
breaches. Bank of America seeks an order requiring
US&nbsp;Airways to market the Bank of America card and prohibit
Juniper from issuing a US&nbsp;Airways credit card, as well as
unspecified damages. On October&nbsp;27, 2005, Juniper, which
was not originally a party to the lawsuit, sought and later
received court permission to intervene as a defendant in the
case and has made counterclaims against Bank of America. Juniper
seeks an order declaring the validity of its new agreement to
issue a US&nbsp;Airways frequent flier credit card. On
November&nbsp;3, 2005, Bank of America filed a motion for
partial summary judgment on the breach of contract claim against
US&nbsp;Airways. After a series of procedural steps, Bank of
America&#146;s motion, along with a cross-motion for summary
judgment filed by Juniper, was heard in the Bankruptcy Court,
where the case is now pending as an adversary proceeding. On
January&nbsp;30, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court ruled that Bank of
America is equitably estopped from pursuing its claims that
US&nbsp;Airways breached its agreement with Bank of America by
negotiating and entering into the agreement with Juniper. Bank
of America is seeking appeal of that ruling while it continues
to pursue its claim that US Airways failed to fulfill
contractual marketing obligations to Bank of America. The
resolution of the final two claims that Bank of America made in
the lawsuit, which are (i)&nbsp;that AWA tortiously interfered
with the contractual relationship between US Airways and Bank of
America and (ii)&nbsp;that US Airways Group and AWA tortiously
interfered with Bank of America&#146;s right to future economic
benefit under its agreement with US Airways, are dependent on
the outcome of the pending appeal. Bank of America will pursue
those two claims only if its appeal of the January&nbsp;30, 2006
order is successful.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;7, 2005, 240 pilots employed by the MidAtlantic
division of US&nbsp;Airways filed a complaint in the federal
district court for the Eastern District of New York against
ALPA, US&nbsp;Airways, US&nbsp;Airways Group, Republic Airways
Holdings, Inc., Wexford Capital LLC and AWA, alleging that
defendants conspired to deceive plaintiffs into believing that
MidAtlantic was a separate entity from
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">192

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
US&nbsp;Airways in order to deprive them of the benefits they
are due as US&nbsp;Airways pilots pursuant to the
US&nbsp;Airways collective bargaining agreement.
Plaintiffs&#146; claims against the airline defendants include
breach of collective bargaining agreement, violation of the
Railway Labor Act and racketeering under the Racketeering
Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (&#147;RICO&#148;).
Plaintiffs&#146; complaint requests $2&nbsp;billion in damages
from the airline defendants and injunctive relief.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA is unable to estimate at this time the amount of loss or
probable losses, if any, that might result from an adverse
resolution of the proceedings discussed above, and currently is
unable to predict whether the outcome of these proceedings will
have a material adverse effect on its results of operations or
financial condition. AWA intends, however, to vigorously pursue
all available defenses and claims in these matters.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA is party to various legal proceedings, including some
purporting to be class action suits, and some that demand large
monetary damages or other relief, which, if granted, would
require significant expenditures. In certain cases where it is
probable that the outcome will result in monetary damages, AWA
will consider all available information and record an accrual.
For those cases where a range of loss is probable but no amount
within the range is a better estimate than any other amount, AWA
will record an accrual at the low end of the range.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(f)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>General Guarantees and Indemnifications</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA is the lessee under many aircraft financing agreements
(including leveraged lease financings of aircraft under the pass
through trusts) and real estate leases. It is common in such
transactions for AWA as the lessee to agree to indemnify the
lessor and other related third parties for the manufacture,
design, ownership, financing, use, operation and maintenance of
the aircraft, and for tort liabilities that arise out of or
relate to AWA&#146;s use or occupancy of the leased asset. In
some cases, this indemnity extends to related liabilities
arising from the negligence of the indemnified parties, but
usually excludes any liabilities caused by their gross
negligence or willful misconduct. Additionally, in the case of
real estate leases, AWA typically indemnifies such parties for
any environmental liability that arises out of or relates to
AWA&#146;s use of the leased premises. AWA expects that it would
be covered by insurance (subject to deductibles) for most tort
liabilities and related indemnities described above with respect
to leased real estate and operated aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes
are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally
and on a senior unsecured basis, by US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
two major operating subsidiaries, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(g)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Concentration of credit risk</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA does not believe it is subject to any significant
concentration of credit risk. Most of AWA&#146;s receivables
result from tickets sold to individual passengers through the
use of major credit cards or from tickets sold by other airlines
and used by passengers on AWA. These receivables are short-term,
generally being settled shortly after the sale.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>10.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Income Taxes</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA is a wholly owned subsidiary of America West Holdings. AWA
is included in America West Holdings&#146; consolidated income
tax returns for the periods ending December&nbsp;31, 2004 and
for the period beginning January&nbsp;1, 2005 ending on
September&nbsp;27, 2005. On September&nbsp;27, 2005,
US&nbsp;Airways Group consummated the transactions contemplated
by its plan of reorganization, including the merger transaction
with America West Holdings. As a result of the merger, America
West Holdings became a wholly owned subsidiary of
US&nbsp;Airways Group. America West Holdings and AWA, as part of
the merger, became
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">193

members of the consolidated US&nbsp;Airways Group on
September&nbsp;28, 2005. Income tax expense in the accompanying
statements of operations has been determined on a separate
company basis.

years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 were
insignificant to the financial statements.

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, AWA has available net operating
loss carryforwards (&#147;NOLs&#148;) and tax credit
carryforwards for federal income tax purposes of approximately
$582&nbsp;million and $1&nbsp;million, respectively. The NOLs
expire during the years 2020 through 2026. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2005, AWA also had capital loss carryforwards
for federal income tax purposes of approximately $1&nbsp;million
which expire in 2008. As a result of a statutory &#147;ownership
change&#148; (as defined for purposes of Section&nbsp;382 of the
Internal Revenue Code) that occurred as a result of America West
Holdings&#146;s merger with US&nbsp;Airways Group on
September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA&#146;s ability to utilize its
regular and AMT NOLs and tax credit carryforwards may be
restricted.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA and the IRS favorably reached an agreement to carryforward
all pre-1994 NOLs that were restricted, as a result of a
statutory &#147;ownership change&#148; (as defined for purposes
of Section&nbsp;382 of the Internal Revenue Code) that occurred
as a result of AWA&#146;s reorganization in 1994.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The settlement with the IRS allowed AWA to utilize all
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">pre-1994</FONT> NOLs of
$546&nbsp;million in total by the end of tax year 1999, as well
$36&nbsp;million of the 1994 NOL. The balance of the 1994 NOL of
$9&nbsp;million and the 1996 NOL of $5&nbsp;million were used in
total during the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2000. The
remaining December&nbsp;31, 2000 taxable income was reduced by
2001 NOL carry back of $27&nbsp;million. After the settlement,
the balance of the NOL carryforward into December&nbsp;31, 2003
is $337&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">194

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

differences between the carrying amounts of assets and
liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts
used for income tax purposes. As of December&nbsp;31, the
significant components of AWA&#146;s deferred tax assets and
liabilities are a result of the temporary differences related to
the items described as follows (in millions):

    Less valuation allowance</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>(284</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" nowrap>)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>(127</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" nowrap>)</TD>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff">
    <TD colspan="3" align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left: 10px; text-indent: -10px">
    Net deferred liability</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>&#151;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>&#151;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;109, &#147;Accounting for Income Taxes,&#148;
(&#147;SFAS&nbsp;109&#148;) requires that a valuation allowance
be established when it is &#147;more likely than not&#148; that
all or a portion of deferred tax assets will not be realized. A
review of all available positive and negative evidence needs to
be considered, including AWA&#146;s performance, the market
environment in which AWA operates, forecasts of future
profitability, the utilization of past tax credits, length of
carryforward periods and similar factors. SFAS&nbsp;109 further
states that it is difficult to conclude that a valuation
allowance is not needed when there is negative evidence such as
cumulative losses in recent years. Therefore, cumulative losses
weigh heavily in the overall assessment.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA was in a cumulative loss position three out of four years
between December&nbsp;31, 2002 through December&nbsp;31, 2005,
which weighed heavily in the overall determination that a
valuation allowance was needed. AWA expects to continue to
record a full valuation allowance on any future tax benefits
until it has achieved several quarters of consecutive profitable
results coupled with an expectation of continued profitability.
As of December 2005 and 2004, the valuation allowance totaled
$284&nbsp;million and $127&nbsp;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>11.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Employee Benefit Plan</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
America West Holdings has a 401(k) defined contribution plan,
covering essentially all employees of AWA. Participants may
contribute from 1 to 50% of their pretax earnings to a maximum
of $14,000 in 2005. AWA&#146;s matching contribution is
determined annually by the Board of Directors. AWA&#146;s
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">195

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
contribution expense to the plan totaled $10&nbsp;million,
$11&nbsp;million and $9&nbsp;million in 2005, 2004 and 2003,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Effective January&nbsp;1, 2005 America West Holdings initiated a
new defined contribution plan covering pilots under the
collective bargaining agreement with the Airline Pilots
Association. Under this plan, AWA is required to make a
non-elective discretionary employer contribution equal to 7% of
each pilot&#146;s compensation (as defined in the plan and
subject to statutory annual maximums). Such contributions are in
addition to the existing AWA company match under the 401(k)
defined contribution plan covering all employees discussed
above. AWA&#146;s contribution expense to this plan totaled
$13&nbsp;million for 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
