<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>12.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Stockholder&#146;s Equity</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Common Stock</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The holder of common stock is entitled to one vote per share on
all matters submitted to a vote of the common shareholder. All
common stock of AWA is held by America West Holdings.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Warrants</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As compensation for various elements of AWA&#146;s financial
restructuring completed in January 2002, America West Holdings
issued a warrant to purchase&nbsp;18.8&nbsp;million shares of
its Class&nbsp;B common stock to the ATSB and additional
warrants to purchase&nbsp;3.8&nbsp;million shares of its
Class&nbsp;B common stock to other loan participants, in each
case at an exercise price of $3&nbsp;per share and a term of ten
years. For accounting purposes, the warrants were valued at
$35&nbsp;million, or $1.57&nbsp;per share, using the
Black-Scholes pricing model with the following assumptions:
expected dividend yield of 0.0%, risk-free interest rate of
4.8%, volatility of 44.9% and an expected life of ten years. The
warrants were recorded by AWA as a non-cash capital contribution
in the consolidated statements of stockholder&#146;s equity and
comprehensive income and classified as &#147;Other Assets,
Net&#148; in the consolidated balance sheet. The warrants were
being amortized over the life of the government guaranteed loan
as an increase to interest expense. In the first quarter of
2004, approximately 220,000 warrants were exercised at
$3&nbsp;per share. In the third quarter of 2003, approximately
2.6&nbsp;million warrants were exercised at $3&nbsp;per share.
These warrant exercises were cashless transactions resulting in
the issuance of approximately 1.6&nbsp;million shares of America
West Holdings&#146; Class&nbsp;B common stock.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the fourth quarter of 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group announced
an agreement to repurchase all of the replacement warrants
issued to the ATSB in connection with the merger with America
West Holdings. US&nbsp;Airways Group repurchased approximately
7.7&nbsp;million warrants to purchase shares of common stock
that had an exercise price of $7.27&nbsp;per share. The total
purchase price for the warrants was $116&nbsp;million, the
estimated fair value of such warrants on the purchase date. In
connection with this repurchase, AWA recorded $8&nbsp;million of
non operating expense. This amount represented the unamortized
balance recorded as an other asset, which was being amortized
over the life of the government guaranteed loan as an increase
to interest expense.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>13.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Advances to Parent Company and Affiliate</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported
by a $380&nbsp;million government loan guarantee, of which
$250&nbsp;million remains outstanding as of December&nbsp;31,
2005. The terms of this loan and AWA&#146;s secured term loan
restrict America West Holdings&#146; and AWA&#146;s ability to
incur additional indebtedness or issue equity unless the
proceeds of those transactions are used to prepay the government
guaranteed loan and the term loan. Accordingly, as a result of
this transaction, AWA&#146;s net advances to America West
Holdings have been classified in &#147;Other Assets&#148; on
AWA&#146;s balance sheet. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, AWA had
net advances to parent company of $261&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">196

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In addition, as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, AWA had a net payable
to affiliate of $443&nbsp;million, which was classified in
&#147;Current Liabilities&#148; on AWA&#146;s condensed balance
sheet. The net payable to affiliate is primarily comprised of a
net payable to US&nbsp;Airways Group and US&nbsp;Airways of
$795&nbsp;million and $601&nbsp;million, respectively, and a net
receivable from US&nbsp;Airways Group and US&nbsp;Airways of
$330&nbsp;million and $621&nbsp;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The net payable to US&nbsp;Airways Group consists of proceeds
received by AWA on behalf of US&nbsp;Airways Group in connection
with the initial equity investments, the public stock offering,
the exercise of options by equity investors, the issuance of
7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes and the Airbus Loans and
amounts payable to US&nbsp;Airways Group related to the
conversion of the 7.25%&nbsp;notes, net of cash retained by
US&nbsp;Airways Group. The net payable to US&nbsp;Airways
primarily consists of operating cash transfers received by AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The net receivable from US&nbsp;Airways Group consists of
payments made on behalf of US&nbsp;Airways Group related to the
repurchase of the warrants issued to the ATSB, merger related
costs and amounts related to the Airbus Loans. The net
receivable from US&nbsp;Airways consists of payments made on
behalf of US&nbsp;Airways to extinguish debt in connection with
the GE Merger MOU, merger related costs and amounts received by
US&nbsp;Airways on behalf of AWA related to the bonus payment
made by Juniper and additional amounts received from Juniper for
prepurchased miles. Payables and receivables among affiliates
are expected to be short-term in duration.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>14.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Nonoperating Income (Expenses)&nbsp;&#151; Other, Net</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the fourth quarter of 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group repurchased
warrants issued to the ATSB. In connection with this repurchase,
AWA recorded $8&nbsp;million of nonoperating expense. This
amount represented the unamortized balance recorded as an other
asset, which was being amortized over the life of the government
guaranteed loan as an increase to interest expense.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the fourth quarter of 2005, AWA wrote off $2&nbsp;million in
issuance costs in connection with the conversion of the 7.25%
exchangeable notes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the term loan refinancing with GECC, AWA
wrote off $1&nbsp;million of debt issue costs associated to the
term loan with Mizuho in 2004. This amount was recorded in
nonoperating expenses.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In April 2003, Congress passed, and the President signed, the
Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act to provide
certain aviation-related assistance. $2.3&nbsp;billion of the
appropriation was for grants by the Transportation Security
Administration to U.S.&nbsp;air carriers based on the
proportional share each carrier had paid or collected as of the
date of enactment of the legislation for passenger security and
air carrier security fees. In May 2003, AWA received
approximately $81&nbsp;million representing its proportional
share of passenger security and air carrier security fees paid
or collected as of April 2003, which has been classified as
&#147;Federal Government Assistance&#148; in the accompanying
statements of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In the fourth quarter of 2003, IAC/ InterActiveCorp completed
its acquisition of Hotwire.com, a discount travel website.
Hotwire was founded by the Texas Pacific Group, American
Airlines, Continental Airlines, Northwest Airlines, United
Airlines, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA in October 2000. AWA had an
ownership interest of approximately 1.5% in Hotwire.com with a
carrying value of approximately $0.03&nbsp;million. Upon closing
of the transaction, AWA received cash of $10&nbsp;million.
Accordingly, AWA recognized a nonoperating gain of
$10&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter of 2003.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">197

    Non-cash transactions:</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>16.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Related Party Transactions</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Robert A. Milton, a member of the board of directors of
US&nbsp;Airways Group, is the Chairman, President and Chief
Executive Officer of ACE. ACE purchased 5,000,000&nbsp;shares of
US&nbsp;Airways Group common stock at a purchase price of
$15.00&nbsp;per share, for a total investment of
$75&nbsp;million. ACE or its subsidiaries entered into
commercial agreements with US&nbsp;Airways Group and America
West Holdings for various services including maintenance and
airport handling. The amount paid in 2005 for these commercial
agreements was approximately $2&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Richard P. Schifter, a member of the board of directors of
US&nbsp;Airways Group, is a partner of Texas Pacific Group,
which was a controlling stockholder of America West Holdings
prior to the completion of the merger. An affiliate of Texas
Pacific Group received $6&nbsp;million as an advisory fee for
providing financial advisory services rendered in connection
with the merger and in contribution for and reimbursement for
certain expenses incurred by Texas Pacific Group and its
affiliates in connection with the merger. In addition, Texas
Pacific Group had agreed to reimburse America West Holdings
approximately $3&nbsp;million for expenses incurred by America
West Holdings in the second half of 2004 on its behalf. The full
amount was reimbursed to America West Holdings in 2005.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">198

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>18.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Quarterly Financial Data (Unaudited)</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The 2005 and 2004 unaudited quarterly financial data has been
adjusted to reflect certain reclassifications. These
reclassifications include reclassing: fuel hedging activities
from nonoperating to operating expenses, the sale of frequent
flier miles and related marketing services to affinity partner
from other operating expenses to operating revenues and Express
expenses from operating revenues to operating expenses. See also
Note&nbsp;4 &#147;Change in Method of Reporting for America West
Express Results and Other Reclassifications.&#148; In addition,
2005 quarterly financial data has been adjusted to reflect the
change in accounting policy for maintenance costs as if the
change occurred on January&nbsp;1, 2005. Pro forma adjustments
have been made to the 2004 quarterly financial data to reflect
comparable information relating to the effect of the change in
accounting policy for maintenance costs. See also Note&nbsp;3
&#147;Change in Accounting Policy for Maintenance Costs.&#148;
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">199

    marketing services to affinity partners from &#147;Other&#148;
    expenses to &#147;Mainline passenger&#148; and &#147;Other&#148;
    revenues. Reflects $5&nbsp;million additional maintenance
    expense, resulting from the accounting policy change from the
    deferral method for maintenance costs to the direct expense
    method.</TD>

    revenues, reclassification of $109&nbsp;million of Express

    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" nowrap>)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>(15</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" nowrap>)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" nowrap>)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>19.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Operating Segments and Related Disclosures</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
AWA is one reportable operating segment. Accordingly, the
segment reporting financial data required by
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;131 is included in the accompanying balance
sheets and statements of operations.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">202

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<A name='115'></A>
</DIV>

<!-- link1 "Item 8C. Financial Statements and Supplementary Data of US Airways, Inc." -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>Item&nbsp;8C.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Financial Statements and Supplementary Data of
    US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Management&#146;s Annual Report on Internal Control over
Financial Reporting</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Management of US&nbsp;Airways is responsible for establishing
and maintaining adequate internal control over financial
reporting as defined in
Rules&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">13a-15(f)</FONT>
and <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">15d-15(f)</FONT> under the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; internal control over financial reporting
is designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the
reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of
financial statements for external purposes in accordance with
generally accepted accounting principles. US&nbsp;Airways&#146;
internal control over financial reporting includes those
policies and procedures that:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable
    detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and
    dispositions of the assets of US&nbsp;Airways;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as
    necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in
    accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and
    that receipts and expenditures of US&nbsp;Airways are being made
    only in accordance with authorizations of management and
    directors of US&nbsp;Airways;&nbsp;and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely
    detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of
    US&nbsp;Airways&#146; assets that could have a material effect
    on the financial statements.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over
financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future
periods are subject to the risk that controls may become
inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree
of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Management assessed the effectiveness of US&nbsp;Airways&#146;
internal control over financial reporting as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005. In making this assessment, management
used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring
Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO)&nbsp;in Internal
Control-Integrated Framework.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Based on our assessment and those criteria, management concludes
that US&nbsp;Airways maintained effective internal control over
financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; independent registered public accounting
firm has issued an audit report on management&#146;s assessment
of US&nbsp;Airways&#146; internal control over financial
reporting. That report has been included herein.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">203
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
The Board of Directors and Stockholder
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We have audited management&#146;s assessment, included in the
accompanying Management&#146;s Annual Report on Internal Control
over Financial Reporting that US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.
(&#147;US&nbsp;Airways&#148; or the &#147;Company&#148;)
maintained effective internal control over financial reporting
as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, based on criteria established in
Internal Control&nbsp;&#151; Integrated Framework issued by the
Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission
(COSO). US&nbsp;Airways&#146; management is responsible for
maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting
and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control
over financial reporting. Our responsibility is to express an
opinion on management&#146;s assessment and an opinion on the
effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over
financial reporting based on our audit.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the
Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those
standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control
over financial reporting was maintained in all material
respects. Our audit included obtaining an understanding of
internal control over financial reporting, evaluating
management&#146;s assessment, testing and evaluating the design
and operating effectiveness of internal control, and performing
such other procedures as we considered necessary in the
circumstances. We believe that our audit provides a reasonable
basis for our opinion.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
A company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting is a
process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the
reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of
financial statements for external purposes in accordance with
generally accepted accounting principles. A company&#146;s
internal control over financial reporting includes those
policies and procedures that (1)&nbsp;pertain to the maintenance
of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly
reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the
company; (2)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance that transactions
are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial
statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting
principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company
are being made only in accordance with authorizations of
management and directors of the company; and (3)&nbsp;provide
reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of
unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the
company&#146;s assets that could have a material effect on the
financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over
financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future
periods are subject to the risk that controls may become
inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree
of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In our opinion, management&#146;s assessment that
US&nbsp;Airways maintained effective internal control over
financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, is fairly
stated, in all material respects, based on criteria established
in Internal Control&nbsp;&#151; Integrated Framework issued by
COSO. Also, in our opinion, US&nbsp;Airways maintained, in all
material respects, effective internal control over financial
reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, based on criteria
established in Internal Control&nbsp;&#151; Integrated Framework
issued by COSO.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">204

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the
Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the
balance sheets of US&nbsp;Airways as of December&nbsp;31, 2005
for the Successor Company and December&nbsp;31, 2004 for the
Predecessor Company, and the related statements of operations,
stockholders&#146; equity (deficit)&nbsp;and cash flows for the
three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 for the Successor
Company, the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, the nine months ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003 for the Predecessor Company and the three
months ended March&nbsp;31, 2003 for the prior Predecessor
Company and our report dated March&nbsp;14, 2006 expressed an
unqualified opinion on those financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 24pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
/s/ KPMG LLP
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
McLean, Virginia
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
March&nbsp;14, 2006
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">205

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
The Board of Directors and Stockholder
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We have audited the accompanying balance sheets of
US&nbsp;Airways, Inc. (US&nbsp;Airways) as of December&nbsp;31,
2005 for the Successor Company and December&nbsp;31, 2004 for
the Predecessor Company, and the related statements of
operations, stockholders&#146; equity (deficit)&nbsp;and cash
flows for the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 for the
Successor Company, the nine months ended September&nbsp;30,
2005, the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, the nine months
ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 for the Predecessor Company and the
three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2003 for the prior Predecessor
Company. These financial statements are the responsibility of
the Company&#146;s management. Our responsibility is to express
an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the
Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those
standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are
free of material misstatement. An audit includes examining, on a
test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in
the financial statements. An audit also includes assessing the
accounting principles used and significant estimates made by
management, as well as evaluating the overall financial
statement presentation. We believe that our audits provide a
reasonable basis for our opinion.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above
present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position
of US&nbsp;Airways as of December&nbsp;31, 2005 for the
Successor Company and December&nbsp;31, 2004 for the Predecessor
Company, and the results of its operations and its cash flows
for the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 for the
Successor Company, the nine months ended September&nbsp;30,
2005, the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, the nine months
ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 for the Predecessor Company and the
three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2003 for the prior Predecessor
Company, in conformity with U.S.&nbsp;generally accepted
accounting principles.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As discussed in Notes&nbsp;1 and 2(b) to the financial
statements, on September&nbsp;16, 2005, the Bankruptcy Court
confirmed the Company&#146;s Plan of Reorganization (the Plan),
related to its second Chapter&nbsp;11 bankruptcy proceeding. The
Plan became effective on September&nbsp;27, 2005 and
US&nbsp;Airways and its parent Company, US&nbsp;Airways Group,
Inc. (US&nbsp;Airways Group), emerged from the second
Chapter&nbsp;11 bankruptcy proceeding. On March&nbsp;31, 2003,
US&nbsp;Airways and US&nbsp;Airways Group emerged from the first
bankruptcy proceeding. In connection with its emergence from the
second and first Chapter&nbsp;11 bankruptcy proceedings,
US&nbsp;Airways adopted fresh-start reporting pursuant to
Statement of
Position&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">90-7,</FONT>
&#147;Financial Reporting by Entities in Reorganization Under
the Bankruptcy Code&#148; as of September&nbsp;27, 2005 and
March&nbsp;31, 2003. In addition, as discussed in Note&nbsp;1,
on September&nbsp;27, 2005, upon emergence from the second
bankruptcy, US&nbsp;Airways Group merged with America West
Holdings Corporation (America West Holdings). Effective with the
merger, the Company conformed its policies with those of America
West Holdings, including the application of the provisions of
Accounting Principles Board Opinion No.&nbsp;25,
&#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees&#148;. As a
result, the financial statements of the Successor Company are
presented on a different basis than those of the Predecessor
Companies and, therefore, are not comparable in all respects. As
discussed in Notes&nbsp;2(m) and 14 to the financial statements,
effective April&nbsp;1, 2003, after emerging from the first
bankruptcy, US&nbsp;Airways changed its method of accounting for
stock-based compensation as described by Statement of Financial
Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;148, &#147;Accounting for
Stock-Based Compensation&nbsp;&#151; Transition and
Disclosure&#148;.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">206
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the
Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the
effectiveness of the US&nbsp;Airways&#146; internal control over
financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, based on
criteria established in &#147;Internal Control-Integrated
Framework&#148; issued by the Committee of Sponsoring
Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO), and our report
dated March&nbsp;14, 2006 expressed an unqualified opinion on
management&#146;s assessment of, and the effective operation of,
internal control over financial reporting.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 24pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
/s/ KPMG LLP
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
McLean, Virginia
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">207

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Statements of Operations</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>(in millions)</B>
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; ">

<TR style="font-size: 1pt;">
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="24%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD><!-- Right VRule -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD><!-- Right VRule -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 8pt;">
    <TD colspan="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap><B>Successor</B></TD><TD></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="16">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 8pt;">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">208

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">211
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>1.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Chapter&nbsp;11 reorganization and merger agreement</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;12, 2004, US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.
(&#147;US&nbsp;Airways&#148;) filed a voluntary petition for
relief under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the United States Bankruptcy
Code (the &#147;Bankruptcy Code&#148;) in the United States
Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of Virginia,
Alexandria Division (the &#147;Bankruptcy Court&#148;) (Case
Nos.&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">04-13819-SSM</FONT>
through <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">04-13823-SSM).</FONT>
On the same day, US&nbsp;Airways Group, Inc.
(&#147;US&nbsp;Airways Group&#148;), US&nbsp;Airways&#146;
parent company, and three of its other subsidiaries
(collectively with US&nbsp;Airways, the &#147;Debtors&#148;)
also filed voluntary petitions for relief under Chapter&nbsp;11
of the Bankruptcy Code. On May&nbsp;19, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways
Group signed a merger agreement with America West Holdings
Corporation (&#147;America West Holdings&#148;) pursuant to
which America West Holdings merged with a wholly owned
subsidiary of US&nbsp;Airways Group upon US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s emergence from bankruptcy on September&nbsp;27,
2005. The Debtors&#146; plan of reorganization was confirmed by
the Bankruptcy Court on September&nbsp;16, 2005 and became
effective on September&nbsp;27, 2005, the same day that the
merger with America West Holdings became effective. As described
in greater detail in Note&nbsp;3(b), while the merger was
structured such that US&nbsp;Airways Group was the legal
acquirer, the merger has been accounted for as a reverse
acquisition such that America West Holdings was treated as the
accounting acquirer.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Critical to US&nbsp;Airways&#146; emergence from bankruptcy and
the merger with America West Holdings was additional financing
and liquidity to fund operations. The financing and liquidity
was provided through a combination of new equity investments in
US&nbsp;Airways Group, new and restructured debt instruments and
agreements with significant stakeholders as described below.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>New equity investments</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; On
September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group received new
equity investments of $565&nbsp;million in the aggregate from
ACE Aviation Holdings Inc. (&#147;ACE&#148;); Par Investment
Partners, L.P. (&#147;Par&#148;); Peninsula Investment Partners,
L.P. (&#147;Peninsula&#148;); a group of investors under the
management of Wellington Management Company, LLP
(&#147;Wellington&#148;); Tudor Proprietary Trading, L.L.C. and
certain investors advised by Tudor Investment Corp.
(&#147;Tudor&#148;); and Eastshore Aviation, LLC
(&#147;Eastshore&#148;). In connection with the equity
investments, each of the equity investors received an option to
purchase additional shares at $15.00&nbsp;per share. Par
purchased the options granted to ACE and Eastshore, and each
option holder exercised the first two-thirds of its option on
September&nbsp;28, 2005, for aggregate proceeds to
US&nbsp;Airways Group of approximately $75&nbsp;million. On
October&nbsp;13, 2005, each of the equity investors exercised
the remaining portion of its option for aggregate proceeds to
US&nbsp;Airways Group of approximately $38&nbsp;million.
Proceeds from these new equity investments, including the option
exercises, totaled approximately $678&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Public stock offering</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; On
September&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group completed a
public offering of common stock in which it issued
9,775,000&nbsp;shares of its common stock at a price of
$19.30&nbsp;per share. The Company received net proceeds of
$180&nbsp;million from the offering.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>GE&nbsp;Merger MOU </I></B>&nbsp;&#151; US&nbsp;Airways
Group and America West Holdings reached a comprehensive
agreement with General Electric Capital Corporation
(&#147;GECC&#148;), and its affiliates as described in the
Master Merger Memorandum of Understanding (the
&#147;GE&nbsp;Merger MOU&#148;). The key aspects of the
GE&nbsp;Merger MOU are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The GE&nbsp;Merger MOU provided for continued use by
    US&nbsp;Airways Group of certain leased Airbus, Boeing and
    regional jet aircraft, the modification of monthly lease rates,
    and the return to GECC of certain other leased Airbus and Boeing
    aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    GECC provided a bridge facility of approximately
    $56&nbsp;million for use by US&nbsp;Airways Group during the
    pendency of the Chapter&nbsp;11 proceedings. US&nbsp;Airways
    paid an affiliate of General Electric (&#147;GE&#148;)
    $125&nbsp;million in cash on September&nbsp;30, 2005 in exchange
    for retirement of the bridge facility, forgiveness and release
    of US&nbsp;Airways from certain prepetition obligations,
    deferral of</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">212

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    certain payment obligations, and amendments to maintenance
    agreements. The payment was funded through the issuance of
    7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes due 2020, as discussed in more
    detail below.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    In June 2005, GECC purchased and immediately leased back to
    US&nbsp;Airways Group: (a)&nbsp;the assets securing the credit
    facility obtained from GE in 2001 (the &#147;2001 GE&nbsp;Credit
    Facility&#148;) and the liquidity facility obtained from GE in
    2003 in connection with US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s emergence
    from the first bankruptcy (the &#147;2003 GE Liquidity
    Facility&#148;), and other GE&nbsp;obligations, consisting of 11
    Airbus aircraft and 28&nbsp;spare engines and engine stands; and
    (b)&nbsp;ten regional jet aircraft previously debt financed by
    GECC. The proceeds from the sale leaseback transaction of
    approximately $633&nbsp;million were used to pay down balances
    due to GE by US&nbsp;Airways Group under the 2003
    GE&nbsp;Liquidity Facility in full, the GECC mortgage-debt
    financed CRJ aircraft in full, and a portion of the 2001
    GE&nbsp;Credit Facility. The 2001 GE&nbsp;Credit Facility was
    amended to allow certain additional borrowings up to
    $28&nbsp;million.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Airbus MOU</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; In connection with the
merger, a Memorandum of Understanding (the &#147;Airbus
MOU&#148;) was executed between AVSA S.A.R.L., an affiliate of
Airbus S.A.S. (&#147;Airbus&#148;), US&nbsp;Airways Group,
US&nbsp;Airways and America West Airlines, Inc.
(&#147;AWA&#148;). The key aspects of the Airbus MOU are as
follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA entered into
    two loan agreements with Airbus Financial Services
    (&#147;AFS&#148;), as Initial Lender and Loan&nbsp;Agent, Wells
    Fargo Bank Northwest, National Association, as Collateral Agent,
    and US&nbsp;Airways Group, as guarantor, with commitments in
    initial aggregate amounts of up to $161&nbsp;million and up to
    $89&nbsp;million (the &#147;Airbus $161&nbsp;Million Loan&#148;
    and the &#147;Airbus $89&nbsp;Million Loan&#148; and,
    collectively, the &#147;Airbus Loans&#148;). The Airbus Loans
    bear interest at a rate of LIBOR plus a margin, subject to
    adjustment. The outstanding principal amount of the Airbus
    $89&nbsp;Million Loan will be forgiven in writing on
    December&nbsp;31, 2010, or an earlier date, if on that date the
    outstanding principal amount of, accrued interest on, and all
    other amounts due under the Airbus $161&nbsp;Million Loan have
    been paid in full.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Airbus has rescheduled US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A320-family</FONT> and
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A330-200</FONT> delivery
    commitments and has agreed to provide backstop financing for a
    substantial number of aircraft, subject to certain terms and
    conditions, on an order of 20 A350 aircraft. US&nbsp;Airways
    Group&#146;s
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A320-family</FONT> aircraft
    are now scheduled for delivery in 2009 and 2010. US&nbsp;Airways
    Group&#146;s <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A330-200</FONT>
    aircraft are scheduled for delivery in 2009 and 2010 and A350
    aircraft deliveries are currently scheduled to occur beginning
    in 2011. The Airbus MOU also eliminates cancellation penalties
    on US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s orders for the ten
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A330-200</FONT> aircraft,
    provided that US&nbsp;Airways Group has met certain predelivery
    payment obligations under the A350&nbsp;order. In connection
    with the restructuring of aircraft firm orders, US&nbsp;Airways
    and America West Holdings were required to pay an aggregate
    non-refundable restructuring fee which was paid by means of
    set-off against existing equipment purchase deposits of
    US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West Holdings held by Airbus.
    US&nbsp;Airways recorded its restructuring fee of
    $39&nbsp;million as a reorganization item in the third quarter
    of 2005. AWA&#146;s restructuring fee was $50&nbsp;million.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Restructuring of the ATSB Loan
Guarantees</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; US&nbsp;Airways Group and America
West Holdings each had loans outstanding guaranteed under the
Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act by the
Air Transportation Stabilization Board (&#147;ATSB&#148; and the
loans, the &#147;ATSB Loans&#148;). In connection with the
September&nbsp;12, 2004 Chapter&nbsp;11 filing, the ATSB and the
lenders under the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan agreed to authorize
US&nbsp;Airways to continue to use cash collateral securing the
US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan on an interim basis (the &#147;Cash
Collateral Agreement&#148;). US&nbsp;Airways reached agreements
with the ATSB concerning interim extensions to the Cash
Collateral Agreement, the last of which was extended to the
earlier of the effective date of the plan of reorganization or
October&nbsp;25, 2005. The Cash Collateral Agreement and
subsequent extensions each required US&nbsp;Airways Group, among
other conditions, to
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">213

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
maintain a weekly minimum unrestricted cash balance which
decreased periodically during the term of the extension.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On July&nbsp;22, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group and America West
Holdings announced that the ATSB approved the proposed merger.
Under the negotiated new loan terms, the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB
Loan is guaranteed by US&nbsp;Airways Group (including all
domestic subsidiaries, with certain limited exceptions) and is
secured by substantially all of the present and future assets of
US&nbsp;Airways Group not otherwise encumbered, other than
certain specified assets, including assets which are subject to
other financing agreements. The AWA ATSB Loan is also guaranteed
by US&nbsp;Airways Group (including all domestic subsidiaries,
with certain limited exceptions) and is secured by a second lien
in the same collateral. The loans continue to have separate
repayment schedules and interest rates; however, the loans are
subject to similar repayments and mandatory amortization in the
event of additional debt issuances, with certain limited
exceptions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;19, 2005, $539&nbsp;million of the
US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan, of which $525&nbsp;million was
guaranteed by the ATSB, was sold by the lender by order of the
ATSB to 13&nbsp;fixed income investors. The sale of the debt
removed the ATSB guaranty and the ATSB has no interest in any of
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; debt. Terms associated with this loan
remain unchanged. As a result of the sale of the loan, the
US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan is now referred to as the
US&nbsp;Airways Citibank Loan, and had an outstanding balance of
$551&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2005. See Note&nbsp;6 for
additional information related to the US&nbsp;Airways Citibank
Loan.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>New Convertible Notes</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; On
September&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group issued
$144&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of 7%&nbsp;Senior
Convertible Notes due 2020 (the &#147;7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible
Notes&#148;) for proceeds, net of expenses, of approximately
$139&nbsp;million. The 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes are
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s senior unsecured obligations and
rank equally in right of payment to its other senior unsecured
and unsubordinated indebtedness and are effectively subordinated
to its secured indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets
securing such indebtedness. The 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible Notes
are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally
and on a senior unsecured basis, by US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
two major operating subsidiaries, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. The
guarantees are the guarantors&#146; unsecured obligations and
rank equally in right of payment to the other senior unsecured
and unsubordinated indebtedness of the guarantors and are
effectively subordinated to the guarantors&#146; secured
indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets securing such
indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Restructuring of Affinity Credit Card Partner
Agreement</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; In connection with the merger,
AWA, US&nbsp;Airways Group and Juniper Bank, a subsidiary of
Barclays PLC (&#147;Juniper&#148;), entered into an agreement on
August&nbsp;8, 2005 amending AWA&#146;s
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">co-branded</FONT> credit card
agreement with Juniper, dated January&nbsp;25, 2005. Pursuant to
the amended credit card agreement, Juniper agreed to offer and
market an airline mileage award credit card program to the
general public to participate in US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
Dividend Miles program through the use of a
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">co-branded</FONT> credit card.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s credit card program is currently
administered by Bank of America, N.A. (USA). On
December&nbsp;28, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways issued a notice of
termination under its agreement with Bank of America and that
notice will become effective on December&nbsp;28, 2007. Pending
termination of the Bank of America agreement, both Juniper and
Bank of America will run separate credit card programs for
US&nbsp;Airways Group. The amended credit card agreement is the
subject of pending litigation filed by Bank of America against
US&nbsp;Airways Group, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA. (See also
Note&nbsp;9(d)).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The amended credit card agreement took effect at the effective
time of the merger. The credit card services provided by Juniper
under the amended credit card agreement began in January 2006,
and will continue until the expiration date, which is the later
of December&nbsp;31, 2012 or seven years from the date on which
Juniper commences marketing to the general public.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">214

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the amended credit card agreement, Juniper will pay to
US&nbsp;Airways Group fees for each mile awarded to each credit
card account administered by Juniper, subject to certain
exceptions. Juniper also agreed to pay a one-time bonus payment
of $130&nbsp;million, following the effectiveness of the merger,
subject to certain conditions. The bonus payment was made to AWA
on October&nbsp;3, 2005. If Juniper is not granted exclusivity
to offer a <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">co-branded</FONT>
credit card after the dual branding period with Bank of America,
US&nbsp;Airways Group must repay this bonus payment and
repurchase unused prepaid miles with interest, plus
$50&nbsp;million in liquidated damages. Juniper will pay an
annual bonus of $5&nbsp;million to US&nbsp;Airways Group,
subject to certain exceptions, for each year after Juniper
becomes the exclusive issuer of the
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">co-branded</FONT> credit card.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Juniper pre-purchased miles from US&nbsp;Airways Group for an
aggregate of $325&nbsp;million, subject to the same conditions
as apply to the $130&nbsp;million bonus payment. To the extent
that these miles are not used by Juniper as allowed under the
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">co-branded</FONT> credit card
program in certain circumstances, US&nbsp;Airways Group will
repurchase these miles in 12 equal quarterly installments
beginning on the fifth year prior to the expiration date until
paid in full. US&nbsp;Airways Group makes monthly interest
payments at LIBOR plus&nbsp;4.75% to Juniper, beginning on
November&nbsp;1, 2005, based on the amount of pre-purchased
miles that have not been used by Juniper in connection with the
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">co-branded</FONT> credit card
program and have not been repurchased by US&nbsp;Airways Group.
US&nbsp;Airways Group will be required to repurchase
pre-purchased miles under certain reductions in the collateral
held under the credit card processing agreement with JPMorgan
Chase Bank, N.A. Accordingly, the prepayment has been recorded
as additional indebtedness in the consolidated financial
statements of AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Juniper may, at its option, terminate the amended credit card
agreement, make payments to US&nbsp;Airways Group under the
amended credit card agreement in the form of pre-purchased miles
rather than cash, or commence the repurchase of the
pre-purchased miles before the fifth year prior to the
expiration date in the event that US&nbsp;Airways Group breaches
its obligations under the amended credit card agreement, or upon
the occurrence of certain events.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I>Asset Based Financings and Sales</I></B>&nbsp;&#151; In
addition to the sale-leaseback transactions completed in June
2005 related to the GE&nbsp;Merger MOU described above,
US&nbsp;Airways also executed flight equipment asset sale and
sale-leaseback transactions in the third and fourth quarters of
2005. US&nbsp;Airways received net proceeds of $209&nbsp;million
and a reduction in aircraft related debt of $561&nbsp;million.
Additionally during the third quarter, US&nbsp;Airways received
net proceeds of $51&nbsp;million in connection with an agreement
to sell and leaseback certain of its commuter slots at Ronald
Reagan Washington National Airport and New York LaGuardia
Airport. US&nbsp;Airways was required to use proceeds totaling
$156&nbsp;million to pay down the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
