<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Reflects the discharge or reclassification of estimated
    liabilities subject to compromise. Most of these obligations are
    only entitled to receive such distributions of cash and common
    stock as provided for under the Plan of Reorganization. A
    portion of the estimated liabilities subject to compromise was
    restructured and will continue, as restructured, to be
    liabilities of the Successor Company.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Includes adjustments to reflect assets and liabilities at fair
    value and the write-off of the Predecessor Company&#146;s equity
    accounts.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In conjunction with the merger and application of purchase
    accounting, US&nbsp;Airways adjusted certain balances to conform
    its accounting policies to those of America West Holdings.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Reorganization items, net</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
SOP&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">90-7</FONT> requires
that the financial statements for periods following the
Chapter&nbsp;11 filing through emergence distinguish
transactions and events that are directly associated with the
reorganization from the ongoing operations of the business.
Accordingly, revenues, expenses, realized gains and losses and
provisions for losses directly associated with the
reorganization and restructuring of the business are reported
separately as reorganization items, net in the statements of
operations. Reorganization items, net as shown on the statements
of operations related to the Chapter&nbsp;11 proceedings consist
of the following (in&nbsp;millions):
</DIV>

<CENTER>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>

    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In January 2005, the Bankruptcy Court approved settlement
    agreements between US&nbsp;Airways and its unions and the
    court-appointed Section&nbsp;1114 Committee, representing
    retirees other than those represented by the IAM and TWU, to
    begin the significant curtailment of postretirement medical
    benefits. US&nbsp;Airways recognized a gain of $183&nbsp;million
    in connection with this curtailment in the first quarter of
    2005. Upon the emergence from bankruptcy and effectiveness of
    the Plan of</TD>

    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Reorganization, an additional gain of $1.24&nbsp;billion was
    recognized as the liability associated with the postretirement
    medical benefits was reduced to fair market value. See also
    Note&nbsp;7.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Also in January 2005, US&nbsp;Airways terminated three defined
    benefit plans related to the flight attendants, mechanics and
    certain other employees (see Note&nbsp;7). The PBGC was
    appointed trustee of the plans upon termination. US&nbsp;Airways
    recognized a curtailment gain of $24&nbsp;million and a
    $91&nbsp;million minimum pension liability adjustment in
    connection with the terminations in the first quarter of 2005.
    Upon the effective date of the Plan of Reorganization and in
    connection with the settlement with the PBGC, the remaining
    liabilities associated with these plans were written off, net of
    settlement amounts.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Effective March&nbsp;31, 2003, US&nbsp;Airways terminated its
    qualified and nonqualified pilot defined benefit pension plans.
    The PBGC was appointed trustee of the qualified plan effective
    with the termination. US&nbsp;Airways recognized a gain in
    connection with the termination which is partially offset by the
    estimate of the PBGC claim.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Reflects the discharge of trade accounts payable and other
    liabilities upon emergence from bankruptcy. Most of these
    obligations were only entitled to receive such distributions of
    cash and common stock as provided for under the plan of
    reorganization in each of the bankruptcies. A portion of the
    liabilities subject to compromise in the bankruptcies were
    restructured and continued, as restructured, to be liabilities
    of the Successor Company.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    As a result of US&nbsp;Airways&#146; bankruptcy filing in
    September 2004, US&nbsp;Airways was not able to secure the
    financing necessary to take on-time delivery of three scheduled
    regional jet aircraft and therefore accrued penalties of
    $3&nbsp;million until delivery of these aircraft was made to a
    US&nbsp;Airways Express affiliate in August 2005. Offsetting
    these penalties is the reversal of $33&nbsp;million in penalties
    recorded by US&nbsp;Airways in the nine months ended
    December&nbsp;31, 2003 due to its intention not to take delivery
    of certain aircraft scheduled for future delivery. In connection
    with the Airbus MOU, the accrual for these penalties was
    reversed (see also Notes&nbsp;1 and 4).</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    As the result of US&nbsp;Airways&#146; bankruptcy filing in
    September 2004, it failed to meet the conditions precedent for
    continued financing of regional jets and was not able to take
    delivery of scheduled aircraft and therefore incurred penalties
    of $7&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter of 2004.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Damage and deficiency claims are largely a result of
    US&nbsp;Airways&#146; election to either restructure, abandon or
    reject aircraft debt and leases during the bankruptcy
    proceedings. As a result of the confirmation of the Plan of
    Reorganization and the effectiveness of the merger, these claims
    were withdrawn and the accruals reversed.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways recorded
    $1.5&nbsp;billion of adjustments to reflect assets and
    liabilities at fair value, including an initial net write-down
    of goodwill of $1.82&nbsp;billion. Goodwill of $584&nbsp;million
    was recorded to reflect the excess of the estimated fair value
    of liabilities and equity over identifiable assets. Subsequent
    to September&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways recorded an
    additional $148&nbsp;million of goodwill to reflect adjustments
    to the fair value of certain assets and liabilities. See
    Note&nbsp;3(b) for a description of changes in goodwill during
    the fourth quarter of 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    As of March&nbsp;31, 2003, US&nbsp;Airways recorded
    $1.11&nbsp;billion of adjustments to reflect assets and
    liabilities at fair value (including a $1.12&nbsp;billion
    liability increase related to the revaluation of
    US&nbsp;Airways&#146; remaining defined benefit pension plans
    and postretirement benefit plans and a $333&nbsp;million
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">write-up</FONT> of gates,
    slots and routes) and the write-off of the Predecessor
    Company&#146;s equity accounts. In addition, goodwill of
    $2.41&nbsp;billion was recorded to reflect the excess of the
    estimated fair value of liabilities and equity over identifiable
    assets.</TD>

    decrease to property and equipment, net, a $121&nbsp;million
    decrease to long-term debt, net of current maturities, a
    $13&nbsp;million increase to</TD>

    several of US&nbsp;Airways&#146; labor groups were involuntarily

    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with the Airbus MOU, US&nbsp;Airways was required
    to pay a restructuring fee of $39&nbsp;million, which was paid
    by means of offset against existing equipment deposits held by
    Airbus. US&nbsp;Airways also received credits from Airbus
    totaling $4&nbsp;million in 2005, primarily related to equipment
    deposits. See also Note&nbsp;1.</TD>

    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The GE Merger MOU provided for the continued use of certain
    leased Airbus, Boeing and regional jet aircraft, the
    modification of monthly lease rates and the return of certain
    other leased Airbus and Boeing aircraft. The GE Merger MOU also
    provided for the sale-leaseback of assets securing various GE
    obligations. In connection with these transactions,
    US&nbsp;Airways recorded a net loss of $5&nbsp;million.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD valign="top">

    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with the first bankruptcy, US&nbsp;Airways
    restructured aircraft debt and lease agreements related to 119
    aircraft including the conversion of 52 mortgages to operating
    leases. The restructured terms generally provide for shorter
    lease periods and lower lease rates.</TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(d)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Liabilities subject to compromise</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
SOP&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">90-7</FONT> also
requires that prepetition liabilities subject to compromise
should be distinguished from both prepetition liabilities that
are not subject to compromise and postpetition liabilities.
Liabilities subject to compromise are reported at the amounts
expected to be allowed by the Bankruptcy Court, even if they are
settled for lesser amounts. The following table summarizes the
components of liabilities subject to compromise included in the
balance sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2004 (in millions):
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with the merger with America West Holdings,
    US&nbsp;Airways incurred $15&nbsp;million of transition and
    merger integration costs in the fourth quarter of 2005. These
    items included $7&nbsp;million in insurance premiums related to
    policies for former officers and directors, $5&nbsp;million for
    severance, retention payments and stock awards, $1&nbsp;million
    of aircraft livery costs, $1&nbsp;million of programming service
    expense and $1&nbsp;million in other expenses.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    During the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2003, US&nbsp;Airways
    recorded a $35&nbsp;million charge in connection with its
    intention not to take delivery of certain aircraft scheduled for
    future delivery. In connection with the Airbus MOU,
    $33&nbsp;million of this charge was reversed as a reorganization
    item in 2005 (see Notes&nbsp;1 and 3(c)).</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In September 2001, US&nbsp;Airways announced that in connection
    with its reduced flight schedule it would terminate or furlough
    approximately 11,000 employees across all employee groups.
    Approximately 10,200 of the affected employees were terminated
    or furloughed on or prior to January&nbsp;1, 2002. Substantially
    all the remaining affected employees were terminated or
    furloughed by May 2002. US&nbsp;Airways&#146; headcount
    reduction was largely accomplished through involuntary
    terminations/furloughs. In connection with this headcount
    reduction, US&nbsp;Airways offered a voluntary leave program to
    certain employee groups. Voluntary leave program participants
    generally received extended benefits, such as medical, dental
    and life insurance, but did not receive any furlough pay
    benefit. In accordance with Emerging Issues Task Force Issue
    No.&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">94-3,</FONT>
    US&nbsp;Airways recorded a pretax charge of $75&nbsp;million
    representing the involuntary severance pay and the benefits for
    affected employees during the third quarter of 2001. In the
    fourth quarter of 2001, US&nbsp;Airways recognized a
    $10&nbsp;million charge representing the estimated costs of
    extended benefits for those employees who elected to take
    voluntary leave and a $2&nbsp;million reduction in accruals
    related to the involuntary severance as a result of employees
    electing to accept voluntary furlough. During the quarters ended
    June&nbsp;30, 2003 and 2002, the US&nbsp;Airways recognized
    $1&nbsp;million and $3&nbsp;million, respectively, in reductions
    to severance pay and benefit accruals related to the involuntary
    termination or furlough of certain employees.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Government compensation</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In April 2003, President George W. Bush signed into law the
Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act, which
included $2.4&nbsp;billion for reimbursement to the airlines for
certain aviation-related security expenses. Certain airlines
that received the aviation-related assistance were required to
agree to limit the total cash compensation for certain executive
officers during the
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">12-month</FONT> period
beginning April&nbsp;1, 2003 to an amount equal to the annual
salary paid to that officer during the air carrier&#146;s fiscal
year 2002. Any violation of this agreement would require the
carrier to repay to the government the amount reimbursed for
airline security fees. US&nbsp;Airways complied with this
limitation on executive compensation. US&nbsp;Airways&#146;
security fee reimbursement was $212&nbsp;million, net of amounts
due to certain
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">233
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
affiliates, and was recorded as a reduction to operating
expenses during the second quarter of 2003. In September 2003,
US&nbsp;Airways received approximately $6&nbsp;million of
compensation associated with flight deck door expenditures,
which was recorded as an offset to capital costs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Gain on sale of Hotwire, Inc.</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In 2003, US&nbsp;Airways recorded a $30&nbsp;million gain on the
sale of its investment in Hotwire, Inc. The gain is reflected in
other, net within nonoperating income (expense) on the statement
of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financial instruments</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>General</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On January&nbsp;1, 1998, as part of a comprehensive information
technology services agreement with Sabre, US&nbsp;Airways was
granted two tranches of stock options (&#147;SHC Stock
Options&#148;) to acquire up to 6,000,000&nbsp;shares of
Class&nbsp;A Common Stock, $.01&nbsp;par value, of Sabre
Holdings Corporation (SHC Common Stock), Sabre&#146;s parent
company. Each tranche included 3,000,000 stock options. In
December 1999, US&nbsp;Airways exercised the first tranche of
stock options at an exercise price of $27&nbsp;per share and
received proceeds of $81&nbsp;million in January 2000 in lieu of
receiving SHC Common Stock. Realized gains resulting from the
exercise of Sabre options are subject to a clawback provision.
Under the clawback provision, if US&nbsp;Airways elects to
terminate its information technology service agreement with
Sabre it will be required to pay Sabre an amount equal to the
gain multiplied by the ratio of the remaining months in the
contract period over 180&nbsp;months. The deferred gain from the
1999 exercise is amortized on a straight-line basis over a
contractually determined period ending December 2012. In
February 2000, SHC declared a cash dividend resulting in a
dilution adjustment to the terms of the second tranche. The
adjusted terms of the second tranche include stock options to
acquire 3,406,914&nbsp;shares of SHC Common Stock at an exercise
price of $23.78&nbsp;per share subject to an $111.83&nbsp;per
share cap on the fair market value of the underlying common
stock. These options are exercisable during a ten-year period
beginning January&nbsp;2, 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways utilizes fixed price swap agreements and other
similar instruments to manage its exposure related to jet fuel
price changes. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, the
nine months ended 2003 and the three months ended March&nbsp;31,
2003, US&nbsp;Airways recognized gains of approximately
$130&nbsp;million, $14&nbsp;million and $27&nbsp;million,
respectively, related to its fuel hedging activities. During the
three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, the gain included
$4&nbsp;million related to hedge ineffectiveness. These
recognized gains were primarily included in aircraft fuel and
related taxes on the statements of operations. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, US&nbsp;Airways had no open
fuel hedge positions in place. At December&nbsp;31, 2004,
US&nbsp;Airways had $22&nbsp;million of unrealized gains related
to previously liquidated fuel hedge positions. During the nine
months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways realized
$17&nbsp;million of the gain as a reduction to aircraft fuel
expense. The remaining US&nbsp;Airways $5&nbsp;million was
recognized as a gain in reorganization items, net as part of
fresh-start reporting.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Fair value of financial instruments</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The carrying amount of cash equivalents, restricted cash and
short-term investments approximates fair value. US&nbsp;Airways
estimated the fair values of its note receivable and long-term
debt by discounting expected future cash flows using current
rates offered to US&nbsp;Airways for notes receivable and debt
with similar maturities. The estimated fair value of the
remaining SHC Stock Options (including the clawback provision)
was calculated using the Black-Scholes model. The fair values of
the fuel contracts were obtained from dealer quotes. These
values represent the estimated amount US&nbsp;Airways would
receive or pay to terminate such agreements as of the valuation
date.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">

Details of US&nbsp;Airways&#146; debt are as follows (variable

unless noted) (in millions):
</DIV>

    <DIV style="margin-left: 10px; text-indent: -10px">
    Secured</DIV>
    </TD>

<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with the consummation of the merger, on
    September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways, as borrower, entered
    into the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan with the ATSB. Also on
    September&nbsp;27, 2005, AWA entered into an Amended and
    Restated Loan Agreement (the &#147;AWA ATSB Loan&#148;). The
    ATSB Loans amended and restated the previously outstanding loans
    of both US&nbsp;Airways and AWA, each guaranteed in part by the
    ATSB. On October&nbsp;19, 2005, $539&nbsp;million of
    US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan, of which $525&nbsp;million was
    guaranteed by the ATSB, was sold by the lender by order of the
    ATSB to 13 fixed income investors. Due to the sale on
    October&nbsp;19, 2005, the ATSB no longer guarantees any portion
    of the loan and has no interest in any of US&nbsp;Airways&#146;
    debt. As a result of the sale of the loan, the principal amounts
    bear interest as a rate per annum equal to LIBOR plus
    600&nbsp;basis points, payable on a quarterly basis, and are no
    longer subject to payment of the quarterly guarantee fee. All
    other terms associated with this loan remain unchanged. As a
    result of the sale of the loan, the US&nbsp;Airways ATSB Loan is
    now referred to as the US&nbsp;Airways Citibank Loan, and had an
    outstanding balance of $551&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31,
    2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Ninety percent of the US&nbsp;Airways Citibank Loan
    (Tranche&nbsp;A), the previously guaranteed portion of the loan,
    was originally funded through a participating lender&#146;s
    commercial paper conduit program and bears interest at a rate
    equal to the conduit provider&#146;s weighted average cost
    related to the issuance of certain commercial paper notes and
    other short term borrowings plus 0.30%, provided that portions
    of Tranche&nbsp;A that are held by the US&nbsp;Airways Citibank
    Loan or by an assignee and no longer subject to such commercial
    paper conduit program bear interest at LIBOR plus 40&nbsp;basis
    points, and portions of Tranche&nbsp;A that are under certain
    circumstances assigned free of the ATSB guarantee bear interest
    at LIBOR plus 6.0%. Ten percent of the US&nbsp;Airways Citibank
    Loan (Tranche&nbsp;B) bears interest at the greater of the
    Tranche&nbsp;A interest rate plus 6.0% and LIBOR plus 6.0%, as
    compared with the previous rate of LIBOR plus 4.0%. The
    US&nbsp;Airways Citibank loan also reschedules amortization
    payments for US&nbsp;Airways with semi-annual payments beginning
    on March&nbsp;31, 2007 and continuing through September&nbsp;30,
    2010.</TD>
</TR>

    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>

</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    US&nbsp;Airways was required to pay down the principal of its
    loan with the first $125&nbsp;million of net proceeds from
    specified asset sales identified in connection with its
    Chapter&nbsp;11 proceedings, whether completed before or after
    emergence. US&nbsp;Airways then retains the next
    $83&nbsp;million of net proceeds from specified assets sales,
    and must prepay the principal of the loan with 60% of net
    proceeds in excess of an aggregate of $208&nbsp;million from
    specified asset sales. Any such asset sales proceeds up to
    $275&nbsp;million are to be applied to the outstanding principal
    balance in order of maturity, and any such asset sales proceeds
    in excess of $275&nbsp;million are to be applied to the
    outstanding principal balance on a pro rata across all
    maturities in accordance with the loan&#146;s early amortization
    provisions. As a result, semi-annual payments are now scheduled
    to begin on September&nbsp;30, 2007, instead of March&nbsp;31,
    2007, as originally scheduled in the loan agreement.
    US&nbsp;Airways made prepayments totaling $156&nbsp;million in
    connection with these specified asset sales completed during
    2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In September 2005, US&nbsp;Airways entered into an agreement to
    sell and leaseback certain of its commuter slots at Ronald
    Reagan Washington National Airport and New York LaGuardia
    Airport. US&nbsp;Airways continues to hold the right to
    repurchase the slots anytime after the second anniversary of the
    slot sale-leaseback transaction. These transactions were
    accounted for as secured financings. Installments are due
    monthly through 2015 at a rate of 8%.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    Capital lease obligations consist principally of certain airport
    maintenance and facility leases which expire in 2018 and 2021.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    General Electric together with its affiliates (collectively,
    &#147;GE&#148;) finances or leases a substantial portion of
    US&nbsp;Airways&#146; aircraft prior to the most recent
    Chapter&nbsp;11 filing. In addition, in November 2001,
    US&nbsp;Airways obtained a $404&nbsp;million credit facility
    from GE (the &#147;GE Credit Facility&#148;), which was secured
    by collateral including 11 A320-family aircraft and 28 spare
    engines. In connection with the first bankruptcy,
    US&nbsp;Airways reached a settlement with GE that resolved
    substantially all aircraft, aircraft engine and loan-related
    issues, and provided US&nbsp;Airways with additional financing
    from GE in the form of a liquidity facility of up to
    $360&nbsp;million that bore interest at the rate of LIBOR plus
    4.25% (the &#147;GE Liquidity Facility&#148;). Most obligations
    to GE are cross-defaulted to the US&nbsp;Airways GE Liquidity
    Facility, GE regional jet leases and GE regional jet mortgage
    financings.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In November 2004, US&nbsp;Airways reached a comprehensive
    agreement with GE and its affiliates, as described in a Master
    Memorandum of Understanding (&#147;GE Master MOU&#148;), that
    was approved by the Bankruptcy Court on December&nbsp;16, 2004.
    The GE Master MOU, together with the transactions contemplated
    by the term sheets attached to the GE Master MOU, provided
    short-term liquidity, reduced debt, lower aircraft ownership
    costs, enhanced engine maintenance services and operating leases
    for new regional jets, while preserving the vast majority of
    US&nbsp;Airway&#146;s mainline fleet owned or otherwise financed
    by GE. In connection with the merger, US&nbsp;Airways and
    America West Holdings renegotiated certain of their respective
    existing agreements, and entered into new agreements, with GE.
    These agreements are set forth in a comprehensive agreement with
    GE and certain of its affiliates in a Master Merger Memorandum
    of Understanding, referred to as the GE Merger MOU,</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">237

<P><HR noshade><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    that was approved by the Bankruptcy Court in June 2005. In part,
    the GE Merger MOU modified and supplemented the agreements
    reached between US&nbsp;Airways and GE in the GE Master MOU,
    which was further amended by an amendment dated
    September&nbsp;9, 2005. The amendment provided that, in lieu of
    the issuance to an affiliate of GE of a convertible note in the
    amount of $125&nbsp;million, US&nbsp;Airways Group would pay
    cash in the amount of $125&nbsp;million. The $125&nbsp;million
    was paid to GE before September&nbsp;30, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The bridge facility entered into between US&nbsp;Airways and GE
    pursuant to the GE Master MOU on December&nbsp;20, 2004 (the
    &#147;GE Bridge Facility&#148;) continued in effect during the
    pendency of the Chapter&nbsp;11 cases. The GE Bridge Facility
    provided for a loan in the amount of up to approximately
    $56&nbsp;million, which was drawn down in 2004 and 2005. The GE
    Bridge Facility bore interest at the rate of LIBOR plus 4.25%
    and matured on the date US&nbsp;Airways Group emerged from the
    Chapter&nbsp;11 cases, and was settled in cash by
    US&nbsp;Airways by September&nbsp;30, 2005 in connection with
    the $125&nbsp;million payment.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In June 2005, GE purchased the assets securing the GE Credit
    Facility in a sale-leaseback transaction. The sale proceeds
    realized from the sale-leaseback transaction were applied to
    repay the 2003 GE Liquidity Facility, the mortgage financing
    associated with the CRJ aircraft and a portion of the 2001 GE
    Credit Facility. The balance of the GE Credit Facility was
    amended to allow additional borrowings of $21&nbsp;million in
    July 2005, which resulted in a total principal balance
    outstanding thereunder of $28&nbsp;million. The operating leases
    are cross-defaulted with all other GE obligations, other than
    excepted obligations, and are subject to agreed upon return
    conditions.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA entered into
    two loan agreements with Airbus Financial Services
    (&#147;AFS&#148;), an affiliate of Airbus, with commitments in
    initial aggregate amounts of up to $161&nbsp;million and up to
    $89&nbsp;million. The Airbus loans bear interest at a rate of
    LIBOR plus a margin, subject to adjustment during the term of
    the loans under certain conditions and have been recorded as an
    obligation of US&nbsp;Airways Group. Amounts drawn upon the
    Airbus loans are drawn first upon the Airbus $161&nbsp;million
    loan until it has been drawn in its full amount, in which event
    the remaining portion of the $250&nbsp;million total commitment
    is drawn upon the Airbus $89&nbsp;million loan.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    On September&nbsp;27, 2005, all of the Airbus $161&nbsp;million
    loan and $14&nbsp;million of the Airbus $89&nbsp;million loan
    were drawn and are available for use for general corporate
    purposes. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, a total of
    $186&nbsp;million was drawn under the Airbus loans. The
    remaining portion of the Airbus loans is payable in multiple
    draws upon the occurrence of certain conditions, including the
    taking of delivery of certain aircraft, on the due dates for
    certain amounts owing to AFS or its affiliates to refinance such
    amounts, after payment of certain invoices for goods and
    services provided by AFS or its affiliates, or upon receipt by
    AFS of certain amounts payable in respect of existing aircraft
    financing transactions. The full amount of the Airbus loans is
    expected to be available by the end of 2006. US&nbsp;Airways and
    AWA are jointly and severally liable for the Airbus loans;
    accordingly, the full amount outstanding under the loans is
    reflected in financial statements of US&nbsp;Airways.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    The amortization payments under the Airbus $161&nbsp;million
    loan will become due in equal quarterly installments of
    $13&nbsp;million beginning on March&nbsp;31, 2008, with the
    final installment due on December&nbsp;31, 2010. The outstanding
    principal amount of the Airbus $89&nbsp;million loan will be
    forgiven in writing December&nbsp;31, 2010, or an earlier date,
    if on that date the outstanding principal amount of, accrued
    interest on, and all other amounts due under the Airbus
    $161&nbsp;million loan have been paid in full and
    US&nbsp;Airways and AWA comply with the aircraft delivery
    schedule.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f)</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="top">
    In connection with US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s emergence from
    bankruptcy in September 2005, it reached a settlement with the
    PBGC related to the termination of three of its defined benefit
    pension plans which included the issuance of a $10&nbsp;million
    note which matures in 2012 and bears interest at 6% payable
    annually in arrears.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">238

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain of US&nbsp;Airways&#146; long-term debt agreements
contain minimum cash balance requirements and other covenants
with which US&nbsp;Airways is in compliance. Certain of
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; long-term debt agreements contain
cross-default provisions, which may be triggered by defaults by
AWA or US&nbsp;Airways Group under other agreements relating to
indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Interest rates on $1.1&nbsp;billion and $1.63&nbsp;billion
principal amount of long-term debt as of December&nbsp;31, 2005
and 2004, respectively, are subject to adjustment to reflect
changes in floating interest rates. As of December&nbsp;31,
2005, the weighted average effective interest rate was 8.5% for
the equipment financing agreements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee pension and benefit
plans</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Substantially all of US&nbsp;Airways&#146; employees meeting
certain service and other requirements are eligible to
participate in various pension, medical, dental, life insurance,
disability and survivorship plans.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Defined benefit and other postretirement benefit
    plans</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On November&nbsp;12, 2004, US&nbsp;Airways filed a motion
requesting a determination from the Bankruptcy Court that
US&nbsp;Airways satisfied the financial requirements for a
&#147;distress termination&#148; under
section&nbsp;4041(c)(2)(B)(ii)(IV) of the Employee Retirement
Income Security Act of 1974, as amended (&#147;ERISA&#148;), of
the Retirement Plan for Flight Attendants in the Service of
US&nbsp;Airways, Inc. (the &#147;AFA Plan&#148;), the Pension
Plan for Employees of US&nbsp;Airways, Inc. Who Are Represented
by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace
Workers (the &#147;IAM Plan&#148;) and the Retirement Plan for
Certain Employees of US&nbsp;Airways, Inc. (the &#147;CE
Plan&#148;), and approval of each such plan&#146;s termination.
These plans had aggregate benefit obligations of
$2.71&nbsp;billion and aggregate plan assets of
$1.76&nbsp;billion, as of the plans&#146; termination dates in
January 2005. On January&nbsp;6, 2005, the Bankruptcy Court
entered an order (i)&nbsp;finding that the financial
requirements for a distress termination of the plans had been
met and (ii)&nbsp;approving termination of the plans. The AFA
Plan and the IAM Plan were terminated effective January&nbsp;10,
2005, which was the date agreed to by the PBGC and
US&nbsp;Airways. The CE Plan was terminated effective
January&nbsp;17, 2005, which was the date agreed to by the PBGC
and US&nbsp;Airways. Effective February&nbsp;1, 2005, the PBGC
was appointed trustee for each of the three plans.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Upon termination of the plans, US&nbsp;Airways recognized a
curtailment gain of $24&nbsp;million and a $91&nbsp;million
charge related to the minimum pension liability, which was
previously recorded in other comprehensive income. These amounts
are included in reorganization items, net in the statements of
operations. Upon emergence from bankruptcy on September&nbsp;27,
2005, the Bankruptcy Court approved a settlement agreement
between US&nbsp;Airways and the PBGC which required the PBGC to
release all claims against US&nbsp;Airways in return for
US&nbsp;Airways issuing (i)&nbsp;a $13.5&nbsp;million cash
payment, paid in October
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">239

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
2005, (ii)&nbsp;a 6.00%&nbsp;note payable for $10&nbsp;million,
and (iii)&nbsp;70%, or 4,873,485&nbsp;shares, of the unsecured
creditors stock, net of the shares allocated to ALPA, valued at
$57&nbsp;million. Accordingly, US&nbsp;Airways eliminated the
$948&nbsp;million liability related to the three terminated
plans, including the minimum liability adjustment, and
recognized a net settlement gain of $868&nbsp;million. This gain
is included in reorganization items, net in the statements of
operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During hearings in late 2004 and January 2005, the Bankruptcy
Court approved various settlement agreements between
US&nbsp;Airways and its unions, and between US&nbsp;Airways and
the court-appointed Section&nbsp;1114 Committee (representing
retirees not represented by the unions) to begin the significant
curtailments of postretirement benefits. Effective March&nbsp;1,
2005, those benefits were significantly reduced. US&nbsp;Airways
re-measured its postretirement benefit obligation based on the
new terms, which resulted in a reduction in the postretirement
benefit obligation of approximately $1.1&nbsp;billion and a
curtailment gain of $183&nbsp;million. Since the remeasurement
and reduction of the postretirement benefit obligation created a
significant unrecognized prior service gain, US&nbsp;Airways
recognized net periodic other postretirement benefit income
until the emergence from bankruptcy on September&nbsp;27, 2005.
In accordance with
SOP&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">90-7,</FONT>
US&nbsp;Airways revalued its postretirement benefit obligation
on emergence, and adjusted its liability to $229&nbsp;million, a
reduction of $1.25&nbsp;billion. Of this, a $1.24&nbsp;billion
gain, including the recognition of the unamortized portion of
the prior service gain created as a result of the benefit
curtailment, is included in reorganization items, net in the
statement of operations. Adjustments made subsequent to
September&nbsp;30, 2005 totaling $10&nbsp;million were made
directly to goodwill.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In December 2003, the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement
and Modernization Act of 2003 (the &#147;Medicare Prescription
Drug Act&#148;) became law in the United States. The Medicare
Prescription Drug Act introduces a prescription drug benefit
under Medicare as well as a federal subsidy to sponsors of
retiree health care benefit plans that provide a benefit that is
at least actuarially equivalent to the Medicare benefit.
US&nbsp;Airways elected to recognize the effects of the Medicare
Prescription Drug Act in the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2004,
as permitted by FASB Staff Position
FAS&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">106-2,</FONT>
&#147;Accounting and Disclosure Requirements Related to the
Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of
2003.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The recognition of this subsidy resulted in a reduction in
expense of $20&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2004 and a $198&nbsp;million actuarial gain that was subject to
amortization, based over the remaining period to expected
retirement. Significant assumptions included in the
re-measurement of the accumulated postretirement benefit
obligation were a 6.25% discount rate and a reduction in retiree
participation in the company-sponsored plan as certain defined
drug benefit caps make the plan more costly to retirees than
Medicare.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">240

    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(1)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    For plans with accumulated benefit obligations in excess of plan
    assets, the aggregate projected benefit obligations, accumulated
    benefit obligations and plan assets were $2.70&nbsp;billion,
    $2.68&nbsp;billion and $1.72&nbsp;billion, respectively, as of
    September&nbsp;30, 2004.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(2)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    In 2005, US&nbsp;Airways recognized curtailments and settlements
    related to the termination of its remaining material defined
    benefit pension plans. These curtailments and settlements were
    recognized in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;88,
    &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for Settlements and
    Curtailments of Defined Benefit Pension Plans and for
    Termination Benefits.&#148; In 2005, US&nbsp;Airways recognized
    curtailments related to the significant redesign of the other
    post retirement benefit plans (primarily medical and dental
    benefits). These curtailments were recognized in accordance with
    SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;106, &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for
    Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions.&#148;</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The accumulated benefit obligation for defined benefit pension
plans was zero as of September&nbsp;30, 2005 and
December&nbsp;31, 2005. The accumulated benefit obligation for
defined benefit pension plans was $2.68&nbsp;billion as of
December&nbsp;31, 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; September&nbsp;30, 2005 assumed discount
rate of 5.30% for measuring its other postretirement benefit
obligations is based on a hypothetical portfolio of high quality
publicly traded U.S.&nbsp;bonds (Aa rated, non-callable or
callable with make-whole provisions), for which the timing and
cash outflows approximate the estimated benefit payments of the
other postretirement benefit plans. US&nbsp;Airways&#146;
discounted both its pension obligations and its other
postretirement benefit obligations using a rate of 6.00% at
September&nbsp;30, 2004, based the current rates earned on
long-term bonds that received one of the two highest ratings
given by a recognized rating agency. The lower 2005 discount
rate primarily reflects the shorter duration of future benefits
due to the significant reduction in post-age&nbsp;65 benefits.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, the assumed health care cost
trend rates are 10% in 2006 and 9% in 2007, decreasing to 5% in
2011 and thereafter. As of September&nbsp;30, 2004, the assumed
health care cost trend were 9% in 2005 and 9% in 2006,
decreasing to 5% in 2010 and thereafter. The assumed health care
cost trend rates could have a significant effect on amounts
reported for retiree health care plans. A one-percentage point
change in the health care cost trend rates would have the
following effects on other postretirement benefits as of
September&nbsp;30, 2005 (in millions):
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

<TR style="font-size: 1pt;">
    <TD width="68%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 8pt;">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap><B>1% Increase</B></TD><TD></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The change in the additional minimum pension liability included
in other comprehensive income (loss) was $120&nbsp;million and
$(34)&nbsp;million for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30,
2005 and the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, respectively.
See Note&nbsp;10 for a reconciliation of the components of other
comprehensive income.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways assumed that its pension plans&#146; assets
would have generated a long-term rate of return of 7.33% at
September&nbsp;30, 2004. The expected long-term rate of return
assumption was developed by evaluating input from the
plans&#146; investment consultants, including their review of
asset class return expectations and long-term inflation
assumptions. The weighted average asset allocations at
September&nbsp;30, 2004 by asset category were as follows:
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff">
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left: 10px; text-indent: -10px">
    Real estate</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>8</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left: 10px; text-indent: -10px">
    Other</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>1</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff">
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left: 10px; text-indent: -10px">
    Total</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>100</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" nowrap>%</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; targeted asset allocation at
September&nbsp;30, 2004 was approximately 46% equity securities,
45% debt securities and 9% real estate. US&nbsp;Airways believed
that its long-term asset allocation on average would approximate
the targeted allocation. US&nbsp;Airways regularly reviewed its
actual asset allocation and periodically rebalanced its
investments to its targeted allocation when considered
appropriate.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Defined contribution pension plans</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways sponsors several defined contribution pension
plans for certain employees. US&nbsp;Airways makes cash
contributions to certain plans based on the employee&#146;s age,
compensation and elected contributions. US&nbsp;Airways also
participates in a multi-employer plan for certain employees.
Cash contributions are a function of hours worked times a
negotiated contribution rate. Company contributions as a
percentage of compensation were generally reduced in late 2004
in connection with US&nbsp;Airways&#146; restructured labor
agreements and non-union wage and benefits reductions. Expenses
related to these plans, excluding expenses related to the
US&nbsp;Airways Employee Stock Ownership Plan (&#147;ESOP&#148;)
and the US&nbsp;Airways pilot defined contribution plans (see
below), were approximately $5&nbsp;million, $24&nbsp;million,
$49&nbsp;million, $38&nbsp;million, and $12&nbsp;million for the
three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, the nine months ended
September&nbsp;30, 2005, the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004,
the nine months ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and three months
ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, respectively. See Note&nbsp;7(d) for
information related to US&nbsp;Airways&#146; ESOP.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with its previous reorganization under
Chapter&nbsp;11 of the Bankruptcy Code, US&nbsp;Airways
terminated the Retirement Income Plan for Pilots of
US&nbsp;Airways, Inc. and the related nonqualified pilot plan
effective March&nbsp;31, 2003. US&nbsp;Airways implemented a
qualified and nonqualified defined contribution plan for pilots
effective April&nbsp;1, 2003. The defined contribution amount
was individually determined based on a target normal retirement
date balance of approximately $1&nbsp;million for a career
US&nbsp;Airways pilot. The target balance included the estimated
value of other retirement benefits including, but not limited
to, the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">245
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
estimated benefit pilots are expected to receive from the PBGC,
the trustee for the terminated pilot defined benefit plan.
Effective October&nbsp;15, 2004, each pilot&#146;s contribution
rate became the lessor of the original rate or 10% of eligible
compensation. Expenses for this plan were $10&nbsp;million,
$32&nbsp;million, $134&nbsp;million and $134&nbsp;million for
the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, the nine months
ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2004 and for the nine months ended December&nbsp;31, 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Postemployment benefits</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways provides certain postemployment benefits to its
employees. These benefits include disability-related benefits
for certain employees. US&nbsp;Airways accrues for the cost of
these benefit expenses once an appropriate triggering event has
occurred.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(d)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Employee stock ownership plan (ESOP)</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In August 1989, US&nbsp;Airways established an ESOP.
US&nbsp;Airways Group sold 2,200,000&nbsp;shares of its common
stock to an Employee Stock Ownership Trust (the
&#147;Trust&#148;) to hold on behalf of US&nbsp;Airways&#146;
employees, exclusive of officers, in accordance with the terms
of the Trust and the ESOP. The trustee placed those shares in a
suspense account pending their release and allocation to
employees. US&nbsp;Airways provided financing to the Trust in
the form of a
9<FONT style="font-size: 70%"><SUP>3</SUP></FONT>/<FONT style="font-size: 60%">4</FONT>%
loan for $111&nbsp;million for its purchase of shares and
US&nbsp;Airways contributed an additional $2&nbsp;million to the
Trust. US&nbsp;Airways made a yearly contribution to the Trust
sufficient to cover the Trust&#146;s debt service requirement.
The contributions were made in amounts equal to the periodic
loan payments as they came due, less dividends available for
loan payment. Since US&nbsp;Airways Group did not pay dividends
on any shares held by the Trust for the three months ended
March&nbsp;31, 2003, the Trust did not utilize dividends to
service its debt during those periods. The initial maturity of
the loan was 30&nbsp;years. As the loan was repaid over time,
the trustee systematically released shares of the common stock
from the suspense account and allocated them to participating
employees. Each participant&#146;s allocation was based on the
participant&#146;s compensation, the total compensation of all
ESOP participants and the total number of shares being released.
For each year after 1989, a minimum of 71,933&nbsp;shares were
released from the suspense account and allocated to participant
accounts. Annual contributions made by US&nbsp;Airways, and
therefore loan repayments made by the Trust, were
$9&nbsp;million in 2003. The interest portion of these
contributions was $7&nbsp;million in 2003. In June 2002,
US&nbsp;Airways Group engaged Aon Fiduciary Counselors
(&#147;Aon&#148;) as an independent fiduciary of the ESOP, with
the authority to make all decisions related to sale of the stock
held in the ESOP. In September 2002, Aon sold all shares that
were allocated to participant accounts. All unallocated shares
in the ESOP were cancelled in accordance with the first
bankruptcy in March 2003. Effective March&nbsp;31, 2003, the
ESOP was terminated as provided in the 2003 plan of
reorganization. The note payable to US&nbsp;Airways was
cancelled under the provisions of the plan of reorganization.
Participant accounts were distributed by December&nbsp;31, 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(e)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Profit sharing plans</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the Defined Contribution Retirement Program,
US&nbsp;Airways makes additional contributions to participant
accounts for certain employees when US&nbsp;Airways Group
achieves certain prescribed pre-tax margin levels.
US&nbsp;Airways did not make any profit sharing contributions
relating to 2005, 2004, or 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Since the emergence from bankruptcy in September 2005, most
non-executive employees of US&nbsp;Airways are eligible to
participate in the 2005 Profit Sharing Plan, an annual bonus
program. Annual bonus awards are paid from a profit-sharing pool
equal to (i)&nbsp;ten percent of the annual profits of
US&nbsp;Airways Group (excluding unusual items) for pre-tax
profit margins up to ten percent, plus (ii)&nbsp;15% of the
annual profits of US&nbsp;Airways Group (excluding unusual
items) for pre-tax profit margins greater than ten percent.
Awards are paid as a lump sum no later than March 15 after the
end of the fiscal year.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">246

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
The profit-sharing pool is shared among eligible employee groups
in proportion to each group&#146;s share of overall cost savings
achieved through US&nbsp;Airways 2005 Transformation Plan;
however, the represented pilots&#146; and flight
attendants&#146; portions of the pool shall not be less than 36%
and 14.5%, respectively. An employee&#146;s share of the pool is
based on the ratio that the employee&#146;s compensation bears
to the respective employee group&#146;s aggregate compensation.
Because of significant losses, no benefits accrued under the
plan in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>8.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Income Taxes</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways accounts for income taxes according to the
provisions in SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;109, &#147;Accounting for
Income Taxes.&#148; US&nbsp;Airways files a consolidated federal
income tax return with its parent company, US&nbsp;Airways
Group. US&nbsp;Airways Group and its wholly owned subsidiaries
allocate tax and tax items, such as net operating losses
(&#147;NOL&#148;) and net tax credits, between members of the
group based on their proportion of taxable income and other
items. Accordingly, US&nbsp;Airways&#146; tax expense is based
on its taxable income, taking into consideration its allocated
tax loss carryforwards/carrybacks and tax credit carryforwards.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In assessing the realizability of the deferred tax assets,
management considers whether it is more likely than not that
some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will be realized.
US&nbsp;Airways has recorded a valuation allowance against its
net deferred tax asset. The ultimate realization of deferred tax
assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income
(including reversals of deferred tax liabilities) during the
periods in which those temporary differences will become
deductible.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The components of the provision (credit)&nbsp;for income taxes
are as follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Included in the employee benefit deferred tax assets at
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, among other items, are
$90&nbsp;million and $661&nbsp;million, respectively, related to
obligations of postretirement medical benefits.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways will be filing a full
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">12-month</FONT> return as part
of its consolidated filing with US&nbsp;Airways Group. The
current tax provision for the nine months ended
September&nbsp;30, 2005 and the three months ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005 was prepared in accordance with this tax
return methodology. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005,
US&nbsp;Airways had a $786&nbsp;million federal net operating
loss carryforward with $52&nbsp;million expiring in 2023,
$551&nbsp;million expiring in 2024, and $183&nbsp;million
expiring in 2025 and $25&nbsp;million of alternative minimum tax
credits which do not expire. US&nbsp;Airways filed for
bankruptcy protection on September&nbsp;12, 2004 and emerged on
September&nbsp;27, 2005. As a result of the bankruptcy
proceedings, the federal and state net operating loss
carryforwards were reduced by cancellation of debt income of
$113&nbsp;million. Additionally, US&nbsp;Airways Group had a
change of ownership upon emergence from bankruptcy and its
issuance of new common stock. Internal Revenue Code
Section&nbsp;382 substantially limits the annual usage of
remaining tax attributes that were generated prior to the change
in ownership.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the federal and state net operating
loss carryforwards were reduced by discharge of indebtedness
income of $1.2&nbsp;billion that resulted from the August 2002
bankruptcy proceedings. In addition, an Internal Revenue Code
Section&nbsp;382 change of ownership occurred for
US&nbsp;Airways Group upon emergence from the first bankruptcy
and issuance of new common stock. Section&nbsp;382 substantially
limits the annual usage of tax attributes that were generated
prior to the change in ownership date.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The federal income tax returns of US&nbsp;Airways through 2002
have been examined and settled with the Internal Revenue
Service. US&nbsp;Airways is not currently under examination.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>9.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commitments and
contingencies</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>
