    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Commitments to purchase flight equipment and maintenance
    services</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Airbus Purchase Commitments</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group,
US&nbsp;Airways and AWA entered into an Airbus&nbsp;A350
Purchase Agreement with Airbus. This agreement provides for the
delivery of 20&nbsp;A350&nbsp;aircraft during the period 2011
through 2014. The agreement contains terms and conditions with
respect to aircraft price, escalation, payment terms and
pre-delivery payments, inspection and certification, technical
acceptance, excusable and inexcusable delays, warranties and
service life policy, patent and copyright indemnity, technical
data and training aids, training, supplier product support,
indemnities and insurance, assignments and transfers, and
termination events. Airbus also agreed to provide backstop
financing with respect to a substantial number of these
A350&nbsp;aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group entered into
Amendment&nbsp;16 to the A319/A320/A321 Purchase Agreement dated
as of October&nbsp;31, 1997 among US&nbsp;Airways Group and
AVSA, S.A.R.L. The amendment provides for the rescheduling of
19&nbsp;firm order
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A320-family</FONT> aircraft
for delivery during the period&nbsp;2009 and 2010. The amendment
also modifies other provisions of the Purchase Agreement
relating to the deletion of certain aircraft cancellation rights
and the rescheduling of aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;27, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways Group entered into
Amendment&nbsp;10 to the A330/340 Purchase Agreement dated as of
November&nbsp;24, 1998 among US&nbsp;Airways Group and AVSA,
S.A.R.L. The amendment provides for the rescheduling of ten firm
order <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A330-200</FONT> aircraft
for delivery during the period 2009 and 2010 and allows for
cancellation in the event that US&nbsp;Airways takes certain
deliveries under the A350 Purchase Agreement described above.
Other provisions of the Purchase Agreement which have been
modified by the amendment relate to the application of existing
pre-delivery payments, adjustments to various cancellation
rights and the cancellation of the right for additional
A330&nbsp;aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Embraer Purchase Commitments</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On February&nbsp;16, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court approved a
settlement and assumption term sheet between US&nbsp;Airways
Group and Embraer, executed by US&nbsp;Airways Group on
February&nbsp;9, 2006, which amends the purchase agreement dated
as of May&nbsp;9, 2003, as amended, between US&nbsp;Airways
Group and Embraer and contemplates an amended and restated
financing letter with Embraer. The Bankruptcy Court
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">250
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
also authorized the assumption of the purchase agreement, as
amended by the term sheet, and a related maintenance agreement,
and disallowed certain proofs of claim filed by Embraer in the
bankruptcy proceedings related to these agreements. The purchase
agreement, as amended by the term sheet, provides that Embraer
will retain and apply approximately $18&nbsp;million in
non-refundable progress and deposit payments (&#147;PDPs&#148;)
previously paid by US&nbsp;Airways Group. US&nbsp;Airways Group
has agreed to place an initial firm order for
25&nbsp;Embraer&nbsp;190 aircraft and an additional firm order
for 32&nbsp;Embraer&nbsp;190 aircraft. The outstanding PDPs will
be applied to these orders in accordance with the terms of the
amended purchase agreement. In addition, upon assumption of the
amended purchase agreement, Embraer granted US&nbsp;Airways
Group the right to purchase up to 50 additional Embraer&nbsp;190
aircraft in accordance with the term sheet. The term sheet also
provides that US&nbsp;Airways Group will be allowed to convert
certain of the Embraer 190 aircraft to Embraer&nbsp;170,
Embraer&nbsp;175 or Embraer 195 aircraft, subject to
availability and upon agreed notice. Embraer has agreed to
provide financing for certain of the aircraft scheduled for
delivery under the amended purchase agreement, under the terms
of the amended and restated financing letter.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Bombardier Purchase Commitments</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under its agreement with Bombardier, US&nbsp;Airways Group
acquired three new
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">CRJ-700</FONT> aircraft in
January 2005. The purchase was financed through the application
of $28&nbsp;million of existing purchase deposits held by
Bombardier, $2&nbsp;million in cash and a financed lease
facility with DVB&nbsp;Bank&nbsp;AG. Additionally,
$7&nbsp;million of purchase deposits held by Bombardier were
used to satisfy existing defaults, cure payments and liquidated
damages. While US&nbsp;Airways Group continued to operate under
the protection of Chapter&nbsp;11 in compliance with the
Bankruptcy Code and until a decision is reached to assume or
reject the Bombardier regional jet purchase agreement, no
obligations arise on the part of US&nbsp;Airways Group or
Bombardier with respect to the purchase and delivery of any
aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I>Engine Maintenance Commitments</I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the merger, US&nbsp;Airways and AWA
restructured their rate per engine hour agreements with General
Electric Engine Services for overhaul maintenance services.
Under the restructured agreements, the minimum monthly payment
on account of accrued engine flight hours for both the
US&nbsp;Airways and AWA agreements together will equal
$3&nbsp;million as long as both agreements remain in effect or
through October 2009.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Leases</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways leases certain aircraft engines and ground
equipment, in addition to the majority of its ground facilities.
Ground facilities include executive offices, maintenance
facilities and ticket and administrative offices. Public
airports are utilized for flight operations under lease
arrangements with the municipalities or agencies owning or
controlling such airports. Substantially all leases provide that
the lessee must pay taxes, maintenance, insurance and certain
other operating expenses applicable to the leased property. Some
leases also include renewal and purchase options.
US&nbsp;Airways subleases to related parties certain leased
aircraft and ground facilities under noncancelable operating
leases expiring in various years through the year 2022 (see
Note&nbsp;11(b)).
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">251

December&nbsp;31, 2004, the nine months ended December&nbsp;31,

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways also leases certain owned flight equipment to
related parties (see Note&nbsp;11(b)) under noncancelable
operating leases expiring in various years through the year
2019. The future minimum rental receipts associated with these
leases are: $76&nbsp;million in 2006, $24&nbsp;million in 2007,
$25&nbsp;million 2008, $26&nbsp;million in 2009,
$28&nbsp;million in 2010 and $246&nbsp;million thereafter.
</DIV>

    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>280</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>477</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways has set up pass through trusts, also known as
&#147;Enhanced Equipment Trust&nbsp;Certificates&#148; or
&#147;EETC&#148;, covering the financing of 19 owned aircraft
and 62 leased aircraft, These trusts are off-balance sheet
entities, the primary purpose of which is to finance the
acquisition of aircraft. Rather than
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">252
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
finance each aircraft separately when such aircraft is purchased
or delivered, these trusts allow US&nbsp;Airways to raise the
financing for several aircraft at one time and place the funds
in escrow pending the purchase or delivery of the relevant
aircraft. The trusts are also structured to provide for certain
credit enhancements, such as liquidity facilities to cover
certain interest payments, that reduce the risks to the
purchasers of the trust certificates and, as a result, reduce
the cost of aircraft financings to US&nbsp;Airways.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Each trust covered a set amount of aircraft scheduled to be
delivered within a specific period of time. At the time of each
covered aircraft financing, the relevant trust used the funds in
escrow to purchase equipment notes relating to the financed
aircraft. The equipment notes were issued, at
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; election, either by US&nbsp;Airways in
connection with a mortgage financing of the aircraft or by a
separate owner trust in connection with a leveraged lease
financing of the aircraft. In the case of a leveraged lease
financing, the owner trust then leased the aircraft to
US&nbsp;Airways. In both cases, the equipment notes are secured
by a security interest in the aircraft. The pass through trust
certificates are not direct obligations of, nor are they
guaranteed by, US&nbsp;Airways Group or US&nbsp;Airways.
However, in the case of mortgage financings, the equipment notes
issued to the trusts are direct obligations of US&nbsp;Airways.
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, $652&nbsp;million is reflected as
debt in the accompanying balance sheet.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In addition, neither US&nbsp;Airways Group nor US&nbsp;Airways
guarantee or participate in any way in the residual value of the
leased aircraft. All aircraft financed by these trusts are
currently structured as leveraged lease financings, which are
not reflected as debt on the balance sheets of either
US&nbsp;Airways Group or US&nbsp;Airways. US&nbsp;Airways does
not provide residual value guarantees under these lease
arrangements. Each lease contains a purchase option that allows
US&nbsp;Airways to purchase the aircraft at a fixed price, which
at the inception of the lease approximated the aircraft&#146;s
expected fair market value at the option date, near the end of
the lease term. These leasing entities meet the criteria for
variable interest entities. However, they do not meet the
consolidation criteria under FIN&nbsp;46(R) because
US&nbsp;Airways is not the primary beneficiary under these
arrangements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Regional jet capacity purchase agreements</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways has entered into capacity purchase agreements
with certain regional jet operators. The capacity purchase
agreements provide that all revenues (passenger, mail and
freight) go to US&nbsp;Airways. In return, US&nbsp;Airways
agrees to pay predetermined fees to the regional airlines for
operating an agreed number of aircraft, without regard to the
number of passengers onboard. In addition, these agreements
provide that certain variable costs, such as fuel and airport
landing fees, will be reimbursed 100% by US&nbsp;Airways.
US&nbsp;Airways controls marketing, scheduling, ticketing,
pricing and seat inventories. The regional jet capacity purchase
agreements have expirations from 2008 to 2015 and provide for
optional extensions at US&nbsp;Airways&#146; discretion. The
future minimum noncancelable commitments under the regional jet
capacity purchase agreements are $597&nbsp;million in 2006,
$604&nbsp;million in 2007, $616&nbsp;million in 2006,
$628&nbsp;million in 2009, $641&nbsp;million in 2010 and
$2.92&nbsp;billion thereafter.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain entities with which US&nbsp;Airways has capacity
purchase agreements are considered variable interest entities
under FIN&nbsp;46(R). In connection with its restructuring and
emergence from bankruptcy, US&nbsp;Airways contracted with Air
Wisconsin, a related party, and Republic to purchase a
significant portion of these companies&#146; regional jet
capacity for a period of ten years. US&nbsp;Airways has
determined that it is not the primary beneficiary of these
variable interest entities, based on cash flow analyses.
Additionally, US&nbsp;Airways has analyzed the arrangements with
other carriers with which US&nbsp;Airways has long-term capacity
purchase agreements and has concluded it is not required to
consolidated any of the entities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(d)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Legal proceedings</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;12, 2004, US&nbsp;Airways Group and its
domestic subsidiaries (the &#147;Debtors&#148;) filed voluntary
petitions for relief under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the Bankruptcy
Code in the United States bankruptcy
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">253

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
court for the Eastern District of Virginia, Alexandria Division
(Case
Nos.&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">04-13819-SSM</FONT>
through <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">03-13823-SSM)</FONT>
(the &#147;2004 Bankruptcy&#148;). On September&nbsp;16, 2005,
the Bankruptcy Court issued an order confirming the plan of
reorganization submitted by the Debtors and on
September&nbsp;27, 2005, the Debtors emerged from the 2004
Bankruptcy. The court&#146;s order confirming the plan included
a provision called the plan injunction, which forever bars other
parties from pursuing most claims against the Debtors that arose
prior to September&nbsp;27, 2005 in any forum other than the
Bankruptcy Court. The great majority of these claims are
pre-petition claims that, if paid out at all, will be paid out
in common stock of the post-bankruptcy US&nbsp;Airways Group at
a fraction of the actual claim value.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On February&nbsp;26, 2004, a company called I.A.P. Intermodal,
LLC filed suit against US&nbsp;Airways Group and its wholly
owned airline subsidiaries in the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Texas alleging that the
defendants&#146; computer scheduling system infringes upon three
patents held by plaintiffs, all of which patents are entitled,
&#147;Method to Schedule a Vehicle in Real-Time to Transport
Freight and Passengers.&#148; Plaintiff seeks various injunctive
relief as well as costs, fees and treble damages.
US&nbsp;Airways Group and its subsidiaries were formally served
with the complaint on June&nbsp;21, 2004. US&nbsp;Airways Group
is unable to ascertain at this time the likelihood or potential
scale of liability. On the same date, the same plaintiff filed
what US&nbsp;Airways Group believes to be substantially similar
cases against nine other major airlines, including British
Airways, Northwest Airlines Corporation, Korean Airlines Co.,
Ltd., Deutsche Lufthansa AG, Air France, Air Canada, Singapore
Airlines Ltd., Delta Air Lines and Continental Airlines, Inc.,
and had filed a suit against AMR Group, Inc., the parent company
of American Airlines, along with its airline subsidiaries, in
December 2003. This action has been stayed as to US&nbsp;Airways
Group and its wholly owned subsidiaries as a result of the 2004
Bankruptcy. In the meantime, several foreign airline defendants
were dismissed from the case for reasons unique to their status
as foreign operators, and the remaining defendants in September
2005 obtained a ruling that there had been no infringement of
any of I.A.P.&#146;s patents. In October 2005, I.A.P. entered
into consent judgments with several defendants but has since
filed a notice of appeal against Continental Airlines and the
AMR Group defendants. I.A.P. did not file any claims against
US&nbsp;Airways Group or any of its subsidiaries in the 2004
Bankruptcy.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey filed a proof of
claim against US&nbsp;Airways in the bankruptcy case filed on
August&nbsp;11, 2002 (the &#147;2002 Bankruptcy&#148;). The
claim was in the amount of $8.5&nbsp;million and it alleged
environmental contamination and building deficiencies at
LaGuardia Airport. US&nbsp;Airways&#146; liability and defenses
to this liability were unaffected by the 2002 Bankruptcy. In
connection with the 2004 Bankruptcy, the Port Authority filed a
proof of claim in the amount of approximately $24&nbsp;million
again alleging environmental contamination and building
deficiencies at LaGuardia Airport, of which approximately
$2&nbsp;million is related to alleged environmental
contamination.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On January&nbsp;7, 2003, the Internal Revenue Service
(&#147;IRS&#148;) issued a notice of proposed adjustment to
US&nbsp;Airways Group proposing to disallow $573&nbsp;million of
capital losses that US&nbsp;Airways Group sustained in the tax
year 1999 on the sale of stock of USLM Corporation (the
&#147;USLM matter&#148;). On February&nbsp;5, 2003, the IRS
filed a proof of claim with the Bankruptcy Court in connection
with the 2002 Bankruptcy asserting the following claims against
US&nbsp;Airways with respect to the USLM matter:
(1)&nbsp;secured claims for U.S.&nbsp;federal income tax and
interest of $1&nbsp;million; (2)&nbsp;unsecured priority claims
for U.S.&nbsp;federal income tax of $68&nbsp;million and
interest of $14&nbsp;million; and (3)&nbsp;an unsecured general
claim for penalties of $25&nbsp;million. On May&nbsp;8, 2003,
US&nbsp;Airways Group reached a tentative agreement with the IRS
on the amount of U.S.&nbsp;federal income taxes, interest and
penalties due subject to final approval from the Joint Committee
on Taxation. By letter dated September&nbsp;11, 2003,
US&nbsp;Airways Group was notified that the Joint Committee on
Taxation had accepted the tentative agreement with the IRS,
including a settlement of all federal income taxes through the
end of 2002. Due to the 2004 Bankruptcy filing, which suspended
payment of prepetition liabilities, final payment terms under
the agreement have not been submitted to the Bankruptcy Court
for approval. The IRS has submitted a proof of claim relating to
the USLM matter in
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">254

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
the 2004 Bankruptcy in the amount of approximately
$31&nbsp;million, and on August&nbsp;2, 2005 the IRS filed a
motion for relief from the automatic stay seeking to setoff
against approximately $4&nbsp;million of tax refunds due to the
Debtors. On October&nbsp;20, 2005, the IRS filed an amended
proof of claim reducing its claim in the USLM matter to
$11&nbsp;million. On November&nbsp;3, 2005, the IRS filed an
amended motion continuing to seek relief for the $4&nbsp;million
setoff. A hearing was set for December&nbsp;15, 2005 on this
matter, but was continued to March&nbsp;16, 2006 for a status
hearing. The Debtors are in the process of analyzing the
IRS&#146; amended motion.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Williard, Inc. and the joint venture of Williard, Inc. and Len
Parker Associates, was awarded construction contracts with
US&nbsp;Airways for work to be performed at the Philadelphia
International Airport. On May&nbsp;29, 2002, US&nbsp;Airways
terminated the largest contracts between the parties. Williard,
Inc. and the joint venture sued US&nbsp;Airways in Pennsylvania
state court for over $14&nbsp;million in damages representing
termination costs and lost profits, along with other alleged
contractual damage claims. Subsequently, Limbach Company, LLC
alleged that it purchased the claims of Williard, Inc. After a
trial, the Bankruptcy Court in the 2002 Bankruptcy, on
June&nbsp;7, 2004, determined the value of the Limbach Company
and the joint venture claims to be approximately
$2.5&nbsp;million. Limbach Company and the joint venture are
challenging on appeal various rulings of the Bankruptcy Court,
including the amount of the claim and its status as an unsecured
claim. US&nbsp;Airways has also filed an appeal regarding the
denial of its right to offset the claims with asserted
backcharges.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Limbach Company and the joint venture have filed an action in
state court against the City of Philadelphia and the
Philadelphia Authority for Industrial Development, as well as
US&nbsp;Airways, but did not assert any claims against
US&nbsp;Airways in that action. In the lawsuit against the City
of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority for Industrial
Development, Limbach Company and the joint venture are seeking
the same sums as in their earlier lawsuit and proofs of claim
against US&nbsp;Airways, but this time under the equitable
theories of third-party beneficiary, quantum meruit and
constructive trust. On a pre-answer motion to dismiss, the court
in the Philadelphia action dismissed US&nbsp;Airways from the
lawsuit and dismissed the third-party beneficiary claims against
the City of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority for
Industrial Development.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On May&nbsp;21, 2004, the City of Philadelphia and the
Philadelphia Authority for Industrial Development filed a Motion
for Summary Judgment seeking dismissal of the remaining claims
for constructive trust and quantum meruit. On October&nbsp;18,
2004, the City of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority
for Industrial Development also filed an alternative Motion for
Partial Summary Judgment that the damages claimed by Limbach
Company and the joint venture, if any, are capped at the amount
determined by the Bankruptcy Court on the prior trial of its
claims. On June&nbsp;29, 2005, the court granted the Motion for
Summary Judgment and dismissed the alternative Motion for
Partial Summary Judgment as moot. Limbach Company and the joint
venture have appealed the dismissal of these claims, as well as
the prior dismissal of its third party beneficiary claim, but
have not appealed the dismissal of US&nbsp;Airways from the
lawsuit.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Should the Philadelphia court&#146;s rulings be reversed on
appeal and Limbach Company and/or the joint venture subsequently
recover in the Philadelphia action against the City of
Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority for Industrial
Development, that award would be paid by them at 100&nbsp;cents
on the dollar. Although US&nbsp;Airways&#146; agreements with
the City of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Authority for
Industrial Development related to the airport development have
neither been assumed nor rejected as part of the 2004
Bankruptcy, if assumed, US&nbsp;Airways may have an obligation,
under those agreements, to indemnify the City of Philadelphia
and the Philadelphia Authority for Industrial Development, at
full value, for any recovery against them by Limbach Company
and/or the joint venture. Proceedings in the Bankruptcy Court
related to the claims in the 2002 Bankruptcy remain stayed by
the 2004 Bankruptcy filing.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">255

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group and US&nbsp;Airways have been named as
defendants in two lawsuits filed in federal district court for
the Eastern District of Michigan in May 1999. Delta Air Lines is
also named as a defendant in both actions, while Northwest
Airlines and the Airlines Reporting Corporation were sued
separately in a third action. The complaints were filed on
behalf of a class of airline passengers who originated or
terminated their trips at the defendant carriers&#146;
respective hubs. These passengers allege that they paid
excessive fares due to the respective airlines&#146; enforcement
of ticketing rules that prohibit the use of a connecting segment
coupon that is part of a through-fare ticket where the passenger
does not fly or intend to fly the entire ticketed itinerary.
Plaintiffs allege monopolization and restraint of trade in
violation of federal antitrust laws. They seek recovery of
treble damages from all named defendants in the amount of
$390&nbsp;million and an injunction prohibiting future
enforcement of the rules at issue. On May&nbsp;16, 2002, the
court denied the defendant airlines&#146; Motion for Summary
Judgment and granted the plaintiffs&#146; Motion for
Class&nbsp;Certification in each of the cases. On May&nbsp;31,
2002, US&nbsp;Airways Group and US&nbsp;Airways filed a petition
with the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
seeking a discretionary review of the certification order. On
November&nbsp;21, 2002, the petition for permission to appeal
the class certification decision was denied. On December&nbsp;4,
2002, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines filed a rehearing
petition seeking en banc review of the initial Sixth Circuit
denial. On February&nbsp;24, 2003, Northwest Airlines&#146; and
Delta Air Lines&#146; petition for rehearing en banc was denied.
Notwithstanding the district court&#146;s denial of summary
judgment and the petition, US&nbsp;Airways Group and
US&nbsp;Airways believe the claims are without merit and intend
to pursue a vigorous defense. The action was stayed as to
US&nbsp;Airways during the 2002 Bankruptcy and again during the
2004 Bankruptcy. On April&nbsp;29, 2005, Northwest Airlines and
Delta Air Lines filed a renewed motion for summary judgment on
all counts. That motion was denied. Delta Air Lines and
Northwest Airlines filed two additional motions: one seeking
decertification of the class and the other seeking dismissal of
all class members who received ticket refunds. While those
motions were pending, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines
filed for bankruptcy. The federal district court has now
deactivated the case because of the bankruptcy filings. However,
in January 2006, plaintiffs filed a motion for relief from the
stay imposed by the Northwest Airlines bankruptcy filing to
pursue litigation against that defendant only. On
December&nbsp;1, 2005, plaintiffs withdrew the claims filed
against US&nbsp;Airways in the 2002 and 2004 Bankruptcies, thus
effectively cutting off their right to obtain any relief against
US&nbsp;Airways for damages that might have accrued prior to
September&nbsp;27, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On September&nbsp;29, 2000, US&nbsp;Airways intervened in a
proceeding that was originally brought on January&nbsp;26, 1998
by the Pennsylvania Department of Environment Protection against
Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, and the Allegheny County
Aviation Administration alleging that a variety of airfield and
aircraft de-icing activities at Pittsburgh International Airport
violated the requirements of (a)&nbsp;a 1994 Consent Order and
Adjudication issued to Allegheny County and air carrier tenants
at the Pittsburgh International Airport, (b)&nbsp;the Pittsburgh
International Airport&#146;s National Pollutant Discharge
Elimination System Permit, and (c)&nbsp;the Pennsylvania Clean
Streams Law. The action was brought before the Pennsylvania
Environmental Hearing Board. During March 2001, the
Environmental Hearing Board approved Allegheny County&#146;s
Motion to Withdraw the Appeal without Prejudice, thereby
terminating the appeal. However, during the course of settlement
discussions leading to the termination of the appeal, the
Pennsylvania Department of Environment Protection advised
Allegheny County and US&nbsp;Airways that the Department of
Environment Protection will require additional measures to be
taken to control de-icing materials at the Pittsburgh
International Airport, and will assess a civil penalty against
Allegheny County and US&nbsp;Airways for the alleged violations
described above. The Allegheny County Aviation Administration,
US&nbsp;Airways and the Pennsylvania Department of Environment
Protection have continued to work together with the goal of
fashioning an ultimate resolution to the de-icing issues.
US&nbsp;Airways Group does not believe that the settlement of
this matter will have a material adverse effect on its financial
condition, results of operations or liquidity.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">256

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;7, 2005, 240 pilots employed by the MidAtlantic
division of US&nbsp;Airways filed a complaint in the federal
district court for the Eastern District of New York against
ALPA, US&nbsp;Airways, US&nbsp;Airways Group, Republic Airways
Holdings, Inc., Wexford Capital LLC and AWA, alleging that
defendants conspired to deceive plaintiffs into believing that
MidAtlantic was a separate entity from US&nbsp;Airways in order
to deprive them of the benefits they are due as US&nbsp;Airways
pilots pursuant to the US&nbsp;Airways collective bargaining
agreement. Plaintiffs&#146; claims against the airline
defendants include breach of collective bargaining agreement,
violation of the Railway Labor Act and racketeering under the
Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act
(&#147;RICO&#148;). Plaintiffs&#146; complaint requests
$2&nbsp;billion in damages from the airline defendants and
injunctive relief.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On February&nbsp;8, 2006, 103 flight attendants employed by the
MidAtlantic division of US&nbsp;Airways filed a complaint
against AFA, AFA&#146;s international president Pat Friend and
US&nbsp;Airways, alleging that defendants conspired to deceive
plaintiffs into believing that MidAtlantic was a separate entity
from US&nbsp;Airways in order to deprive them of the benefits
they are due as US&nbsp;Airways flight attendants pursuant to
the US&nbsp;Airways collective bargaining agreement.
Plaintiffs&#146; claims against US&nbsp;Airways include breach
of collective bargaining agreement, violation of the Railway
Labor Act and racketeering under RICO. Plaintiffs&#146;
complaint requests $400&nbsp;million in damages from
US&nbsp;Airways and injunctive relief. Because the complaint has
not yet been served on US&nbsp;Airways, no action is due on its
part at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;12, 2005, Bank of America, N.A., which is the
issuing bank of the US&nbsp;Airways frequent flier program
credit card and also acts as the processing bank for most
airline ticket purchases paid for with credit cards, filed suit
in the Delaware Chancery Court in New Castle County, against
US&nbsp;Airways, US&nbsp;Airways Group and AWA, alleging that
US&nbsp;Airways breached its frequent flier credit card contract
with Bank of America by entering into a similar, competing
agreement with Juniper and allowing Juniper to issue a
US&nbsp;Airways frequent flier credit card. Bank of America also
alleges that US&nbsp;Airways Group and AWA induced these
breaches. Bank of America seeks an order requiring
US&nbsp;Airways to market the Bank of America card and prohibit
Juniper from issuing a US&nbsp;Airways credit card, as well as
unspecified damages. On October&nbsp;27, 2005, Juniper, which
was not originally a party to the lawsuit, sought and later
received court permission to intervene as a defendant in the
case and has made counterclaims against Bank of America. Juniper
seeks an order declaring the validity of its new agreement to
issue a US&nbsp;Airways frequent flier credit card. On
November&nbsp;3, 2005, Bank of America filed a motion for
partial summary judgment on the breach of contract claim against
US&nbsp;Airways. After a series of procedural steps, Bank of
America&#146;s motion, along with a cross-motion for summary
judgment filed by Juniper, was heard in the Bankruptcy Court,
where the case is now pending as an adversary proceeding. On
January&nbsp;30, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court ruled that Bank of
America is equitably estopped from pursuing its claims that
US&nbsp;Airways breached its agreement with Bank of America by
negotiating and entering into the agreement with Juniper. Bank
of America is seeking appeal of that ruling while it continues
to pursue its claim that US Airways failed to fulfill
contractual marketing obligations to Bank of America. The
resolution of the final two claims that Bank of America made in
the lawsuit, which are (i)&nbsp;that AWA tortiously interfered
with the contractual relationship between US Airways and Bank of
America and (ii)&nbsp;that US Airways Group and AWA tortiously
interfered with Bank of America&#146;s right to future economic
benefit under its agreement with US Airways, are dependent on
the outcome of the pending appeal. Bank of America will pursue
those two claims only if its appeal of the January&nbsp;30, 2006
order is successful.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways is unable to estimate at this time the amount of
loss or probable losses, if any, that might result from an
adverse resolution of the proceedings discussed above, and
currently is unable to predict whether the outcome of these
proceedings will have a material adverse effect on its results
of operations or financial condition. US&nbsp;Airways intends,
however, to vigorously pursue all available defenses and claims
in these matters.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">257

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways is party to various legal proceedings, including
some purporting to be class action suits, and some that demand
large monetary damages or other relief, which, if granted, would
require significant expenditures. In certain cases where it is
probable that the outcome will result in monetary damages,
US&nbsp;Airways will consider all available information and
record an accrual. For those cases where a range of loss is
probable but no amount within the range is a better estimate
than any other amount, US&nbsp;Airways will record an accrual at
the low end of the range.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(e)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Guarantees</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways guarantees the payment of principal and interest
on certain special facility revenue bonds issued by
municipalities to build or improve certain airport and
maintenance facilities which are leased to US&nbsp;Airways.
Under such leases, US&nbsp;Airways is required to make rental
payments through 2023, sufficient to pay maturing principal and
interest payments on the related bonds. As of December&nbsp;31,
2005, the principal amount outstanding of these bonds was
$77&nbsp;million. Remaining lease payments guaranteeing the
principal and interest on these bonds will be $131&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways enters into real estate leases in substantially
all cities that it serves. It is common in such commercial lease
transactions for US&nbsp;Airways as the lessee to agree to
indemnify the lessor and other related third parties for tort
liabilities that arise out of or relate to the use or occupancy
of the leased premises. In some cases, this indemnity extends to
related liabilities arising from the negligence of the
indemnified parties, but usually excludes any liabilities caused
by their gross negligence or willful misconduct. Additionally,
US&nbsp;Airways typically indemnifies such parties for any
environmental liability that arises out of or relates to its use
of the leased premises.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In aircraft financing agreements, US&nbsp;Airways typically
indemnifies the financing parties, trustees acting on their
behalf and other related parties against liabilities that arise
from the manufacture, design, ownership, financing, use,
operation and maintenance of the aircraft and for tort
liability, whether or not these liabilities arise out of or
relate to the negligence of these indemnified parties, except
for their gross negligence or willful misconduct. In aircraft
financing transactions structured as leveraged leases,
US&nbsp;Airways typically indemnifies the lessor with respect to
adverse changes in U.S.&nbsp;tax laws.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways expects that it would be covered by insurance
(subject to deductibles) for most tort liabilities and related
indemnities described above with respect to real estate leases
and aircraft it operates. US&nbsp;Airways cannot estimate the
potential amount of future payments under the foregoing
indemnities and guarantees.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways reviewed its long-term operating leases at a
number of airports, including leases where US&nbsp;Airways is
also the guarantor of the underlying debt. Such leases are
typically with municipalities or other governmental entities.
The arrangements are not required to be consolidated based on
the provisions of FIN&nbsp;46(R).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As discussed in Note&nbsp;1, the 7%&nbsp;Senior Convertible
Notes are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and
severally and on a senior unsecured basis, by US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s two major operating subsidiaries, US&nbsp;Airways
and AWA. The guarantees are the guarantors&#146; unsecured
obligations and rank equally in right of payment to the other
senior unsecured and unsubordinated indebtedness of the
guarantors and are effectively subordinated to the
guarantors&#146; secured indebtedness to the extent of the value
of assets securing such indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(f)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Concentration of credit risk</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways invests available cash in money market
securities of various banks, commercial paper and asset-backed
securities of various financial institutions, other companies
with high credit ratings and securities backed by the
U.S.&nbsp;government.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">258

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, most of US&nbsp;Airways&#146;
receivables related to tickets sold to individual passengers
through the use of major credit cards or to tickets sold by
other airlines and used by passengers on US&nbsp;Airways or its
regional airline affiliates. These receivables are short-term,
mostly being settled within seven days after sale. Bad debt
losses, which have been minimal in the past, have been
considered in establishing allowances for doubtful accounts.
US&nbsp;Airways does not believe it is subject to any
significant concentration of credit risk.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>10.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Accumulated other
comprehensive income (loss), net</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Comprehensive income encompasses net income and &#147;other
comprehensive income,&#148; which includes all other non-owner
transactions and events that change stockholders&#146; equity.
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; other comprehensive income includes
unrealized gains (losses) on available-for-sale securities,
certain changes in the fair value of certain derivative
instruments and an adjustment for minimum pension liability,
each shown net of income tax effects.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As presented in the accompanying statements of
stockholders&#146; equity (deficit), US&nbsp;Airways recognized
a comprehensive loss of $120&nbsp;million, including a net loss
of $120&nbsp;million with no other comprehensive loss for the
three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. For the nine months
ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, US&nbsp;Airways recognized
comprehensive income of $378&nbsp;million including net income
of $280&nbsp;million and other comprehensive income of
$98&nbsp;million. US&nbsp;Airways recognized comprehensive loss
of $621&nbsp;million, including a net loss of $578&nbsp;million
and other comprehensive loss of $43&nbsp;million, for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2004. For the nine months ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003, US&nbsp;Airways recognized a
comprehensive loss of $215&nbsp;million including a net loss of
$160&nbsp;million and other comprehensive loss of
$55&nbsp;million. US&nbsp;Airways recognized comprehensive
income of $2.48&nbsp;billion, including net income of
$1.61&nbsp;billion and other comprehensive income of
$870&nbsp;million, for the three months ended March&nbsp;31,
2003.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
There was no activity within other comprehensive income during
the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. The activity
within other comprehensive income (loss) and the related income
tax effects for all other periods is as follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways provides funds to and receives funds from
US&nbsp;Airways Group which arise in the normal course of
business and bear interest at market rates, which are reset
quarterly. US&nbsp;Airways had a net payable to US&nbsp;Airways
Group of $269&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2005 and $53&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways recorded interest expense of $6&nbsp;million for
the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, $1&nbsp;million
for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005,
$2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 and
interest income of $1&nbsp;million for the three months ended
March&nbsp;31, 2003 related to the above transactions. No
interest income or expense was recorded for the nine months
ended December&nbsp;31, 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Airline subsidiaries of US&nbsp;Airways Group</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways purchases all of the capacity (available seat
miles or ASMs) generated by US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s wholly
owned regional airline subsidiaries at a rate per ASM that is
periodically determined by US&nbsp;Airways and, concurrently,
recognizes revenues that result primarily from passengers being
carried by these affiliated companies. The rate per ASM that
US&nbsp;Airways pays is based on estimates of the costs incurred
to supply the capacity. US&nbsp;Airways recognized
US&nbsp;Airways Express capacity purchase expense of
$96&nbsp;million for the three months ended December&nbsp;31,
2005, $306&nbsp;million for the nine months ended
September&nbsp;30, 2005, $472&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2004, $349&nbsp;million for the nine months
ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and $112&nbsp;million for the three
months ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, related to this program.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways provides various services to these regional
airlines including passenger handling, maintenance and catering.
US&nbsp;Airways recognized other operating revenues of
$22&nbsp;million for the three months ended December&nbsp;31,
2005, $64&nbsp;million for the nine months ended
September&nbsp;30, 2005, $71&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2004, $40&nbsp;million for the nine months
ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and $12&nbsp;million for the three
months ended March&nbsp;31, 2003 related to these services.
These regional airlines also perform passenger and ground
handling for US&nbsp;Airways at certain airports for which
US&nbsp;Airways recognized other operating expenses of
$32&nbsp;million for the three months ended December&nbsp;31,
2005, $100&nbsp;million for the nine months ended
September&nbsp;30, 2005, $126&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2004, $55&nbsp;million for the nine months
ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and $15&nbsp;million for the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">260

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, related to these
expenses. US&nbsp;Airways also leases or subleases certain
aircraft to these regional airline subsidiaries. US&nbsp;Airways
recognized other operating revenues related to these
arrangements of $21&nbsp;million for the three months ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005, $65&nbsp;million for the nine months
ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, $55&nbsp;million for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, $12&nbsp;million for the nine
months ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and $2&nbsp;million for the
three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2003.

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; net payable to Piedmont and PSA was
$19&nbsp;million and $12&nbsp;million, respectively, at
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and $17&nbsp;million and $6&nbsp;million,
respectively, at December&nbsp;31, 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways has a net payable to AWA of $20&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2005, which consists of receivable of
$601&nbsp;million and a payable of $621&nbsp;million. The
receivable from AWA consists primarily of operating cash
transfers received by AWA. The payable to AWA consists of
payments made by AWA on behalf of US&nbsp;Airways to extinguish
debt associated with the GE Merger MOU, amounts received by
US&nbsp;Airways for AWA related to a bonus payment and
prepurchased miles by Juniper and various other transactions
occurring in the normal course of business that AWA settles on
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; behalf.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, $186&nbsp;million is included in
Long-term debt for the Airbus Loans. US&nbsp;Airways and AWA are
borrowers under the Airbus Loans and are jointly and severally
liable for these obligations, with US&nbsp;Airways Group as the
guarantor. See Note&nbsp;6(f) for additional information
regarding US&nbsp;Airways&#146; debt.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Other US&nbsp;Airways Group subsidiaries</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways purchases a portion of its aviation fuel from
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned subsidiary, Material
Services Company, Inc. (&#147;MSC&#148;), which acts as a fuel
wholesaler to US&nbsp;Airways in certain circumstances.
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; aviation fuel purchases from MSC were
$120&nbsp;million for the three months ended December&nbsp;31,
2005, $191&nbsp;million for the nine months ended
September&nbsp;30, 2005, $34&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2004, $9&nbsp;million for the nine months
ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and $11&nbsp;million for the three
months ended March&nbsp;31, 2003. US&nbsp;Airways&#146; payable
to MSC was $47&nbsp;million and $4&nbsp;million as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Effective July&nbsp;1, 2000, the activities of a certain
division of MSC were transferred into US&nbsp;Airways and MSC
began receiving a portion of its fuel inventory from
US&nbsp;Airways. As a result, US&nbsp;Airways&#146; receivable
from MSC was $31&nbsp;million and $12&nbsp;million as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(d)&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>RSA</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As of March&nbsp;31, 2003, at the time of emergence from
US&nbsp;Airways first bankruptcy, Retirement Systems of Alabama
Holdings LLC (&#147;RSA&#148;) held approximately 36.2%, on a
fully-diluted basis, of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s equity, had
a voting interest of approximately 71.6% and was entitled to
designate and vote to elect eight of 15&nbsp;directors to
US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s Board of Directors. Total amounts
due to RSA at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003 included
$54&nbsp;million and $73&nbsp;million, respectively, of the
initial $100&nbsp;million at-risk amounts under the ATSB Loan.
Interest expense and interest payments on RSA&#146;s portion of
the ATSB Loan was $4&nbsp;million for the nine months ended
September&nbsp;30, 2005. Interest expense on RSA&#146;s portion
of the ATSB Loan was $5&nbsp;million with interest payments of
$5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004.
Interest expense on RSA&#146;s portion of the ATSB Loan was
$3&nbsp;million with interest payments of $2&nbsp;million for
the nine months ended December&nbsp;31, 2003. In connection with
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; emergence from bankruptcy and merger with
America West Holdings on September&nbsp;27, 2005, any stock held
by RSA and their board seats were cancelled. RSA no longer has
the right to elect directors to the US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s
Board of Directors.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">261

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 24pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>12.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Stockholder&#146;s equity and dividend restrictions</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group owns all of US&nbsp;Airways&#146;
outstanding common stock, par value $1&nbsp;per share.
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; board of directors has not authorized the
payment of dividends on the common stock since 1988.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways, organized under the laws of the State of
Delaware, is subject to Sections&nbsp;160 and 170 of the
Delaware General Corporation Law with respect to the payment of
dividends on or the repurchase or redemption of its capital
stock. US&nbsp;Airways is restricted from engaging in any of
these activities unless it maintains a capital surplus. In
addition, US&nbsp;Airways may not pay dividends in accordance
with provisions contained in the US&nbsp;Airways Citibank Loan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>13.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Operating segments and related disclosures</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways Group is managed as a single business unit that
provides air transportation for passengers and cargo. This
allows it to benefit from an integrated revenue pricing and
route network that includes US&nbsp;Airways, AWA, Piedmont, PSA
and third-party carriers that fly under capacity purchase
agreements as part of US&nbsp;Airways Express. The flight
equipment of all these carriers is combined to form one fleet
that is deployed through a single route scheduling system. When
making resource allocation decisions, the chief operating
decision maker evaluates flight profitability data, which
considers aircraft type and route economics, but gives no weight
to the financial impact of the resource allocation decision on
an individual carrier basis. The objective in making resource
allocation decisions is to maximize consolidated financial
results, not the individual results of US&nbsp;Airways, AWA,
Piedmont and PSA.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Information concerning operating revenues in principal
geographic areas is as follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>14.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Stock-based compensation</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Upon confirmation of the Plan of Reorganization, existing shares
of US&nbsp;Airways Group&#146;s common stock were cancelled. The
plan of reorganization resulted in holders of US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s common stock and related equity securities
receiving no distribution on account of their interest.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
After emerging from the first bankruptcy, the Predecessor
Company adopted the fair value method of recording stock-based
employee compensation contained in SFAS&nbsp;123 and accounted
for this change in accounting principle using the
&#147;prospective method&#148; as described by SFAS&nbsp;148.
Accordingly, the fair value of all Predecessor Company stock
option and warrant grants, as determined on the date of grant,
were amortized as compensation expense (an element of Personnel
costs) in the Statement of Operations over the vesting period.
The Company has disclosed in Note&nbsp;2(m) the effect on net
income (loss) and net earnings (loss) per common share as if the
fair value based recognition provisions of SFAS&nbsp;123 had
been applied to all outstanding and unvested stock option awards
in each Predecessor Company period presented.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">262

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>US&nbsp;Airways, Inc.</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Notes to the Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Pursuant to collective bargaining agreements,
23,028,687&nbsp;shares of Class&nbsp;A Common Stock of
US&nbsp;Airways Group allocated to employees were valued at
$169&nbsp;million in the aggregate and were included as deferred
compensation as a reduction to stockholders&#146; equity
(deficit)&nbsp;upon emergence from the first bankruptcy.
US&nbsp;Airways recorded the deferred compensation as
compensation expense as the related shares vested.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Prior to cancellation of the shares of US&nbsp;Airways
Group&#146;s common stock upon emergence from bankruptcy on
September&nbsp;27, 2005, there were 4,750,000&nbsp;shares of
US&nbsp;Airways Group Class&nbsp;A Common Stock and 2,220,570
each of Class&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A-1</FONT>
Warrants and shares of Class&nbsp;A Preferred Stock authorized
to be granted to US&nbsp;Airways&#146; management. Through
September&nbsp;27, 2005, 3,649,159&nbsp;shares of
US&nbsp;Airways Group Class&nbsp;A Common Stock, 2,101,240 each
of Class&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A-1</FONT>
warrants and Class&nbsp;A Preferred Stock, and 354,350 options
to purchase Class&nbsp;A Common Stock were granted to
US&nbsp;Airways&#146; management. Grants of Class&nbsp;A Common
Stock, stock options and warrants generally vested over four
years. The Predecessor Company recorded compensation expense
over the vesting period. The following table summarizes the
activity of the Predecessor Company&#146;s stock options and
warrants granted since emergence from the first bankruptcy
through cancellation of those shares upon emergence from the
second bankruptcy:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
There were no stock options or warrants granted during the nine
months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005. The weighted average fair
value of stock option and warrants granted during the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2004 was $0.80 and $2.70, respectively. The
weighted average fair value for warrants granted during the nine
month period ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 was $3.38.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
US&nbsp;Airways did not grant any shares of restricted stock
during the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005.
US&nbsp;Airways granted 835,160 and 3,627,923&nbsp;shares of
restricted Class&nbsp;A Common Stock during the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2004 and the nine months ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003. There were 1,683,674 non-vested shares
of restricted stock outstanding immediately prior to
cancellation upon emergence from the second bankruptcy on
September&nbsp;27, 2005.
</DIV>
